column2: The Post of June 9, says: The French Government has decided on sending more ships to the Neapolitan station in order to take on board the French subjects, who number 2,000 persons in the capital.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 100 bbls. Ashes, 9,225 bbls. Flour, 700 bbls. Corn Meal, 16,606 bushels Wheat, 22,202 bushels Corn, 500 bushels Rye, 39,650 bushels Oats, 600 bushels Malt, 177 pkgs. Provisions, and 539 bbls. Whisky.

It is stated that immediately after the formal annexation of Savoy and Nice, France will address a note to the European Powers notifying the fact, and demanding a reply as a recognition of the annexation by Europe.
Steamships Roanoke, Coach, Richmond, Ludlam Heineken; Huntsville, Stennard, Savannah, H.B. Cromwell Co.; Prince Albert, Prowse, Galway, Am. Express Co.

The managers of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents vs. Otto Hoym and Edward F. Harmonn. This is the application for an attachment against defendants for a contempt in opening the Stadt Theatre in violation of an injunction order. The case came up for decision upon application, and the following opinion was rendered.
The demand for Money had been quite moderate, and the applications at the Bank of England were on a limited scale. On the 8th, however, there was a decided increase in the demand.

The telegraph brought us the news from Richmond, Va., yesterday morning that EDWIN ROBINSON, President of the Washington and Richmond Railroad, had voluntarily confessed a fraudulent appropriation of the funds of the company, to a large amount, and awaited an investigation. In these days of speculation and defalcation this is nothing very extraordinary. But the telegraph adds "His conduct in this affair is highly honorable, and he is much respected."

ADOLPH MAEURKIEWIEZ, a boy three years of age, while playing at a fifth story window of the house No. 343 East Tenth-street, missed his balnce, and fell to the sidewalk. He did not survive his injuries...

In the House of Lords on the 7th inst., Lord TEYNHAM moved a series of resolutions virtually indorsing the doctrine of universal suffrage, but the proposition was ridiculed and negatived without a division.
A good part of this, the fifth day of the Convention, has been spent in parliamentary manoeuverings, intended to gain time.
The steamer Cahawba arrived here yesterday bringing Havana advices to the 18th inst.

We have received the following card from the proprietors of the Metropoliton Hotel, in reference to the disgusting charge made in the columns of a journal of this City, that they have permitted their house to be disgraced by "intrigues without number," between its inmates and the young Japanese rather foolishly known as " TOMMY."

The exercises connected with the Annual Commencement of Rutgers College, began on Sunday morning last with a Baccalaureate Sermon by Prof. HOWARD CROSBY, D.D. His discourse was based on the text found in Second Peter, iii, 19. It was an eloquent and finished production.

THE SECRETARY OF WAR MAKES A DENIAL. A communication was received to-day by the Senate from the Secretary of War, denying that he had ever given orders to any officers directing them to give preference to particular individuals, in the cases alluded to in the Senate's resolution, or in any other cases whatever. The Secretary gives a full history of the marble and other contracts.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Does anybody doubt the efficacy of sanitary improvements, in preserving health, life and morals? Such doubts can only arise from the want of a knowledge of well established facts.
This is the fourth day of the second session, and it has been spent thus:--met at at 10, had a row, adjourned to 5; met at 5, had two rows, adjourned to 10, and that's the whole of it.

The examination in the case of the slave brig Falmouth in the United States Commissioner's Court was resumed yesterday before Commissioner BRIDGHAM, the captian Leinas, his mates and six of the craw being present.

The British Association for the Advancement of Science holds its thirtieth reunion at Oxford on the 27th of the present month. The names of its officers would seem to indicate a perfect entente cordiale between science and rank the President being Lord WROTLESLEY, with Lord DERBY for Vice-President.

We were again startled at the report that the Mohawk had made another capture, but it has turned out to have arisen from the fact that Capt. CRAVEN was seen with a vessel in tow on the south side of Cuba. The vessel had gotten ashore, and the Mohawk was assisting her out of danger.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last, have been: 6 bbls. Ashes, 13,524 bbls. Flour, 171 bbls. Corn-meal, 28,761 bushels Wheat, 29,630 bushels Corn, 2,679 bushels Rye, 29,665 bushels Oats, 594 bushels Malt, 343 pkgs. Provisions, and 211 bbls. Whisky.

The contest between the Independent and Evangelist, the organs of the Congregationalists and New School Presbyterians respectively, relative to the Home Missionary Society, loses none of its vigor. The Evangelist surrenders nearly the whole of its editorial space to this topic.

An Act making appropriations to defray the deficiencies in appropriations for the service of the Post-office Department for the fiscal year ending the 30th of June, 1859, and in part for the support of the Post office Department for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1860.
SIR: In view of the early adjournment of Congress, I submit to you a statement of the probable means of the Treasury, and the probable demands upon it, for the fiscal year ending 30th June, 1861.

SIR : I regret to be unable to accept the invitation to the public meeting of the inhabitants of Rocadale; but feeling that my constituents have a right to know my sentiments upon the recent proceedings of the House of Lords, which are, I understand, to be brought under their consideration, I beg leave to trouble you with this communication.

Lord BROUGHAM, on whose zeal and activity in all good causes advancing age seems to make no impression, and who has apparently as clear a head at more than four score as he had at forty, is now seeking to add one more to the long list of valuable reforms for which English law is indebted to his exertions.

The political doings of the Democratic "statesmen" assembled in Convention at Baltimore of course receive due attention from the public; but we think their martial exploits, also, should not be lost sight of. We therefore beg to present a short summary of the encounters of the past week in chronological order.

The case of the United States vs. the captured steamers, General Miramon and Marques de la Habana, came up before the United States District Court in New-Orleans on the 11th. A large amount of testimony, taken by a Commissioner in Vera Cruz, was read. That of DOMINGO DE GIOCURIA was as follows:

Recorder BARNARD yesterday sentenced Chas. P. Thompson, convicted of perjury for giving false bail for his father, who was charged with forgery and false pretences, to the State Prison for three years. The Jury, on account of his youth, and the fact that his father was the party in whose behalf he committed the perjury, recommended him to mercy, otherwise his sentence would have been more severe.
O.H. Browning, Esq., Quincy, Ill. DEAR SIR: When I received your letter of May 22d, I had no thought that the answer would be so long delayed; but, waiving all excuses, I proceed to answer it now.

Two novelties distracted the attention of the dramatic world on Thursday night. We call them novelties, because they are both so old that to the present generation they must appear as fresh as buds in May.
A large audience assembled at Niblo's Theatre on Thursday morning, to witness the annual Commencement exercises of the New-York University.

Fine weather and hopeful spirits enliven the Spanish people at present. The war with Morocco at an end, ORTEGA and his conspiracy forgotten, ferias, toros and balls have taken their places, and seem to answer better for a substitute than the dismal thought of the last war.
The Overland Mail from San Francisco arrived this evening, and brings the following summary of news from the Pacific Coast:
We translate from the Independance Belge the following manifesto from MAZZINI:

The Republicans of the Ninth Congressional District of Indiana assembled in Convention, a few days ago, to nominate a Representative. SCHUYLER COLFAX was nominated by acclamation. Preferring to attend to his duties in Washington rather than make a journey home to speak to his friends, he addressed them a letter, from which we make the following extract:
To the Editor of the New-York Times: A firm of engine builders charge me, in your paper of yesterday, with having given false information to your reporter.
The mails from Melbourne, 24th April, had reached England. The political and general news is unimportant. The shipments of gold since the previous mail were 192,000 ounces.

On Saturday, Dennis Sayre was tried before Recorder BARNARD on a charge of false pretences, in defrauding Appleton A. Oaksmith by means of a spurious check for $368 off the Market Bank, and a promissory note for the payment of $375. He was acquitted, the evidence being manifestly insufficient for conviction.
The Sardinian Senate had approved the treaty ceding Savoy and Nice by a vote of 92 against 10.

Wilson Eyre and Louisa Lincoln Eyre, his wife, vs. Edward Y. Higbee and Fanny L. Higbee, his wife This was an action brought to recover a large number of letters and other documents, written by Gen. Geo. Washington to Col. Lear.

The steamship Melita, chartered from the Cunard Company to take the place of the Canadian, left Liverpool at 3 P.M. of the 13th, called at Londonderry on the 14th, and passed this Point to-day on her way to Quebec.

On motion of Mr. BONHAM, of South Carolina (Dem.,) the President was requested to furnish the House, at the next session, all information that can be obtained as to disposition, by the British Government, of the Africans captured by the British Navy, and its disposition of the officers and crews of the slavers thus captured.
The Seceders' Convention met at noon to-day, in the Maryland Institute, what was crowded to its utmost capacity.
The evidence in this case was continued on Saturday.
The steamer Melita, from Liverpool 14th inst., or Quebec, which passed Father Point yesterday, brings us four days later news from Europe.

Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, on Saturday at No. 196 West Thirtieth-street, upon the body of HENRY W. SMITH, a lad sixteen years of age, who was drowned, on the 14th inst., while returning to this City from Dudley's Grove, on the Hudson, where he had been attending a Sabbath School picnic.
We referred, a few days ago, to the circumstances which gave rise to, and subsequently attended, the issue of twenty millions United States Treasury Bills, now authorized by Congress to be funded.

The Emperor would leave Paris on the 15th for Baden, there to meet the Prince Regent of Prussia and other German Sovereigns. On the 14th, the Emperor was to hold a grand military review, to celebrate the annexation of SAVOY and Nice, which was to be formally accomplished that day.

The Baltimore Convention has closed its labors. It met to nominate a Presidential candidate, and to adopt a platform; it has ended by giving the party two of each. Its ostensible object was to harmonize the party, to compromise points of difference, to reconcile sectional jealousies and distrusts, and to nominate a candidate who should unite the sentiment and support of the party, and thus secure a victory in the coming canvass.
TOMPKINS MARKET FINISHED. The long looked for completion of the new Tompkins Market building is announced at last.

The sun has closed upon a glorious day in the history of the New York Light Guard, and I hasten to chronicle some of the events which have made the occasion of their visit a source of the most delightful recollections, and which was characterized by the happiest success. Prompted by the generous friendship ...

Adam Wright and Frederick Simms, German laborers were apprehended on Saturday night for stealing a case of shoes from a store in Grand-street. In their possession the officer found a quantity of knives and forks, a silver cup, spoons, table linen, and other articles having the names of the proprietors of the Metropolitan and St. Nicholas Hotels stamped upon them.

The festivities of Commencement week at the Wesleyan University have just closed with the usual gathering of the friends and graduates of the institution at the house of the President, Rev. Dr. CUMMINGS; and despite the unfavorable weather which has prevailed a long part of the time, the occasion has been one of much interest.

CHURCHES DEDICATED. The new building recently erected by the Warren-street Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally dedicated for divine worship yesterday. It is located on Warren-street, between smith sad Court-streets. The building is constructed of brick, with brown-stone trimmings; size 22 feet front, extending back from the street 87 feet. When completed and furnished it will cost about $22,000 $12,000 of which sum has been proviced for. The interior is divided two rooms.
At a recent Republican meeting in Burlington, Vt., Hon. GEORGE P. MARSH made the following remarks as reported in the Free Press:

In the House of Commons, on the 11th, Lord JOHN RUSSELL announced that, as there was but very little prospect of the Reform bill being passed this session, the Government, with the view of preventing further waste of time, was reluctantly compelled to withdraw the measure. He promised to bring forward a new bill at the earliest opportunity at the next session.
We have assurances from persons who ought to know that both BRECKINRIDGE and LANE will accept their nominations by the Convention of seceders.
On the reassembling of the Convention, BENJAMIN FITZPATRICK, of Alabama, was unanimously nominated for Vice-President on the first ballot.
There is a brisk demand, but rates are generally unchanged. Consols closed tuesday at 93 5/8 for account, ex dividend.

The time has come when the public expect some general outline of the programme likely to be observed in the reception of the Prince; and without being oracular, we may be able to give our readers a general idea of what will be done.
The Great Eastern, on her return voyage, will make Milford Haven her port of call.

The Circuit Court of this county came in session yesterday, and among the first business was brought up the decision on the motion of the defendant for a charge of venue in the celebrated Burch divorce case.
The theatre is again crowded to-day. The Douglas delegates from Louisiana and Alabama have taken seats.
The Japanese furore in the Metropolis culminates in the grand Municipal Ball and Promenade at the Metropolitan this evening.

The Baltimore nominations are the leading topics of conversation among all classes here, and the impression prevails that Mr. BRECKINRIDGE will decline heading the Secession ticket, particularly in view of the fact that the Seceders made no nomination under the rule adopted by themselves.

The Austrian Goverment had resolved upon increasing the effective strength of the second army is Venetia, and a corps of cavalry is also to be collected is the Italian Tyrol, that part of the Austrian territory nearest to Lombardy.

APPREHENDED FAILURE OF THE POST-OFFICE DEFICIENCY BILL. Apprehensions are now felt for the passage of the Post-office Deficiency bill, and the Post-Route bill; the former containing a clause restoring mail service, on which the two Houses disagree, and the latter certain Overland Mail provisions which hang fire, as they are vigorously opposed by the steamer interests.
The May mails from the various parts of the West Coast of Africa had reached England. There was no news of importance.

Special Dispatch to the New-York Times: At Pittsfield one hundred guns were fired on the reception of the news that the people had conquered and that DOUGLAS was nominated. Great indignation is expressed against the factionists of the Massachusetis delegation who so basely disregarded the wishes of their constituents. It is thought they will have a more difficult matter to settle at home than they had at Charleston or Baltimore.
Steamships Yorktown, Parrish, Norflok, Ludiam Heineken; Augusta, Woodbull Savannah, S.L. Mitchill Son; Karnak, Brownless Aavana, E. Cunard;...
Several private bills were passed. A message from the President vetoing the Homestead bill was received and read at length.
We have reliable information here that HARDEN has made a confession of having poisoned his wife, showing in the whole transaction a degree of guilt seldom equalled.

A fire happened at 3 o'clokc yesterday morning in the apartment of Rev. Dr. MCMENAMY, on the second floor of the boarding-house, No. 264 Tenth-street, Damage of about $300 was done, which is fully covered by insurance. In attempting to extinguish the flames, the reverend gentleman was seriously burned.
The capitulation was signed at Palermo on the 6th of June.

Any one in search of violent emotions cannot do better than set off at once for Palermo. However blaze he may be, or however milk-and-water his blood, I promise it will be stirred up. He will be carried away by the tide of popular feeling, or else the impetuosity and variation of this torrent will produce in him a reaction such as he rarely felt.
The House acceded to the request of the Senate to appoint another Committee of Conference on the Post-office Deficiency bill.

Further news from Pike's Peak is received this evening. A band of Arapahoe Indians have just returned from the South Fork, where they had a battle with the whites, in which the latter was defeated with some considerable loss. The Arapahoes lost several warriors, among whom is little RAVEN, one of their Chiefs. They also took some of the whites prisoners.

The Great Eastern made a short trip of 24 hours yesterday and to-day, chiefly to ascertain the working condition of her engines. The result suggested a few minor adjustments, but was, on the whole, satisfactory as far as the machinery is concerned. The celebrated Giffard injectors had been applied to the paddle-boilers, but were not of sufficient size to supply them with the water required. The ...
Gov. FITZPATRICK having declined the nomination of Vice-President, the National Committee have substituted HERSCHEL V. JOHNSON, of Georgia.

The Presidential canvass has at last fairly opened. The several political parties have taken their ground, all the candidates are in the field, and it is not difficult to foresee the result. The Republican ticket is morally certain to be elected. Strong in the public sentiment ...

The Senate met at 9 o'clock. The reading of the Journal occupied half an hour. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented a petition of citizens of Massachusetts praying for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law, the inter-State Slave-trade, and the prohibition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. He asked that it might lay on the table, and it was so ordered.

Yesterday witnessed the close of the First Session of the Thirty-sixth Congress; and few, probably, who hsve been cognizant of its proceedings from first to last, will regret that the country is at length at liberty to breathe with a little more freedom, in view of the fact that one element of discord and strife is for the present quieted. BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.?A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. The principal portion of the session was occupied in the consideration of subjects possessing no general interest.

The Butterfield Overland Mail coach, with San Francisco dates of June 4, arrived here at 7 o'clock last evening.

Messrs. GRINNELL, MINTURN Co. had received no information yesterday, previous to the arrival of the New-York, of the day of sailing of the Great Eastern. Our special correspondent writes, however, that she was positively announced for the 16th, though so little confidence is felt in anything pertaining to her management that no great reliance was placed on the advertisement. Yesterday was the last day of the June term of this Court or, rather, it was the last day of the extension of the term the number of cases to be tried, especially since the commencement of the Baltimore Convention, when Judge RUSSELL adjourned his division of the Court, being very large. The Commissioners appointed by the Legislature to inquire into and determine the amount of damages suffered by the State, and by various individuals, in the destructicn of the Quarantine establishment, resumed their sessions yesterday, after a recess of ten days.
The investigation was continued yesterday, before the Legislative Committee present, Mr. ROTOH and Mr. MONROE.

Hon. WILLIAM PENNINGTON, Speaker of the House of Representatives, left Washington yesterday morning and arrived at his home, in Newark, at 9 o'clock last evening. A large concourse of people, comprising men of all parties, had collected at the depot awaiting his arrival, and the enthusiastic cheers which greeted his return testified to the universal popularity which he enjoys among all classes of his fellow-townsmen.

This match was played on Monday on the Eckford ground. The spectators encroached too much on the limits of the game to make the play entirely satisfactory to all parties, especially as it was the means of putting out BERGEN, when he would otherwise have completed the run.

An immense torchlight procession, with music, greeted the return of Messrs. COVODE, BURLINGAME, GROW, BLAIR and MORRIS, and a grand entertainment was given them by HENRY C. CAREY, Esq. The meeting at the Square was so large that there was speaking from four stands. There was great enthusiasm when the speakers introduced the names of the Chicago nominees.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last have been 8 bble. Ashes, 5,641 bbls. Flour, 685 bbls, Corn-meal, 76,661 bushels Wheat, 23,980 bushels Corn, 4,201 bushels Rye, 16,600 bushels Oats, 668 pkgs. Provisions, and 235 bbls Whisky.

The People Vs. Christian Hansen.--The trial of this case, which is a prosecution for arson in the first degree, was commenced, yesterday in the Oyer and Terminer, before Justice GOULD. The facts of the case, as stated by the Assistant District Attorney, Mr. Sedgwick, in his opening address to the jury, are these: The defendant kept a lager bier saloon at the corner of Centre-street and Park: and had girls boarding in the establishment.

The Tribune yesterday announced that the City Inspector, Mr. DELAVAN, has appointed JOHN E. ENRIGHT to be one of the Health Wardens of the City. As we have seen no contradiction of the statement, we are constrained --discreditable as it is to a City officer whom we have found frequent occasion to commend--to believe it to be true. Who and what this man ENRIGHT IS, the community in general need not be informed.
The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool on the 16th inst. via Queenstown on the l7th inst., has arrived at this port.

The following bids were awarded yesterday by the Comptroller and Street Commissioner: Regulating and grading Fourteenth-street, from First to Third avenue, awarded to Peter Meehan, for $16,925 25.Surities, owen McGovern and John McGrane.

Strictures dispensed by editors from the columns of thetr own journals "rarely fall within the range of the topics which" your correspondent "feels called upon to treat," but the attacks of the TIMES, in some of its recent issues, on Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, of this City, "furnish an exception."

SANDY HOOK, June 26, sunset.--No vessels in sights Wind moderate, N.W. Weather clear. BOSTON, June 26.--Arr. steamers J. Whitney, Leveland, from Savannah: Ben Deford, Hallett, from Baltimore; ship Art Union, Nickerson from Calcutta; brig Meteor, Raynes, from Manzanilla.

If not "first in peace," GARIBALDI has assuredly made himself first in war and first in the hearts of his countrymen, of all Italy, by his heroic invasion and brilliant conquest of Sicily. And the motives which have ruled the whole life of this great patriot are not left to the conjectures either of his friends or his foes.

It will be recollected that, at our late County Convention, resolutions were introduced by Dr. GREGG and unanimously adopted, approving the late letter of ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, in favor of non-intervention, and rebuking the seceders. Having forwarded a copy of the proceedings to Mr. STEPHENS, we have reserved from him the following letter acknowledging their reception.

Congress has adjourned, without attracting special attention from any quarter. The country was watching the clamorous political wrangle at Baltimore too eagerly to have any thought for federal legislation,--and when the late session had passed off the stage, them were few who felt interest enough in its action to know that the curtain had dropped.

A NEW FORGERY.--Some shrewd rascal has lately got up a lithographic fac-simile of the Brooklyn Ferry Co.'s tickets, so exact in every particular that the best judges cannot distinguish the difference without the closest scrutiny and comparison. How many of these tickets have been sold is a matter of uncertainty, but it is quite certain that a large quantity have been received at the offices of the Ferry Company.

We received intelligence on Saturday evening, which is reliable, not only confirmatory of the charges made against HARDEN during the trial, but revealing an amount of guilt beyond these circumstances almost incredible. Our informant states that HARDEN is even now writing his confession, and that he has communicated certain portions of it to the jailor and one or two others.
The friends of Mr. DOUGLAS held a ratification meeting here last night. A salute of thirty-four guns was fired, with bonfires, music, speeches,
Vandervoort vs. Gould.--This case is now on trial for the second time before Justice LEONARD, at the Supreme Court Circuit. On the former trial which took place in March, 1859, the jury disagreed.

The regulars and volunteers under Col. HAYES and Capt. STEWART were attacked on the afternoon of the 2d inst. near Pyramid Lake. The Indians were defeated, with a loss of 70 killed and several wounded. Two volunteers were killed and three wounded. Capt. STORER was mortally wounded. Three regulars were killed and one wounded.

The Great Eastern sailed from Liverpool on the 16th inst., and is now, therefore, fully due at this port. It is quite probable that she will arrive to-day. We understand that it is not high tide until 1 P.M., and that she will not cross the bar, at whatever hour she may reach it, until that time.
The Senate was called to order at noon to-day. After Prayer by the Chaplain, the President's proclamation, convening an extraordinary session was read.

The members of the New-York Lyceum of Natural history, held their usual regular meeting on Monday evening, June 25, at their room in the Medical College, in Fourteenth-street. The President, JOSEPH DELAFIELD, took the Chair at 8 o'clock. The visitors for the evening were Dr. STEVENS and Messrs. ROBERTSON and JOHNSTON.
The will of Joseph Wolff, known in New-York as Joseph wolff Ashman, was on Monday admitted to probate by the Surrogate, Hon. Edw. C. West.

A communication from the late City Chamberlain, announcing the fact of his having paid over the balance of the City moneys in his hands to his sucessor, was referred, but not without a unanimous and cheerfully paid compliment to Mr. Stout, the retiring Chamberlain.

Morpheus was extensively courted yesterday among the Japanese visitors at the Metropolitan. The zest with which the entire Embassy, from the prince down to the cooks, enjoyed the festivities of the grand ball, necessitated a day of rest. The chief Ambassador, however, found time in the morning to visit the Brooklyn Glass Works in company with two or three of his suite, under the guidance...

LECTURE BEFORE THE YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN UNION.--A lecture was delivered before the Young Men;s Christian Union at their meeting on Monday evening, by C.W. TOLLES, Esq., of Newark. His subject was Orthodoxy.
The Senate, without transacting any business of the least public importance, at l0 o'clock went into Executive Session.

The propeller Kenosha, of the Collingwood and Chicago line, exploded her boiler off Sheboygan, yesterday morning, instantly killing CURTIS BURTON, of Cleveland, clerk, and MICHAEL CAREY, of Buffalo, first engineer. Three deck hands and the chambermaid were dangerously injured. The Kenosha was towed into Milwaukee this morning, by the steamer Huron.

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending June 27, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who ship their Produce to this market to be sold on Commission.

During the reception of the Japanese by Mayor WOOD at the City Hall, his Honor took occasion to invite the Embassy to his residence at Bloomingdale, leaving to them the determination of the day for the visit. It appears that several days were spoken of for the purpose, during the past week, and for some reason yet unexplained, the Princes determined upon yesterday, at 2 P.M., as the appropriate time for calling upon his Honor.

The People, and Taylor and Brennan vs. The Mayor, This is the commencement of the argument of the motion of the Comptroller to set aside the judgment in this case, on the ground of fraud and collusion in obtaining it.

The action recently taken by the French Government on the subject of the French codfisheries significantly illustrates the determination with which NAPOLEON III. is following up his purpose of raising the French navy to the highest possible point of efficiency.

THE COOPER UNION COMMENCEMENT. The Annual Commencement Exhibition of the "Class of Vacal Muaic" of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, was given last evening, in the lower hall of the Cooper Institute.

On the receipt here of the news announcing the nomination of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE a salute of one hundred guns was fired by the National Democracy, accompanied with the ringing of bells, lighting of bonfires, the letting off of fireworks, and other demonstrations of rejoicing.

The Society for Juvenile Delinquents vs. Charles S. Eustachi. This was an application for an attachment to punish defendant for contempt in violating an injunction order forbidding defendant to open his theatre until he should procure a license.
Mr. RANNEY, whose note we published yesterday, [is entirely mistaken in supposing that we have mis-stated the facts of his case, or done him any injustice.

It was harmless and wise pastime, undoubtedly, for the good grandfather to teach his grandson chess, until, more to the old gentleman's mortification than he would have cared to acknowledge, the youngster learned to check-mate him, and fairly drove his knights,

The Pike's Peak Express arrived here this evening with $11,353 in gold dust and dates to June 21. The reported death of LITTLE RAVEN, chief of the Arapahoes, in the recent battle with the Utes, proves to be false. His brother was severely wounded. The Arapahoes lost five killed and 32 wounded. They captured four Utes' children and 63 ponies. The loss of the Utes is not known.

FATE OF THE MEXICAN TREATY. The Senate, to-day, took hold of the Mexican Treaty, and after a sharp debate postponed its further consideration till December next, with but little hope of its approval.

To the Editor of the World: THE NEW-YORK TIMES Was Courteous enough to publish a letter a day or two since signed "A True American Woman," which seems to have given you infinite gratification, because it mourned the trifling but comparatively harmless remarks of a great portion of the newspaper Press regarding the experiences of the Japanese Embassy.

Mr. BUCHANAN has at last plucked up courage to remove GEORGE SANDERS. Why he has not done it months ago remains a profound mystery. While the President has been breathing out threatenings and slaughter, against every man.
THE LEE-AVENUE SUNDAY SCHOOL JUBILEE. One of the most delightful of the Strawberry and Floral Festivals of the season was enjoyed yesterday in Mr. BREVOORT'S grove, in Bedford, Long Island.

Commencing at four o'clock yesterday afternoon, there was an alarm of fire for every hour until 11 o'clock at night. The bell during that time rang almost incessantly, and the Firemen were on a constant run. Fortunately, however, at neither of the seven fires was there a great demand for their services. The first happened at No. 300 Henry-street in the saw-mill of Mr. BOANELL. Very slight damage was suffered.

The Difficulties under which the Democratic Party of Pennsylvania is to labor in consequence of the Baltimore split is already becoming clearly manifest in this city, where the feeling between the officeholders and non-officeholders is very bitter.
The sage observation that " People have a great deal of human nature in them," finds a new illustration in a high quarter.

The steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 19th, with the California mails and treasure of the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The California advices by this arrival have been anticipated, but she brings our correspondence from New-Granada and other points on the Pacific coast to the latest moment.

The Special Committee, consisting of Messrs. TUCKER, WATERBURY and EAGER, appointed at the last meeting of the Board of Education, to investigate the facts connected with the removal of school teachers from the Fourth Ward, held their first meeting last evening, at the Hall of the Board of Education. Mr. WATERBURY was not present.

There is no special news to report from this quarter, as there has been no arrivals here from Central America or the South Pacific since the departure of the steamer Ariel from Aspinwall on the 9th inst.
The Great Eastern sailed from Southampton on the morning of Sunday, June 17, and arrived off Sandy Hook at 7:20 A.M., on the morning of the 28th. She brings 38 passengers and 8 guests.

Congress has adjourned and dispersed, and yet both Houses of the National Legislature are congregated at the Federal Capitol. The President has summoned the Senate into extra session for the consideration of Executive business, and Mr. BRADY, the eminent photographer of New-York and Washington, has caught the House of Representatives by the power of his wonderful art, and holds them still in continuous, and what is more surprising, in respectable and harmonious session.

Mrs. Rachel T. Medkerk, a teacher in a District School in Cincinnati, has been presented by the citizens with a gold hunting watch and chain, valued at $125, and the freedom of twenty railroad lines, as a reward for her bravery in preventing the children under her care from rushing into the street during the terrible tornado which swept over the city some weeks ago.

The exciting scenes of the past two days are numbered with the past, and the College buildings are deserted. Yesterday evening and to-day the ex citement was at its height. The minor orators acquitted themselves well and were often greeted with expressions of approbation.

The deputation from Nice, taking advantage of the celebration at Paris of the annexation of Savoy and Nice, desired a mass for those who fell last year for Italian Independence. The priest refused upon the ground that the ecclesiastical ritual prohibits the celebration of mass for the dead during the octave of Corpus Christi, unless the body of the deceased person be actually lying in the building.

It has never been difficult to foresee that the completion of the Central Park must inevitably produce a very marked effect upon the character and habits of our people, especially on Sundays. The fashionable classes, professional men, and people whose engagements give them some leisure every day, will visit the Park and use it for recreation on week days.

An aritcle from Sir JOHN BURGOYNE, who commanded the English engineers at Sebastopol, until he was snubbed and sent home for maintaining that the Malakoff was the key of the position, published in the Cornhill Magazine, upon the defence of London, has thrown the British public into a state of great excitement.

In the House of Lords, June 18, Lord BROUGHAM asked Her Majesty's Government whether there was any truth in a report which had been current for the last two days, that France either had dispatched, or was about to do so, a large military force to Naples, exclusive of the naval force of seven vessels of war, which she now bad in the Neapolitan waters.

BOOLE seems to have carried into effect a modification of his roving Sanitary Commission. Not being able to secure a trip to Europe in the beginning of the season in company with "a savant," he has contented himself with a less exciting visit to Boston; but what he has lost in the length of the tour, he has gained in the number of the tourists.
The steamship Adriatic arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon, from Havre and Southampton, having left the latter port on the evening of the 20th June. Her advices are three days later.

The Overland Mail coach, with San Francisco papers of the 8th, and dates by Telegraph to Vizalia of the 9th inst., passed here at four o'clock this morning.

The Emperor NAPOLEON arrived at Baden on the 16th to take part in the Conference. He met with a warm reception. At a preliminary meeting of the German Princes an agreeable unanimity was manifested on all questions referring to the relations of Germany with foreign Powers.

Shortly before 12 o'clock on Saturday night two murders, as deliberately committed as the most shocking that have ever marked the criminal annals of the City, were perpetrated in Eighteenth-street near Third-avenue. The victims are Mr. JOHN WALTON, a well-known distiller, doing business in this City, and Mr. JOHN WARTS MATHEWS, a railroad contractor, who resided with his brother at No. 31 Union-place.
The schooner John A. Taylor has arrived here with Ruatan dates to the 20th.

Prof. JAMES RENWICK'S idea of a Park for New-York, as developed before the Senatorial Committee on Friday, is a number of roads, thirty feet wide fifteen feet in the centre macadamized with borders of native mud and dust running through a vast extent of swamp and wood, such as the ground now covered by the Central Park was before the year 1857.
The case of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania vs. STEPHEN DILLAYE, which we noticed a day or two ago, came on for trial as Pittsburg, on Tuesday.

BACKER acted as Secretary. There were no speeches made, but the following resolutions were passed unanimously.

A dispatch dated at Cagliari, June 12, says: "Two steamers, bearing the American flag, have entered the harbor this morning, having on board volunteers for Sicily.

I fear that M. DE LA GUARRONIERE is about to be superseded in his post of pamphlet-writer in ordinary, for he seems to have a dangerous rival to dispute the laurels with him. This rival is the well-known M. ABOUT, who has just brought out a pamphlet with the ominous title of "L'Empereur Napoleon III et la Prusse." Opinions vary as to its merit.

The lightning last night struck the house of JONATHAN B. GOODENOUGH, in Brighton, killing Mr. G. and his son, and seriously injuring Mrs. G. The force of the gale was terrific, uprooting large trees, demolishing chimneys, awnings, and doing other damage. Many sailing boats in the harbor were upset, and there are reports that several lives are lost, but those reports are not confirmed, though there were many narrow escapes.

POLICE ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY. The Police Captains have been instructed by a general order from Superintendent KENNEDY, to have every men of their respective commands on duty on the Fourth. The officers are cautioned to exercise forbearance, but to use prompt measures to prevent breaches of the peace. A reserve force is to be kept in each station-house to act as circumstances may require, either in its own or other precincts.

Donalson vs. Hurst. This action, to recover damages for an assault on a scholar was tried in the Marine Court, and the Jury gave a verdict for $200 in favor of the plaintiff, as reported in the TIMES of March 24. It now came up on appeal by the defendant to General Term of the Marine Court.

The clouds that have hovered over us like Fall, Pouring out rain almost incessantly for nearly two months, have at last cleared away, and the sun, so long shut out from view so that we had almost forgotten how it looked, is shining to-day in all its glory, and all nature seems gladdened as the genial rays fall upon tree and flower, opening bud and bursting germ.
Paymaster CHILTON has been relieved by Major CUNNINGHAM, as Paymaster in the Department of Texas, and ordered to Detroit, Michigan.

The community was profoundly shocked, yesterday, by the information of the deliberate mur- der of Mr. JOHN WALTON, in Eighteenth-street, on Saturday night, coupled as it was with the death of Mr. JOHN W. MATHEWS, as estimable citizen, whose life was taken by the hand of the same assassin, to whom he was unknown, and who, consequently, could have borne him no-malice.

The refusal of Commodore VANDERBILT to carry the California mails for the postages, and the failure of Congrees to provide for the termination of Mr. VANDERBILT'S provisional contract, has occasioned considerable inconvenience to our merchants in the California trade, and others desiring to maintain cor- respondence with the Golden State.

Two of the officers recently appointed by the War Department to the recruiting offices in this City reported for duty yesterday. Lieut. BANKHEAD, vice WINDER, to the chief rendezvous in Cedar-street; Lieut. COGGSWELL, vice SWEENEY, in Chatham street.
Tammany Hall was very well filled, last evening, by those who desired to respond favorably to the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS for the Presidency, and Mr. JOHNSON for the Vice-Presidency.

The case was on trial, it will be remembered, before Justice INGRAHAM, at the Special Term of the Supreme Court, during March, April and May last.
The steamer Arizona brings Brazos dates to the 26th ult., and $73,000 in specie.

The usual exercises of Class-day were celebrated yesterday before a large audience. NATHANIEL MIGHILL, of Rowley, gave an oration, and J.W. WARD, jr., of Madison, Wisconsin, a poem. The theme of the oration was the "Individualism of Man." It was gracefully, eloquently and thoroughly handled, as was testified to by an appreciative audience.
The Commissioners met at the usual hour yesterday morning, Hon. ED. LEAVENWORTH presiding.
This institution is situated near the village of Nyack, on the west bank of the Hudson, about 30 miles above New-York. The closing exercises of the Spring term took place on Thursday evening last.

The Indian troubles have occurred six hundred miles west of Camp Floyd. One or two stations have been threatened between here and Ruby Val- ley, (300 miles west;) but between Ruby Valley and Carson City the Mail and Express route has been almost abandoned.

Pursuant to law and the adjournment made at the last meeting, the Board of Supervisors met at 12 o'clock M., yesterday, specially for the purpose of receiving the assessment rolls for the year from the Board of Tax Commissioners, and afterwards another matter of some importance was acted on.

CITY MARSHAL'S MONTHLY REPORT There were committed to the City Prison, during the month of June, 174 prisoners, for the following offences: Drunkennees 101, threatening life 1, stealing 15, assault and battery 28, insane 2, violating city ordinance 2, grand larceny 1, incendiary 2, vagrancy 3, burglary 2, rioting 2, malicious mischief 1. Nativity: Ireland 114, United States 28, England 8, Scotland 11, Hungary 1, Germany 9, Wales 1, France 1, Colored 3 total 174.

The thirty-fifth annual Commencement of this growing College, which has taken its place among the first of our scholastic institutions, has been in progress during the present week. Twenty gentlemen have been dubbed A.B., amid a series of exercises varying from grave to gay, and crowned with the most pleasant weather.

The Democratic State Executive Committee met this afternoon at the Merchants' Hotel. The proceedings were conducted with closed doors. A motion to admit substitutes was negatived; also a motion for reassembling of the State Convention to take action.

--A wild child is roaming through the forests of Iowa, and exciting much discussion among the primitive naturalists of that section of the country. The nearest approach that has been made to its capture was to find the place where it had slept, and the remains of a frog, whereon it had supped. This latter fact seems very clearly to indicate a French parentage for the young Orson. He probably resembles a canard.

The Democracy are out in force to-night to ratify the nomination of DOUGLAS and JOHNSON. A large procession, with torches, Roman candles and music, have just passed through the streets, and the City Hall is filled with a crowd. There is great enthusiasm.
At a regular meeting of the Board, held last evening, the Board concurred with the Board of Councilmen to appoint an additional Clerk for that Board, at a salary of $900 per annum.
The extra session of the Oyer and Terminer, now holding by Justice GOULD, was resumed yesterday.

The Committee of the Common Council, to whom is intrusted an appropriation of $7,000 for duly celebrating "the Fourth," held a meeting on Saturday, at which Jackson square was added to the places designated for the exhibition of the municipal fireworks, and $75 were set apart to furnish a pyrotechnic display on Randall's Island.

A pubic meeting to ratify the nomination of DOUGLAS and JOHNSON took place to-night in front of the City Hall. The stand was beautifully illuminated with numerous transparencies, Resolutions indorsing the Cincinnati Platform and non-inter vention were passed. G.W. CREUT, of Virginia, and others delivered speeches in earnest advocacy of the nominees, and predicting the triumph of the principles which they declared. The proceedings were continued till a late hour.

YOUNG MEN'S REPUBLICAN UNION. A regular meeting of this association was to have been held at their head-quarters last evening, but owing to the small number in attendance, the President recommended an adjournment, which was carried. It was stated by the President that no meeting of the Union would be held on Tuesday next. It was expected that Mr. SUMNER would speak in the City on Monday.

An election was held in Leavenworth County yesterday, on the issuing of bonds to the amount of $150,000 to the Leavenworth and Cameron Railroad Company. The returns indicate a large majority for the subscription.

The Santa Fe mails, with dates to June 18, arrived to-day, making the regular schedule time. No rain had fallen in New-Mexico this year, and the crops are almost entirely destroyed. There has never been such a scarcity of provisions and forage in that country as at present. Corn is selling at almost any price asked.

Counterfeit fives on the Commonwealth Bank of Philadelphia are in circulation in this city. They are so well executed that few persons can detect them.

Robert Bruce Kenney, alias Stone, was tried yesterday on a charge of forgery in the third degree. He presented a forged check, purporting to be signed by Dr. Reese, to the amount of $375, to the Chemical Bank, when the amount was paid. Defendant had been previously engaged as driver in the Doctor's service. The jury found him guilty, and he was sentenced to three years in the State Prison.

As an evidence of the conservative disposition of the Court, this is undoubtedly justified. But the holders of that class of Securities must not infer from that decision that the contest is over, and the Bonds will now be paid or recognized by the mortgagors.

HENRY W. Hartt et al vs. George W. White et el. This was a motion heard before Justice INRAHAM, of Chambers, for an order compelling the defendants to put in a more specific return to the mandamus, or to show cause why the return now made should not be quashed, and a peremptory mandamus issue.
The Pike's Peak Express, which arrived last night, brings advices from Denver City to the 26th ultimo.

The steamship Parana from Galway 27th ult. arrived at this port at 7 o'clock this morning. The new steamship Connaught was to sail on the 26th, but when about starting blew out the bottom part of her cylinder. The Parana accordingly took her place, sailing on the following day.
The proceedings of Parliament were generally unimportant.

The tendency of the funds would probably have been towards improvement to-day, the weather being more promising, but that the delivery of the large amount of Government Stock recently sold caused considerable pressure for money in the Stock Ex change. As much as 4 cent. was paid readily for short loans.

Patrick Murphy, who was convicted on Monday last of manslaughter in the fourth degree, for killing Peter Hall in a drunken brawl in Water-street, was brought up for sentence. The judge thought these drunken quarrels should be more severely dealt with, he therefore sentenced the prisoner to imprisonment with hard labor in the State prison at Sing Sing for two years.
RICHARD ELLIS was injured in the head in Fifthstreet, near First-avenue, while discharging a pistol. He was taken to his residence.

All was quiet in Sicily. It was reported that GARIBALDI had held a council, at which it was determined to march on Messina as soon as the plans were fully organized. It was expected that the march would commence on the 28th of June.

It is asserted that at the final conference between the Prince Regent of Prussia and the German sovereigns, before their departure from Baden, a decisive argreement was come to on those questions which refer to the relations of Germany with foreign countries.

One of the Montreal papers is in a quandary. "The passengers by the train from NewYork," says the puzzled journal, "arrived last night; the mails did not. What is the reason?" The phenomenon may easiest be accounted for by supposing that they were not on the train.

The Coroner's inquest into the facts connected with the recent murder of GEORGE W. WALTON and JOHN W. MATHEWS, was resumed yesterday at the Bellevue Hospital. There was a large attendance of spectators.

All along the Hudson the glorious Fourth was celebrated in a becoming manner and so various were the amusements in the different cities and villages that all who had money to spend could take their choice as to whether they should witness a firemen's or military parade, balloon ascension, regatta, or join in an excursion or ball. In almost every town a splendid exhibition of fireworks closed the day.

The demand for money was active and no transactions were reported below 4 per cent. The supply was scanty. The English funds were dull, but on 22d there was a tendency towards improvement, which was checked by the pressure for money. Consols closed at 93 @5/8 for account ex-dividend. The weekly Bank statement shows an increase in bullion of 303,932.
Prince JEROME BONAPARTE is dead. The Emperor NAPOLEON visits Savoy in July.

The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, a small number only attending. J.S. ALLEN, B. BABCOCK, S. ELY, Jr., J.JEX, D.H.P. NOYES, G.W. PRATT, A.L. VAN BLARCOM and D. WAGSTAFF, were elected membere.
Ten wet Saturdays running, and to-morrow perchance the eleventh. It is enough to turn creation mouldy, besides threatening to spoil a harvest and a London season. Folks begin to shake their heads...

The weather was delightful yesterday, and the programme for the celebration of Independence was carried out with complete success, EDWARD EVERRET'S oration was among the best of his many patriotic and brilliant addresses.

The China mail was telegraphed. The steamer Malabar, having on board Lord ELGIN and Baron GRAOS, was wrecked in the harbor of Galle. No lives were lost. The bullion in the ship was lost and both Ambassadors lost their credentials and all their papers, and would be delayed at Galle until the 6th of June.
The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. W. SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans and Havana, arrived here Wednesday morning at 11 O'clock, in three days and twenty-three hours from Havana.
Yesterday afternoon the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, proceeded to Staten Island for ten days' encampment. The turn out was not as showy...

The camp ground presented a brilliant scene on Thursday evening, on the arrival of the Regiment, although the universal dampness that prevailed was a source of some regret. Through the promptness of Quartermaster WINCHESTER'S department, the heavy stores had all been forwarded, and the first thing to be done was the pitching of the tents.
Rev. Mr. GILLETTE will preach at the French Theatre, Broadway, in the evening. Rev. THOS. GALLAUDET will conduct service for deaf mutes at St. Ann's Church at 3 P.M.

At the time of which we write nearly the whole of the Spanish Peninsula, south of the Pyrenees, was under the Moorish rule. Abderahman III, sat upon the throne of Cordova, and the season of his reign is known as the Golden Age of the Moorish Empire.

Hon. JOSEPH LANE Sir: I am directed by a vote of the National Democratic Convention to inform you that you have been this day unanimously nominated by it as the candidate of the Democratic party for the office of Vice-President of the United States, and in their behalf to request you accept the same.
The friends of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE are holding a large ratification meeting here to-night, in Monument-square. The speakers are Ex-Governor LOWE, Hon. HUMPHREY MARSHALL, and others.
The West Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church, of which Rev. F.G. CLARK is Pastor, has recently paid off its entire debt, which one year ago was $23,000.

This Club held a meeting at their Head Quarters in Union Square last evening. It was anticipated that it would be somewhat interesting from the fact that there were pending at their last adjournment, resolutions indorsing as their Presidential ticket DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, which had been referred to a Committee unintentionally composed of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE men.

Returns from the Oregon election come in slowly. Official and reported returns are received from Jackson, Josephine, Douglas, Umpqua, Lane, Benton, Linn, Marion, Moltmoneli, Clackanas, Washington, and Yarnhill counties. In all these counties the Democratic candidate for Congress received 1,032 votes, and the Republican 1,033.

It was not until Senor ALMONTE, accredited to the Courts of France and England, had extended his diplomatic mission to Spain, that her Catholic Majesty, lately, sent a Minister to the Government at the City of Mexico.

Mayor WOOD is turning his attention to the healing art. He is becoming anxious for the health and prosperity of the Democratic Party. Not repenting of his own agency in dividing and distracting it hitherto, but consoled therefor by the personal profit he has reaped from the process, he is now intent on healing its divisions, and adopting some policy which shall prevent the spoils of office from passing into other hands.
The steamship Fulton from Havre 26th, via Southampton 27th ult., passed this point at 4 P.M., bound to New-York. She has 93 passengers and 600 tons of freight.
The telegraph line was completed to this place yesterday.

The Board, at their meeting yesterday, resumed the claim of Dr. Thompson, who was examined at length, and gave a statement of the articles of household furniture which were destroyed, together with their value. Only 151 volumes of his medical library were saved, and those damaged to the amount of $100.

The position of being between the upper and nether millstone has long been proverbially unpleasant. Perhaps new forms of old ideas are all that we can expect in these days. Certainly, that idea remains the same, when put into the shape of being "between a Collector and a District-Attorney," an instance of which our readers will find in our law reports this morning.

COMPLIMENTARY DINNER TO THE OFFICERS OF THE GREAT EASTERN. A complimentary dinner was given to the officers of the Great Eastern last evening, at the Lafarge House, by the proprietors of the New-York Illustrated News, at which about thirty invited guests, besides the officers of the steamer, were present.

The People and Taylor Brennan vs. The Mayor, , of New-York. This case, it will be remembered, is pending before Justice PROKHAM, at the special term of the Supreme Court, on a motion to vacate the judgment recovered by the plaintiffs against the City, on the ground that it was obtained by fraud and collusion.

The London Times was not far wrong when, in commenting on Earl GREY'S recent attack upon the political organization of the United States, it declared a loss of confidence in the institutions which it has itself deliberately adopted to be the greatest misfortune which can befall a nation; and under this affliction it solemnly pronounced America to be writhing.
The match between Flora Temple and George M. Patchen, mile heats, best three in five, took place on the Suffolk Park Track, Philadelphia, on July 4, in presence of about four thousand spectators.

British Columbia dates to the 9th have little news of importance. The ship Lawson arrived at Victoria from China, with 70 Chinese passengers. The Leonidas and the Daniel Elliott were overdue, with 600 more of the same kind of passengers.

During the past year, the casualties among naval officers were as follows: resigned, 49; died, 28; Marine Corps, died, 1 ; dismissed, 16; no resignations. There are now about 120 officers employed on special service.

Prince Albert has generally been unfortunate in those of his public appearances in which he has ventured to touch on political questions. He speaks and writes English well, and has managed to identify himself with the country and the people in a great many things, but on matters of Government he has never been able to rid himself of the old leaven of German despotism. He shoots, hunts, and dines lives ...

A drunken chap in Louisville attempted to enter a lady's room, but was pushed down stairs by the occupant. After reaching the bottom he picked himself up and apologetically remarked that he perceived he had made a mistake. His perceptive faculties must have been remarkably acute. It is not every one that can distinguish between a flight of fancy and a flight of stairs.

Some months ago the Chicago Zouaves issued a manifesto declaring themselves the best organized and drilled military company in the country, and challenging any other organization to dispute their claims to this preeminence.

The Democratic Party avows its determination of preserving the Union. Can they do it in their great jar?

James Carrol, convicted of arson in the first degree, was brought up on Saturday for sentence. District Attorney moved for judgment in this case. The Court thought the evidence warranted the verdiet, and that the statute fixed the punishment. The prisoner was, therefore, sentenced to hard labor in the State Prison at Sing Sing for the term of his natural life.

The Democrat learns from the passengers from St. Joseph's that the new four-story building in that city, owned and occupied by NOVE, McCORD Co., wholesale grocers, fell at two o'clock yesterday, crushing a frame building adjoining, occupied by three families, killing nine of the ten occupants instantly, viz: Mrs. BOYCE and three children.

It is probable that, before the end of the current week, the Prince of Wales will be on his way to visit the great transatlantic inheritance of the crown which he is destined, should his life be spared, one day to wear.

GENTLEMEN: Your kind note, inviting me to attend a festival in Boston, on the 13th inst., in honor of the birthday of THOMAS JEFFERSON, was duly received, My engagements are such that I cannot attend.
A correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune writes from Key West, on June 21, as follows:

We have just learned of the butchery of a woman and her two children a short distance northwest of Batavia Station, on the Burlington and Missouri Railroad, in Jefferson County. Their dead and mutilated bodies were discovered on Saturday by a fishing party, in the Cedar Creek, into which they had been thrown by the murderer.
The People ex rel. George Peckham vs. The Manhattan Gas-Light Company. This was a mandamus sped out to test the right of the detendants to exact a deposit before furnisaing gas to consumers.
If the Pope does not speedily provide better accommodations for his Irish Volunteers, and favor them with some excitement, there is great danger of their going over bodily to GARIBALDI.

It is well-known that for about a week previous to the departure of the last Vanderbilt steamer, Postmaster-General HOLT was in almost constant telegraphic communication with Mr. VANDERBILT on the subject of the Pacific mails--Mr. HOLT making earnest appeals to him to take them and rely on the justice of the Government to make a fair compensation for the service over and above the postages.

On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building known as the Brooklyn City Mills, belonging to Messrs. SMITH, LEECH JEWELL, which, before the flames could be extinguished, was entirely destroyed. It was situated on the corner of Fulton and Furman streets, and was 24 feet by 100 in extent. A large amount of business was done in the place, there being two engines and six run of stone.

The fifth annual Cricket match between the above nationalities was played at Camden, near Philadelphia, on the 4th and 5th of July, and after a brilliant contest in presence of the largest number of spectators which has ever assembled on the ground of the Philadelphia Club, victory rewarded the exertions of the American Cricketers for the first time in five years, who beat their opponents, with eight wickets to spare.
The Arch-street Theatre, Philadelphia, opened last week, for the Summer season, with the spectacle of the "Naiad Queen," produced in splendid style.
The Beirut, Syria, correspondent of the Boston Traveller, writing on the 6th ult., says:

We publish this morning details of the Mexican news relative to the capture of MIRAMON and the movements of VIDAURRI, in Coahuila- a brief telegraphic report of which reached us from New-Orleans a few days since.

Your correspondent spent a few days quite recently in and around the Pawnee Indian Reservation, located on the Loup Fork of the Platte River, about one hundred miles inland from the Missouri River settlements.

Since the adjournment of the Coroner's Inquest, on Tuesday last, no facts have transpired tending to solve the mystery which enshrouds the circumstances connected with the murder of Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS, in the Eighteenth Ward, on Saturday night week.
Petition of Wm. Holmes. This case has been frequently reported in the TIMES, and will be well remembered.
The Hartford times Says that the story that Gov. TOUGEY is in favor of the election of Mr. DOUGLAS, is wholly untrue.
Mr. BRECKINRIDGE has formally accepted the nomination for the Presidency. His letter will be published Tuesday.

Camp Scott yesterday presented a lively scene. The divine service in the spacious mess tent, the continued influx of visitors from the City, the regimental review, and the picturesque scene of so many citizens and soldiers mingling in so romantic a locality, made the occasion one to be remembered with pleasant reminiscences by all who witnessed it.
Mr. John M. Price, a house-builder living in Richmond, is missing from home. When last seen he had between $150 and $300 in money on his person.
Mr. W.A. WALLACE, one of the editors of the Alta California, arrived in our city last evening from San Francisco, having come by the Butterfield Overland Mail route.

The Conventions have all completed their work, and it only remains to record the votes in order to complete a drama in which Farce, Comedy and Tragedy are about equally mixed. The Conventions have ended just about where old and experienced politicians foresaw they would.

A wrong impression has been spread throughout the country concerning the extent and prevalence of the cattle distemper in Massachusetts. True, there has been a panic, but it arose from what was feared rather than from what was known and seen.

Three young men connected with the Brooklyn Yacht Club yesterday narrowly escaped drowning by the capsizing of a small boat in which they were attempting to effect a landing from the yacht Wild Wave at the camp grounds on the south side of Staten Island.

The People and Taylor and Brennan vs. The Mayor, In this case the argument of the motion to set aside the judgment against the City was proceeded with on Saturday, before Justice INGRAHAM, at the Special Term of the Supreme Court.

During the difficulties with the Mormons, which came near leading to a serious collision with the American troops, a plan proposed by Capt. WALTER M. GIBSON for the immediate emigration of the Mormons to Oceanica was adopted by BRIGHAM YOUNG, and forwarded to Dr. BERNHEISEL to be laid before the President for his approval, with a request for some proposition on the part of the Government to purchase their improvements in Utah.

On Wednesday next a grand entertainment will be given at the Academy of Music in behalf of the heroic struggle which Sicily is now making, under the command of GARIBALDI, for liberty and independence.
The Pike's Peak express arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing $15,500 in gold dust.
We are indebted to WM. HOWLAND, Esq., of Sherwood's Corners, in this country, for the privilege of perusing and transcribing for publication this veritable original letter from PATRICK HENRY.
We are delighted with the prompt and man- ly frankness of Archbishop HUGHES in confess- ing his faults and tendering an apology for acts of injustice.
One of the largest meetings ever held here, last night ratified the nomination of DOUGLAS and JOHNSON. Bonfires blazed, cannon thundered, and enthusiasm prevailed.

GENTLEMEN: I have the honor to acknowledge your note of invitation to address the Democratic meeting on Monday night. I regret my inability, proved on the last occasion when I made the experiment, to speak in the open air; but so it is, and I must content myself with this mode of expressing my earnest sympathy in the cause of the National Democracy, and its Candidate, Mr. BRECKINRIDGE.

A new programme for the Mormons is indicated in our Washington dispatches. It is now proposed that they shall emigrate to one of the East India Islands, and reliable information is said to have been received that they will do so.

An act of Congress, passed in 1842, and a supplemental act passed in 1856, makes it the duty of the Secretary of State to lay before Congress annually, at the commencement of each session, a compendious view of the commercial relations of the United States with foreign countries, to be derived from the reports of the Consuls resident abroad.

Not much comes from Naples at the moment touching the progress of the revolution on the main land. Administrative councils are busy devising schemes for protecting the throne of FRANCIS II. from the destruction with which it is menaced by the storm which is raging.

The opinion avowed by THEODORE PARKER, in the letter which we published yesterday, preferring a constitutional monarchy like that of Great Britain to a republic like ours, does not, after all, indicate nearly as much as it seems to indicate, as he evidently, in company with Earl GREY and others, overlooked a fact of considerable importance in the controversy now raging as to the comparative merits of the institutions of the two countries.

Capt. Otto, of the alleged slave bark Kate, together with the entire crew of that vessel, was arraigned for examination, yesterday, before United States Commissioner NEWTON, at the Grand Jury room of the United States Court. The following letter from Mazatlan, the 31st of May, furnishes a connected narrative of late events on the Pacific coast, of which we have before had brief mention:

IN A DRUGGISTS' TIN WARE MANUFACTORY. About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire hap pened in the fourth story of the building No. 161 Water-street. About $500 damage was done by water. Insured in the Citizen', Kings County and Mechanics' Companies for $9,200.

The news received by the Arabia, that the Chinese Government had assented to the demands of England, caused some surprise, but it was soon discovered that the date was not so late as those already to hand, and that the intelligence was therefore false.

Ere the excitement incident to the recent murders of Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS has in the least degree subsided, we are called upon to give the particulars of another fearful tragedy, which more than parallels the first crime in features of atrocity.

The colony just ceded to Honduras is known as the Colony of the Bay Islands. It consists of a group of islands, six in number, lying off the northern coast of Honduras, and bearing the names respectively of Ruatan, Utilla, Bonacca, Barbarat, Helena, and Morat.
The English funds closed heavy last evening. There were no gold operations at the Bank. The new Sardinian loan is expected to be offered at Turin for public subscription by the first of July.

A destructive fire broke out this morning at 3 o'clock, in the saddlery-shop of OWEN DUFFY, on Delaware-street, destroying fourteen frame buildings. The following are the principal losses and insurance: Owen Duffy, saddler, loss on building and stock, $2,000, insured for $1,900; restaurant owned ...

The People and Taylor Brennan vs. The Mayor, argument on the motion to set aside the judgment in this case, was proceeded with before Justice INGRAHAM, at a Special Term, and Mr. McKeon first concluded his remarks.

The accounts of the civil war in Syria, between the Christians and the Druses, which have reached us so far, are somewhat confused as to the origin of the quarrel, but they agree in representing it to be very bloody, and to have resulted thus far in the defeat and massacre of large numbers of the Christians.

Esther Black, by her Guardian, vs. Morritz G. Black.--The parties to this action are of highly-respectable families, the parents of each having wealth and a good position in society. The action is to obtain an order declaring a marriage between the plaintiff and defendant null and void, on the ground that the plaintiff was an infant under the age of fourteen years.
From the 30th day of June to the 7th day of July, 1860. Men, 91; Women, 73; Boys, 141; Girls, 126--Total, 431. Adults, 164; Youths, 14; Children, 253; Males, 232; Females, 199; Colored Persons, 5.

In the House of Lords on the 25th, Lord STRATHEDEN moved an address to the Queen in favor of the reappointment of a Consul at Mozambique, with a view to promote the interests of commerce and check the Slave-trade.
The overland Mail for California leaves St. Louis every Monday and Thursday, at 8 A.M. Letters designed for it should be marked, "Overland via St. Louis."

A correspondent in Iowa desires to know "more in full, the objections we entertain to the doctrine of non-intervention, or Popular Sovereignty," as represented by the Douglas Presidential ticket. We take great pleasure in responding to his request.
The Cunard screw-steamer Etna, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool at about 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 26th, and from Queenstown on the 27th of June, arrived at this port yesterday morning.
The Cunard screw steamship AEtna, already telegraphed from St. John's, and the United States Mail steamship Fulton, telegraphed from Cape Race, arrived at this port yesterday.

It hardly seems possible that only eighty-four years have departed since the birth of our great and powerful nation--when the colonies emerged from a despotic thraldom into the broad sunlight and pure atmosphere of perfect freedom and independence.
The Washington States positively denies the statement that Hon. A.H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, has declared for Mr. BRECKINRIDGE.

The parade in London of some twenty or thirty thousand British Volunteers, who actually contrived to manoeuvre before the Queen without doing any more damage than frightening a Cabinet Minister off his horse, and who solved the Duke of WELLINGTON'S famous military problem of marching themselves in and out of Hyde Park without breaking down the fences, has evidently turned the heads of our respectable cousins over the sea.

Tne reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been 68 bbls. Ashes, 19,981 bbls. Flour, 120 bbls. Corn Meal, 69,407 bushels Wheat, 17,470 bush. Corn, 5,214 bushels Oats, 344 pkgs. Provisions, and 410 bbls. Whisky.
The will of Charles Goodyear, the celebrated inventor and patentee in India rubber fabrics, has been offered for probate before the Surrogate, Hon. EDWARD C. WEST.

You hardly need to be told what is the subject about which the Germans are now talking with their usual volubility, and more than their usual ignorance. For the last fortnight the meeting of Sovereigns at Baden Baden has taken the wind out of every other political sail.
A story of a child having been devoured by bears has been traveling the rounds of newspapers and horrifying mothers for some time. It is now ponounced to be a bare falsehood.

The day fixed upon for the execution of the notorious pirate HICKS, is Friday, the 13th instant, and the place, Bedloe's Island, in the harbor of New-York. As the time for this execution approaches, something of the excitement which was produced by the first details of the awful crime is renewed in the public mind, and thousands have already applied to the U.S. Marshal for tickets to witness it.

The sympathetic interest with which every intelligent American is following the strange and splendid career of GARIBALDI in Sicily, and which will be cordially manifested to-night, we trust, at the Academy of Music, is not likely to be diminished by the news which reaches us this morning from Naples. While the Liberator of Sicily is seemingly bent only on consolidating ...

In pursuance of an order issued by Justice CONNOLLY, FREDERIC HOFFMAN, the alleged defaulter and forger, and late Secretary of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was brought before the bar of Jefferson Market Police Court, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

DEAR SIR: In answer to the request of the President, as communicated to me by your telegraphic dispatch addressed to me at Saratoga Springs, on the 30th ult., I have to say that the California mails shal go by the steamer of the llth inst., upon the terms proposed by you, and that the service shall be maintained thrice-monthly until the 4th day of March, 1861.

The Louisville Courier states positively that Mr. GUTHRIE is not in favor of the election of Mr. DOUGLAS. It does not enlighten the public as to his predilections, however.

We are evidently in a period of penitence. Archbishop HUGHES has just condescended most kindly to express his regret at having borne false witness against one at least of his neighbors; and now we have Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, in a letter which we published yesterday and which we reprint to-day, lamenting that by somebody's blunder he should have been led into trampling on anybody's rights. It is an ungracious office...

The new Mexican mail arrived yesterday, making schedule time. The mail that arrived there before this one left, went through in fourteen days. The roads may now be considered open and the mails will hereafter run through on time. Mails sent this way arrive some ten days sooner than by the overland California route.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last have been: 69 bbls. Ashes, 6,763 bbls. Flour, 681 bbls. Corn Meal, 113,363 bushels Wheat, 86,161 bushels Corn, 750 bushels Rye, 18,066 bushels Oats, 339 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,012 bbls. Whisky.

The correspondent of the New-Orleans Delta, writing from Washington on the 22d ult., says:

At no time within recollection has Young America been so visible on the surface and in the highways and by-ways of Paris life as at present. As if there were not always enough of that class here fitting themselves to become the future husbands of American wives, the last few steamers have discharged upon the continent a number hitherto unknown.

It is now officially announced that the Prince of Wales will sail for America on Thursday next, and that he will visit the City of New York on the invitation of the Common Council, as a private gentleman, and not as the heir apparent of the British crown. He comes, in short, as Lord RENFREW, and not as the Prince of Wales.

Also, one directing the Corporation Attorney to discontinue all suits for incumbering the sidewalks where parties have since complied with the law. Also, to furnish the members of the Board with a copy of the Session laws.

Mrs. ANNA SCHUMAKER, who was attacked last Monday morning, by a roober who had entered her house, situated near the corner of Seventy-first-street and Eleventh-avenue, and whose child was murdered outright by the same ruffian, died on Tuesday night in consequence of her injuries.

Several Washington correspondents have referred of late to a recent quarrel between President BUCHANAN and Senator GWIN, of California, but none of them are quite accurate in their statements of the origin of the difficulty.

THE OVERLAND MAILS. The Cabinet have the Overland Mail service under consideration. The present contract provides for a semi-monthly mail in coaches from St. Joseph to Salt Lake in twenty-two days, at $125,000, and from Salt Lake to Placerville semi-monthly, in sixteen days, at $33,000.

This forenoon a detachment of United States Dragoons will leave New-York for Carlisle, Penn., where they are to be immediately qualified for active service in the Western departments of the Army Lieut. WHEELER will take temporary charge of the command.

The announcement that Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, of Boston, was to deliver a speech before the Young Men's Republican Union of this City, drew together last evening one of the largest audiences that ever assembled within the walls of the Cooper Institute Long before 8 o'clock, the time designated for the....

In the TIMES of Tuesday morning we published a report of the improper and insulting treatment of two ladies by two of our City officials, and of the threats of the brother of one of them, a well-known political character, to revenge the outrage. The affair came near a bloody consummation yesterday afternoon.

The demand for beef cattle has been rather larger to-day than usual for this season. Just now there is an influx of Southerners on the way to their various Summer quarters. There are also large crowds of temporary visitors arriving from the surrounding country to see the Great Eastern steamship now on exhibition at a reduced price of admission.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last have been: 44 bbls. Ashes, 12,161 bbls. Flour, 1,177 bbls. Corn Meal, 75,623 bushels Wheat, 79,131 bushels Corn, 6,000 bushels Oats, 523 pkgs. Provisions, and 331 bbls. Whisky.
