CRAVEN from his post as Engineer, and Mr. TAPPAN from his position as Commissioner of the Croten Aqueduct Department. He has been busy for some weeks in making those "little arrangements" with members of the Board of Aldermen, which are essential to the...

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending July 11, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who ship their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.
At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, an ordinance was adopted by which the Twenty-second Ward is to be re-districted, and the number of election districts increased to 14.

The following statement has been published in the Journal of Commerce, by way of reply to the current charge of negligence and inefficiency against vessels of the American squadron on the Coast of Africa, in regard to the arrest of slavers. It sets forth the vessels which have been captured by our cruisers, on suspicion of being engaged in the Slave-trade, during the past year:

Bishop O'Connor, who recently resigned the charge of his diocese, is now in Pittsburgh. It is his intention to go to Rome at an early day. Rumor, says the Pittsburgh Chronicle, has connected his name with the office of Principal of the American College in that city, but the state of his health would seem to forbid his accepting the appointment.
The Overland Mail coach has arrived here, and brings the following advices:

The Pacific Steamship Navigation Company's steamer Bogota, from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, arrived at this port on the 22d ult., bringing $448,730 in specie and the mails for Europe. She left Valparaiso on the 2d of June, and Callao the 14th. The news from all sections of the West Coast is unimportant.
The steamship North Star, A.G.JONES, Commander, from Aspinwall July 4, with 389 passengers, the California mails of June 20, and $1,514,884 in treasure, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

This trotting match took place, yesterday, at the Union Course. About a thousand persons were present, one-half of whom went by the 2 o'clock sporting train of the Long Island Railroad. The track was in excellent condition and considerable interest existed amongst sporting men in regard to the time which might be made in comparison with the recent performances of Flora Temple and Patchen.

The correspondents of the Missouri Republican, writing from Mesilla, A.T., on the 26th ult., and from Tucson on the 22d, give interesttng information regarding affairs in the Territory. "Hisperian," writing from Tucson, says:
It is with the utmost regret that we lay before our readers an account of one of the most terrible and heart-rending calamities that has ever happened in Minnesota.

Tue organs of public opinion in Sardinia fling back the last hope of the Bourbon dynasty of Naples into the face of King FRANCIS, with an emphasis which cannot be mistaken. The hour of Villafranca has passed, and it is no longer possible for Southern Italy to expect peace, freedom and progress under the heirs of King Bomba.
The Central Revolutionary Committee at Naples has issued the following appeal to the inhabitants of Naples. It is dated the 15th of June:

The pronunciamiento of Mr. WOOD, on Presidential politics, is attracting wide attention from both wings of the harmonious Democracy; and, judging from the comments on it, it would seem to be one of those happy documents which possess the rare power of displeasing both parties, while still leaving both in ignorance as to the side of the fence on which the writer means finally to land.

Early yesterday morning Marshal RYNDERS had the gallows on which HICKS is to be hung, with its appendages, sent to Bedloe's Island, with a party of mechanics, to put it in order for the execution to-day. The instrument of death stands upon the green slope of the terrace which surrounds the East portion of the island, and is in plain view from the Battery.

Postmaster FOWLER seems to be ubiquitous. Now at Pike's Peak, anon at Washoe, and again reported at Havana. His locality seems as difficult to fix as that of the Flying Dutchman. At last accounts he is said to be studying Spanish in the interior of Cuba. He was always a man of letters.

The Constitutional Union Convention of the friends of BELL and EVERETT, met at Mcchanics' Hall at 12 o'clock to-day. The attendance was moderate in point of numbers, but highly respectable in character.

The Cunard steamship Arabia arrived at Boston yesterday morning, and her mails, forwarded by the 8 o'clock train, reached this City at 5 P.M. Our correspondence and files of foreign journals furnish as with some additional news of interest.
We have received files of Kingston, Jamaica, papers to Saturday, the 23d of June, inclusive.

The Syracuse Journal says that Mr. Morris Beardsley, who disappeared from that place about three months ago, was discovered on Sunday evening last, lying on the grass in the cemetery at Batasia, in a dying state. He was able to tell his residence, but died before medial aid could be summoned. It is not yet known where he has been during his three months absence from home.

The American steamer Columbus, from San Jose de Guatemala and intermediate ports, arrived here on the 20th ult. with two weeks' later advices from all the Central American States. The news is unimportant, and with the exception of a few items from Costa Rica, there is nothing to report. The Congress of the latter State was still in session at San Jose de Costa Rica.

We heard on Monday of the failure of two houses in Marysville WM. HAWLEY Co., and SCOTT, VANTINE Co. They, jointly, were indebted to R.E. BREWSTER Co., of this city, some $40,000. Yesterday, rumors were around all the morning, that this extensive house had failed. At 2 o'clock it came out that they had confessed judgment for $104,921, and that they acknowledged their liabilities to be $300,000.

The perplexitiy of the inexperienced traveler, who sees a high wall of mountain suddenly rise up before him, write no visible gap in its perpendicular face, nor winding pathway over its cloudcapped comb, not inaptly illustrates the bewilderment which timid people feel in view of the great political revolution which confronts them at the present moment. All before them is dark and threatening, and they see no hope of escape from the dilemma.
The friends of Mr. DOUGLAS are about starting a paper in his interest in Petersburgh, Va.

Mr. WIGFALL, of Texas, is the only politician left at the present crisis who has the courage and consistency to be alarmed for the fate of the Union, in case LINCOLN is elected. He boldly declares his adherence to the old doctrine, that the only safety for the Confederacy lies in the success of the BRECKINRIDGE and LANE ticket.

NEW REPUBLICAN CLUB. The Republicans of the Assembly District, composed of the Fourth and Tenth Wards, held a meeting on Thursday evening, when it was resolved to organize a Lincoln and Hamlin Club for that District. A public meeting will be held next week to elect officers and perfect the organization, at which time also several distinguished advocates of Republican principles will make addresses.

For a year past the combustible condition of Southern Italy has in a special degree attracted the attention of statesmen, and the results now developed in that beautiful and unhappy land have long been expected. The kindling fires of revolution, still slumbering in Umbria and the Marches, have burst into a flame in Sicily, and threaten to involve, as a dry prairie, the Kingdom of Naples in the conflagration.
Our programme of celebration for the Fourth was intrusted to the "Genesee River Fleet;" an organization which owns twenty-five or thirty row-boats, some of which are the work of the best makers.

One very great defect in the various projects that have been broached for dissolving the Union, has been their lack of any practical, tangible, feasible shape. It was not easy to see how a beginning could be made. The Montgomery, Alabama, Mail has removed this little difficulty, and sketched a scheme by which the Union can be dissolved without the slightest difficulty.

The letter-carriers of our City Post-office compisin of the construction put on the second section of the bill making appropriations for the service of the Post-office Department during the current year.
Rev. FRANK REMINGTON will preach at Palace Garden Music Hall, at 3 P.M.

Yesterday our Congress assembled. The President's Message was at once received. Some of the public journals anticipate the inauguration of a new life of policy by the new minister VARAS, who has recently entered, or, more srictly speaking, returned to the Cabinet. However, be his intentions as they may, no hint has transpired about them yet.

Richard Canovan vs. The New-York and NewHaven Railroad Company. This was an action before Judge McCARTHY, in the Marine Court, brought by the plaintiff against the defendants to recover the value of a horse killed, and a wagon broken to pieces by defendants' cars.
Grant H. Adams vs. The Mayor, This is a motion to vacate a judgement for $1,420,83, obtained by the plaintiff against the City.
By the Overland Mail-coach, with the regular San Francisco dates of June 25, and telegraphic advices of the 26th, arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning.

A proclamation has been issued for the sale of 1,000,000 of acres of heretofore unoffered lands in Minnesota, during October next. They include lands reverting to the United States from Railroad grants.

The act of our State Legislature to provide for the accurate and full return of burns, marriages and deaths, though well meant, has been so bunglingly constructed, that our City Inspector finds himself at his wit's end to attain under it anything like an approximation to either accuracy or fullness, so that his aggregate returns are sadly imperfect.

The marriage registration question is one of such importance that I shall make no apology for calling the attention of your readers to it once more. How important it is, all legal gentlemen who have had to do with title searches, marriage settlements, and all that branch of the profession known as, conveyancing, can bear me witness.

The St. Joseph papers contain details of the dreadful occurrence which took place recently in that place. The buildings which fell were four-story bricks, with iron fronts, and were erected over a year ago. They were uniformly built, constituting the finest block in the city. Fears had been expressed that they were not as substantial as they should have been, as one of the stores fell while building.

The pastoral letter of his Grace, the Archbishop of Baltimore, and the Suffragans of that great province of the Roman Catholic Church, an extract from which appears in another column, marks an era in the history of the Church militant, over which every American Protestant will probably exult.

Mayor WOOD is out with a letter explaining the position in which he stands. His position has long been a standing joke.

The City was resonant with the sound of martial music on Saturday, The parades of the Eighth Regiment, receiving the Seventh on their return from Camp Scott; of the Sixth to receive the Chicago Zouaves, or United States Cadets, and the wonderful drill of the last-named in the Park, in the afternoon, kept the City alive with excitement the entire day.

Archbishop HUGHES, or somebody whom he inspires, has addressed a letter to the Tribune, in reply to our recent remarks upon his address at the Commencement of St. John's College, Fordham. He flatly denies having charged Protestants, on that occasion, with hostility or indifference to the cause of education. We can only say that every report of his speech which has appeared that of the Tribune amongst the number confirms our statement.
By the arrival of the brig Isabel Beurmann, we have advices from Port-au-Prince, Hayti, to the 1st inst.
The United States Mail steamship Vanderbill, P.E. LIFEVRE, Commander, from Havre and Southampton on the 4th inst., at 8 P.M. arrived at this port on Saturday night. The news is four days later.
The conquering hero has come without his conquest. Jason without his golden Heece, however, would have been Jason still, and HEENAN without his belt is HEENAN.

The attempt to organize a Douglas party, nowhere a thrifty business, is especially unfortunate in Delaware. Not only was the State Convention, summoned to approve the action of the Charleston Convention, a failure, but a meeting called at Wilmington, on Saturday, to ratify the nomination of the Squatter Giant, lacked the numbers requisite to raise it to the dignity and bulk of a Committee meeting, and an adjournment was had without other proceedings.

We publish in another column a copy of a memorial, which has just been put into circulation among the taxpayers of New-York, urging the Board of Councilmen to arrest the march of Mayor WOOD towards a pure municipal despotism, by refusing their concurrence in the removal of two officers from the Croton Aqueduct Department for "insubordination."

THE GREAT EASTERN. On Saturday there was a greater number of visitors to this mammoth megamerian, mastedonical, matchless marine marvel than on any other previous day, and it was gratifying to notice that one-half, at least, of these who inspected her, were children from public and private schools, who took advantage of the "holiday" and the reduced fare, to satisfy a natural and laudable curiosity.

Notwithstanding the remarkable difference of opinion among the morning papers as to where the Zouaves would drill yesterday, about five thousand people, (no doubt having read the correct announcement in the TIMES,) were at Madison-Park to witness the interesting exhibition in the afternoon. General Superintendent KENNEDY had ordered fifteen platoons, or nearly three hundred policemen, on the ground, and theoretically made every requisite arrangement to have the crowd kept back.

SIR: I am directed by the Postmaster-General to transmit to you the inclosed copy of an order made this day, declaring the streets in New-York City Post Routes, and to request you to have the same published for the information of all concerned.

On Monday last the following note was sent to me by the Collector of this port. CUSTOM HOUSE, NEW-YORK, July 7, 1860. SIR: You are hereby informed that your services as a Weigher of the Customs are no longer required. Respectfully, AUGUSTUS SCHELL, Collector. To JAMES P. DUNN.
Hon. T. G. DAVIDSON, Representative from the Third Congressional District of Louisiana, has taken the stump for BRECKINRIDGE and LANE.
The mail from New-Mexico, with dates to the 2d inst., arrived this evening.

The weekly statement of the City Inspector shows that there were 442 deaths in the City last week, showing an increase of 11 over the mortality of the previous, and 155 less than the corresponding week in 1859. Deaths from acute disease, 277; from chronic disease, 135 external causes, , 30.

George Chanman et al vs. John Cochran. This case, which has been two years before the Marine Court, has at length been finally decided by the General Term in favor of the plaintiffs. The case involves questions of considerable importance to merchants, involving the rights and liabilities of a guarantor or surety, as affected by the "Statute of Fraud's."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The laws of a certain neighboring State require the minister or magistrate who solemnizes a marriage, to furnish to each of the parties, on request, "a certificate under his hand, specifying the names, ages, and places of residence of the parties married.

Contrary to general expectation, but much to everybody's satisfaction, the California mail arrived in this city last night, all safe. Some anxiety had been felt here concerning the fate of certain enter prising traders on the route from this place for California, but it is now understood that they came to no harm, excepting one poor fellow whom the over-ac commodating red-skins relieved of the care of four hundred head of stock, in the daylight.

The screw steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. Telegraphic intelligence, received vid Queenstown from London, is of one day's later data but is wholly unimportant. It is reported from Naples that the effect of the King's concessions was very uncertain. The English hide and leather trade, consequent upon the late panic, continues in a most disorganized state.

THE WALTON-MATHEWS MURDERS. To-day the investigation of these mysterious murders will be resumed, in the Superiou Court Room, by Coroner JACKMAN. Some twenty-five additional witnesses were subpoenaed yesterday to testify in the matter, but whether their evidence will serve to fix the crime upon anybody is a matter of great doubt.

Col. John W. Forney, Philadelphia: MY DEAR SIR; I embrace the first leisure moment, since the adjournment of the Baltimore Convention, to congratulate you upon the nomination of Hon. STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS as the candidate of the Democratic Party for the office of President of the United States.
I never before spent a day so hard, yet delightful so monotonous, yet varied so full of deformity, and of beauty. We left our hotel in Naples about 10 o'clock, and drove to Resina.

Something more than two thousand persons gathered in Union Square, near Washington Statue, last evening, in response to a call upon "citizens, irrespective of party, who believe that the best interests of our country, the stability of the Union, the success of our free institutions, will be best served and promoted by the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency," to meet in Union Square.

OUR STREET CHILDREN. A large number of children from the Juvenile Asylum, who had, heretofore, been rovers in the streets, started on Monday for Illinois, under the superintendance of Mr. ALLAN, one of the Officers of that Institution. They will be located on farms in that State, and will, in all probability, become honorable men. The best possible account is received of those who have preceded them. He adds that Miss ABBY FAY, of Boston, was to sing on the evening of July 1, at a concert to be given in behalf of the Sicilian fund. It would be her first appearance.

The inquest in the Walton and Matthews case was brought to a termination, yesterday, by the Coroner's Jury bringing in a verdict that both the deceased came to their death from a pistol-shot wound, inflicted by CHARLES JERRERD. At the hour of opening the Court, there was a large attendance.

The United States vs. Henrico De Costa. In the proceedings of giving bail for Mr. De Costa, Mr. Pinkerton, of No. 11 Attorney street, was offered as bail, and notice was given that he would execute the bail piece on Tuesday. He did not appear, however, and the proceedings were adjourned till yesterday at 12 o'clock.

-Referring to the abandonment of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE by Senator BROWN, the Chicago Times declares the "back of secession is broken." How does the Times know? The Secessionists have not yet shown their backs.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, July 18, 1860--6 P. M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last have been: 51 bbls. Ashes, 4,318 bbls Flour, 522 bbls. Corn Meal, 43,705 bushels Wheat, 2,418 bushels Corn, 600 bushels Malt, 248 pkgs Provisions, and 352 bbls. Whisky.

The address of Ex-Gov. HUNT was delivered tonight, in response to an invitation of citizens. The Court-room of the City Hall was filled to overflowing, and quite a large number attended more than the room could accommodate.
Secretary TOUCEY is again convalescent, and laboriously engaged in the arduous duties of his office.

Now, that all the recruits have left Governor's Island, that post is garrisoned merely by the permanent party, whose strength has diminished recently. Recruiting for the several regiments is to continue with fresh vigor at the different rendezvous.

Owing to certain misrepresentations of the public conduct of Gen. DEGOLLADO, the Liberal Chief, which have recently appeared in some of the newspapers, several gentlemen sojourning in this city, and thoroughly acquainted with Mexican affairs, have prepared a brief history of events since January, 1858, which relieves him from all uncharitable imputations, and shows him to be a true patriot, constantly striving, amid accumulated difficulties, for the welfare of his distracted country.
The brig Kate has arrived here, with Ruatan dates of 11th inst.

The Annual Commencement exercises at Harvard University took place on Wednesday, and were attended by the largest company that has assembled there for years. The galleries and side pews were reserved for the ladies, and by 9 o'clock every seat and standing place were occupied. The graduating class this year is the largest that has ever left the College at one time.

Hardly had the Metropolitan tympanums recovered from the incessant din of Japanese receptions, Fourth of July parades, Camp Scott festivities and Chicago Zouave drills, than a new sensation appears in the arrival of the Savannah Republican Blues.

The outrages perpetrated by Senator DAVIS on the mechanics of the country, begin to be seriously felt by the Government. Orders received to-day from the army in the field, for a supply of trusses, cannot be filled, as these are "patented" articles, and under Senator DAVIS' law cannot be purchased except by special act of Congress. The Senator's bowels of compassion were insufficient to afford protection to the bowels of the soldiers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your report of the Breckinridge and Lane Meeting held last evening at Cooper Institute, you make mention that my watch was stolen. Such was not the fact no thieving occurring at the principal meeting, outside the Hall.

On Thursday, Judge DOUGLAS, by invitation of several citizens of Lexington, visited that celebrated battle-ground, and viewed the spot where the new monument is to be erected.

An adjourned meeting of the Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors was held in the Common Council Chamber last evening. The Board of Councilmen met last evening in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen, MORGAN JONES, Esq., President, in the Chair. The Minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved.

Arrangements have been made for a series of international matches, to be played annually, under the auspices of the St. George's Club, of New-York, and the Montreal Club, of Montreal, Canada East. The first match will be played at Montreal during the Prince of WALES' visit to that city.

The schooner Washington Irving, which left Erie for this port a week ago, has not since been heard from, and there is no longer room to doubt that she is lost with all on board. The following is a list of her crew and passengers: Capt. Stephen H. Varmatta, Antonia Hary, Henry House, Owen Keep, Refer Silvy, and one passenger, Cornelius Leary. Owen Keep belonged in Buffalo, the others in Erie.

The condition of Peru is about the same as at last report. CASTILLA still holds the reins of Government, and has his own way in everything; although, occasionally, we hear of secret organizations having for their object the overthrow of his Government.

His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales is to drop all royal state on entering the American Republic. In the British Colonies it will, however, be preserved, and will doubtless prove irksome enough, both to him and to those about him. Col. BRUCE is understood to have strict orders to see that he is treated like Her Majesty the Queen in all respects, and Col. BRUCE is not the man to disobey orders.

The results of the census, as reported through the newspapers, indicate that Eastern and Western cities, especially those engaged in manufactures, have fallen below the rate of increase which marked their career prior to 1850. Providence, in Rhode Island, is said to have declined in population. Cincinnati falls short of public expectation by fifty to seventy thousand.

By your journal of this day I notice the order of the Postmaster General, and also several letters from City deliverers. The first claims attention from the whole community for various reasons, simply because our City Dispatch Post has been conducted with notorious inefficiency and bad management, and forcing us to use, for protection sake, the facilities of a "City Express Box," simply because their service was more reliable.

San Francisco has been stirred very deeply again to its marrow but this time with joy. The Supreme Court at Sacramento has reversed its own decision of 1857, and pronounced the Peter Smith title invalid. Now PETER SMITH was an innocent, crack-brained doctor, who lived here in 1849 and 1850. When the contract for taking care of the sick of the city was to be awarded, PETER got it.

After my previous letter had left my possession, but before its appearance in the NEW-YORK TIMES, the speech of Senator SUMNER at the Cooper Institute was printed. Had I seen that speech before I should not have indulged in the unwonted occupation of writing upon such a subject. It is evident that some friends have made to Mr. SUMNER the suggestions my letter was designed to offer.

FREDERICK HOFFMAN, the alleged defaulter, Judge LEONARD has established a claim to public approval. Justice CONNOLLY, it will be remembered, after listening to the affidavits of the officers of the Pacific Steamship Company, thought proper to fix the security necessary to the prisoner's temporary release at the handsome sum of $22,000.

FRENCH INTERVENTION IN MEXICO. M. DUBOYS DE SALIGNY, the Special Minister of France to Mexico, is expected to arrive here about Sept. 1, to consult with the Washington Cabinet, prior to intervening in the affairs of that country.

Prof. T.S.C. is Lowe in Philadelphia, and has actually persuaded some of the citizens to advance him funds, so that he may undertake his long-promised balloon trip to Europe. He is to be accompanied by an astronomer, a historian, a sea-captain and an artist.
The Houston (Texas) Republic, of the 14th inst., contains an account of the great fire, which destroyed the town of Dallas on the 8th inst., a brief notice of which we obtained by telegraph. It says:

The Bangor Whig states that the company engaged in raising goods from the lost steamer Hungarian are taking out from the wreck about $600 worth per day. At low water, large numbers of dead bodies may be seen.

Straws, we are told, show which way the wind blows; and in this sense, it is presumed, political demonstrations indicate, in some degree, their present and future condition. We have already had our BRECKINRIDGE and LANE and our DOUGLAS and JOHNSON ratification meetings, together with some previous outpourings of the Union Party. My impressions and observations regarding these were given you in a previous letter.
The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 14th inst., with the passengers and treasure from San Francisco, arrived at this port last night.
The telegraph line is now completed to this point, and an office is opened for business.
The mails from Melbourne to May 17, and Sydney May 12, had arrived in England.

COTTON The business on Saturday was supposed to reach 20,000 bales not 12,000, as telegraphed per Africa and yesterday, Monday, the sales were about 15,000 bales, including 5,000 on speculation and for export. There was a better tone in the market, but still there is some irregularity, and prices show no improvement.

TO THE PEOPLE OF MARYLAND: The Executive Committee of the Republican Party of the State of Maryland, in submitting to you an Electoral Ticket for President and Vice-President, deem it a proper occasion to present a brief address, in explanation and defence of their principles and objects.

The Atlantic and Harpers' for August are out; the former containing its customary variety, and the latter exceeding its average degree of excellence. The leading article of the Atlantic, "The Carnival of the Romantic," is a well-digested and suggestive review of the art of novel-writing. This is followed by "A Legend of Maryland," Eleusinia," ...
The Cunard screw-steamship Jura, Capt. MOODIE, which sailed, from Liverpool on the afternoon of the 10th, and from Queenstown on the 11th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The preparations for the reception of the Prince of Wales are nearly completed. There is much excitement among all classes in view of the contemplated event. Following is the programme of the demonstration:
The Bombay mail of June 7 had reached England.

The Charleston Courier of the 18th has late intelligence from Key West. The Courier says: "A passenger by the steamer which brought our advices expressed much surprise relative to the story in the papers of the rescue of a portion of the negroes at Key West, and of their being carried off. He assured us positively that there is not a particle of truth in the report.
By the brig Helen Jane, Capt. ROGERS, from St. Domingo city, we have dates to the 6th inst. Business was very dull. The health of the place good.
The United States steam-sloop of war Brooklyn, apt. FARRAGUT, called off Mobile Bay yesterday morning, the 16th, on her way to Pensacola.

Among the general orders promulgated yesterday, by the War Department, is one directing the removal from the Presidio, San Francisco, of Company I. Third Artillery, which is to proceed at once to Honey Lake Valley, for the protection of the inhabitants of that region. Supplies for the command are to be furnished by the Chief Commissary.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, the following communication was received from the Comptroller, giving the estimate of the additional amount of money required for the support of the City Government for the year 1860:

In the House of Lords on the 9th inst., the Marquis of NORMANBY was anxious to correct the erroneous impressions which might have been created a few evenings since by the somewhat disparaging tone in which his noble and learned friend (Lord BROUGHAM) had spoken of certain correspondents from whom he had received information with respect to the acts of the Provisional Government at Florence.
The steamship North Briton, from Liverpool 11th, via Galway 13th inst., arrived at St. Johns at 5 P.M. to-day, and sailed at 6 o'clock for Quebec, having landed the mails.

An appeal to the public is seldom more than a thinly-vailed demand for popular favor. I have no such appeal to make; and yet I desire to be heard upon a matter which pertains to public, as well as private rights; for, whatever is an attack upon the good name or citizenship of an American citizen, is an infringement upon those immunities, it is the duty of every man to protect.
Two large steamers are in sight coming in, and are undoubtedly the Hero with the Prince of Wales on board, and Ariadne.
HOOLEY CAMPBELL'S MINSTRELS AT NEWARK. Hooley Campbell's Minstrels have arranged to appear to-night and to-morrow night in Concert Hall, Newark.

Capt. TEAL and the officers of the Pennsylvania returned to the wreck yesterday morning, accompanied by Capt. CROWELL, the agent of the line in this city. William Winans et al., Administrator of Reuben Withers and James M. Waterbury, vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company et al. The plaintiffs in this action held an assignment from Oliver Charlick of a claim to a fifth portion of the profits of the lease of the Williamsburgh Ferry, amounting as calculated by them, to $200,000.

A great railroad manoeuvre has been on hand for some time past, which involves four of the largest railway concerns in our country, excepting, perhaps, the New-York Central and Illinois Central. The history of this scheme has not yet found its way into the public prints. I venture, therefore, to give a brief foreshadowing and outline of it.

The political contest is assuming a curious shape. The shattered condition of the Democratic Party has destroyed everything like an organized opposition to the Republicans, based upon principle, and converted the whole campaign into a desperate struggle not to get into power themselves, but to keep their opponents out. The highest ambition of the motley Anti-Republican host just now, is to play the dog in the manger.

We imagine that some of the Conservative and Union-loving people of Louisiana would like to know the reason why some of the Breckinridge and Lane papers in the South support that ticket, as the said papers themselves state it. The reason is, in some instances, not a little suggestive and curious.

The London Times, of the 22d ult., forebodes a famine in England, owing to bad weather and consequent short crops. The prospect of the grain crops in France is also said to be unpromising. On the other hand, the cereal crops in the United States and Canada never promised better.
The Board met last evening in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen. In the absence of the President, ALEX. L. SHAW, Esq., was called to the Chair.
The steamer Habana has arrived here, with Havana dates of the 20th inst.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 125 bbls. Ashes, 5,518 bbls. Flour, 369 bbls. Corn Meal, 30,769 bushels Wheat, 114,252 bushels Corn. 33,861 bushels Oats, 2,122 pkes. Provisions, and 1,212 bbls. Whisky.

Senator DOUGLAS, in his recent speech at Albany, repudiated, in very strong terms, the Breckinridge doctrine, that slaveholders are entitled to the Federal protection for their slaveproperty in the Territories. He does this, not on the ground that slave-property differs from any other kind of property, but on the ground that all property must rely for its safety on local laws. He says:

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. The monthly meeting of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association was held at their rooms, cor ner of Broadway and Twelfth-street, on Monday evening, the President, Mr. GOODRICH, in the Chair. Reports were received from the Church, Visiting, Employment and Boarding-house Committees, all of which appear now to be in good working order.

For an unreasonable number of years the steamship Great Eastern has attracted a large share of the curiosity, interest and enthusiasm of Europe and America. At first it was proposed that she should be built. This proposition was received with what the reporters style "derisive laughter."

Five companies of the Third Infantry, to be stationed at Ringgold Barracks, will be designated by the Colonel of the Regiment. The other five companies will take post at Fort Clarke, Texas, where will be established the Head quarters of the Regiment.

The steamer Austin; from Brazos on the 20th inst., with $80,000 in specie, has arrived here.

DILLAYE. Our readers may remember the hue and cry which was made a few months ago over the arrest of STEPHEN D. DILLAYE, Esq., a prominent politician of this State, for forgery, and his trial at Pittsburgh. Mr. D. had been a very active Democrat, and had taken a very conspicuous part in the party politics of the State for several years.

LIVERPOOL, Tuesday. RICHARDSON, SPENCE CO. report FLOUR dull, and 6d. lower; American, 26s.@29s. WHEAT dull, and nominally unchanged; red, 10s. 9d.@11s.; white, 11s. 6d.@12s. 6d. CORN firm, with a better demand; mixed, 30s. 6d.@31s.; yellow, 31s.@31s. 6d.; white, 34s.@34s. 6d.

The first annual commencement exercises of the Long Island College Hospital took place last evening in the Chapel attached to the Packer Institute, Joralemon-street. SAMUEL SLOAN, Esq., President of the Board of Regents, occupied the Chair and the house was well filled, principally by medica' gentlemen and their friends.

New-Mexico dates to the 9th inst. arrived today, the mail making schedule time. They have had copious showers of rain in Santa Fe for ten days, and crops look finely, and will yield an abundant harvest.

The city is full of people, who have come to the annual College Union Regatta. The hotels are all overrun with guests, among whom are more than three hundred college students. The interest is intense, and at no previous time has there been known to be such excitement concerning aquatics.

The examination of Wm. D. Haight on a charge of perjury, in swearing to the possession of $13,000 worth of unincumbered real estate, while offering himself as bail in the case of Da Costa, was commenced yesterday before United States Commissioner MORELL. Mr. Steutenberg appeared as counsel for Haight.
Quartermaster SUTHERLAND'S sureties are bound for $25,000. His defalcation is about $33,000.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, July 25, 1860. Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending July 25, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who ship their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Saturday, July 21, 1860. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE'S carefully-prepared speech at Frankfort, on the 18th, is much criticised. It is regarded as an electioneering appeal to Kentuckians ostensibly for "the great cause," but really for his embarrassed and rather despondent self.
Commencement exercises have commenced. Sunday, President LORD delivered rather a mediocre Baccalaureate. Yesterday was Class-day.

PHELAN has brought here one of his best tables, and the Yale and Harvard representatives have just finished a match game. The time was two hours and a half, and Harvard won by eighty points. The hall was crowded with students, and there was great enthusiasm.

Just as we expected, and cautioned people against, cattle dealers, and owners also, were excited over the advance in the price of beef secured by the forestalling operations of the New-York dealers during two weeks past. The result is, we have had nearly five thousand head of beef cattle forced into this week's market, when less that four thousand head were really needed.

Poecisely at 12 o'clock JACOB VANATTA called the Convention to order, and said, that after a consultation with the friends of the regular nominees, and finding that there was a disposition in the Convention called by the Committee to nominate an electoral ticket unfavorable to the nomination, it had been decided to call this Convention. He called the body to order, and called for nominations for Chairman. A delegate named Col. CANNON, of Bordentown.

Shortly before 12 o'clock yesterday noon as embarrassing a fire as any with which the firemen have ever contended, occurred in the cellar of the large brick warehouse, situated at the corner of Broad and Stone streets. Mr. SPENCER D.C. VAN BOKKELEN, a dealer in provisions and naval stores, occupied the entire premises, excepting the second floor, in which the business of R.R. BARTHOLD, commission merchant, was conducted.
The R.M. steamship Canada, from Liverpool, arrived at Halifax at 11:30 A.M., yesterday, and sailed at 6 P.M. for Boston, where she will be due about 12 o'clock to-night.

At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, a communication was received from the School Officers of the Fourth Ward, asking authority to advertise for proposals to furnish the new school house in that Ward. The resolution attached to the communication was adopted.

The Douglas State Convention meets this afternoon. A great crowd of politicians are here, The opinions are divided about the policy of nominating straightout Douglas Electors, and also as to the policy of the State Convention.

The People and Gaylor Brennan vs. the Mayor, This case, it will be remembered, was a motion heard before Justice INGRAHAM, at the special term of the Supreme Court, to set aside a judgment against the City. His Honor has now rendered a long opinion in this case, reviewing all the facts involved, in a very elaborate manner, and granting the motion.
The Ponp press reached here this noon, with San Francisco dotes of July 11, four days later. The following is a summary of the news by this arrival : SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, July 11.
Mr. FALLS, President of the Norfolk Steamboat Line, informs me that the Great Eastern will certainly visit the Annapolis Roads. The arrangements are all made, and the required bonus has been raised.

The city is full of strangers to-night, and great excitement prevails. The Hartford Wide-Awakes, numbering 500 men, turned out, and in torch-light procession paraded on the Park. They received the Newark Wide-Awakes, numbering 300, at 10 o'clock, and, accompanied by thousands, they marched through the city, entering the City Hall at 11. There they gave a splendid banquet to their visitors. The Hall was beautifully decorated by the ladies of Hartford.

It seems we were slightly mistaken in supposing that no steps would be taken to resist payment of the nice little bill of $105,000 which the Common Council Committee have brought in against the City for "entertaining" the Japanese. Mr. LEVI S. CHATFIELD, as a City tax-payer, has stepped forward and applied for an injunction to restrain the Comptroller from paying the bill.

The Commandant of Marines at Pensacola Capt. SIMMS, left, to join the Richmond, at Norfolk, a few days ago. (He has since been ordered to the Susquehanna.) Lieut. STARK, who brought a detachment of Marines here some time since, replaces him. The change pleases everybody.

To the intelligent foreigner, who has studied DE TOCQUEVILLE, and looks with interest at the working of American institutions, the most striking peculiarity of the actual Presidential canvass must be the professed readiness of popular leaders to defeat the popular will. Of the six candidates named, two alone calculate upon and work for an election by the people.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Several New-York Archaeologists have, within the past week, received various communications concerning the discovery of a very curious stone relic, covered with Hebrew inscriptions, said to have been found by Mr. WYRICK, of Newark, Ohio, in one of those artificial earthworks so numerous in that vicinity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In vain have I watched your columns, for some days past, to see if they contained an account of the terrific rain and hail storm which passed over and near this place about a week since. I would not even now attempt a description of that storm was it not of so remarkable a character as to entitle it to notice.
Denver City dates to the 28th of June are brought by express this evening.
Yale College Commencement exercises closed at 6 o'clock this evening.

Judge DOUGLAS is in the receipt of pressing invitations to visit several Southern States, and it is not Improbable that he may make a short tour during the Summer. The proprietors of the Greenbrier White Sulphur Spriags in Virginia have also offered to him the hospitalities of that famed watering-place. The Springs are controlled by a Joint Stock Association of the gentlemen of the neighborhood, with Whom the "Little Giant" is very popular.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am an elderly lady, in moderate circumstances, dependent for my subsistence upon the income of a small estate; this estate consists of Bank stock at the North, which I am told is indisputably good, and of two negroes at the South, that bring me in a very neat little sum for their hired services; one of them is a carpenter, and the other a journeyman barber.

THE DOUGLAS CONVENTION IN PENNSYLVANIA. The Douglas Convention held at Harrisburgh on the 26th, (partially reported by telegraph,) appears to have been a very enthusiastic gathering. The principal speech was that of Hon. CHAS. BROWN, of Philadelphia, who bore hard upon the Administration wing of the party. We quote a passage from the report of his remarks in the Press:

It is evident that there is an undercurrent of ill-feeling among the European Courts in regard to the events beyond the Alps, which forebodes no good to the glorious cause in which GARIBALDI is engaged.

Eliphalet Lyon vs. Richard Dudgeon. This was an action argued before Judge LEONARD, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, to dissolve a copartnership hitherto existing between the parties, in the manufacture and sale of hydraulic jacks and punches instruments used in handling and careening vessels.

The Spaniards have long been laboring under the reproach of an excessive passion for rhet oric. There is no QUATTLEBUM SO explosive, no CUSMING so metaphorical that he must not have his fling at the pompous declamations of Spanish oratory. We dare say that KWTTI himself never speaks of Spanish pronunciamentos without a compassionate curl of the lip. But at least one Spanish orator has just earned the right to a very different reputation.

Advices have reached us from the Western Departments of the Army. The troops at the several stations were in good health of the date our news left, viz: the middle of June. The Ordnance Department of Fort Leavenworth, agreably to instructions from Headquarters, has been converted into and will henceforward be known as an Arsenal. All well and peaceable at the fort.

A procession of three thousand Republicans, headed by one thousand Wide-Awakes, paraded the City this evening, and marched to the Depot, where they welcomed delegations from New-Haven, Springfield, and other towns who swelled the procession to the number of at least five thousand.

THE BRECKINRIDGE CENTRAL CAMPAIGN CLUB. The first regular meeting of this Club was held last evening, at the National Music Hall, No. 765 Broadway, the President, GIDEON J. TUCKER, Esq., in the Chair, and about forty members present.

The following is the text of the amnesty lately granted by the King of Naples: ARTICLE 1. Penal proceedings are abolished as regards all persons accused of political offences, and consequently any ulterior action against those in confinement or absent for facts anterior to the 25th June is prohibited.

The American career of the Prince of Wales has thus far been creditable and satisfactory to all concerned. The people of Newfoundland, so unused in their remote and specially slow corner of creation to the luxruy of new sensations, might fairly have been expected to have committed any number of extravagances upon such extraordinary provocation.
Much feeling has been expressed here to-day on the removal of Messrs. McQUADE, SIGSBY and GAFFNEY from the Custom-house,-and the appointment of Mesers. FARRELL, GRIFFIN and BLANCHARD.

This Board met yesterday afternoon in their Chamber for the first time, which has been vacated by them for the past two months.

A STEAM BARGE ON FIRE CONSTERNATION OF THE PASSENGERS. About 6 o'clock last night, great excitement was caused in Hoboken by the announcement that a barge containing passengers was on fire in the river, and was heading for the shore. It was at first supposed to be an excursion boat in which event the loss of life would undoubtedly have been very great.
At a meeting of the trustees of the New-York Produce Exchange Company, held July 27, 1860, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:
The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool 18th vi Queenstown 19th inst., passed Cape Race on her way to New-York, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

Advices from Messina to the 8th inst., transmitted by way of Marseilles, state that Col. MEDICI was at the village of Barcelona, waiting volunteers. He had reconnoitered the heights of Messina. The attack of Milazzo was fixed for the 10th inst. Assassinations took place at Messina on the night of the 7th. The Neapolitan army was demoralized. The soldiers were deserting.

By the arrival of the steamship City of Washington, off Cape Race, yesterday morning, we are put in possession of advices from Europe four days later than those previously received. The news is unimportant.

The steamship Austin, Capt. FORBES, from Brazos Santiago, the 20th inst., via Indianola the 21st, arrived at New-Orleans at an early hour on the 23d inst. The following is from the New-Orleans Picayune of the 24th inst.:

The selection of candidates for the West Point Military Academy and Annapolis Naval School devolves alternately upon members of Congress, so that all sections of the country may be represented in those valuable institutions. The result hitherto, however, has not been to secure an equal representation of all the States in the graduating classes as cadets, either from physical or mental incapacity, have been obliged to leave the institutions before finishing the course.

BURGLARY. On Saturday night the coal-office of VALENTINE PROVOOST, corner of Franklin-avenue and Freeman-street, was entered through the front window. The burglars had charged the lock with gunpowder, when they were discovered by Mr. GEORGE KINGSLAND, CHAS. BROWN, JAS. WILLIAMSON and JOHN RILEY were subsequently arrested on the charge.

Perhaps nothing is more astonishing in the constitution of American society, than the extraordinary elasticity which our people display under the pressure of deluges, conflagrations, commercial crises, and disasters generally. We have the talent of a trained goldfinch for "shamming dead," and the genius of a Mantalini for suicide. Probably no nation has ever existed which could stand so much ruining.

The steamer Quaker City, R.W. SHUFELDT, Commander, arrived from Havana yesterday morning, having left that port Wednesday last, 25th inst., at 1 P.M.

Cotton in good demand for export; sales yesterday 10,000 bales, including 4,000 on speculation and for export. The sales of the two days (Monday and Tuesday) are 23,140 bales, at prices showing no change from last week. Trade is generally healthy, and speculation is dormant.

SIR: The popular mind inclines to the sentiment that national self-respect should shield the position of President from any exposure of the delinquencies of the incumbent. The Constitution declares otherwise, and, in your case, it is most healthy for the public to advance to the constitutional limit. You have, besides, voluntarily entered the lists of partisan discussion, inviting all the consequences of the position.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, Capt. JEFFREY, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 18th, and from Queenstown on the 19th of July, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices have been anticipated, but we find in our newspaper files additional details of interest.

Senator SEWARD, with a large party of NewYorkers and others, has been visiting Little Sodus Bay. Mr.SEWARD'S health was never better, and he is ready at the proper time to buckle on his working harness, and to lend his utmost aid for the furtherance of the interests of the party of which he was the originator, is the life, and may yet be the popular representative.

It is thought that the fire on Monday night, in Fowler's Buildings, Nassau-street, was kindled by an incendiary. It broke out on the fourth floor, which was untenanted, and this fact leads to the belief that it was the work of design; while the supposition is supported by another circumstance, viz. : the finding of some pieces of paper, apparently saturated with camphene, which had blown into the street.

JOSEPHINE KEPLER, a German woman, residing at 746 Third-avenue, was fatally injured on the night of the 1st inst., by the explosion of a fluid lamp which she was engaged in replenishing. Soon after the accident the poor woman was removed to Bellevue Hospital, where her death occurred yesterday. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body.

HANOVER, Saturday, July 28, 1860. We are completely disappointed in Dartmouth Commencement. Mr. EDWARD EVERETT has failed to deliver his expected oration before the United Literary Societies, the "Social Fraternity" and the "Brothers in Unity." In lieu, however, Col. E.G. PARKER, of Boston, delivered an address on "True Statesmanship and False Demagogueism," which evinced extensive learning in illustration and a deep penetration into the political history of America.

The steamship Prince Albert, from Galway 24th inst., arrived at this port at 6 o'clock this morning, and sailed for New-York at 8 o'clock.

The steamship Great Eastern arrived here at 8 o'clock this morning. She has two thousand and eighty-seven passengers. One steamboat accompanied her to the bar last evening. She got over the bar safely at 7.12 P.M., (at which hour it was high tide,) and had two feet to spare under the keel.

Times have altered. Ever since I came here I have been lying in wait to see some of "Podgers'" boasted fleas, but my cabinet is not yet supplied with one. I got me a terrible little Scotch terrier as a trap, but not a flea yet. Our colored population has of late been in almost constant alarm, in consequence of several cases of kidnapping. The unfortunate victims have been seized at night by armed men, and secretly conveyed into Missouri, and there sold to slavetraders going South, or lodged in jail until a favorable opportunity should occur to send them down the river to the Southern market.

Our Special Correspondent at Palermo writes us that the existence of a secret treaty between France and Piedmont has been discovered by GARIBALDI. By the terms of this treats Piedmont will be allowed to annex the two Sicilias; but she must not touch Umbria and the Marches unless the populations first revolt, in which case these also may be annexed.

This morning at 4 o'clock the General reviewed his troops foreign and native, or Italian and Sicilian as they say here on the plains of Monte Pelegrims. They amounted to about 10,000 i.e., the remnants of the General's veteran band.

There can be no more delightful coasting journey than that from St. John, New-Brunswick to Windsor, Nova Scotia, when traveled by daylight. John Mitchel, if we are to believe the Richmond Examiner, has left his adopted country, not only for that country's good, but for his own emolument. There remained unsold at the Twenty-fourthstreet Stables 410 horses at the beginning of the week. First-class horses were in limited demand. Three coach teams were sold at $650 to $800 per team. The supply is light. A few good road and business horses changed hands at $200@$225 each. Saddle horses have been partially neglected.

The circumstances attending the stabbing of HENRY PAEBLER, a German, 32 years of age, who died at Believue Hospital on Wednesday morning, were yesterday investigated by Coroner JACKMAN. The inquest resulted in a verdict against ADAM JAGER, who inflicted the fatal injury. It appeared from the testimony of PHILIP RICHARD, a witness of the affray, that a difficulty between JAGER and deceased occurred at MEYER'S lager-bier saloon, in Third-street, on Sunday night.

The consecration of the new synagogue of the congregation B'nai Israel, located on the corner of Stanton and Forsyth streets, took place yesterday afternoon. The building, which is capable of holding about 800 people, was formerly a Baptist Church, but has recently been purchased, and converted into a synagogue by the above congregation, most of whom are natives of Holland.

Mr. JOHNSON, counsel for the claimants, yesterday summoned up before the Commissioners, and replied at length to the positions of the opposing counsel.
The sixth annual Convention of Dental Surgeons of the United States commenced here this day. About 75 members were enrolled at the morning session, and about as many more are expected.

Charles, Miller vs. Eli Bennett. This was a motion to vacate an order of arrest, granted in this case in September last. The motion was now made before Justice SUTHERLAND at Chambers of the Supreme Court.

No divisions into sections took place to-day; and only a morning session was held the afternoon being devoted to a visit to the Fort. Very general interest was felt to hear Prof. AGASSIZ' address on ...
DEATH OF MRS. GARDINER SPRING. Mrs. SUSAN SPRING, wife of Rev. Dr. SPRING, the venerable pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, died in this City yesterday morning.
Col. TUERO, R.A., in a letter to the Times, defends GARIBALDI against certain insinuations of Signor FARINI, late agent of the Sardinian Cabinet at Paris.

The last of the African slaves were sent on board the ship Star of the Union, on the 19th inst., and she sailed the same afternoon for Sinon, Africa. The number placed on board was 385, constituting what was known as the cargo of the unknown or "unnamed" French bark. The total number delivered over to the three vessels for return is 1138, the balance of the original number have died.

When the thermometer is at its present altitude business naturally flags in law Courts, civil and criminal. A man's indignation must be high indeed, if he can get higher than "Phoebus Apollo" has reached during the past two days.
COOMUS' majority in Jefferson County is 3,206; in Fayette County, 650; in Bourbon County, about 380; in St. Nicholas County, about 125; in Hardin ...

The usual number of petitions were presented and referred, and the special order of the day having been called up, viz., the adoption of plans for the erecting a new house of detention for witnesses, the plans submitted by the Committee were adopted.
The New Mexican mail, with dates to the 23d of July, arrived to-day. No Indians were seen on the route.
A letter from the Canadian Chief Commissioner of Public Works of ISSAC BUCHANAN, gives the following as the programme of the Prince's tour in Canada:
SANDY HOOK, Aug. 7, sunset. Two ships outside the Bar bound in; no signals. Wind fresh, S. Weather clear. Ship David Stewart cld. the Bar at 5 P.M., bound out.
The Breckinridge and Lane Democratic State Convention assembled at Corinthian Hall at noon today.

The Second Annual Aquatic Festival of the Mendelssohn Union, of this City, occurred on Monday night, and will long be remembered as a pleasant incident by those who were so fortunate as to participate in it.

We are very sorry for the Bostonians. Atnonians without an Athens, although they have all the will in the world to hear or to tell some new thing, they can never get any new thing, least of all any "big thing" to hear or to tell.
Caroline Stowell vs. Charles Stowell. This was an action for divorce founded on charges of adultery.

The circumstances attending the death of RoBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, are at present under investigation by Coroner GAMBLE. From the information so far obtained, it appears that the parents of deceased reside at No.159 West Eleventh-Street, and the child being supposed to need medical attention, Dr. BUCK, of Grand-Street, physician to the family, was sent for.
The activity in the market continues with a grad ual upward tendency in prices. Receipts have been moderate, with an undiminished demand for export.

The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th ult., arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her advices, which are two days later and meagre in the extreme, have been briefly telegraphed. It was reported incorrectly that a Convention had been signed at Paris relative to the intervention of the European Powers in the Syrian outbreak.

I wrote you very hurriedly a few days ago, and now find, to meet the mail, which departs in an hour, must again write in haste. I have just indulged in a delightful dinner, and am slightly apprehensive my ideas may not flow so rapidly as might be desired.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A notice of another extensive Auroral exhibition may not be uninteresting to your subscribers. On rising at about 4 o'clock this morning, my attention was directed by a friend to the heavens, which were overspread by the peculiar auroral manifestations.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A meteor of unusual brilliancy appeared Monday evening, soon after sunset. Its altitude was about 5-0 , and its apparent path was from southwest to north-northwest.

The New-Jersey Republican State Convention for the nomination of Electors of President and VicePresident, assembled at Trenton Yesterday. There was not so large a gathering at the New-Jersey Capital, as on the occasion of the triple Conventions held there three weeks ago; nevertheless, the various sections of the State were fairly represented, and the proceedings were very harmonious, and were carried through with commendable dispatch.
The sole-leather Tanners of the States of NewYork and Pennsylvania held a semi-annual meeting in the Astor House yesterday afternoon.

The "mysterious circumstances" connected with the supposed murder of some unknown person at Long Branch, on Sunday night last, continued to agitate the people of the immediate neighborhood of the supposed crime until yesterday.

To-day we are floating on a sea of contradictions in regard to GARIBALDI and Neapolitan affairs; the telegraphs have grown quite as much partisan as the journals, and so we have a confusion of truths and untruths sufficient to throw doubt into the best settled conviction.

In opening the question it was remarked by Prof. PUGH ("Investigations on the Assimilation of Gaseous Nitrogen of Plants,") that there are two sources whence plants might be supposed to derive a nitrogen either from combined nitrogen in its varied forms or from the gaseous nitrogen of the atmosphere.
On the 13h of May, Mr. Silas Gregory, of Croton Falls, lost a valuable horse, which he had every reason to believe was stolen. Indeed, he could have lost him in no other way.
The R.M. stemship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool 28th, via Queenstown 29th, arrived here at 3 A.M. to-day.

The New Haven Palladium, of the 7th, says: "Another very brilliant meteor was seen on Monday, August 6, by persons in Branford. Just at sunset, the sky being clear, a fire-ball like a star was observed near the south-eastern horizon, sailing around slowly and gradually through the north eastern quarter of the heavens, and a few degrees above the horizon, and disappearing some degrees west of north.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since noon yesterday, have been 16 bbls. Ashes, 5,901 bbls. Flour, 33,771 bush. Wheat, 92,496 bushels Corn, 7,100 bushels Oats, 522 pkgs. Provisions, and 370 bbls. Whisky.

The Breckinridge and Lane Democratic State Convention have made the following nominations: For Governor, JAMES T. BRADY, of New-York; for Lieutenent-Governor, H. K. VILLE, of Buffalo; or Canal Commissioner, JOHN M. JAYCOX, of Onondaga; for State-Prison Inspector, ROBERT W. ALLEN, of Kings.

The regular exercises of commencement week at Amherst College opened on Sunday with the baccalaureate sermon by the President. His text was II. Timothy, chap. iv., verses 6,7,8. The subject of the discourse, which was most impressive and appropriate, was "the principles which should control the Christian student in the choice of his profession."
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Another double meteor, somewhat resembling that of the 20th ult., passed over to the westward of our village last evening, a few minutes before 8 o'clock.

The Republican Ratification meeting for the Eastern District was held last evening in the Odeon, the large hall of which was filled to overflowing. The meeting was organized at 8 o'clock by electing THOMAS W. FIELD, Esq., Chairman, and the usual number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Addresses were delivered by J.L. WOODWARD, Esq., of New-York, Gen. BRUCE, and others.
The programme for to-day was as follows: SECTION A. MATHEMATICS, PHYSICS AND CHEM ISTRY.

Dunn and friend, Mr. and Mrs. Crocker and infant, Judge Warren, Mrs. Pierce, Miss. Groom. Mr. Baring, lady and servant; Messrs. Groom, Goodwin, Bubbles, Allen, Moore, Mrs. Jordan, Graham, Walton and wife, Winter, Kupper, Stickney, Healy,...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A morning paper recently expressed a "hope that GARIBALDI would show himself as incorruptible while a statesman as he had been while a soldier." Allow me, in this connection to narrate an anecdote of GARIBALDI in New-York, that will show clearly his notions in such matters.

The continued large receipts (14,500 per week for two weeks,) have caused a decline of 25c.@50c. per head on lambs, and about c. per lb. for sheep. The stock on hand was larger than could be disposed of to-day, and dealers called the market heavy. A very few of the best sheep brought about 5c. per lb., live weight, but they generally went at 4c.@4 c., and lambs at 6c.@6 c.
Our village has recently been the scene of a murder, a suicide, and of an unsuccessful attempt at suicide.
Archbishop HUGHES has written the following letter to the editor of his organ in this City:

Among the latest news from Europe in the scientific world, is an eloquent essay of the eminent REICHENBACH proving the identity of comets and meteorties. This intellignece, interesting as it is to scientific men, will doubtless at this time interest a large portion of the general public here, on account of the recent appearance of a most magnificent meteor.

LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF AN M.E. MISSION CHURCH. The corner-stone of an M.E. Mission Church in Twenty-fourth street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop JANES, with appropriate ceremonies. There were some two hundred persons present mostly ladies interested in the success of the Mission.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A meteor of nearly equal brilliance and size of the one of July 20, was seen passing along the western sky this evening at about twenty minutes after sunset. Its course was from south to north, in an almost straight horizontal line, and its velocity about the same as that of the meteor of the other evening which it much resembled and forcibly suggested.

The corps of Cadets in the Military Academy is at present encamped on the plain, all studies having been abandoned for the time, that the opportunity might be given for instruction in the practical details of military life. The following is a brief schedule of the regular routine: At 5 A.M. the reveille is beaten, the several companies are formed, and the roll is called by the First Sergeants.
The mails for California, Oregon, New-Granada, the Sandwich Islands and the South Pacific, by the Northern Light, will close on Saturday at 10 o'clock, A.M.

From the largest mass of statistics ever collected on this subject, viz: 1,252 cases, furnished by Dr. HOWE, Dr. ELLIOTT has constructed a biometre or life-table for the blind; by which we are able to compute a number of interesting and practical problems.

The Richmond Enquirer, usually one of the tamest and most moderate of journals, has been moved to an extraordinary display of excitement by the intelligence that Virginia has absolutely condescended to arm herself with Massachusetts weapons. It discourses upon the subject in the following strain:

The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, and received the first quarterly report made by Sergeant LORD, of the Sanitary Squad. The report includes the operations of the Squad up to the 1st inst., and shows that the total number of nuisances abolished, and dangerous buildings made, secure, is 5,819. In regard to steam boilers the Sergeant was unable to make a correct return.

The Republicans of the Nineteenth Ward have recently completed a wigwam on the corner of Thirdavenue and Sixtieth-street, capable of holding twentyfive hundred persons. Last evening a grand mass meeting of the voters of the Ward was held in it, for the purpose of dedicating it to the interests of LINCOLN and HAMLIN.

The Texas papers come to us with extended details of the recent conflagrations in that State. On the 24th ult., the steam mill of GEORGE GLANCOCK, Esq., at Austin, was set on fire, and totally destroyed. It contained machinery valued at $30,000, and 450 bushels of wheat. The house of Dr. W.W. STELL, of Lamar County, was fired by a negro on the 16th, and completely burned.
The sales of COTTON, to-day, were 8,000 bales, of which 3,000 were to speculators and exporters. The market closed dull.
Matter of Ellen McManus. This was the return to a writ of habeas corpus previously obtained by Betsey McManus for the recovery of her child Ellen.

The Soutern Guardian, of Columbus, S.C., says about 7 o'clock, on the evening of the 2d, a meteor was seen in the northern part of the heavens, and at 10 o'clock a very large meteor made its appearance, which, according to the accounts we have received from those who noticed it, was quite a brilliant affair.

The news from Kentucky has paralyzed the operations of the Breckinridge National Committee here, and disbursements will be less liberal. The Administration is shocked at Mr. BRECKINRIDGE losing his own county. Bets are now freely offered that no three States can be named for BRECKINRIDGE.
A correspondent of the Philadelphia North American, writing from on board the brig Kilby, at Key West, on the 25th ult., says: ...
Long vs. Riplet Burr, Assignees, The defendants herein are assignees of Coyler Degord. Application was now made to remove them from such office, and to appint trustees in their places.
Greene County (official) gives Orr 1,337; C. T. Jackson, 502; and H. Jackson, 137. For Congress--Rains, 1,168; Phelps, 576; Price; 280.

Quite an excitement exists among the medical profession, relative to a quarrel between a well-known ex-professor of midwifery and a leading surgeon of this City. Unprofessional conduct is said to be the charge of the former against the latter, and it is suggested that the Ethical Committee of the Academy of Medicine will again have an opportunity for their grave sessions and non-committal reports.

The Prince and his suite crossed during the night from St. John, and landed at Hantsport at 6 o'clock in a shower of rain. He then drove here, and breakfasted at the Clifton Hotel with Lord MULGEAVU and some members of the Nova Scotia Legislature. The Band of the Sixty-third Regiment played during the meal. The Prince always likes music at his meals.
Cleared. Steamship R.R. Cuyler, Crocker, Savannah, H.B. Cromwell Co. Ships Rockingham, McJeber, St. John, N.B., Sinnes, Chase Co,; Cornelia, Woodside, Glassgow, Boyd Hincken.
Arrived at San Francisco, 26th, ship Comet, from New York; schooner Caroline E. Foote, from Amoor Rover via Hakodadi; schooner R.E. Raymond, from Guayaquil. Sailed, 28th, ship Enterprise for Callao.
The programme for to-day was as follows: SECTION A MATHEMATICS AND PHYSICS. 1. An attempt to estimate the Height, Velocity, , of the Meteors of the evening of July 20, 1860, By H.M. HARMAN.
The Prince of WALES and suite drove post-haste from Truro to this place. Arches were erected along the road in several places, and the bridges, too, were covered with evergreens.
NEW-JERSEY. The returns as far as received indicate that the present population of Newark is 75,000. In 1850 it was but 38,894.

The Courier takes to task the regular Democratic and Union Press for publishing the address of GEORGE N. SANDERS to the Kentucky Democracy; as if he had not as good a right to be heard by Kentuckians as the Slidells, Brights and Yanceys, or even JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE himself. We tell the Courier that GEORGE N. SANDERS is the peer of Major BRACKINRIDGE by intellect and by antecedent.
THE APACHES AFFAIES IN SONOEA. "Hesperian," writing from Tubac on the 18th ult. to St. Louis Republican, says:
The Pony Express, with California news to July 28th, reached here at 2 o'clock A.M.
The Schooner Caroline had arrived on the 24th from Nicolaifsky , on the Amoor River, via Hakodadi June 22.
SUTHERLAND, J. Miller vs. Bennett. Motion denied with $7 costs.

It is rumored that Secretary CASS contemplates a resignation. This rumor seems to be without foundation, however, as a letter received at the Department to-day announces his good health, and his intention to return about the 1st of September.
Steamship Europa, from Liverpool via Halifax, arrived at this port about 6 o'clock this evening. Her mail will be due in New-York to-morrow.

The Annual meeting of the American Normal School Association and of the National Teachers' Association are now being held in this City, and the occasion has drawn together a large collection of the active educational talent of the country. To-day there are some three or four hundred present, and to-morrow will bring many more.

The town is overflowing. At least 500 guests are at the Mountain House from all parts of the State. Over fifty registered their names this morning. Among those present are Gen. FOSTER, H.M. WEIGHT, JOHN CESSNA, and a large Philadelphia delegation. Tne Douglasites are in strong force, and will probably present, as an ultimatum, the calling of a new Convention, on which there will doubtless be an exciting debate.

Coroner GAMBLE yesterday concluded an investigation of the circumstances connected with the death of ROBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, who area alleged to have been the victim of malpractice on the part of Dr. MACDONALD ALLEN, of No. 447 Grand-street, the attending physician.

QUARANTINE AND THE PUBLIC HEALTH. Mr. CYRUS CURTISS has addressed several interrogatories to Dr. A.H. GUNN, the Health Officer of the Port, touching the enforcement of Quarantine regulations upon emigrant and other vessels arriving with passengers after long voyages, and also relative to the facilities which he has, under the present Quarantine regime ...

The Mouette, French war steamer, arrived yesterday morning, from Palermo, as also the Froquois, United States steamer, and we have an influx of Sicilian intelligence. Rumor has it that the British Consul, whose family is at present in Saratoga, has secured the whole of the Clarendon Hotel at that place for the accommodation of Lord Renfrew, who will make a brief stay there on his way to Washington.

The extraordinary excitement which has been raging for the last few weeks at the Stock Exchange of New-York, has now so nearly reached its acme of possible exaltation, that sagacious observers are visibly preparing to profit by the inevitable revulsion which must now be near at hand.

George Barnes et al. vs. James C. Willett. This was an action brought against the defendant, as Sheriff of the City and County of New-York, to recover the amount of a debt owed the plaintiff by one Jacob Cohen, who escaped from the custody of the Sheriff.

The ghost of the Kamdactylus sub-humanus haunts the last hours of the Scientific Congress. No exorcism of parliamentary tactics no amount of public and scientific cacchination at the odd pictures are of any avail; the spectre will not down.
GENTLEMEN: My high respect for you induces me to hasten to reply to your note.

FLOUR steady and in moderate demand. WHEAT dull and 1c. lower; sales, yesterday afternoon, 25,000 bushels Red Winter Ohio and Indiana at $1 10; this morning, 2,000 bushels Red Ohio at $1 09, and 10,000 bushels Red Winter Illinois at $1 09 .
The new "Wigwam" recently erected by the Republicans of South Brooklyn, in Court-street, opposite Douglass, was dedicated last evening with great eclat.

SUNDAY SCHOOLS IN MONROE COUNTY. The Sabbath School teachers of Menroe County held a Convention in Rochester a few days ago. The number of Protestant schools in the County is 187, an increase of 11 over last year.

It appears that the massacre at Damascus commenced in the afternoon of the 9th, and that before night 500 Christians had been killed. The first consulate attacked was that of Russia. The Russian and Greek consuls took refuge with ABD-EL KADER. All the Catholic and Greek churches and convents, as well as the consulates, are burnt. The American vice consul was wounded, and the Dutch vice-consul said to be killed.

The critics of the Drama may expect a splendid Fall campaign. Mr. NIXON has engaged the services of Mr. FORREST for a season of two hundred nights, and will commence operations at Niblo's Garden on the 17th inst.

At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, a resolution was adopted directing the paving of Chambers-street, from Chatham-street to North River, with Belgian pavement, from curb to curb. The President stated that the contract was already awarded for same paving from gutter to gutter. The contract, as amended, was subsequently confirmed.
The United States corvette Jamestown is to be taken in hands at once and prepared for active squadron duty. She is at Philadelphia, where operations will be immediately commenced on her.
It is understood here that Capt. SAMUEL JONES, of the First Artillery, will be appointed Commandant at West Point.

Benjamin Sherwood, Trustee, , vs. Henry L. Parsons et al The plaintiff herein is Trustee under the will of Francis Child, deceased, and brings this action and twelve others in ejectment, to obtain possession of 13 lots in Forty-seventh-street, between Broadway and Eighth-avenue.
The following is the speech made by Mr. LINCOLN at the great Republican demonstration at Springfield on the 8th inst.:

The ball at Frederickton last night was the one redeeming feature of an otherwise miserable day. Dancing did not commence until 10 o'clock, by which time the heat had moderated, and a refreshing breeze springing up made the temperature quite pleasant.

Yesterday's exercises opened with the meeting of the Alumni. In the absence of the President and all the Vice Presidents, Prof. SEELYE called the meeting to order. Hon. HORACE MAYNARD was chosen President for the coming year, and the same Vice Presidents hold over.

The interest attaching to the Prince of Wales' visit continues to increase, each day presenting novel and more striking incidents, the most impressive of which, at least to me, has been his attending divine service in the Cathedral here this morning.

The Prince of Wales landed at two o'clock on Thursday from the Hero. The Admiral's ship Nile, and the Ariodne, Cossack, Valorous and Flying Fish accompanied him, as also the French Commodore's ship Pomene. The day was stormy and wet.

The regular semi-monthly meeting of the Board of Police Justices was held last evening, in the room of the Clerk of the Court of Special Sessions, at the Tombs, but, in the absence of a quorum of the members, no other business was transacted than the reception, and tabling for future action, of the following report, presented by Justice WELSH, Chairman of the Committee on Laws and Ordinances:

A letter from the Monumental City, to be in keeping with its funereal name, should be of rather a grave character. But to maintain demureness of thought and of action in Baltimore is simply an impossibility, Jollity is the pervading feature of this city.
The Charleston Mercury the other day said that LINCOLN would certainly be elected, unless the North could be made to believe that in such an event the South would dissolve the Union.
