This has been the first really warm time we have had since the Prince of WALES landed in America. With one remarkable exception, there has not been a cloud in the sky to-day, from dusty morn to sultry eve, and the thermometer has run up into the nineties.
The Europa's mails reached this City last evening from Boston. We derive from our correspondence and foreign files, which extend to the 28th ult., some additional details of interest.

Yesterday was the last day of the August Term of this Court. The business was brisk. Constable Hurley, whose duty it was to keep the peace, but who, on the contrary, broke it, was sent on the charge to which he pleaded guilty, to the Penitentiary for five months and fined $50. He is liable to be tried on other charges when he is released, but, of course, being a politician, he will not.

The Hero and the Ariadne arrived off this port on Thursday morning early, and entered the harbor at 10 o'clock. The Nile grounded twice in trying to come in, and then started round to Quebec. The Valorous accompanied her.
The Cunard steamship Europa arrived at Boston on Thursday night, and her mails, dispatched south by yesterday morning's train, reached this City in the evening.
The North Presbyterian Church, Rev. Dr. HATFIELD, which has been temporarily closed for repairs, will be reopened at 10 A.M. Services in the evening at 7 P.M. The pastor will officiate.

The sympathy for GARIBALDI expressed at the late Newport meeting will, we hope, be reechoed throughout the whole country to some practical purpose. The State Convention of the friends of Messrs. BRECKINRIDGE and LANE in Ohio was held in Columbus on the 7th. Hon. REUBEN WOOD of Cuyahoga County, was elected permanent President. After the appointment of a State Central Committee District Electors were chosen.

The President and Miss LANE, accompanied by Mrs. COBB, Secretary TOUCEY, and a distinguished party, left the city yesterday morning at about 7 o'clock, by special train for Annapolis, to visit the monster steamship Great Eastern, now on exhibition there.

Rev. W.A. Bartlett, of Brooklyn, is improving his Summer vacation by lecturing and preaching in the West. His efforts do not meet universal approbation. One of the Milwaukee papers moderates its praise with the following criticism: "The gentleman has talents of no mean order, and what is very much to be regretted, knows it as well as anybody. ...

Josiah H. Cain et. al. vs. Michael Miller. This was an application for an order of arrest against the defendant upon an allegation of false pretenses.

The visitors at Long Branch were shocked on Saturday by the occurrence of a disaster, which threw a gloom over the place and for a time put an end to festivities among the people temporarily sojourning there. ...

The Camden and Amboy Railroad is generally conceded to be a credit to New-Jersey. The cars are new and comfortable, the engines whirl their attendant trains along at quite a respectable rate of speed, the sleepers lie quietly in their beds, and the conductors generally conduct themselves in a proper manner. ...

Miriam Sherwood vs. The Mayor, This was an action to recover the amount of a certain mortgage on two lots now appropriated as a portion of the site for the new reservoir. The plaintiff, who was mortgagee, had no notice of the proceedings, except by publication, by which the lots were taken into possession by the City. ...
The Tammany Hall Delegation to the Democratic State Convention to be held at Syracuse, held a meeting at Tammany Hotel Saturday evening, in order to organize previous to leaving for that city.
The annexed letter was addressed by Hon. JOHN A. DIX to a Committee for a meeting of the National Democracy of Kings, Queens, and Suffolk Counties:

Capt. WALLING recently received information from the authorities of New-Brunswick, N.J., that a series of robberies had been committed at that place, chiefly of harness, sleigh robes and stable equipments, the wealthy residents of the village being the sufferers, but no clue to the thief had been obtained.

The Democracy held a county meeting last night, at which there was regular skirmish between the Douglas and Breckinridge parties, and much bitter feeling was evinced. The meeting broke up in a row.

FLATBUSH-AVENUE RAILROAD. The cars on the Flatbush-avenue Railroad began their through trips on Saturday morning. The fare has been fixed at 10 cents, or 8 cents if tickets are purchased. To any point within the city limits five cents will be charged, or four cents by ticket.

Two men, named JOSIAH H. BISSELL and WALTER F. CHADWICK, are now in jail here on a charge of conspiring to burn the bridge across the Mississippi at Rock Island. Mr. BISSELL is from St. Louis, but has a family residing in Rochester, New York. Mr. CHADWICK is an attorney of Rock Island.

A full share of vicissitudes...

Stevens sailed this morning for Panama, with 202 passengers and $876,000 in treasure, of which $786,000 is for New-York. Among her passengers are Lieut. --A remarkable case of very "early piety" has just been found in Brussels. The Police, making their rounds at midnight, found an ordinary clothes-line hanging near a door, several feet above the ground, and tracing its history discovered that it came out of a garret-window above.

You have now another chapter in Western politics--in the Kentucky election, where BRECKINRIDGE is thoroughly defeated by a large majority. It will be said that Douglas men and Republicans helped to produce this result.

THE GREAT EASTERN.--According to previous announcement, the Great Eastern was yesterday reopened to exhibition, at the usual rate of fifty cents, and during the day about one thousand persons went on board.

Lewis D. Stelle vs. Charles S. Palmer.--The defendant in this action was charged with defrauding the plaintiff, by means of false pretences, of a large sum of money. Upon that charge he was arrested in August, 1858, but was subsequently discharged.

The third annual meeting of this Association was formally opened this afternoon at 3 o'clock, in American Hall. A dispatch by telegraph was received by the President from the New-York State Sabbath-school Association, sending friendly greeting, to which the President and Secretary were authorized to respond is fit terms.

In response to a public call, signed by a number of influential citizens, a meeting was held at the Tract-Society House yesterday afternoon, to consider the subject of the Christian massacre in Syria, and to adopt measures for rendering assistance to the sufferers. About twenty persons were present, among them some of our most prominent clergymen.

Some details of a personal nature, obtained from the census returns, having found their way into the papers of a Western city, the Superintendent of the census has requested the United States Marshal of the District to make explanation of the manner whereby this information was obtained for publication.

In consequence of and order prohibiting a torchlight procession in honor of Superintendent SZEKASS, large crowds of excited people have assembled every evening on the streets between the Protestant churches of Lutheran and Helvaetian persuasion, and every time had to be fossibly dispersed; numerous arrests also taking place each evening.

The meteoric Benicis Boy, whose corruscations have been temporarily eclipsed by the Japanese, the Great Eastern, and the Zouaves, reappeared in a blaze of glory yeaterday afternoon at Jones' Wood-- not for the purpose of engaging in a sanguinary "mill," but, to preserve the astronomical simile--as Messrs. WOOD and NIXION'S bright particular star.

It has often been remarked that, under all the superficial crust of civilization, the primitive barbarity of man remains. The cruelty that prompts the Indian to torture his captives and the cannibal to eat his enemy, is smothered, not extinguished, by the refinements of life. Man cannot rid himself of the disposition to put his fellows to pain, and to shield himself under the plea of necessity.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was passed, formally declaring Sixth-avenue open from One Hundred and Twentyninth street to Harlem River, and directing the collection of the assessment for the carrying out of the improvement. The Supreme Court has already approved of the assessment.

The sixtieth anniversary exercises of "Old Middlebury" have just concluded; and, in spite of the intense heat, the attendance has been large.
This standard and comprehensive sheet, containing ample details of news to the latest moment from all parts of the world, is issued THIS MORNING from the office of this paper.

France and Russia have entitled themselves to the gratitude and esteem of the civilized world, by the energy and promptitude which they have shown in dealing with the intolerable demoralization of the Turkish power in the East.

Our old mercantile friend of the Southern Confederacy has taken to politics. The editor gets his old trade and his new one somewhat "jumbled up" in his swiftly-revolving mind, and makes a rather agreeable journal in consequence. His views of Hon. HOWELL COBB are particularly striking. Of this illustrious Georgian he observes:

This is the last week of the immortal RAVELS at the Winter Garden. On Thursday FRANOOIS takes his benefit, when the charming YRCA MATHIAS will dance for him and us; on Saturday GABRIEL, the delight off two generations of children, makes his five or six hundredth bow; and then the RAVELS disappear with the roses, with the roses, of course, to come back. This is the theatrical event of the current week.

For many a long year we have enjoyed the enthusiasm of affection and the intensity of admiration manifested by our solid brethren of Boston town toward their Common. No malls can compare, say they, with our Common's malls, no grass is so green ...

The R.M. steamship Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 1st inst. and Queenstown on the 2d, arrived at this port last night. Her news is mostly anticipated by the arrival of the Adriatic, which left Southampton on the 1st; but we have one day later advices telegraphed vid Queenstown.

Senator SEWARD arrived at Bangor, Me., on Saturday, in the midst of a heavy shower. His arrival was quite unexpected. The Republicans, however, mustered pretty strongly. The English funds were firm to-day. In the discount market there was an increased demand owing to the preparations for the fourth of the month. About 4,000 in gold was taken from the Bank to-day for exportation. On the Paris Bourse to-day there was a decline of more than per cent.
The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 2d, vid Londonderry on the 3d inst., passed this point this forenoon. Her dates are two days later than those already received.
The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., vid Londonderry on the 3d, passed Father Point yesterday, from which place her advices, which are two days later, are telegraphed.

The fate of that eccentric but determined man, Dr. VOGEL, whose reputation as a learned traveler is world-wide, is as yet uncertain. The Duke of SAKE-COBURG has decided to send an expedition to Africa in search of him, or of information concerning his disappearance.
The fine bark Eliza Barss starts to-day for New-York, and I hasten to send you all the news that I have collected.

A meeting of the prominent merchants, bankers, and other well-known citizens of the City was held yesterday, at the Merchants' Bank, in Wall-Street, to adopt measures for extending and appropriate reception and welcome on behalf of the poeple of NewYork to the Prince of WALES on the occasion of his visit to this City. Among the distinguished citizens present was Lieutenant General WINFIELD Score.

The Annual Exhibition of the Grammar School of Madison University, under the charge of Prof. BROWN, occurred on Friday evening, the 10th instant, in the chapel of the University. The audience was large, and the young men acquitted themselves well. The school has been steadily improving since it has been under the direction of Prof. BROWN.

There is great excitement in the city to-night but there is every prospect of harmony in the Convention to-morrow. There are but few muscular political Christians on hand the results last year not justifying the repetition of the physical-force experiment.
The correspondent of the Boston Traveller, writing from Beirut, under date of July 6, furnishes some interesting items regarding the state of affairs in Syria. He says:

In an editorial article contained in your issue of the 10th instant, under the caption of "The SlaveTrade," you refer to Mr. BUXTON, M.P., being about to move that the British Government immediately demand of Spain the prompt execution of the treaty stipulation with that Government for the extinction of the Slave-trade; also the suppression of diplomatic relations with Spain until she shuts her colonial ports to this traffic.
Levi S. Chatfield vs. The Mayor, This case now came up for argument before Justice SUTHERLAND, at Special Term of the Supreme Court, pursuant to notice.
The Bell and Everett State Convention assembled here yesterday. It was large and harmonious. BENJAMIN HILL and Judge LAW were appointed electors for the State at large.
By the arrival of the bark Eliza Barss, we have received Hamilton (Bermuda) papers of Aug. 7, and our correspondence to Aug. 9.

The attendance at the Douglas Democratic State Convention promises, from present appearances, to be unusually large. The hotels are rapidly filling up, and some are already crowded. Probably a greater number of outsiders are here already than at any Convention some for years past. The character of the delegations appear much better than the average many prominent Democratic names from different parts of the State being on the list.

The man who was found by Officer Petty, of the Fourth Precinct, early on Sunday morning last, in an insensible condition in the halfway of the premises No. 38 Madison-street, has been recognized as James Cusick, a laborer, living at No. 73 Cherry-street. He still remains at the New-York Hospital in a very precarious condition, his skull being fractured, and the bone of his lower jaw shattered.
On Friday afternoon last, ALEXANDER WILSON murdered SAMUEL PIERSON at or near the residence of Mr. LAMADEE, in Green township, in this county. They were both residents of that township.

MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DELEGATES OF AMERICAN ISRAELITES. The Board of Delegates of American Israelites has been in session two evenings at the Cooper Institute, comprising representatives of thirty congregations in various parts of the country nine out of eighteen New-York City congregations were represented.

THE CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION THE GYMNASIUM. The monthly meeting of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was held last evening at their rooms, in the Washington-street Institute. The attendance was comparatively small, on account of the inclement weather and the absence of many members from the City.

Philadelphia was visited, on Monday, by a thunder-storm of remarkable severity. At noon the rain, which had commenced about 11 o'clock, seemed to be falling as rapidly as it was possible for it to do, ...
The telegraph yesterday informed us of the discovery of the remains of British and American soldiers, near the Old Fort, at Toronto. The Daily Globe, of that city, of the 13th, has the following:

If any care of earthly things possess the spirits of the dead, two royal ghosts, at least, must be strangely perturbed in looking down upon our planet at the present hour. To CHARLES V. and PHILIP II., once arbiters of Europe, and masters of the commerce of the world, the spectacle of Castile and Leon knocking for readmission to the great Council of the European States, must be a marvel without a name.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which sailed from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 4th, and From Queenstown on the evening of the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning.

Again the military spirit is aroused in France by the departure of soldiers for another war. A year ago it was to Lombardy; six months later to China, and to-day it is to the Holy Land. The cry' "Partant pour la Syrie!" has been sounded by every trooper's horn throughout the Empire, and is to-day the war-cry of the French army. What was to the Queen HORTENSE a romance is to her son a reality.

The Times City Article, of Monday evening, the 6th, says: "The English Funds continue to show depression. On the state of the weather, and the business on the Paris Bourse, the Corn market was heavy, at an occasional reduction of 1s @2s. quarter for wheat. About 4,000 in bar Gold was taken from the Bank to-day, for export. These small withdrawals are chiefly for transmission to Spain.

Gen. WEBB is having quite an animated controversy with the Tribune concerning the Republican nomination for Governor. The following paragraph from yesterday's Courier and Enquirer contains some revelations that may be of general interest:

The Patric of this evening says the regiments in tended for Syria left Chaloos this morning. Four steamers left Toulon yesterday to embark troops. News received here states that great agitation prevails in Candia, Jeddah and Arabia.

Nothing certain was known as to the state of the negotiations at Paris for intervention in Syria. It is asserted by various authorities that the points of dissension were so marked and important that the Conference could not grapple with them, and the Ambassadors were compelled to adjourn and refer matters to their respective Governments.

The chief topic here is the singular letter which the Emperor has written to his Ambassador at London. The extreme peace party, of course, receive it with acclamation. By Englishmen generally it is thought to be too civil by half, undignified, somewhat false, and very suspicious. On the principle of qui s'excuse s'exeuse, the letter is open to criticism, and the motives of the writer to doubt.

Judge DOUGLAS has been rusticating at Newport. He attends balls, goes to dinners, bathes in the surf, and talks politics. According to one of our Newport correspondents he expresses his sentiments with the utmost freedom, and does not hesitate to state precisely what he expects to accomplish in the pending Presidential canvass.

By the arrival of the steamer Pocahontas at Vera Cruz, we received early this month the news of the final rejection of the Treaty?or at least that it was laid over until the next session, which I consider about the same thing.

We learn, by the Persia, that the representatives of the European Powers, lately assembled in Paris, have agreed upon the conditions of intervention in Syria. This intervention will doubtless be complete, and will fully attain the end in view. It is understood that, as soon as the Porte's assent is obtained, 20,000 troops will be dispatched to the Levant. One half of this force will be French, and the other half Russian and English.

A public meeting to celebrate the abolition of British Colonial Slavery was held last night in Spafields Chapel, Exmouth-street, Clerkenwell. The large chapel was well filled by a most respectable audience.

The changed aspect of this gay and brilliant watering-place on Sunday arrests the attention of every visitor. No railway trains arrive or depart. The business of the place is entirely suspended. The churches are thronged. The splendid equipages which crowd Broadway, near the large Hotels, on other days, are mostly unseen and unused on the Sabbath. A subdued air steals over the groups that gather in the long verandahs.

The People ex rel. James H. Jerome vs. The Commissioners of Emigration.?The case of Dr. Jerome, which was recently before Justice LEONARD at Chambers of the Supreme Court, was now decided in a lengthy opinion.

After one of the most turbulent and bitterly contested elections which it has ever been my fortune, good or bad, in an experience of thirty years, to participate, the community has relapsed into a quletude, from its contrast almost startling in its intensity. In communicating its coincident results, the telegraph will, of course, have long anticipated me; but upon its inside history I may perhaps let in a ray or two of particular sunshine.
The steamship Star of the West has arrived from Havana, 13th inst.
The United States steamer Pocahontas has arrived from Vera Cruz 9th.

Several of the staple amusements of Newport have lost their attraction, in no small degree, this season. Fishing expeditions, for example, are much less in vogue partly because "luck" is more uncertain than formerly, and partly on account of the lack of Southern sportsmen, who once frequented this "Isle of Peace." The former fact is attributed to the great use of seines by the professional fishermen, whereby the stock is materially lessened.

The Douglas Democratic State Convention closed its labors yesterday, with the selection of an electoral ticket in fusion with the Bell and Everett men, and the adoption of a series Of resolutions expressive of the sense of the Convention relative to the questions at issue in the campaign, and the duty of the Democracy in the premises.

The Commissioners of Record vs. the Board of Supervisors. This matter is familiar to the public. The return to the mandamus directed to the Board of Supervisors, commanding them to provide for the payment to the plaintiffs of $80,000, as provided by act of the last Legislature, or show cause why they did not do so, was now made.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 17 bbls, Ashes; 5,777 bbls, Flour; 937 bbls, Corn Meal; 33,141 bushels Wheat; 117,914 bushels Corn, 3,000 bushels Oats; 41 pkgs. Provisions, and 420 bbls. Whisky.

R. J. Williams vs. The Steamship Great Eastern. This was an application made before Justice SUTHERLAND, at Chambers of the Supreme Court, for an attachment against the Great Eastern, on a claim for supplies, for $270. The claim was considered a lien, and the attachment was allowed.

Newport is at present in the height of its glory. The "season" will reach its culminating point about the 15th, but for at least a month after that time, beauty, wealth and fashion will link the days into rosy series of gaiety and enjoyment.

The presence in our waters of two captured slavers is ample evidence of the existence and flourishing condition of the African slave traffic. We say flourishig, because both of the vessels brought into this port had safely landed their human freights on the Island of Cuba. The adventurers who bought, equipped and dispatched these ships have reaped the handsome profits of their daring enterprise.

A strange and almost romantic interest surrounds the history of the three little African boys who have just been cast upon our shores from on board the slave brig William R. Kibby. Out of a cargo of over 400 of their countrymen, stolen from their African homes, they alone remain not indeed to tell ...
The city is full of strangers; the hotels are sending their guests to private houses for rooms, and hundreds cannot be accommodated. Board is advanced to $4 per diem.

The Douglas Convention to-day is largely attended. A Committee on Organization was appointed, when the Convention adjourned till 4 o'clock. Nothing indicating a fusion movement has transpired.

Application of Abraham Voorhis. The applicant is a judgment creditor of the lucky man who had a part of the job of fitting the rooms for the Japanese Ball. He now made application before Judge BRADY at Special Term of the Common Pleas Court for an attachment for contempt against Warren Leland and others for not appearing as witnesses upon an order supplementary to execution against the property of the judgment debtor.

The Committee appointed at the meeting held on Monday last, to adopt measures for extending relief to the sufferers from the late massacres in Syria, held a meeting at the Tract House yesterday afternoon. Although the Committee consists of twentyfive members, only seven were present.
The Pony Express arrived here last night with California dates to the 4th inst., Honolulu to July 19, and Hong Kong to June 15.

I desire to draw the attention of those who love beautiful, scenery to the neighborhood of the "Laurel House." The hotel is situated immediately above the Katterskill Falls, which for picturesque beauty and even grandeur, not surpassed by any other in the United States, has been immortalized by the pen of BRYANT and the pencil of COLE.
Archbishop Hughes is rusticating in Canada. On Sunday last he preached in St. Michael's Cathedral, Toronto.

The Democratic Convention at Syracuse yesterday completed its labors. Having thrown Tammany Hall overboard the day before, and rushed into the arms of Mayor WOOD, it consummated its work of self-immolation by burying itself in the embraces of Messrs. HUNT and BROOKS. And yet its sacrifice is not complete enough to be magnanimous, nor bold enough to be effective.
The Democratic State Convention met at 9 o'clock, but the committees not being prepared to report, took a recess till 11.

The great ship left us yesterday. Her arrival at this port on the 28th of June will long dwell in the memories of the multitude who assembled, at every convenient and inconvenient spot, on both sides of the bay, from New-York and Jersey cities to the Narrows, to see her steam up the harbor and reach her dock.

POLICE. Sergeant BOYCE, in command of the Sanitary Police, yesterday, laid before the Commissioners his first report, for the quarter ending 1st instant, from which it appears that 3,970 complaints were made, against persons for maintaining nuisances, of which number 2,998 were promptly abated. In all the cases legal proceedings have been commenced. The complaints are classified as follows: Cow-stables and yards, 131; hog-pens and goats, 112; slaughter-houses, ...

If there be any of your readers unfortunate enough to see our Saturday Review, they may be surprised to find that I am still in existence, after the terrific mauling which I received in that eminent periodical. Yes, Sir! thanks to the cautious care of kind friends, who locked all my razors out ...

In addition to the matter previously sent, I would mention that a second grand dinner is being given at the Government. House by the Government officials, to Lord LYONS, Admiral MILNE and Gen. WILLIAMS, with their suites.

This morning two French line-of-battle ships arrived, one bearing the flag of a Rear-Admiral. More French, English and Russian war ships are expected soon. This gives assurance that something will be done to redress the wrongs of the Christians. Seven French monks were killed at Damascus.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce since our last, have been; 14 bbls. Ashes, 24,690 bbls. Flour, 1,200 bbls. Corn Meal, 74,778 bushels Wheat, 92,898 bushels Corn, 324 bushels Rye, 870 pkgs. Provisions, and 424 bbls. Whisky.

COTTON firm; sales to-day, 600 bales, at 10 c.@ 10 c. for middling; sales of the week, 2,950 bales; receipts do., 4,500 bales, against 2,350 bales the corresponding week last year. Exports 90,000 bales. Total receipts to date, 2,205,250 bales.

Gov. HUNT ought to be more careful of what he says. In his recent speech at Buffalo, he is reported to have made some remarks as to the relation of his Constitutional Union party to the interests of freedom.

On the morning of the 22d of April last a fire occurred in the building No. 869 Broadway, occupied as a liquor and cigar store by a man named Wm. H. Purley, and the building, with most of the stock, was destroyed.

There have been plenty of incidents on the voyage of the Royal party so far. The scenery is magnificent at Bonaventure, where the Prince first sighted Canada. Lofty precipices and rocky islands are the principal features of the landscape. From both banks of the river the progress of the Prince was heralded with salute after salute; and the reverberation of one cannonade only died away to give place to another.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the columns of the TIMES of this day there appears an account of an occurrence which happened to me the previous evening.

INTERESTING TO BIOGRAPHERS. In the Sixth District Court, before Justice FONDA, the case of WHITLEY against CRAIG, was to have been heard yesterday, but after some conversation, it was postponed to Monday.

At a public meeting held in this City on the 18th instant,the undersigned were appointed a Committee to devise measures whereby the sympathy of our American people in behalf of the sufferers in Syria may find practicable and effective expression.

The Prince of Wales will arrive at Quebec today. On Wednesday and Thursday he went up the Saguenay River the latter day on a fishing excursion. The voyage up the St. Lawrence was marked by the usual enthusiastic demonstrations of welcome on the part of the people on both banks of the river.

The number of candidates for the United States Senate is increasing with great rapidity. Our neighbor GREELEY is openly in the field.

The Austin, Texas, correspondent of the Galveston News, writing on the 3d, says:
If Dr. CHEEVER has failed to excite the sympathy of his own countrymen by his ferocious onslaughts upon America and her institutions, he does not seem destined to much better fortune in England.

The last of the yacht squadron has just sailed. The schooner Restless, MOSES H. GRINNELL, Commander, has just fired her parting salute to the hospitable town of New-Bedford, and steered her course for Edgartown, to which point the rest of the yacht squadron have sailed.

Judge BUEL died at his residence in Troy, on Thursday night, aged 76 years. For more than a generation, says the Troy Daily Whig, Judge BUEL has been one of the best known and highly esteemed citizens of Troy.

The Boston Post gives a detailed report of the movements of Mr. DOUGLAS in Maine. He went from Boston to Bangor by boat, touching at Rockland, Camden, Belfast, Searsport, Bucksport and Hampden, on the route, at each of which places he was met by numbers of his admirers. The principal demonstration, however, was at Bangor, where he made the following speech:

I had hardly sent that last Roundabout Paper to the Printer (which, I submit, was written in a pacable and not unchristian frame of mind,) when Saturday came, and with it, of course, my Saturday Review.

The instructions issued by the Lieut. Col. Commanding the 2nd general column of troops, en route to New-Mexico, relative to the exploration to be made to Santa Fe by the Spanish trail, vid the Dolars River, have been received by the War Department.
The Douglas Convention has organized. HENRY L. HOPKINS was chosen President. The indications are that a straight Douglas ticket will be selected.

The Adriatic is soon to lose a commander and ocean travelers a firm friend. Capt. COMSTOCK has been elected President of the NewYork and Fall River line of steamers, and the large salary which is attached to the position has induced him to resign his present post. He will make his last voyage in the Adriatic on her next trip.

We have advices from China to the 15th inst. One thing only is clear in the chaos of uncertain intelligence which reaches us by this arrival, and that is the more than moral certainty that the Chinese authorities have prepared ...

My last letter was written you from Old Point Comfort. I am again at home, and would have renewed my correspondence ere this, but for the excellent racy Baltimore letter emanations, as I presume, from your "Special," who accompanied the Great ...

The Scandinavians who lately seceded from the Northern Synod of Northern Illinois have organized a distinct association under the name of the Augustana Synod. Twenty-seven clerical members enrolled themselves as members of the body, and adopted the annexed confessional basis and doctrinal platform:
Rev. HEMAN BANGS, D.D., will preach in the North-street M.E. Church at 10 A.M., and Rev. J. S. INSKIP at 7 P.M.

Simon Musina and Jacob Musina vs. Charles Stillman et al, This is the case in which the plaintiffs sue to recover $500,000 damages, alleged to have been suffered by them in consequence of certain frauds charged upon the defendants.

-One of our religious exchanges dwells upon the evil consequences of the regattas, which are becoming so fashionable among the students of several of our leading colleges. It remarks that they lead to betting upon the speed of boats, sometimes to drinking beer and other stimulants for recovery from fatigue and exhausted strength, and to heavy expenses from the paternal pocket.

A GREAT (EASTERN) DIFFERENCE. It is well known the folks on the other side of the water could not launch the "big ship" without making a mess of it. It is equally certain they they could not launch the passengers here without the same result.

SIR: I have the honor to inform you that the dispatch from Lord JOHN RUSSELL, dated the 11th of July, 1860, which you read me, and a copy of which you left at this Department, has been submitted to the President, with its accompaniment of printed documents relative to the Coolie-trade.

"Twenty minutes allowed for dinner!" Who, that has traveled, and that means everybody, along any of our lines of railroad, has not waited for a long time in earnest and hungry expectation of that sound?

The Daily New's City Article says: The Funds opened with more firmness in consequence of the majority obtained by the Ministry last night. In the afternoon the tendency was rather favorable, and Consols closed at an advance of 1/8/ cent.

DEATH FROM INJURIES RECEIVED AT A ROPEWALK. Coroner MURPHY, on Saturday, held an inquest on 'the body of HENRY NOLAN, who died on Friday. Three years since, the deceased, then 18 years of age, worked in THURSBY'S rope-walk, in the Eastern District.
The following is a translation (from the Monitear) of the first Protocol of the Conference on the affairs of Syria, held at the French Foreign Office, Paris, on the 3d inst:

French political pamphlets fall thick as snow-flakes, and melt away quite as rapidly. The last absurdity of the kind is entitled La Syrie et L'Alliance Russe, from which it would appear that, according to the Emperor's present programme, Russia is to be bribed by the offer of Constantinople, to assist France in the revendication of the Rhine frontier.

William H. Richards in his own right, and as Trustee, , vs. The Northwest Protestant Dutch Church and others. This was an action to obtain a perpetual injunction against the defendants to restrain them from removing the remains of the plaintiff's relations from a certain vault owned by the plaintiff, and from destroying the vault.

If the disembodied spirit of JOHN BROWN be observant of earthly affairs, and ordinarily conversant with the primary rules of arithmetic, the aspect of affairs in Virginia at the present moment must greatly glorify his martyr's crown. For infinitely vaster evils than the largest preconceived results of the Harper's Fery enterprise at any time involved, seem about to flow from that tragedy.
The greatest excitement prevailed here this morning, in anticipation of the Prince of Wales' arrival, and much disappointment was felt at the unpropitious state of the weather.

We have advices from Buenos Ayres, via England, to the 27th of June. The compact of Union between the Argentine Confederation and province of Buenos Ayres, was celebrated at Parana on the 6th of June, and ratified by both Governments on the 19th. This second compact settles at once the grand question of the day.

We learn from Havana, by the Quaker City, whose arrival is elsewhere reported, that a new decree has been issued by the Spanish Government upon the subject of Chinese immigration. There are eighty-four articles in the decree, and a plan for regulating the introduction of Chinese laborers is elaborately drawn out.

Henceforth let it be remembered that there are two Blondins, not in the field, but on the ropes. The long-heralded Faring made his d but at Niagara Falls on Wednesday last. The cable on which he performed was stretched across the river a third of a mile below the Clifton House, and was in length nearly double that on which Blondin has been exhibiting.

The Cincinnati Gazette is sanguine regarding the result in Indiana. It says that the result is now as certain as any political calculation can be. One of the "Pocket" counties in particular could be named where the vote will be as one-sided for LINCOLN as it was BUCHANAN at the last election. A careful canvas of eight counties gives a total majority for LINCOLN of 8,500.

We have news of our old friends, the Japanese Ambassadors. On the 16th of July they had got as far as the Cape de Verde Islands, on their way home. The skies had been propitious. They had had but little wind, and consequently but little sea-sickness.

A letter from Marseilles of the 3d inst. announces the arrival there, by the mail steamboat Mersey, of the P re Est ve, superior of the missionaries in Syria. He has come to France to give an account to the French Government of the massacres and plunder which have taken place in the Lebanon.
Mr. JORDAN CLARK: I have your letter of the 30th ult., and hasten to let you know the precise time when I expect to come out and formally announce that I have joined the Democratic Party.

The first thing the Japanese did, after getting fairly established on board, was to have all those costly and beautiful arm-chairs sent out of their cabin. Then came the grand extension table,--these being articles of furniture the luxury of which they could not appreciate, preferring rather their own custom of sitting cross-legged upon the carpet.

Lord Palmerston announced to the House that we really must Fortify. He meant no disrespect to Anybody anywhere, and Nobody had any "call" to be offended; but it would not do for England to owe her safety to Anybody's forbearance, and she must be as strong as Anybody else.

The Breckinridge party begin to be alarmed at the prospect of affairs in the Southern States. They counted upon an easy and a rapid victory. They supposed all they had to do was to raise the standard of Southern Rights, to sound the alarm that Slavery was in danger, and that every Southern State would instantly rush to the rescue and sweep their enemies like chaff before the whirlwind.

The steamship Glasgow, from Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th, passed Cape Race on Friday night. A brief summary of her news, which is two days later, has been telegraphed. We have also London journals to the 7th inst., by the Cunard steamship Etna, which arrived at this port yesterday.

Messrs. J.C.W. BAILEY Co., of Chicago, have just issued the Illinois State Business Directory, for 1860; a handsome volume of over nine hundred pages, comprising ample details of the mercantile, manufacturing, mechanical and professional departments of the Industry of the State.

SUICIDE BY HANGING. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on Sunday upon the body of Mrs. ARABELLA TUKEY, who committed suicide on Saturday worning at the Water-Cure establishment, No.15 Laigh street, by hanging herself in the bed chamer.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last, have been 42 bbls. Ashes, 7,186 bbls. Flour, 200 bbls. Corn Meal, 35,597 bushels Wheat, 108,392 bushels Corn, 360 bushels Rye, 1,976 bushels Oats, 668 pkgs. Provisions, and 452 bbls. Whisky.

In compliance with a Ministerial circular addressed to the supporters of the Government in the House of Commons, upwards of 180 members of the Liberal Party motion the 5th inst., at the official residence of the Prime Minister, in Downing-street. All the Cabinet Ministers who have seats in the House of Commons were present. The meeting had been summoned in reference to the resolutions on the PaperCustoms Act.

This is rather an exceptional season with us. Usually by this time of year our fashionables are thinking of clearing off into the country, and the "dead season" has begun; but this year we have scarcely noticed anything like a cessation in the usual bustle of London. This may be accounted for in two ways. The upper classes stop because they can't help it.

Another and a new act in the great Drama of Politics has been enacted, the actors have returned behind the scenes, the curtain has fallen, and the audience has been dismissed to reflect on the moral of the play.

Before Justice Nelson. The following are decisions rendered on a final hearing on pleadings and proofs in five sewing-machine cases which were argued in June last, by Gen. Gifford and E.W. Stoughton for the complainants, and by George G. Sickles and C.A. Seward for the defendants, before Justice NELSON, Judge SMALLEY, sitting with him, at Cooperstown, New-York. The arguments occupied about two weeks, and the cases have since been held under advisement by the Court.

By the steamer Etna from Liverpool, we have received letters from our Correspondents on board the U.S. frigate Niagara on her way to Japan with the Ambassadors. She left this port on the 30th of June and the 17th of July had reached the Cape de Verde Islands, from which points our dispatches were forwarded to England and thence to this country.

Quebec? Yes, I came down here from Montreal in the good steamboat Columbia on Wednesday night in company with a host of travelers, all of whom were on their way rejoicing in the full hope of seeing His Royal Highness, the Duke of Rothsay and Lord of the Isles. I had the pleasure of seeing and conversing with Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS, the hero of Kars and Commander-in-Chief of Her Majesty's forces in the Canadas.

We copied some time since a paragraph from the Levant Herald warning the American public against two young men, natives of Syria, who were about to visit this country to collect money for the ostensible purpose of founding a hospital on Mount Lebanon. A few days since Rev. Dr. WOOD, of the American, Board of Missions, published a card, upon the arrival of two young Syrians.
The Cunard steamship Arabia, which left Liverpool Aug. 11, and Queenstown on the 12th, passed Cape Race at 4 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) afternoon, en route for Halifax and Boston.

The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th and Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed Father Point yesterday morning, and the steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 11th, and Queenstown on the 12th, was intercepted off Cape Race by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. We are thus put in possession of advices from Europe two days later than that by the Glasgow, published yesterday.
The steamship North American, from Liverpool 9th, via Londonderry 10th inst., passed this point at 5 A.M. to-day, bound to Quebec.

By the British mail steamship Clyde, at Havana, we have advices from Vera Cruz to the evening of the 1st inst. The day previous to her sailing the English Extraordinary arrived from the City of Mexico, the 29th with the important news that MIRAMON had sustained another and severe defeat near Lagos, where he has been a long time surrounded.

As we have already stated, the City Collector found the tenants of West Washington Market indisposed to pay their rents to the City, so long as their leases from J.B. TAYLOR, as the State's lessee, remained in force. The obvious result of compliance with the demand of the City would be to subject them to double payment. Failing in this the Collector endeavored yesterday to secure the signatures of the tenants to the following document:

The telegraph lines were not open on Sunday evening, and it was an impossibility to send you any account of the Prince's reception, or his subsequent movements, owing to the inclemency of the weather.
A more lovely day than yesterday could not be desired. This village, always beautiful, appeared were neat, cheerful and refreshed after the rain of Monday night.
JOHN W. PARKER, Captain, and JAMES M. LEBBY, mate of the brig Achorn, were yesterday examined before U.S. Commissioner MORELL upon the charge of voluntarily serving on board a slaver.
The Pony Express, two days behind time, arrived, this evening, with dates to the 8th inst.
The Council of State is discussing at Naples the programme of "Leatorio Romano." The Queen's mother is to leave instantly, that is, if the programme is accepted.

To-day the Missouri and Western Telegraph Company commenced stretching their wire westward in the direction of Fort Kearney. The poles are set 160 miles out from here, and the wire will be up that distance in two weeks. A large party is at work further west getting out and setting the poles. It is expected that the line will be finished to Fort Kearney by the middle of November.
On Saturday over a thousand spectators assembled on the Empire ground at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, to witness a contest between these two leading clubs.

BEATING AN OFFICER. Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Sunday night, a desperate fight occurred between a party of drunken men who were assembled at a lov, unlicensed groggery, at No. 14 Morganstreet, Jersey City, kept by PATRICK RAHAN. Officer WARD, hearing the cry of "murder," and "watch," proceeded to the place and took into custody JOHN SULLIVAN and WM. WELCH, and endeavored to take them to the lock-up.

HON. GERRIT SMITH Sir: You and I are antipodes on the subject of Slavery. I believe it to be a divine institution created by Heaven, and such is the doctrine of the Bible. African Slavery has christianized and civilized, during the same length of time, more human beings than all the missionaries of the world combined.

Yesterday afternoon, after the routine business in the Supreme Court, Chambers, was disposed of, Mr. Wm. S. Sears moved that the Court do adjourn out of respect to the memory of Ex-Judge MASON, whose funeral would take place at 4 P.M. The motion was seconded by Mr. Marvin and the Court duly adjourned till this morning at 10 o'clock.

This morning, at 8 o'clock, the Governor-General left his steamer under a royal salute, and went on board the Prince's ship, taking his aide with him. Then the whole fleet Hero, Ariadne, Flying Fish, Victoria, and Lady Head, in line, steamed up into the beautiful basin in which the bay terminates.
This morning we discover land on both sides, and on the south shore perceive the white houses near the water which run in a continuous street all the way to Quebec.

We publish, this morning, Mr. YANCEY'S great speech made on Tuesday last, at Memphis, Tenn., in support of the Secession ticket. We receive it from our Special Reporter, sent by us for the express purpose of laying before the readers of the TIMES the views and sentiments, by which this great leader of the Breckinridge Party endeavors to induce the Southern States to give that ticket their votes.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce since our last have been: 19 bbls. Ashes, 17,500 bbls. Flour, 467 bbls. Corn Meal, 78,005 bushels Wheat, 184,528 bushels Corn, 220 bushels Barley, 10,000 bushels Oats, 67 pkgs. Provisions, and 283 bbls. Whisky.

FLQUR dull and unchanged, WHEAT in good demand, and market better; sales 27,000 bush. Chicago Spring at 95c.@95 c; 40,000 bush. Red Winter at $1.09; 16,000 bush. White Winter at $1.11@$1.11 . CORN dull and heavg; sales 12,000 bush. at 49c. Other Grains nominal.

Alexander Smith, et al. vs. Alva Higgins et al. This case was an action at law for the infringement of a patent. It was tried before Judge BETTS and a jury, in 1856. The jury found for the defendants, but the verdict was afterwards set aside, and a new trial ordered.

The prospects of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE even in the South, which at the outset he was expected to carry by acclamation, are not increasing in brilliancy. Indeed, the elections of the past few weeks have covered them with clouds and doubt.

The New Mexican mail, with dates to the 5th inst., arrived this evening. There is great excitement in Santa Fe. The Navajo Indians made an attack upon a little settlement, 11 miles below, and killed two men and drove off all their stock.

CONSOLIDATION OF WIDE-AWAKE CLUBS. In view of the fact that the various Wide-Awake Clubs of this City have heretofore acted without unison, it occured to certain members of the organization that it would be advantageous to have a consolidation of the fraternity under a general government, so that all could be called out on parade if necessity should require.
The yacht squadron has dispersed; the cruise has terminated earlier than I could have desired. It has been productive of health and pleasure to the yachtmen and their guests.

The Tribune has our thanks for making its warfare open, direct and manly. With bitterness in its heart for four years, of which we were unconscious, the Editor of the Tribune had us at disadvantage. It is a relief, instead of crossing palms in supposed friendship, to meet an enemy "face to face."

We do most sincerely trust that in the ardor of their desire to make themselves useful to the State in doing honor to the Prince of Wales, our excellent fellow-citizens will bear in mind TALLEYRAND'S excellent advice to diplomatists, and forbear to damage a good work by superfluous zeal.

The Republicans hold their State Convention at Syracuse to-morrow. All the other parties have their candidates in the field, and it only remains for them to complete the preparations for the great campaign. So far as their nominations are concerned they will probably have an easy task.

The road from New-York to Saratoga is well marked enough. Indeed, so definitely is it staked out that one could not very well get lost on it, ever with the aid of a "Guide Book." The gliding keels of boats have worn a path in midriver, while the impetuous cars have left their track along the river-side.

The firmness in the Funds was checked by fears for the crops, owing to continual wet and cold weather, which neutralized the more favorable feeling relative to Continental politics. The tendency on the 8th was downward, but there was no material variation in prices. The Discount market on the 8th was rather quiet, and best bills taken at a reduction from the Bank rate. Business at the Bank limited.
The Prince and his suite have had a jolly time of it on the Saguenay. On Wednesday, the 15th inst., they went up it on the Victoria for forty-five miles, nearly to Ha-Ha Bay.

It cannot be said of our theatres as it was of SHAKESPEARE, that they have "Small Latin and less Greek. Niblo's Garden announces a "Contest of the Curriculum." and Mr. ANDERSON at the Winter Garden has converted that whilsome temple of the Drama into a "Psychomentheum." Of course everybody is delighted.

Of course every man and his wife is just now talking politics talking up and talking down candidates. It's a perfect millenium for every man and his wife, for no matter how diversifed the tastes, no matter how discordant the views of every man and his wife may be, it would be an odd kind of a man and his wife that would not find one or more to suit among the multiplicity of would-be's.

A genius who writes for the Philadelphia North American, tries to make out that the City of Brotherly love is the metropolis of the Western hemisphere. He bases his argument on the assertion that Philadelphia has more houses, more churches, and more public schools than NewYork.

We published yesterday the official reply of the American Government to Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S circular dispatch on the Coolie-trade and the Slave-trade. The President's objections to the British Minister's three propositions have been well taken.

A Report has gained currency that the visit of the Prince of WALES to this country is designed to further the scheme of a BritishAmerican Confederation. The story appears to have been started by a City evening cotemporary, and, more recently, has been reechoed by Canadian journals.

A fatal accident to the artillery volunteers of Dover occurred on Thursday evening. While the corps were engaged in gun practice at Archilieff Fort, one of the guns burst, scattering its fragments in all directions. G.T. THOMPSON, one of the Lieutenants and a Sergeant were killed on the spot. Several other members of the corps are seriously injured.
The Prince's squadron left Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, on the 11th inst., and the ship proceeded cautiously through Northumberland Straits during the ensuing night.
The House of Commons has voted a subsidy to the Galway line, thereby confirming the contract.

The last European mail furnishes us with accounts of the crops in those countries where the harvest is terminated. It is only in the North of Italy that the wheat crop is considered satisfactory; in Lombardy it is middling, and in the provinces of Modena, Parma and Bologna it is indifferent. In Venetia results differ in various localities; in Naples the crop is less than was at first expected.

The Republicans completed their work yesterday at Syracuse. The plaintiff in this case, brought in the Supreme Court, was a Miss Tayleur, a danseuse at Niblo's. She was married in 1852 to the defendant, her husband, who is the principal dancer of the Martinetti family with the Ravel troupe. The lady commenced a proceeding for divorce against her husband, on the ground of adultery on the 8th of August last. The Ravels left this city for Boston on Monday.

This match, which was begun yesterday on the St. George's cricket-ground, Hoboken, bids fair to re sult in another victory for St. George. By a fixed law of Saratoga every one, on first arrising in the morning, is compelled to repair to the rural temples in the grove, and bow down at the shrine of two twin constellations--the Little Dipper and the Great Dipper. This duty your correspondent has this morning faithfully performed. I am proud to say that so villainous a mixture as this mineral water, has never before passed the threshold of my throat.

The bark Kate, which was libeled for attempting to leave this port on a slave voyage, has not, as yet, been bonded. Yesterday, Mr. Charles P. Lake, the reported owner, and Mr. John S. Diehl, of No. 133 Essex-street, offered to enter into the required bonds, $18,200. A partial examination only was had, when the case was adjourned over to Friday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Much attention has been created of late by a variety of subjects, all tending to telegraphic communication with Europe. They are the proposed line across Behring Straits, the line across Iceland, Greenland and Labrador, the report of Mr. VARLEY on his attempts to raise the cable near Newfoundland, and the report of the British Government Committee on submarine cables generally.

--The piety of the Western Roman Catholics seems to be like Mr. Pogram's patriotism, as expansive as the pararies. A certain good Sister of Charity received a kind of ovation recently at Emmetsburgh, which is duly chronicled by the Cincinnati Catholic Telegraph. Among other incidents of the occasion, we are informed that the lady in question received "a letter from St. Vincent of Paul, just arrived from Heaven, by mail."

BURSTING OF WATER PIPES. In digging the trenches for the sewer pipes in different parts of the city, the water pipes are often exposed. In several of the districts these pipes were thus exposed during the recent heavy rains, and the water washing the earth from under them, has frequently caused the pipes to settle and become disjointed.

An accident oc curred to the early Newspaper Express train, yesterday morning, which delayed it for some time, but caused no serious damage. This is the first mishap which has befallen this train since it was started. Considering the very high rate of speed at which it is run, this fact affords marked testimony to the vigilance and care which distinguish the management of the Hudson River Railroad.

On Tuesday, the 26th, they met again, 26 being present, and 10 absent. The 26 sent out cordial invitations to the 10 absentees to come in; but the absentees persisted in their absence.

The Neapolitan Government, having proved unable to prevent GARIBALDI'S expedition to the provinces on the mainland, or to induce France and England to oppose it with their fleets, has collected 40,000 men in Calabria, and put Naples in a state of defence. London and Paris journals by the Arabia are to the 11th of August inclusive. We obtain from them some additional European intelligence and details of news previously telegraphed.

The rain this morning caused great damage to the Chestnut Hill Railroad. A culvert over Cresham Creek was carried away with the embankment, fiftyeight feet high. A large stone bridge on the same creek was carried away. There was much other damage to farms in the vicinity, and many houses were flooded. No lives were lost as far as ascertained. Very little rain fell in the city.

About twenty thousand persons assembled on the Putnam ground at Gates and LaFayette-avenues; Brooklyn, to witness the deciding contest between the Atlantic and Excelsior Clubs, on Thursday, Aug. 23d. According to all accounts, the crisis in Mexico will be hastened by events not generally foreseen some months ago. Senor PACHECO, the new Spanish Minister in Mexico, has made certain peremptory demands on the Constitutional Government at Vera Cruz, to which demands the Constitutional Government refused compliance in a firm and decided manner.

The Philadelphia North American is hugely disturbed by the size of New-York, and without the fear of AEsop before its eyes, is determined to swell the straight waistcoat of Quakerism to the uttermost. It is sure that Philadelphia is a "much larger city" than New-York, and relies as a reason for the faith that is in it upon the "number of houses, churches and schools" in which the home of brotherly love rejoices.

The weather of the past week, though below the usual temperature and cloudy, with some rain, has further improved the appearance of the crops, and has been more calculated to produce a better sample than a very hot sun.

If this rain continues it is feared that the pattern of this little Island will be washed out, like a badly printed cotton. Seriously, the most disastrous consequences are to be apprehended, for it is now impossible for a great portion of the grain crop to be restored by any sort of weather. On Monday last I saw wheat resembling the rushes formerly strewn, in default of carpets, in the halls of our Saxon forefathers.

It was a very peaceably disposed body was this Convention especially on the face. It was an orderly Convention, in which though there might have been diverse purposes, there was such a respect for the obverse necessity of keeping within the bounds of decorumr, that nobody ventured to overstep them. If there were two sides, the two sides very carefully refrained from giving or taking offence at what was proposed, or at what was done.

A largely attended meeting of the Republican Central Campaign Club was held in their fine room, No. 722 Broadway, last evening. Resolutions were adopted approving the nominations recently made by the Republican State Convention at Syracuse, as calculated from the certainty of election of the gentlemen on the ticket to secure legislative purity.

Gov. BANKS declines a re-nomination and announces his intention to retire from political life. He has accepted a position as Resident Director of the Illinois Central Railroad, at a salary of about $7,500 a year. It is stated that his principal motive for this step has been the necessity of making better provision for his family than the emoluments of political office would enable him to do.

DUTCHER in the Chair, Messrs. R.C. JEFFRIES, W.F.T. CHAPMAN, J.H.H. WARD, E. WARNER, and F. SHEPHERD, were appointed a committee to examine and report upon the credentials of new delegates.

The Alpine Club played their first Base Ball match, since their organization at the beginning of the season, on Friday at the Elysian Fields; it was with a Jersey Club and resulted in a victory for the Alpines after a very pleasant and well contested game.

BURKE in his second series of Vicissitudes of Families, says that there is not now in the British House of Peers a single male descendant of the twenty-five barons who were appointed to enforce the observance of Magna Charta.

The return match between St. George and East New-York has resulted in another victory for St. George it being their twelfth this season, and all won by their legitimate members. They had still ten wickets to fall.

Farini came very near breaking his neck on Wednesday. He attempted to cross his cable at Niagara Falls, enveloped in a sack of glazed muslin. Hardly had he taken a dozen steps before he found that his feet were slipping.

THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD. The extension of the track of this road from the depot at Vanderbilt's Landing down to the wharf, is in rapid progress, and will be completed in a few days. Passengers will then be enabled to step from the boat directly aboard ...

Judge DOUGLAS arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon. He was met at the depot by a few friends, and conducted to the Gilmor House. There he interchanged congratulations with his friends and dined. The number of visitors was very limited, and he made no speech. He departed at 4 o'clock this afternoon for Norfolk, where he expects to address the citizens to-morrow.

The yearly scientific harvest being now fairly garnered in, it remains to inquire what actual yields of wealth the year has brought us, and estimate that practical "fruit" which BACON makes the measure of the value of all scientific investigation.
Arrived schooners Red Fox and Balear, from Tampico 9th. They bring $400,000 in specie. A conducta of $2,600,000 in specie arrived at Tampico the 2d inst.

The ceremony of consecrating the new Female Catholic School recently opened at Flushing, was performed, yesterday, in the presence of a large congregation, many of whom came from a distance to witness it.

A telegram from Berlin, dated the 13th inst., says: "It is certain that Austria has abandoned the idea of having the possession of Venetia guaranteed by Germany. Nevertheless, at the interview at Toplitz a perfect understanding was established between Austria and Prussia relative to the basis of the principle of non-intervention in reference to the affairs of Italy."

The rumors which reach us to-day by the Vanderbilt of a diplomatic manifestation made by Austria to Sardinia, with the avowed purpose of preparing the way for an armed interference of the Austrian Government in defence of the threatened throne of FRANCIS II., may well intensify the anxious attention with which the world is watching the perilous march of the Italian people to independence and unity.

The Constitutional Union State Central Committee met here to-day, every Congressional District being represented. Cheering accounts from all parts of the State were received; and a strong disposition manifested for the union of all national men. A Committee has been appointed to select Presidential Electors.

A GANG OF YOUNG BURGLARS BROKEN UP. On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, four boys were discovered attempting to break into Mr. JOHN DILLON'S store, No. 9 Jay-street. They were subsequently arrested in a stable in John-street by Offices KERRIGAN, of the Second Precinct.

It seems to be pretty well settled that Gen. WALKER is again on his way to Nicaragua. He has selected rather a circuitous route, to be sure, and is pretty certain to encounter some very serious obstacles, growing out of the nature of the country to be traversed, in the round-about crusade in which he has embarked.
The festivities of Saratoga were rather rudely broken in upon Saturday evening. A gentleman, who had been taking his usual afternoon drive, dropped dead as he alighted from his carriage.

Letters from Monterey state that VIDAURRI had left that city for Saltillo for the purpose of raising men and money. Saltillo was known to be unfavorable to him, and for the purpose of enforcing his demands he had taken about eight hundred men with him.

In the House of Lords, Aug. 14, Lord STRATPORD DE REDCLIFFE, late British Ambassador at Constantinople, said: I have given notice in writing to my noble friend the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, of certain questions which I wish to put to him before your lordships proceed to the business of the day. The first relates to the state of affairs in Syria.

We regret to learn that "old Ironsides," on entering the harbor of Annapolis, got aground, and that she was hard and fast in the sand on Thursday. It was believed she sustained little injury, and would float off at high tide.

The Institute assembled last evening at halfpust seven o'clock, filling the Temple. The first business was the report of the Treasurer, William D. Ticknor, Esq., from which it appears that the Institute is in a dourishing condition.

Turkey, for a nation said to be in the article of death, has a pretty strong army and navy. She has actually under arms a total of 150,000, but, in two months' time and with funds, this number could be increased to 400,000 fighting men.

This morning four steamers the Aberdeen, the Oregon, the Medea, and the Franklin brought from Palermo 1,600 men of the Brigade Sacchi, a number of muskets, and considerable materiel of artillery. All these were disembarked at the Faro, at the entrance of the Straits, as the most convenient point for future operations.

The Genoa journals publish dispatches announcing the unopposed disembarkation of GARIBALDI with 8,000 men near Reggio, on the night of the 10th inst. The same dispatches report the evacuation of the fortress of Scilla by the Neapolitans. The above must be received with great reserve.

CASUALTIES. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning JOHN BRENNAN, a laborer, fell from the third story of house No. 26 Jay-street, and sustained a fracture of both legs and other injuries. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital.

The Summer is officially announced to be at an end. A few more days it has to live; a few more hours of flirtation by the seaside, and in the shadow of the mountains; a few more hops on shore, and dips in the briny wave, and moonlight drives, may still be snatched by fashion's votaries from the flying year, and then back to Broadway and the Central Park they must turn their loyal steps.

The rumor current in the city, that Gov. BANKS intends to decline a renomination for the Governorship, is correct. He does this in consequence of an important business arrangement with the Illinois Central Railroad Company, which will require him to remove his residence to Chicago.

To-day the exercises were opened with prayer, by Rev. A.H. QUINT, of Jamaica Plain. The Committee appointed yesterday to visit Dr. LEWIS' Class, reported that they were highly pleased with the exercises they witnessed, on account of their simplicity and adaptability to all schools.

In a letter which Senator PUGH, of Ohio, addressed to the late Douglas State Convention of Kentucky, he says: I wish to applaud the true and loyal Democracy of Kentucky, face to face, for their noble courage in adhering to the principles and pledges of the Democratic party (even as against the temptation of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE'S candidacy) in regard to the single question which now menaces the stability and perpetuity of our Federal Government.

Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, of whose expedition to Nicaragua we have before had accounts, made his appearance before the town of Truxillo, Honduras, on the 5th inst., and took possession without serious opposition. Only one gun was fired by the troops stationed there, by which two of WALKER'S men, were wounded. WALKER then entered the town and took possession. The greatest excitement prevailed.

The renewed attempt which WALKER is understood to be making for the conquest of Nicaragua, gives special importance to the treaties, concluded during the past year, between that Republic and the Government of Great Britain.

A FIREMAN KILLED IN A FIGHT. EDWARD FLYNN, a fireman attached to Engine Company No. 16, died on Sunday night from congestion of the brain, produced by a blow upon the head with a stone, received on the 3d of July in Chatham-street.

The friends of Judge DOUGLAS, now sojourning at the Hygeia, were greatly disappointed this morning, in not finding their standard-bearer on board the Baltimore steamer as anticipated, the papers having announced that he would leave Baltimore last evening for Norfolk.

The assembly, though very large, was chiefly composed of ladies. Among the clergymen present were Rev. Drs. KENNEDY, and PERRY, and Rev. Messrs. SCUDDEH, PURTCHER, MACOMBER, WARD and LAWRENCE.

LIVERPOOL COTTON MARKET. The Brokers' Circular reports the sales of the week at 90,430 bales, of which 15,960 bales were to speculators, and 19,029 to exporters. Imports of the week, 28,619 bales. Prices of the lower qualities are quoted d. higher, while those of the middling descriptions are fully 1/8d. better, and fair qualities unchanged. The advance in prices was caused by advices from the United States.

The attempts that have been made to recover the Atlantic Telegraph Cable have proved how erroneously it was constructed. The heavy wire covering, twisted round the central core and meant to constitute the main stay of strength, was found to be quite rotten, while the copper wires and gutta-percha of the core were always in good condition.

The Republican State Convention is very largely attended, with a great outside pressure. Ex-Gov. BOUTWELL was chosen President, who addressed the Convention, and was followed by CHARLES SUMNER.

Judge DOUGLAS arrived here this afternoon, and met with a most enthusiastic reception. Hundreds had assembled to welcome him at the depot. A delegation of citizens were also awaiting him, by whom, through their speaker, Mr. H.W. MILLER, he was formally welcomed to North Carolina.

The Superintendents of the Poor for the County of Kings submitted their annual report yesterday. There were submitted to the Almshouse during the year, 2,816 persons; discharged 2,806; remaining, 307. This institution is supported at a cost of $31,257; received from labor of inmates, $11,060.57; net expense to the county, $20,256.26.

The Republicans of the Eastern District of Brooklyn held a mass ratification meeting in the Odeon last evening. The principal address was delivered by Hon. HENRY B. STANTON. The proceedings were interspersed with vocal and instrumental music.
The Democratic State Convention is now in session in this city, for the nomination of an Electoral ticket.

A Select Committee of the British House of Commons on Merchant Shipping have made an elaborate report on the subject intrusted to their care, and have discussed, among other questions referred to them, Reciprocity and Belligerent Rights at Sea. We extract those portions of this important document that touch upon American interests. Referring to the American Coasting Trade, the report says:
The great International Horse Fair opened this morning, on the Black River Park grounds, under very flattering circumstances. The exhibition of horses has been very fine.

DEATH ON THE STEAMER PERSIA. Yesterday forenoon, a short time previous to the sailing of the steamship Persia, from Jersey City, CHARLES KINGSBURY, the steward, was prostrated with a fit, three of which he had in succession.
From the New-Orleans Picayune, Aug. 25. By the schooner Red Fox, which arrived this morning, we have files of Mexican papers from all the interior towns of Mexico nearest the scene of the war.

The Special Committee appointed by the Republican Central Committee to make arrangements for a meeting to ratify the State ticket, held a meeting at No. 618 Broadway last night, and decided to hold it on Thursday evening, Sept. 13, at Cooper Institute. It is expected that all the Republican Clubs and organizations will participate in this demonstration. Eminent speakers have been invited.

The Musical Festival last night in honor of the Prince, was a very successful affair. It lasted five hours and upwards of 8,000 persons were present. On the platform were one hundred and fifty performers who commenced the evening's entertainment by playing various selected pieces.

The Independent Reform Party of our city met in secret council last night at Barnum's Hotel, and, after some deliberation, nominated GEORGE, WILLIAM BROWN as an independent Reform candidate for the Mayoralty of Baltimore.

The arrival at Madeira of the new steam gunboat Dacotch has been announced. We have a report of her outward trip. She is pronounced successful, and her officers take pleasure in congratulating the Norfolk constructors on the fact. She made a very quick passage being only a little over eleven days at sea.

The following is a detail of officers for duty at the Academy at West Point to report the 1st of September: Tactical Department, Brevet-Major Reynolds, Third Artillery; instructor and commandant, Lieuts, Griffin, Forny and Hood; Ethical Department. Lieuts, Piper and Breek; Spanish Department, Lieuts, Williams, Owen and Bush. Lieut, Webb will be relieved from duty at the Academy.

Mrs. Mary Roope Bond, widow of the late Prof. Bond, of Harwood Astronomical Observatory, died at Cambridge, Mass., on Sunday, at the age of 73 years.

Having attended, this week, some large sales of fine thorough-bred and trotting-horse stock, in Woodford County, Ky., I send you a brief report of the sale at Mr. R.A. ALEXANDER'S place, "Woodburn Farm," one of the largest and most complete stock farms in the Union, and also some notice of a sale in the same neighborhood, at Mr. W.F. HARPER'S.

DESTRUCTION OF A CHEMICAL FACTORY BY FIRE LOSS $30,000 Between 3 and 4 o'clock yester day morning, the Chemical Factory of Messrs. DURKEE Co., on Sedgwick, near Columbia-street, was discovered to be on fire in the second story, and be fore the fire could be stayed the building and contents were entirely consumed. The building was owned by CHARLES KELSEY, and cost $10,000.

Our readers will remember the account given not long since, of two or three terrible murders committed at Denver by a drunken desperado named GORDON, and of the unavailing attempts to capture him after their commission. We have the pleasure of chronicling the capture of the criminal.

At 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon the little daughter of B.D. DAVIS, of this city, whose familiarity with a snake has been frequently noticed, died at the residence of her parents, on Centre-street. The facts connected with her case we shall state, and leave the public to draw their own inference.

MONTREAL, Thursday, Aug. 30.

The first of a new series of International Cricket matches between the United States and Canada was commenced to-day, on the ground of the Montreal Cricket Club, under whose auspices the Canada Eleven were selected the United States Eleven being selected by the St. George's Club, of New-York.

As a general thing, the men appointed to office by Mr. BUCHANAN have not won any very brilliant laurels in the public service. The President himself has achieved so much distinction as probably to discourage rivalry. Secretary FLOYD, however, seems likely to prove an exception to this general rule.
The mails for Southampton and Bremen, by the NewYork, will close to-day (Saturday) at 12 o'clock P.M.
The arrival of the Royal Mail steamship Africa at this port was announced in a portion of yesterday morning's edition of the TIMES.

The news by the Africa, whose arrival was announced in a portion of yesterday morning's edition, is of an interesting character. The report that the Austrian Cabinet had declared its intention to assume the offensive if GARIBALDI should succeed in effecting a revolution in Naples, is not officially confirmed. It is certain that up to the 15th ult., no Austrian note embodying any such views had reached Turin.
The Pony Express with a summary of news to Aug. 18, arrived last night.

There has been an ominous kind of lull in the Italian storm. The diorama of strife seems to have hitched momentarily, as it were, soon to resume its rapid movement in pictured desolation and scenes of carnage.
In the hope of catching the French mail to Marseilles, I write a few words to announce to you the following Order of the Day, which has been just given out:

The schooner Dewdrop, Capt. TERRY, arrived at this port this morning, from Ruatan Island the l6th inst. Among the passengers is a gentleman who left Truxillo on the l2th. From him we have full partic ulars of the capture of that city, and a full narrative of the events up to the latest dates.

The announcement a few days since in the Paris journals, on the foundation of a telegraphic dispatch, of the landing of 1,500 of the troops of GARIBALDI on the coast of Calabria, was not true, but it may become a fact before this letter comes to hand.

By the arrival of the Havre packet ship Zurich, Capt. BAXTER, we have intelligence of the loss of the Liverpool packet ship Roscius, Capt. HALLETT, which was abandoned on Sunday, Aug. 26, in a sinking condition, the officers, two lady passengers, and the crew escaping on board the Zurich, by which they were brought to this port.

His Holiness Pope PIUS IX., and his Majesty HIEN FUNG, making somewhat similar claims to the exercise of certain celestial attributes, may well sympathise with each other in the rather awkward predicament in which they severally find themselves placed in this year of grace 1860.

Hamilton W. Shipman vs. Charles L. Larrabee et al. This was a motion at Chambers of the Supreme Court, before Justice INGRAHAM, to vacate an order of arrest against the defendant Larrabee, granted in March last by Justice SUTHERLAND.

"Italy," says M. GRANDGUILLOT, "is now entering the most critical and most decisive period of her regeneration. Henceforth she stakes on a single card either her ruin or her salvation." It is, then, true, according to the information of the Foreign-office at Paris, that the programme which has been passed about for some days in London circles is about to be put in action.

The preparations in the future seat of the Canadian Government have been remarkably extensive and costly. Some two hundred canoes, rowed by eight men each, sailed down the river in wedge shape and escorted the Prince, as did several small steamboats filled with people, from a point some twenty miles below the city.

The London Times has been attacked with a sudden fever of anxiety about the future of Italy. The forms in which this disease manifests itself vary from day to day; but its virulence is only to be likened to the fury with which the endemics of southern climes seize upon the constitution of a newly-imported stranger.

The removal of Gov. BANKS from Massachusetts to Illinois has excited considerable comment from the Press, and been ascribed to various motives. Disgust with political life, inability to support his family, and a desire to connect himself with the industrial interests rather than the political contests of the country, are among the motives generally assigned to him.
New-Orleans dates of Tuesday last are received, containing Texas news.
The schooner J.A. Taylor has sailed for Ruatan, with fifty men for Gen. WALKER. The brig Creole, from Ruatan on the 17th instant, brings Honduras advices to the 15th.

From Raleigh to Richmond, at every station, DOUGLAS was met by large numbers of his friends. At Weldon, North Carolina, he received quite an ovation, and made a speech. McRAE, one of the Douglas Electors, also ably addressed the people here.
