The Douglas State Convention met here at noon yesterday Dr. CHAS, J. FOX, of Charlotte, President. Resolutions indorsing the Cincinnati and Charleston Platforms were passed, and a full Douglas Electoral ticket was put in the field. R.P. DICK and DUNCAN K. McRAE were chosen the Electors at Large.
Further advices from Denver City to the 25th inst., reached here this morning.

To-day, however, for a wonder, the weather was fair, and the streets were crowded with people hurrying to the grounds where the new Parliament Buildings are to be erected, and the corner-stone of which the Prince was to lay.

Among the many terrors which just now haunt the path of John Bull, it is doubtful whether the fear of the French naval supremacy or of American competition in mercantile shipping, is predominant. Early in the recent session of Parliament a committee was appointed in the Commons to investigate the condition of the shipping interest.

The curiosity of the Artillery officers, and of the guests at Old Point was gratified yesterday by the first firing of the great "Floyd" Gun of which I have before spoken. The first shell weighing 360 pounds was thrown fifteen hundred and forty yards at an angle of five degrees and striking the sand, bounced seven hundred and fifty yards further. The charge of powder was twenty pounds.

TO "MANY CITIZENS OF CHARLESTON." In your communication addressed to me, in the Courier of the 24th inst., you ask whether my recent letter, or my resolutions in the Legislature last Win ter, "is intended to be considered my opinion?" and "a candid answer is desired." In all candor and sincerity, I answer both, and will adhere to both with all that "honesty" which you say you have heretofore given me credit for.

The Richmond Enquirer is an amiable journal, almost as amiable as it is sensible. It is just now in a mood of malignant glee, because the State of Virginia has concluded to have the arms and munitions of war, with which she proposes to dissolve the Union, made at home, instead of buying them in Massachusetts.

This grand affair, which was got up in honor of His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, took place in Longueuil Bay, in the St. Lawrence River, on Thursday last. Six steamers, and the Committee's barge in tow of another, took 3,000 persons to the Bay, in which were anchored the war steamers Valorous and Styx.

The steamship Cahawba, J.W. SMITH, Commander, from New Orleans and Havana, arrived here yesterday at one o'clock P.M., four days from Havana. The Cahawba left New Orleans at 8 o'clock A.M. on the 25th ult., reaching Havana on the 27th, at 2 P.M., from whence she took her departure for this port at 1 P.M. on the 28th.

That a person, famous for passing Niagara River on a bridge of hemp, is to perform feats of the same character and hardly less daring in this City during the present week, is ineffaceably proclaimed upon the dead walls. M. BLONDIN, envious of Metropolitan applause, is coming to town.

The American schooner Plumes of Dennis, which came ashore in the norther twelve days ago, driven high and dry on the beach, has been got off, and is afloat again. She was sold at public auction, by order of the Captain, on Saturday last; price, $1,000. A.LEMPARTE was her purchaser. The hull seems to sit well enough on the water. One mast is standing. The rest and the bowsprit are good.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamer Columbus, with two weeks' later intelligence from all the Central American States, arrived here on the 20th inst., but her news is unimportant. She brought the mails for Europe and the United States, and the usual cargo of Central American products.

By the arrival at Panama of a small coastingschooner from Buenaventura, which port she left on the 12th inst., six days' later news has been received from Cauca.

The long-pending differences between the Mother Country and this Colony, in reference to the transfer of the Post-office Department from Imperial to local control, have at length been settled. The act to effect the transfer, passed during the late special session of the Legislature, held in the month of April last, has received the assent of her Majesty the Queen, and the Department has been formally handed over to the management of the Colonial Government.

We publish a second capital letter from Col. PERRY, of South Carolina, in another part of this morning's TIMES. It is like the first, which we copied a week or two ago, able, independent and full of common sense. The appearance of such documents in the South at the present time is quite a phenomenon.

All has been merry and money-making during the past week at the theatres. The closing weeks of August, and opening ones of September, are the dramatic Carnival, and the busy managers endeavor to improve those shining hours, and gather in sufficient store to carry them through the bleak weeks which mid-winter brings.

FATAL RESULT OF A BAR-ROOM BRAWL. The circumstances relating to the decease of DANIEL HORRIGAN, a native of Ireland, 20 years of age, who was fatally injured on the night of the 20th ult., during the progress of a fight between a number of persons, in the bar-room of AUGUSTUS FENDAGO, corner of West and Cedar-streets, were investigated on Saturday by Coroner O'KEEFE.

Commodore JAMES McINTOSH, one of the ablest officers in the Navy, is dead. He breathed his last on Thursday, at Pensacola, where he was Commandant of the, Navy-yard. Forty-nine years ago, a short time previous to the war of 1812, Commodore McINTOSH donned his cadet's jacket, and has since performed 32 years' service, of which 20 were spent on sea, and the remainder on land. His unemployed time counts over 13 years.

A word or two in advance may enable you to understand properly some movements that are now on foot here, and likely to be developed within the next three months. Kansas has already, and for so long a time, occupied so much of public attention, that nothing but matters of real importance can now elicit general interest abroad.

On Friday afternoon, Coroner MURPHY, of the Eastern District, held an inquest on the body of JOSEPH BEBON, who died that day from the effect of wounds inflicted by his son, JOSEPH BEBON, Jr., on the 19th inst. Dr. JOHN A. BRADY was the first witness examined.

The English steamer Valparaiso, from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, arrived here on the 21st inst., bringing the mail and $432,592 in specie for England, and also the following cargo: 5 seroons of hats, 32 packages of sugar, 4 seroons of bark, 92 bales of sundries, 339 bags of cocoa, 23 packages of bark, 11 do, of sundries, 6,300 ingots of copper, , mostly for Europe.

The meteorology of this country appears to be as unsettled as the condition of the mines. Last Summer and Fall the principal characteristic of the weather was an almost uninterrupted dryness. Between the 1st of May and the 1st of December the aggregate fall of rain did not exceed five inches.

Election returns from the border counties of this State have a rough road to travel before they can render a true account of themselves at this seat of intelligence. Nearly a month has elapsed since the Gubernatorial election, and the official account still lingers in a pleasing uncertainty. In 1857, three weeks rolled around before the vote of the unterrified in the remote Democratic fastnesses was known.

A slave brig, whose name is not definitely ascertained probably the Triten came into the Capes Monday, and anchored at Quarantine yesterday morning, in charge of Midshipman N. H. FARQUHAR, fortyone days from Loango, on the west coast of Africa.

The Sunday night mail train from Boston ran over and killed an unknown man-near New-Rochelle. The morning train from New-London to New-Haven, on Monday, also ran over a boy named McFarland, near the junction. His injuries were expected to prove fatal.

Detectives Elder and McCord yesterday morning secured the arrest of a Prussian, known as J.F. de l' Are, alias Newman or Nieman, but whose real name is Ludovic Joachim Julius Tode, on a charge of being a fugitive from St. Petersburg, Russia, where he is alleged to have embezzled, in the month of August, 1859, the sum of $55,000 from an English firm, by whom he was employed as confidential clerk.

One of those chronic spasms of activity to which our Police Department is subject, occurred yesterday. Superintendent KENNEDY mustered a strong force of his officers, dispensing with the usual indications of their business, and suddenly dispersing them over the region southward of Canal-street, succeeded in capturing one hundred persons, who were carried to the Lower Police Court.

The steamship Palestine passed Father Point yesterday morning on her way to Quebec, having left Liverpool on the 23d, and Londonderry on the 24th ult. Her advices are consequently one day later than those by the City of Manchester, published yesterday morning.

The large number of arrivals from Southern ports during the past week has caused quite a collection of vessels at and about the old anchorage. On Saturday we counted twenty-five, and on Sunday eighteen, and on Monday and Tuesday the number was still further diminished.

The public are more than usually curious to-day about the movements of GARIBALDI. The Dictator suddenly left Messina eight days ago, after addressing the citizens of the town a speech on the necessity of harmonious and energetic action in order to maintain the liberty they had acquired. It has been asserted and denied that during this time he has been at Naples.

SMART, the well-known English Elocutionist and Lexicographer, under date of London, Aug. 7, 1860, writes: "I have examined as far as time has permitted the splendid volume you did me the honor to transmit last week the Pictorial Edition of Webster's Dictionary, unabridged, 1859. Dr. GWIN, "the daily mail-killer," is home again. On the day of his arrival a military company fired 30 guns for the departure of its Captain, but not a fire cracker exploded on the Senator's account. Nobody gave him a dinner. Nobody made much of him. Nobody has spoken well of him. He is a shrewd man, however, and will go back to the Untited States Senate if he wishes, without a question.

On Monday the Academy of Music opened its portals and gave to New-York the cheering conviction that the world of fashion, if not come, was at all events coming home. The election for State officers and members of Congress in Maine took place to-day. The vote is probably the largest ever cast in the State. Scattering returns, including several of the larger cities and towns, show Republican gains, and indicate the elec- tion of the full Republican ticket by large majorities. Twenty towns, heard from early in the evening, give WASHBURNE, (Rep.,) for Governor, 2,576 majority.

Will of Victor Gifford Andubon The testator was the son of the great natuaralist of his name. His will gave his entire estate to his widow, Georgiana R. Andubon, whether she lived a widow or again married, and appointed her executrix, together with John W. Andubon and George Burgess, executors.

The guests of the New-York Hotel were thrown into consternation after midnight, on Monday, by the pranks of a burglar who had concealed himself in the house. The fellow was discovered by Patrick Smith, the night-watchman, in the room of one of the boarders, helping himself to the property of the occupant.

The Neapolitan troops were attacked by Garibaldians near Piale, by whom they were surrounded and defeated. An armistice was then proposed. The commanding officer referred their proposition to the General-in-Chief in order to obtain his decision. In the meantime the enthusiasm of the Neapolitan troops abated. They became disorganized and dispersed, leaving the batteries without any defenders.

A Lincoln meeting was held on the Brandywine Battle Ground this afternoon. It was one of the greatest assemblages ever held in Eastern Pennsylvania, for numbers and enthusiasm far eclipsing the campaigns of 1840 and 1844, when meetings were held at the same point. The number of people is estimated at from 20,000 to 25,000.

The Italian drama is moving forward to its denouement with startling rapidity. The news which reaches us to-day brings Sardinia face to face with the dynastic party of Italy and of Europe, and fully explains the recent lull in the storm which broke so suddenly over Sicily a few short weeks ago.

SATURDAY'S CONCERT AT THE CENTRAL PARK. The Central Park was the centre of attraction last Saturday afternoon. Thither all classes and conditions of people, upon whose hands hung a leisure hour or two, wended their way on foot, on horse-back and in all manner of vehicles.

Hon. CALEB CUSHING spoke at a Breckinridge and Lane ratification meeting in Boston, on Wednesday evening. He did not see how either Mr. DOUGLAS or Mr. BELL could hope to obtain a single electoral vote in any of the Northern States, except by the aid of the supporters of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE.

We learn unofficially from Fort Buchanan that Capt. EWELL has received dispatches from Gov. PESQUEIRA, of Sonora, announcing the capture of nine of the wretches engaged in the diabolical massacre and robbery at the San Pedro Mines. He desires the witnesses to be sent to Hermosillo, to testify against the prisoners on their trial, and promises that they shall be shot upon conviction.

Under the heavy pressure of European public opinion, and of the threatening demonstrations of the Great Powers, the Ottoman Government has been swift to punish the authors and abettors of the late Syrian massacres. The General Term of the Supreme Court will commence its September session to-day, (Monday.) To-day motions will be heard.

The Union was again saved at the Cooper Institute last evening. At an early hour on Saturday night the extensive piano-forte manufactory of BOARDMAN, GRAY Co., corner of Broadway and North Ferry streets, Albany, was discovered to be on fire. In the yard were 50,060 feet of lumber, which barely escaped destruction.

Grant H. Adams vs. The Mayor, This case has been several times fully stated in the TIMES. The plaintiff was a Health Warden of the Eighteenth Ward, and was removed from office on the 15th of May, 1858, but still claimed title thereto, and brought his action for salary claimed subsequently to the date of his removal.
The last Pony Express brought the rumor, and the denial of it, that BRECKINRIDGE had withdrawn. It scarcely produced a ripple in political circles, for nobody believed the rumor true.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 15th instant, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings the California mails of Sept. 1, anticipated by overland advices, and $1,202,675 in treasure.

The American ship Chatsworth, Capt. HORN, of Boston, of 1,150 tons register, went ashore in a gale, on the l3th of July last, off the coast of Chili, 150 miles south of Valparaiso, and broke to pieces.

Mr. BUCHANAN'S efforts to settle the American claims against Peru are not likely to be crowned with more success than his efforts in the same direction in other quarters have been.

The Santa Fe Mail, with dates to the 10th inst., aarived this evening. They have had two copious showers of rain at Santa Fe, which have restored the spirits of the people very much.

Oregon dates are to the 6th inst. The silver excitement has been brewing in Oregon for several months, and the most extravagant rumors now prevail respecting the mines in different parts of the Cascade Mountains, bordering on Willamette Valley. Several parties have been prospecting during the Summer, and many more are now preparing to go.

We understand that letters of the highest authority were received in this city, by the Cahawba, from Havana, which leave no room to doubt that something serious is pending between Spain and Mexico. At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, Mr. PURDY, Chairman of the Committee to whome the business of preparing the lists of Registers of Election was referred, expressed his regret that thay were not ready to report, and he therefore asked that the matter be postponed until Tuesday next at 3 P.M. which was acceded to.

It is rumored that the Breckinridge men decline the absolute surrender to which they are invited by the Committee of Fifteen. It is said that their State Committee will soon issue as address repudiating the fusion, and that the men who have been put upon the electoral ticket will decline to serve.

The Republican Judiciary Convention met last night at No. 618 Broadway. There were five delegates from each Ward, including a number of the most promonent members of the Party. Among these were D.D.FIELD, A.OAKET HALL, Judge COWLES, GEO. OEDVKE, Ex-Judges PEABODY and BEEBE, and others of equal note, HIRAM BARNEY, of the Fifteenth Ward, was chosen Chairman, and Messrs. HALL, of the Ninth and SHEPHARD, of the Fifth, Secretaries.

SMALL-POX HOSPITAL In consequence of the increase of small-Pox cases in Jersey City a special meeting of the Common Council was held last evening, and on the recomendation of the Board of Health $560 was appropriated for the erection of a temprory small-pox Hospital.

The American schooner Plumas, that was driven ashore three or four weeks ago, and was sold at auction on the beach for a thousand two hundred and sixty dollars, having been in the dry dock, has had her leaks stopped, and is now afloat again. It is, however said that she is no bargain to her purchaser that her timbers are decayed and so forth.

The Fair of the State Agricultural Society opened here to-day at noon. Upward of three thousand entries of articles and stock have been made up to this time. In consequence of the rush of exhibitors from all parts of the State, the books of entry will be continued open until Wednesday evening.

The Board of State Assessors closed them labors yesterday, by submitting to the Commissioners of the Land Office an equalization table of the values of real and personal estate in the several, counties. The report, being approved by the Commissioners, has become the basis for taxation the ensuing year.

-In ordinary war fare one effective bullet in fifty is considered a fair average. Chinese fighting is done largely with gongs : women and children get sadly frightened, but there is little work for the surgeon. It is an economical mode of warfare, too; the gong is always loaded, and if it does not go off, it allows the enemy to do so.

The tenth anniversary of the Pastoral Aid Society of the Diocese of New-York, was held last evening at St. Mark's Church,(Rev. Dr. ANTHON'S,)corner of Tenth-street and Second-avenue. After the transaction of the usual preliminary business, Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, Chairman, in a brief addreas, set forth the purposes and aims of the Society ; after which prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. TYNG, and a hynm was sung.

BRECKINRIDGE had an immense demonstration to-night in front of Congress Hall. Mr. BRADY'S speech is regarded as a death blow to fusion. He denounced DOUGLAS and his doctrines, and gave it as his opinion that he would not carry a single State. He characterized CAGGER and RICHMOND as tricksters. The meeting was a great success.

The great Powers of Europe are loud in their professions of anxiety and alarm over the situation of Italy. From London to St. Petersburgh the most earnest voices are raised by public men and the Press, warning Italy that she has entered upon a perilous career, and imploring GARIBALDI to pause before he throws down all the ramparts of public law in his victorious march from Palermo to Venice.

Mr. YANCEY, the eloquent advocate of Union, whose arguments always tend to make Disunionists, has reached this city on his Northern stumping tour. It is his purpose, I believe, to stump Pennsylvania, and he expects, doubtless, to frighten the good people of that State into the support of BRECKINRIDGE, by telling them of the fearful things which the election of LINCOLN will bring upon them.

The anniversary of the New-York Bible and Common Prayer-book Society, and of the Missionary Committee of the Diocese of New-York, will be held in the evening, at the Church of the Transfiguration. Rev. Dr. RUDDER will preach.

Senator DOUGLAS arrived here at 8 o'lock-tonight by a special train from Cincinnati, and was received at the depot by a very large crowd of citizens and escorted to the Bates House. He speaks here tomorrow at the State Democratic mass meeting. At Lawrensburgh, Greensburgh, Shelbyville, and other places along the route, Mr. DOUGLAS made short speeches to crowds assembled at the depots. Extensive preparations have been made for the demonstration to-morrow.

It is now ascertained, we believe, beyond a peradventure, that Gen. WALKER was executed on the 12th inst., as stated in yesterday's TIMES. The British war-steamer Gladiator brought the news to New-Orleans, together with the remnant of WALKER'S "army." Ten shots, it is stated, were fired at him, amid the cheers of the native, and he was afterwards buried by foreigners. Col. RUDLER has escaped with a sentence to four years' imprisonment.

Judge DOUGLAS is gradually drawing his weary pilgrimage to a close. At the latest advices he had reached Cincinnati, where he enjoyed a brilliant reception and again made the speech which has delighted and edified the inhabitants of the route he has traversed. Mr. DOUGLAS is a good stump speaker, accustomed to study the character and tastes of his audiences, and ready and able always to meet them at least half way.

DESCENT ON AN ALLEGED GAMBLING HOUSE At 5 o'clock yesterday morning Chief of Police MARINUS, with a posse of men, made a descent upon the premises No. 98 Newark-avenue, where it is alleged gambling is carried on. The officers arrested CHAS. SICKLE, the proprietor, and J.S. BISHOP, JAMES SPENCER and R.S. TILDEN, inmates, who were there gambling and drinking in violation of a city ordin- ance. The accused were all committed for examination.

RAILROAD ROUTE SUSPENDED.?The running of horse-cars on Furman-street, between Fulton-street and Atlantic-avenue, has been stopped by a decision of the Supreme Court. The City Railroad Company in 1854 obtained from the Common Council a right of way over Furman with other streets for the purpose of running horse-cars, conditionally, among other things, that the road should be in operation at a certain time.

Touching the figures furnished from week to week by the City Inspector, it may be a truism to say that while they obtain less attention from ordinary readers than from statisticians, they are nevertheless full of matter of every-day practical concern. State elections of great importance, inasmuch as they will be significant of the probable issue of the Presidential election, occur in several States during the present month. To-day State officers are chosen in Mississippi and Florida; on next Monday, the 8th, South Carolina is to choose members of the Legislature, and on the 9th, Tuesday of next week, State elections will be held in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Iowa and Minnesota.

Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS addressed an immense audience in this city this evening, at the Bell and Everett Head-quarters. Over 4,000 persons, of both sexes, were present. The stage was beautifully decorated with wreaths of flowers twined around the portraits of WASHINGTON, CLAY, PLEASANTS and others. Mr. BOTTS was greeted with tremendous applause.

JOHN MINOR BOTTS has entered the field in Virginia against the Disunionists. He made a four hours' speech at Richmond last night, in which he denounced without measure or mercy the men who are threatening to secede from the Union in case LINCOLN is elected.

Judge DOUGLAS has been received in a flattering manner in the State of Ohio. The State is populous, and a very considerable proportion of the population had a curiosity to see the Little Giant. So he has been met at every point by enormous crowds. The turnout here, last night, was prodigious. At least fifty thousand people crowded to the market space where he was advertised to speak.

Yesterday, the first business transacted in this Court was the receiving pleas of guilty of grand larceny from Eliza Reynolds and Mary Watson, charged with stealing a piece of silk, valued at $80. Reynolds, though, quite a young girl, was an old offender, and had already been in the penitentiary. The Recorder sentenced her to the State prison for three years. The woman (Watson) was discharged.

It is announced with a flourish of trumpets that Fusion has at last been effected, that an electoral ticket has been nominated for which the Breckinridge and the Douglas Democrats and the Bell and Everett men of this State are expected to vote.

The fifth annual Fair of the St. Lawrence International Agricultural and Mechanics' Society commenced on the grounds of the Society, here, yesterday. The grounds are distant two miles from the depot of the Northern New-York Railroad, vid which you get here at the unseasonable hour when graveyards are popularly supposed to yawn, and disembodied spirits to revisit the glimpses of the moon.

John Richardson et. al. vs. The Schooner G.H. Montague. This is a libel filed in the U.S. Circuit Court, Judge NELSON presiding, to recover the possession of the schooner by the owners. The proofs are very voluminous and complicated, embracing some nine hundred folios in manuscript.

Capt. HINCKLEY, of the British steamer Gladia tor, came to the city yesterday morning, and went, in company with Mr. EASTMAN, acting British Consul in the absence of Mr. MURE, to see Mayor MONROE about making arrangements for the transfer of the sick men on board the Gladiator, from the vessel to the hospital.
The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held last evening in Cooper Institute, Dr. POST in the Chair. The attendance was not large.

Edward Potter vs. John Odier. On the 28th of October, 1859, the plaintiff herein was injured while passing the premises No. 95 John street, by the fall of a derrick there in use. He sued the owner of the premises for damages, but the Court holding that the contractor was the party liable, action was now brought in the Common Pleas Court against the contractor who was using the derrick.

Unwearied by the mammoth demonstration of Wednesday evening, undaunted by the threatening storm, and no doubt cheered by the news of the glorious Wide-Awake demonstration of New York, the Republicans of Philadelphia and vicinity flocked to the Battle-field of Germantown yesterday the anniversary of that contest which fills so important a place in our history.

The Board has been occupied most of the day with eloquent addresses, urging a series of resolutions from the Prudential Committee appropriate to the present jubilee period. A beautiful address was delivered by Rev. JOHN KEEP, one of the only two survivors of the Association that formed the Board.
The Board of Councilmen met at 5 o'clock P.M., MORGAN JONES, the President, in the Chair.
The Third District Republican Assembly Convention met at the Fifth Ward Hotel, last evening, and nominated WILLIAM H. GIBSON.
The Pony Express, with news to Sept. 22, arrived last night.

The New-York Associated Press has leased the New foundland Telegraph lines for five years. This step has been taken by the members of the Association to protect themselves against the hostility with which they are men aced by the American Telegraph Company.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon at the rooms of that body. There was a large attendance of members. The President, PELATIAH PERIT, Esq., occupied the Chair.
The President gave in honor of the Prince on Wednesday evening a grand State dinner, the socialty of which continued until after 10 o'clock, at which time the Prince retired.

Important advices reach us from Mexico, by way of New-Orleans. The report of the final condemnation and confiscation of the Spanish bark Maria Concepcion is confirmed. The Spanish Commodore threatened to bombard the city in retaliation, and would probably have put his threat in execution, but Capt. JARVIS, of the American squadron, interfered and condemned such a course, and the whole Spainsh squadron, with the exception of one vessel, thereupon left for Havana.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 4?Midnight. The display of fireworks to-night was viewed by thousands of spectators, who waited patiently for several hours in the penetrating rain before the exhibition could take place.

By the Canada's mails, which reached this City last evening from Boston, we receive London and Paris journals to the 22d ul'., reclusive. Later advices, vid Cape Race, have been published, but the details are interesting.
The steamer Atlantic, from Brazos 29th ult., has arrived, with $49,000 in specie. She reports the brig Kineo, bound to Vera Cruz, ashore near the Belize.

Though cloudy this morning, it cleared up by 10 o'clock, and a dense mass of humanity poured through each of the four entrance gates.

The British mail steamship Lima arrived at Panama on the 22d, bringing dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chili to Sept. 1, and from Callao and Lima to the 14th. The news is not important.

REOPENING OF CALVARY CHURCH.--This beautiful Episcopal Church, on the corner of Twentieth-street and Fourth-avenue, was re-opened yesterday for divine service, after having been closed for several weeks to allow repairs and alterations to be made, which have added much to the beauty and ornament of the edifice and the comfort of the congregation.
The United States mail steamship Vanderbilt, E. LE FEVRE, commander, from Havre and Southampton on the 26th ult., arrived at this port on Saturday night.
An unusually large congregation attended St. Ann's Church for Deaf Mutes, in Eighteenth-street, yesterday morning, on the occasion of the eighth annual sermon by the Rector, Rev. THOS. GALLAUDET.
The U.S. Mail steamship Northern Light, Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, from Aspinwall on the 30th ult., with mails and passengers from the South Pacific and Central-America only, arrived at this port last night.

The positions occupied by the contending parties in Italy is at this moment as striking in strategical as in political points of view. If a triangle be drawn on the map with its base extending along a line a few minutes westward of, but parallel to, the fourteenth meridian, it would have at its southernmost point Gaeta, and at the northernmost, Ancona.

A very general and profound interest is felt in the State elections which take place tomorrow, especially those in Pennsylvania and Ohio. The result in these States will have a very decided effect on the sentiment of the public and the action of parties concerning the Presidential contest in November.

The steamship Northern Light, the delay in the arrival of which had begun to cause some apprehensions as to her safety, reached this port last night. She brings no mails, passengers or treasure from California, the John L. Stephens, the steamer on the Pacific side, having failed to reach Panama up to the 30th ult., the day on which the Northern Light left Aspinwall.

A mass meeting is to be held this evening at the Cooper Institute to ratify the Fusion electoral ticket. It will be large and enthusiastic, for instead of being addressed to the members of any one political party, it invites all of every party who are opposed to the election of a President by the American people, and in favor of throwing the election into the House of Representatives.

Coroner SCHIRMER, yesterday, investigated the circumstances attending the murder of HESTER FINLEY, by her husband, DANIEL FINLEY, on Sunday afternoon, at the tenement house, No. 199 East Fourteenth-street.

The most intense anxiety prevails as to the result of the Pennsylvania election to-day. We shall without doubt be able to announce it in to-morrow's TIMES. It is generally felt to be decisive of the Presidential contest, especially if it results in a Republican victory.

SAN FRANCISCO, 26th Arrived 24th, ship Pamflush, from Philadelphia ; steamer Sonoru, from Panama; spoken. July 11, ship Sunshine, from New-York, for San Francisco, lat. 24 North, lon. 34 west.

IMPROVEMENTS IN BROADWAY DEMOLITION OF AN ENTIRE BLOCK. Pedestrians in Broadway were not a little astonished yesterday at beholding in sudden and active progress the wholesale destructions of the entire block of buildings between Ninth and Tenth streets, on the east side. Early in the morning an army of some three hundred men appeared on the ground and commenced the work of demolition.

Some wag, no doubt disappointed in his hopes of shining among the starry elect of New-York at the coming ball to the coming Prince, has perpetrated a very unjustifiable hoax upon his more fortunate competitors.

The New-Orleans Picayene, of Friday, gives a verbal report that Capt. JARVIS passed a note to the Spanish Commodore, in which he not only condemned his threats to bombard Vera Cruz in case the Maria Concepcion was not restored and demages paid, but declared he would consider the first shot fired upon Vera Cruz as a shot upon the American squadron. In consequence of this note, further action in this matter was suspended.

FIRE. A short ride on horseback, a breakfast, an endurance of popular regard during his ride to the depot, and a telescopic view of the country from the roof of the ear-house comprise the list of his operations at the city of Richmond.

Early in the Spring of the present year, the English newspapers favored us with occasional paragraphs, wonderfully suggestive but mysterious enough in details, about a remarkable ship to be launched for the Galway line. She was guaranteed to sail 20 knots an hour; she was promised to fulfill the conditions of safety in an extraordinary degree, and she has to outstrip all competitors as to elegance and comfort.

A correspondent of the Courrier des Etats Unis, writing from Managua, announces the discovery of a new and practicable transit route through Nicaragua. He locates its Atlantic terminus half way up the Mosquito coast, at the mouth of a stream named on the maps "Rio Grande," but which is delineated there as anything but a great river, a mere trace indicating its approach to the sea.

ANOTHER ATTEMPT AT WIFE-MURDER. A man named ALBERT LANDER was arrested by Officer HAIL, of the Second Precinct Police, late Monday night, for attempting to kill his wife at the house of a friend on Hudson-avenue.

The accounts received here to-day from Norfolk represent that all is quiet again in Norfolk and Princess Anne counties.
In the Thirteenth District, BRINKERHOFF, the Republican candidate for Supreme Court Judge, and SHERMAN, Republican, for Congress, have 284 majority a gain over DENNISTON'S vote of 67.

In Galveston papers of the 28th and 29th alt. We find accounts of the dreadful disaster which befell the steamboat Bayou City, Capt. FOREST, on the night of the 27t. She was bound from Galveston to Houston, and when about to make a landing at Lynchburg, her boilers burst with terrific explosion and fearful result.

The Brokers and Stock speculators are very busy just now in their vocation. They are determined to make what hay they can while the sun shines. Although they do not believe a syllable of the rigmarole by which reckless demagogues are endeavoring to alarm the public, for their own political purposes, yet they have faith enough in public credulity to belies a that it will produce some effect.

To the curious in literature, a visit to the late Mr. BURTON'S library offers peculiar inducements. They will find there much to interest, either the student of dramatic literature, or the observer of human character.

DEATH FROM VIOLENCE THE PERPETRATOR UNKNOWN Coroner O'KEEPE was notified, yesterday, that MICHAEL HALEY, residing at No. 38 City Hallplace, had died at the New-York Hospital, in consequence of a terrible wound in the abdomen, received last Saturday night. The Democracy, and especially the official portion of the Democracy, in Washington, were never before so thoroughly overwhelmed with a sense of ruin as at the present moment; and the reflection that the blow comes from the old Keystone State adds poignancy to despair. In all former defeats there was still hope of resurrection. But now they sink to rise no more.

From Lousiana and Mississippi we begin to obtain sad accounts of the loss by the gale on Tuesday last. For its duration and for the force of the wind, it has scarcely been equaled for many years. No similar record of large and deplorable losses of buildings and machinery, to say nothing of the growing crops, has been lately experienced.

The spectacle presented on Broadway on the evermemorable day of the Japanese reception was fairly outdone yesterday. America triumphed in the weather, which was as bright as October in his best humor could make it, and a feeling more generous than mere curiosity emptied New-York into Broadway. The Schooner Potomac, Capt. ARNET, from Vera Cruz the 18th ult., arrived at this port last evening. Among her passengers is Col. BRAVO, of the Liberal army of the North, who comes to this country for the purpose of purchasing arms.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article in the TIMES of this date, headed "An Alleged Fraudulent Assignment of Real Estate" contains too many errors to allow it to pass uncontradicted.

The artists and the dealers in Art are beginning to stir with the general revival of metropolitan life. The rural studies of the Summer will soon be ripening under the City's Autumn sun, and new visions of the "light that never was on land or sea" begin to be evoked from the outlines of mountain and shore under the painter's magical wand. More activity is thus far observ.

The organs of the Democratic Party are doing their best to keep their courage up. They try to persuade themselves that all is not lost. They acknowledge the stunning character of the blow they have received, but console themselves with the thought that there is a month left in which they may recover. The Washington Constitution talks about reconquering Pennsylvania; but most of the other organs confess that New-York is their forlorn hope.

We find in the Philadelphia Bulletin of last evening returns which indicate a majority of over 30,000 for CURTIN in Pennsylvania. The Legislature will probably stand as follows: Senate, 25 Republicans to 8 Democrats; house, 67 Republicans to 33 Democrats.

The Prince of Wales and suite yesterday visited the New-York University, the Woman's Library, the Astor Library, the Cooper Institute, and the Free Academy, and then rode to the Central Park, where he assisted at the transplanting of an English oak and an American elm. Last evening Broadway was enlivened by theglare of the Wide-Awake torches of our City companies. The parade was an impromptu affair, each Ward and company parading independently, gotten up by way of celebrating the recent Republican triumphs in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Maine, and was well calculated to remind the people that their next President has been indicated by these elections.

Private advices from Sonora report the success Of GANDARA, who has taken Guaymas, and every other town but Hermosilla, where PESQUEIRA is fortifying for a last and desperate battle. The Mexicans in Arizona are going over and joining the successful party in Sonora.
The official count this morning shows the election of JOHN M. BUTLER, Republican, for Congress in the First District, over LEHMAN, by 185 majority.

One of the minor but not the least gratifying results of the Republican victories in Pennsylvania and Indiana, is that they consign to private life those inestimable public servants, BIGLER and BRIGHT. Is it absolutely impossible for us to do anything well? We do not mean passably but perfectly, just as it should be done, without any drawbacks or breakdowns. We pride ourselves greatly on our practical qualities, and yet it is precisely there that our failures occur. Either from some constitutional defect, or from habit, we half do a great many things, and the instances of complete success are the rare exceptions to the general rule.

Peter Rowe and Seneca P. Dutcher, convicted of passing counterfelt coin, were sentenced each to pay a fine of one dollar, and to be imprisoned at hard labor for one year.

The news from Costa Rica is highly important. On the night of the 28th ult., the troops of President MONTEALEGRE, 1,300 strong, under Gen. MAXEMO BLANCO, attacked the fort of Ex-President MORA, at the Augostura, near Punta Arenas. We find the particulars of the affair in the Panama Star and Herold.

A summary of the Pope's allocation at the Consistory of the 28th, is published. He reproves, and condemned in the strongest terms, the detestable and sacrilegious attack of the King and Government of Piedmont. He protested, and would not cease to protest, against their acts, which he declared null and of no effect. He eulogised and blessed his defenders,

POLITICS AND LITERATURE THE PRESIDENT AS A NEWSPAPER WRITER. The political history of the United States during the first 60 years of their existence has yet to be written. The journals, up to a recent period, were in the hands of small politicians, who used them to further their own ends, and did not scruple to publish the vilest personal attacks and the most odious libels upon the party leaders who were opposed to them.

COMMON COUNCIL. The Board of Aldermen last evening received a communication from the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, asking that the petition for permission to lay rail tracks and run horse-ears through Hicks-street to Fulton Ferry, be referred to a Committee, so that they may protect their rights. The communication was laid on the table. After the transaction of some further business the Board adjourned.

The organization known as the City WideAwakes held a mass-meeting at their Head-quarters, No. 638 Broadway, last evening, which was largely attended. Mr. A.C. HILLS presided.
The California Pony Express reached here this noon, 24 hours behind time, with dates to and including Oct. 3d.

FATAL STREET ENCOUNTER On Saturday evening JAMES ROBINSON, a young man residing at No.135 Eighth-street, went out with two of his friends to see the great procession of firemen.All of them had been drinking together, and the effect of ROBINSON'S potations was manifested in boisterous behavior. Reaching the corner of Prince-street and Broadway he became involved in a dispute with two strangers, one of whom finally struck him a heavy blow on the head.

As late as a fortnight ago GARIBALDI was still the hero of the Parisians; the famous "Rodolphe" of the Mysteries of Paris was never a greater. The daily doings of the hero of EUGENE SUN were not looked for with more anxiety by the public than were those of the hero of Varesa. But to-day all this is changed. He that was a hero yesterday is to-day but a headstrong and senseless adventurer.

We publish this morning a curious and instructive article, from the Charleston Mercury, upon the results of Southern submission to Mr. LINCOLN'S election. It sets forth the manner in which a Republican administration of the General Government may be expected to operate injuriously upon Southern interests.

The official visit of the Prince of Wales was to lay the last stone of the seven-and-a-halfmillion-dollar Victoria Bridge, or, in other words, the tombstone of the Grand Trunk Railway. The Toronto Leader at length informs us that "it cannot be longer concealed that a tremendous financial catastrophe is impending over the road, BARING BROTHERS having taken steps to recover advances amounting to millions of dollars."

In my last, dated the 29th ult., I informed you that the authorities here had called upon the commanders of the American and British ships of war in port, for aid to restore order in this city, and that Commander PORTER, of the United States sloop-of-war St. Marys, and Capt. The trip from West Point to Albany was one continued ovation. The Republican mass meeting here to-day has been one of the largest demonstrations that has taken place in Central New-York during the canvass. The chagrin and mortification of the office-holding fraternity here is great, as might be expected; and threats of taking up arms in defence of Southern rights are freely made by the young and ardent recipients of Government bounty, who hail from the extreme South. Senator DOUGLAS arrived here at noon, on a special train, from Detroit. He was met at the depot by an immense crowd, and escorted through the principal streets, followed by a procession two miles in length. An arch was thrown across the street, bearing "Welcome to DOUGLAS," on one side, and "Popular Sovereignty" on the other. 25,000 people are estimated to have been present. There will be a torchlight procession this evening.

Howe, counsel for James Massey--the novel pugilist, indicted for felonious assault on Officer Patterson, of the Fourteenth Precinet, with intent to kill--applied to the Court, upon affidavits, to postpone the trial, assigning, as his reason, the absence of material witnesses. The Court granted the request, stating that the defendant was entitled to a postponement and the trial was set down for the first Monday in December.

The annual inspection and review of the Seventh Regiment, Col. ROCHESTER, Thursday, Oct. 18. The Republican mass meeting here to-day has been one of the most splendid and successful political demonstrations of the canvass. The weather has been unpropitious for two days past, but cleared up about noon to-day. Immense delegations from the neighboring towns and counties came pouring in at an early hour.

Wednesday night witnessed the most, magnificent ball ever given in Portland. The price of tickets was set at $10. All that were issued were readily sold. Much credit is due the managers for keeping the number within the capacity of the Hall, and each man's name being written on the ticket he purchased, no room was left for speculation.

This morning's TIMES contains an editorial headed, "Medical Education in New-York," which would be unexceptionable if it told only the truth, but, unfortunately, along with some truth is mingled a considerable misrepresentation and a few misstatements. Judge CROSBY arrived in this city, from the East, last Saturday, at midnight. The Judge came by the mail carriage as far as Echo Canon, where it is reported the mail driver managed somehow to get half seas over, and so far quarrelsome as to delay the mail, and stab an emigrant, wounding him severely, but not fatally. The Judge completed his journey in company with Mr. G.W. MYERS, a mail station employe.

VALPARAISO, Tuesday, Sept. 17, 1860. Tomorrow will be the anniversary of Chilian Independence, and the festivities, beginning to-day, generally last three or four days. The position of the Post-office Department is this: The public demands facilities like those of London and Paris. The Department, anxious to grant them, claims that it can be done only by having a monopoly of the business, which it is now endeavoring to secure by the enforcement of the laws against private expresses. The opposition with which it meets occasions much embarrassment.

The day of long as well as expensive ocean trips has gone by. The time was when our fathers parted slowly with the land, after seeing the sun set thrice behind the dear heights of Nevasink. Now, in the same time, their children trace the cost line of half the Atlantic States and sleep on the third night within sound of the guns of Fort Moultrie.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution to increase the salary of JOSEPH MURPHY, Deputy Superintendent of Lands and Places, to $1,500, was laid over. Pier No. 20, East river, was ordered to be repaired. A report in favor of paying Lexington-avenue, from Forty-second to Fifty-second steel, one-half the expense to be borne by the owners, was laid over.

Senator COLLAMER, of Vermont, who has just been reelected by the General Assembly of that State, on Thursday last, addressed the members of the two branches, in accordance with a resolution inviting him to do so. After some allusions purely personal in their character, he touched upon the question of Slavery.

Nothing more pointedly indicates the utter demoralization of the Democratic Party than the exhibitions of rowdyism rampant and ruffians in the ascendency, which have recently been made in the nominating conventions of that party in this City, the last stronghold of Democracy north of Mason and Dixon's line. Conventions of all kinds, except the respect able, have sprung up with the rapidity of mushrooms on a sheep-walk after a night of autumnal rain.

Our town was thrown into excitement yesterday about 10 o'clock, by the circulation of a report that the body of a man had been found on the hill, about a mile from town, hanging to the limb of a tree. I immediately repaired to the spot, and found that a desperate character, known as PHIL MAGUIRE, had been there summarily executed; but at what time, or by whom, is unknown.

Their field-notes show that a very large amount of work has been ac- complished, the entire region of Grand Traverse Bay, including the Manitou and Fox Islands, having been obtained with extreme accuracy.

Our Washington correspondent discloses the scheme of the Disunionists at Washington, for the accomplishment of their traitorous designs. He asserts that it has its headquarters in the Treasury Department, and that high officials of the Federal Administration are parties to it. It is proposed that the Legislatures of the seceding States meet immediately after the election of LINCOLN, de- clare the Union dissolved, and proclaim Mr. BRECKINRIDGE President.

Hon. P. PHILIPS, of this city, has been employed by the Government to assist in the prosecution of the parties at Key West, charged with being engaged in the Slave-trade. He leaves here on Saturday vid Charleston. The Court sits on Monday week.

Mr. YANCEY, this afternoon, after an eulogistic introduction by Gov. MAGOFFIN, addressed here an immense and attentive Kentucky audience. I reckon four thousand were present, and they kept perfect order. He spoke for two hours and a quarter with much energy and power.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 10th inst., and the Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 13th and Queenstown on the 14th inst., have arrived at this port. The friends of the Union movement held another meeting last night in the Cooper Institute. It was largely attended, and the speakers were very warmly received. Among those who composed the assemblage were Messrs. Augustus Schell, Joshua J. Henry, Washington Hunt, Moses H. Grinnell, S. J. Tilden, Capt. Wiley, H. CARTER, an old New-York merchant, a Henry Clay Whig, and a good, substantial man. The Charleston Mercury bitterly laments the apathy of the South for lending no encouragement to newspaper enterprise. The deeds and vouchers of title of the Dutch Church property have passed the scrutiny of the Attorney-General, and been found in all respects valid; and, but for the additional formality exacted by the act of Congress, that the transfer be sanctioned by the State Legislature, there is nothing to prevent the immediate preparations for building.

The dispatches from New-Granda, the contents of which I gave yesterday, were wrongly stated to have been received from Minister JONES, instead of the Legation now in charge of the Vice-Consul at Bogota.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Columbus arrived at Panama on the 21st. She left San Jose de Guatemala on the 10th, La Libertad in Salvador on the 12th, Realejo in Nicaragua on the 16th, and Punta Arenas de Costa Rica on the 18th.

I wrote you in my last that the British guard, stationed on shore, ostensibly to protect the British and French Consulates, were assuming and exercising a protectorate over the city by challenging all persons who passed through the streets on which these Consulates are situated; and that probably these assumptions would lead to a correspondence between the British and American commanders.
The steamship Northern Light. Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, from Aspinwall the 25th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning.

That was a happy thought of Mr. BOTTS when he denounced the idea of the South deserting the Union on account of the election of Mr. LINCOLN, as "base, cowardly and unmanly." It is to run away, he says, "not only before we are whipped, but before we are even struck a blow." The Government of the Union owns.
The British steamship Valparaiso brings dates from Valparaiso and Santiago to the 20th October, and from Lima and Callao to the 13th.

The Breckinridge Democratic procession tonight was large and enthusiastic. It contained about four thousand torch men uniformed, and five hundred mounted men hav- ing banners, transparencies and music. They marched through the principal streets, which were partially illuminated. The procession contained a large number of boys. The uniforms and torches were all furnished gratuitously, it is supposed, by "Uncle Sam."

The meeting in Corinthian Hall on Wednesday evening was large and enthusiastic. The Hall was densely filled, and a large number were obliged to content themselves with only a place to stand about the entrances.
SALEM, Oregon, Tuesday, Oct. 2 3 P.M. The Legislature have at last elected Senators.

SEWARD, at Palace Garden, last evening, was listened to by as many thousands as could get within sound of his voice, while innumerable thousands of Republicans in different parts of the grounds, unable to get within ear-shot of him, were listening to other orators, who addressed them from platforms erected in the open sir. The marine guard of the United States corvette Vandalia arrived here yesterday, and are quartered at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. They will be put on board their vessel in a few days.

To J.J. HENRY,ESQ.: Dear Sir You have done me the honor to send me a political circular, headed (Private,) urging me to vote the Union Ticket. Permit me to say that I cannot consider any political communication private.

Rev. N.S.S.G. BEMAN, D.D., the pastor of a Presbyterian church in Troy, and the stepfather of the very much overrated Southern spouter YANCEY, is one of the most energetic men of his age, in the world. He is at the head of the Polytechnic Institute in Rensselaer county and an-...

It will please our readers to know that the health of Rev. JOSEPH SCUDDER is so far restored as to enable him to preach once more with something of his usual power. A service of about eight years in India, under an unfavorable climate, rendered his return to the United States necessary.

The project of Alderman PLATT has come to an untimely end. Having passed the august assembly which that gentleman illustrates, it had an equally speedy transit through the Board of Councilmen, and only needed the assent of the executive officer of the county, Sheriff KELLY, to become a week's law of the town.

The Herald for Disunion. The Herald of Wednesday has a strong article in favor of the secession of the Southern States, in the event of Mr. LINCOLN'S election. The treasonable manifesto of the Herald is founded on the text furnished by the census of Delaware.
One of the largest meetings of the Fusion Party yet held in this City during the campaign assembled at the Cooper Institute last evening.
The steamship Hammonia, from Hamburg on the 15th, and Southampton on the 18th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. We receive London journals of the 18th-two days later than previous mails.

THE EAGLE HOAX. The denizens of Wallstreet and vicinity; yesterday afternoon, were the victims of a hoax which, if the number of those taken in is a fair index, was one of the greatest magnitude. About noon small squads of people were seen collecting about Trinity Church and looking at the spire to discover the whereabouts of an eagle which it was said, was perched on a projection near the dial.

The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 20th of October, via Queenstown on the 21st arrived here at 11 o'clock last night, and sailed again for Boston at 3 o'clock this morning, where she will be due to-morrow (Sunday) evening.

FALCONER THE STREET PREACHER AGAIN. EDWARD FALCONER, the temperance lecturer and open air preacher, who has been apprehended almost every Sabbath during the past six months, for violating the City ordinance which prohibits street preaching with- out a license, as usual fell into the hands of the police yesterday. Why Americans, and even English, who swarm in Dresden, should rarely visit Prague, one of the most interesting capitals in this part of Europe, is a mystery which can only be explained by the circumstance that the former is decidedly preferable for all purposes of practical loafing. Not without justice has the Saxon capital been styled the Florence of Germany. It is so full of museums and collections of Germany.

Plymouth Church was, at an early hour last evening, crowded, packed and filled to overflowing with people, drawn by the various motives of worship, curiosity or habit. The church is always well filled; but the audience last evening exceeded any we hate ever before witnessed in that or any other temple of the Lord.

By the steamship Prince Albert, whose arrival at St. Johns is elsewhere announced, we receive two days later advices from Europe. They are not of an important character. The meeting at War- saw of the Emperors of Austria and Russia and the Prince Regent of Prussia had taken place, but nothing had transpired as to the Conferences.
The Pony Express, with dates to the 21st from California, arrived yesterday afternoon, but was detained here in consequence of the telegraph line being prostrated by a severe storm.

The prolonged and unusually mild weather of the past week terminated what was regarded as the Indian Summer on Saturday. The soft south wind which had prevailed for several days, and given to the atmosphere uncomfortable warmth and moisture, then changed to the northeast, with signs of a storm, and towards noon the wind increased to a stiff gale, accompanied with rain.

DESTRUCTION OF A PAPER MILL BY FIRE. At about 5 o'clock on Saturday evening, and while the storm was at its height, a fire broke out in the buildings occupied by Messrs. HAMILTON DONNELSON, at the corner of Carroll and Nevins streets, and the entire establishment, including buildings, machinery and stock were destroyed.

The city is all in a buzz this morning over great preaching yesterday, in the Bowery. The Chief Apostle HYDE; opened the ball in a most extraordinary discourse upon "precedents " that had been established by the Gentiles towards the Mormons, setting forth that the measure that had been measured to the followers of JOSEPH SMITH, or as they style themselves, the Saints, that some would be measured to them again.

All non-professional men who have ever had occasion to visit a dissecting-room, can well understand the intense loathing and horror with which even condemned malefactors shrink from that portion of the death-sentence which delivers over their bodies after execution to be dissected for the instruction of medical students.

The steamship Prince Albert, from Galway on the 23d of October, arrived at this port at 12 o'clock on Friday night, but the telegraph wires not being in working order, it was impossible to transmit her news to the Associated Press.

GEORGE SANDERS seems to be emulating the Apostle of Donaghadee, and having been decapitated, is now foretelling all manner of woes to follow to the United States generally, and New-York in par- ticular, from the election of Mr. LINCOLN.
SIR: We appeal to you, not as a partisan, but as a good citizen and a man of business.

The news of WALKER'S capture and execution was received here on the 28th ult., and occasioned such a ringing of bells and firing of guns as you have seldom heard. The great mass of the people, however, appeared to be perfectly indifferent about the matter. The defeat and execution of MORA, in Costa Rica, was actually the cause of more excitement than the downfall of the "gray-eyed man of desiny."

The Western Stage Company's coach which left Denver City on Monday, with the mail, passed here for Omaha on Thursday morning, with a full load of passengers.

Our Prince has arrived, and, in our quiet, undemonstrative way, we are enjoying him. On Thursday morning a pretty yacht of 156 tons, the Emma Rooke, (a little sister of the bark Yankee, both having been sired by a New-London builder,) came into our harbor, flying the royal standard of Hawaii. The American ship Carrier Dove is still here. She brought from California 25,000 bags of barley. Sales were effected at $3 for 155 pounds, but the gain proving to be worm-eaten, the sale has been annulled. Probably it will be sold at auction. The native barley rules at $3.37.
Since my last, not much of importance has happened.

The Southern Illinois (M.E.) Conference was lately in session at Bunker Hill, Illinois. During one of the meetings, the hanging of Rev. Mr. BEWLEY, by a Pro-Slavery mob in Texas, was announced. A series of resolutions was adopted denouncing the outrage in the most foreible terms. Besides this, the Committee on Slavery reported a series of resolutions.

The divisions among the Anti-Republicans of the Eighth Congressional District having been settled by the withdrawal of the rival candidates, and the nomination of ISAAC C. DELAPLAINE to represent the Dis trict in the next Congress, a meeting was held on Saturday evening, at the corner of Broadway and Thirtysecond-street, to ratify the nomination.

The evidences of our impending election are not yet very strong at the Capital. Except about local candidates, there appears to be less talk and movement than there was four weeks ago. Since the October elections excitement has subsided here. Probably the admitted fact that the State will go Republican has something to do with the calm now prevailing.

-NO- thing is easier than to threaten disunion. But unfortunately, disunion cannot be effected by resolutions or by words. It is a practical things, to be accomplished by practical movements. Justices CONNOLLY, KELLY, and STEERS, on Saturday disposed of seventy-three cases, as follows: Of thirty-six prisoners charged with assault and battery, one was discharged by request of complainant, eight were dismissed, no witnesses appearing against them, the complaint against one was withdrawn, three were allowed postponement, five were discharged under suspended judgment, seven were remanded for sentence, five were fined, three imprisoned, and three acquitted.

Lord PALMERSTON was on a visit to Yorkshire, presiding at sundry educational and other meetings. His speeches were devoid of political allusions. The Yorkshiremen were very enthusiastic in their reception of the Premier.

The crowd which gathered about Tammany last evening, dispersed and reassembled several times before the old wigwam showed any signs of life. Not only was there no "Rynders pocket-piece," to scare the echoes in the Park, but there was no tarbarrel, there were no rockets or Roman candles. Not to speak of a full Band of music, there was not even a single drum or fife. Tammany was dismal.

EDITORS: Having been frequently interrogated during the last two days as to whether I would continue to hold the office of United States Commissioner. I consider that it is due to myself that my fellow-citizens should not misunderstand the position I occupy.

Since the beginning of the present month there have been arraigned in the Special Sessions one hundred and six persons charged with the commission of assault and battery. The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall on the 5th inst., arrived at this port last night, with the California, Istharas and Central American mails.

Our Democratic friends seem to be laboring under some delusion in regard to the actual condition of our Federal Government. They are greatly alarmed lest the Union should be dissolved, and are calling loudly on Mr. LINCOLN to issue a Proclamation, or do something else to save it. They evidently think that LINCOLN is already President, and they look to him for safety now as they looked to Gen. JACKSON in 1832.

In this Court, yesterday, fifty-one cases were disposed of as follows: Of twenty persons charged with assault and battery, four were discharged on account of non-appearance of witnesses against them, two were discharged by request of complainant, four were discharged under suspended judgment, one was remanded for sentence, two were fined, and seven were imprisoned. Of twenty-five persons charged with petty larceny, one was discharged because no witness appeared against him, two were discharged...

According to the Neapolitan accounts CIALDINI was beaten by the Neapolitans with great loss at the Garigliano, some dispatches placing his losses as high as two thousand killed and wounded, and five guns.

Three car-loads of provisions arrived here yesterday and the day before, for the relief of the settlers of this Territory, making six car-loads within the past week, and each car-load ranging from six to eight tons.

Mr. KEITT was serenaded by the people at 12 o'clock last night. He made an exciting speech, urging prompt and decided action. He said that Mr. BUCHANAN was pledged to secession, and would be held to it. South Carolina should shatter the accursed Union. If she could not accomplish it otherwise, she would throw her arms around the pillars of the Constitution, and involve all the States in common ruin.

Now that South Carolina, and the "Fire-eaters" of other Southern States, threaten to dissolve the Union, we have instituted a rigid personal inquiry into our own course and conduct towards the South. This inquiry results in a conviction that, with one exception, we have not, in thought, word, or deed, wronged our brethren of the Slave States.
GORDON, THE TICKET-SWINDLER, CONVICTED. Trials in this Court were commenced again yes terday, beore Judge GOULD.

Since closing my Panama letter, the Railroad Company's steamship Guatemala has arrived, bringing dates from Guatemala to Oct. 24, Salvador to the 30th, Nicaragua to the 31st, and Costa Rica to Nov. 2. The news is unimportant.

Jacob Wickelhousen vs. James C. Willett.--The particulars of this case were fully stated in the TIMES of February 10, at which time it was on trial at the Special Term of the Superior Court, before Justice HOFFMAN.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your editorial in Friday's Daily TIMES, headed "Analysis of our Local Contest," a passage occurs reflecting unjustly upon the political intelligence and the patriotism of the German Republican voters of New-York. In the name of this large and respectable class of your fellow-citizens, the insertion in your esteemed paper of these few lines is respectfully requested.

The parties in the Burch case are all here, and the legal gentlemen to whose care the case has been intrusted, have all arrived. The Clerk's Office already contains a mass of sealed depositions bearing upon the case, taken at St. Louis, Chicago, Albany, New-York and Cincinnati, most of them at the instance of Mrs. BURCH, with the intention of showing the cruelty practiced towards her by her husband.

Mr. KING, the Chief Engineer of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, has received instructions to commence work on the machinery of the U.S. steam-frigate Roanoke. Some alterations contemplated will be effected, while others are not approved. The Roanoke is the largest propeller in the navy, and has been comparatively useful. There is employment for fully half a year on her machinery alone.

As Mr. LINCOLN is a characteristic man himself, he must of course have characteristic visitors. Of this class is honest farmer JOAB WILKINSON, who made a brief speech here on Wednesday night last, and was rewarded with the glory of having his name divided into three by the telegraph. JOAB is a great favorite hereabouts. He is a brother of Senator WILKINSON, from Minnesota, though that does not occasion his popularity. JOAB has individual peculiarities.

A Grand Union Mass Meeting, irrespecive of parties, will be held at Staunton, next Saturday. The call is signed by 48 prominent citizens, among whom are Hon. ALEXANDER H.H. STUART, Judge BALDWIN, Mr. YOST, editor of the Vindicator, HUGH SHIFFER, and GEORGE BAYLOR.
A special meeting of this Board was held last evening President CURTIS in the chair.
Elias J. Pattison vs. Jared G. Bacon. In this action, judgment was recovered against the defendant, upon a promissory note more than a year ago, by default.

Laura H. Gildersleeve vs. John Vance. The plaintiff in this case was formerly principal of the Primary Department of Ward School No. 37, in the Twelfth Ward. The defendant is one of the editors of the New-York Sun, and is also one of the Trustees of the Twelfth Ward School.

From the National Capital, the intelligence Reaches us that a decidedly better feeling prevails in reference to the excitement in the South, the dispatches received there warranting the belief that the comparative calmness which will follow the first ebullition of feeling will bring with it a corresponding caution, which must prevent the commission of any act which would tend to precipitate disunion. Our dispatches from various points this morning will tend to confirm this view.

Rev. Dr. BELLOWS delivered a lecture last evening before, the New York Teachers' Association in the hall of the Board of Education, upon the subject of "Education its Diversity of Methods and Unity of Purpose." The hall was well filled with a large and appreciative audience, composed mostly of teachers, of both sexes, in our Public Schools.

The Board of County Canvassers reassembled at 10 A.M. yesterday, Mr. TWEED, the President, in the Chair. It is the intention of the Board to finish the canvassing the present week, if possible, although by statute they could draw pay for twenty meetings.

At a meeting of the Board of Supervisors, at 4 P.M. yesterday Mr. STEWART, the President, in the chair a long discussion ensued upon an application of the Sheriff's Jury for permission to use the Common Pleas Court for their sessions.

The Police are still busily engaged in ferroting out the murderer of JAMES DEBEVOICE KOLYER, who was murdered in his own barn last Monday night, at NewLots. The two SPRATTS father and son-arrested on Tuesday by Detectives Frost and DENTON, were discharged yesterday, there appearing no evidence against them.

The Spanish frigate Berenguela, whose arrival at this port was briefly noticed in our issue of yesterday, is now lying off the Battery, and attracts considerable numbers of the curious, who go around her in row boats. She comes here to have her machinery overhauled at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, to enable her to do which the steam-frigate Wabash, now in the drydock, will be floated into the stream.

The Charleston Mercury, it seems, is fearful that matters will not be so harmonious as desirable. In reference to the choice of delegates to the State Convention, it holds the following language:

A general mass meeting was held this evening to take into consideration the action proper for the the South in the present crisis. CHARLES T. POLLARD was chosen President of the meeting, being supported by a numerous corps of Vice-Presidents, most of whom a few days since represented the strongest conservative element of the city. The speaking of the evening was opened by Gov. MOORE.

A meeting, designed to give formal exepression to so much of the public opinion as concurs in the claims of superiority that are made in behalf of the Railroad proposed to be constructed between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, via Pike's Peak and Utah, was held last evening in the large hall of the Cooper Institute.

HERR GOLDSCHMIDT, the distinguished artist astronomer, like the hero whose mouth could not " Ope. But out there flew a trope." can scarce look through the telescopic tube without finding some new asteroid, and adding to that remarkable group of bodies of singularly insignificant size, which revolve round the sun in plane tary orbits between Mars and Jupiter. Escorts of volunteer companies on occasions of Presidential Inaugurations have been usual through all our past history. The Albany Burgesses Corps formed a port of the escort on the occasion of President BUCHANAN'S Inauguration, and their appearance at Washington was then regarded as a compliment to the Democratic choice of the American people.
The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 4th inst., via Halifax, arrived at Boston at 12 o'clock yesterday morning. The mails by the Canada reached this City yesterday at 5 o'clock P.M.

This week is one of great doubt and uncertainty. The Warsaw Conference has come to an end, no one knows how. Austria has made a decisive communication to France, whose contents are variously reported; the answer of France is equally unknown, and the position of Prussia and Russia is more puzzling than all.
GENTLEMEN: I have the pleasure to report for the information of the patrons and friends of the expedition my arrival at this port.

The Secretary of War has received intelligence to-day that the troops held the Charleston arsenal at the request of the United States Naval Storekeeper, who apprehended a possible attack from a mob.

Any good deed of the Aldermen has peculiar claims to recognition. One such was recorded yesterday, in the shape of a resolution assigning to the Superior Court a suite of rooms in the brown-stone building at the corner of Chambers and Centre streets apartments free from all the sanitary objections to which its present accommodations are subject.
Steamships Atlantic, Gray, Havre, North Atlantic Steamship Co.; Edinburgh, Kennedy, Liverpool, J. G. Dale.

On Thursday Detectives McDougall and Bennett saw two men, whom they suspected to be thieves, in Greenwich-avenue, carrying a box of soap. Bennett arrested one of them, who gave the name of Thomas Neely, and McDougall entered upon a cross-examination of the other. Finding these interrogatories of too searching a character, McDougall's man, who held the soap, dropped it and ran into an alley in Eighth-street, the officer following him closely.

The steamship Teutonia, from Hamburgh on the 1st inst., and Southampion on the 4th, arrived at this port last night. We find in the Evening Edition of the London Times of Saturday the following telegrams:

A women claiming to be the son of Mr. Charles Halcomb, owner of the trotting-horse Ethan Allen, was arrested in Meinphis, Tenn., a few days since, charged with assuming attire inconsistent with her sex. She was fined $25 for the offence. It is said that she has traveled with Mr. Halcomb, in this disguise, for nearly a year, and that she had never before been suspected.

The United States ship Savannah arrived off the Navy-yand yesterday afternoon, twenty-eight days from Vera Cruz, having left there at 6 A.M. on the 19th October. She had very light and unfavorable winds until reaching the latitude of Charleston, S. C., when the wind shifted to the southward and eastward, and from thence almost immediately round to the westward and northward, blowing for several days a succession of strong gales, at times quite heavy.

In addition to our own very interesting letter, which we publish this morning, we copy also from the special correspondence of the London Times a graphic description of the important battles that have recently taken place on the banks of the Pei-ho. The result, as every one anticipated, has been highly favorable to the Anglo-French arms.

I left New-Orleans on the 15th of Oct. and Vera Cruz on the 20th, and arrived here safe and sound, having been robbed once, and that in the outskirts of this city.
The city is busily preparing for the jubilee of Tuesday next. We are expecting a great invasion of Wide-Awakes.
A meeting of the Life-Saving Benevolent Association was held at Room No. 13 Insurance Buildings, Wall-street, yesterday afternoon. THOMAS TILESION, Esq., President, presided.
The first business in this Court yesterday was the trial of Martin Halligan, indicted for the murder of Marry Halligan, his wife, at No. 317 West Fortythird-street, on the 5th of August last.

Mr. ABBOTT has very generously offered the Chapel of the Spingler Institute for the use of the French Protestant Church, and service will hereafter be held there on Sabbath evenings. This will be very gratifying to many French residents and others residing in that part of the City. The first service will be held to-morrow evening at 7 o'clock.

The chivalry of South Carolina, it would seem, are not without influential sympathizers in the Empire City. The telegraph announces that "a distinguished officer" of New-York has offered Gov. GIST to enlist under the Palmetto flag "at the head of twelve hundred fighting New-Yorkers."

The popular movement towards secession in the South is watched with profound anxiety in this City. In the rural sections of the North it excites as yet but very little feeling. The people of the interior, as a general thing, regard it merely with curiosity.
The ruin of the Grand Trunk Railway Company has, homever, other aspects besides its unfortune connection with royalty.

The late Republican electoral candidates in Maryland have issued an address. They set forth the principles which they hold as Republicans, by way of introduction. Slavery they recognize as a social and political evil, which local law defends, and with which they would not interfere directly or indirectly.
M. BERGER'S FAREWELL. This celebrated billiard-player takes his departure for Boston to-day, having inaugurated a great taste for the French threeball carom game of billiards.

We must dissent in toto from the suggestion made in a quarter certainly entitled to some authority, that the Republican organizations of our City should make no regular nominations for the various important offices to be filled at the December Election.
The United States mail steamship Vanderbilt, P.E. LEFEVRE Commander, from Havre on the 7th, and Southampton on the following morning, arrived at this port yesterday.

The group of illustrious men who came into the world in the same decade with the French Revolution is fast dying out. The survivors of that epoch are now more than threescore and ten years of age, and very few of them are left.
