By the steamship Vanderbilt, which arrived at this port yesterday, we receive four days' later European advices. The Italian news is important, and, summed up briefly, announces the total defeat of the Bourbon army, and the polling of one million three hundred thousand Neapolitan votes in favor of annexation to Sardinia.

The statement to the effect that Mr. BUCHANAN, touched with the sufferings of Kansas, had given a hundred dollars for their relief, is evidently deemed so improbable as to demand more than ordinary proof.

Great delight has been aroused amongst the lower strata of the Democratic factions, by a proposition gravely made through a prominent Republican journal, to the effect that no nominations for the City of ficers to be filled next December should be made by the Republican organization.

To the few confiding souls who still retain faith in the Academy of Music's operatic announcements, it may be fit to mention that "La Juive" is promised on Monday, the 26th. Miss HINCKLEY, the Albanian songstress has arrived.

The "Brigade," as already anticipated, is dead and done for, to all reasonable intents and purposes, and we hear now only faint echoes from afar of the "tumultuous greetings" with which the heroes are being welcomed as they reach their several unions and electoral divisions throughout the country. Dublin, at all events, is well rid of them.

MARTIN, of Atchison, and R.G. ELLIOTT, of Douglas County, Secretaries. A Territorial Central Committee, composed of thirteen members, one from each Council District, with Gen. S. Our readers will remember what a hue and cry was raised recently when the State Legislature enacted a law for the suppression of theatrical performances in this City on Sunday.
In the case of Martin Halligan, tried on Friday for the murder of his wife, the Jury did not agree upon a verdict until 4 o'clock on Saturday morning, when they acquitted him.
The United States vs. The Bark Kate, her cargo, The bark and her cargo were seized on July 6, 1860, under an allegation of a violation of the laws against the Slave-trade.

While some of our own States are demonstrating their higher civilization by cries of secession, the weak little States of Central America, which have had such a disastrous experience of disunion, are earnestly looking forward to the reverse as the balm for all their wounds and the cure for all their sorrows.

I learn from a reliable source that President BUCHAMAN not only condemns the doctrine of secession, but that he stands by the Proclamation of Gen. JACKSON, issued in December, 1832, against the nullification experiment of JOHN C. CALHOUN.

Fate gives to almost every public man who survives and continues in power for six months after the commission of any folly or offence, some special opportunity of redeeming his character and atoning for the injuries inflicted.

The first advices from the election on the Pacific shore came to hand yesterday. They announce a most unexpected development of the Republican vote in California, rendering the contest an exceedingly close one between the Douglas and Lincoln tickets; though the latest reports accord the State to the former.

We have nothing new of special importance from the South this morning, with reference to the question of secession. Matters are reported to be quiet at all the principal points from which we naturally look for exciting dispatches.
As previously stated in the TIMES, Mr. McLANE did not desire to return to Mexico, and only consented to do so and remain until a successor could be determined upon.

Fifty-one vessels arrive at this port during the quarantine season recently closed which had cases of yellow fever on board, either on the voyage home or at ports from which they sailed. One hundred and nineteen cases of sickness were reported in the ports of clearance, and deaths in port twenty-eight, besides a large number of cases sent to hospital.

LA ROCHEFOUCAULD assures us that there is always something gratifying in the mishaps of our best friends; and whether the maxim of the social sage be sound or not in the relatians of man with man, it has an undeniable application to the intercourse of States.

CITY MORTALITY. The City Inspector's report of City Mortality the week ending Saturday last, states that the number of deaths during the week was 344, of which 80 were men; 88 women; 102 boys; and 74 girl's; being an increase of 23 on the week previous, and 73 less than during the corresponding week of 1859. Of the number 154 were under 5 years of age.

S.J. FLINT, Esq. Dear Sir: I have read with much interest your elaborate communication of yesterday relating to the mulatto population of the United States, and the inferences drawn by Mr. DE BOW and published in an official document.
The Pony Express from San Francisco 7th, arrived at 9 o'clock last night, bringing California dates via Fort Churchill, by telegraph, to 10 P.M. of the 8th.

To-day extensive preparations will be made at Governor's Island to dispatch a large force of United States soldiers to California. They are to strengthen the First Regiment of United States Dragoons and the Sixth Regiment of Infantry.

Although the preliminary skirmishes of the counsel in the Burch divorce case do not bring out the long-expected evidence which has been so assiduously collected, they serve to whet the public appetite.

WINTER GARDER. TOBIN'S comedy, "The Honeymoon," is seldom placed upon the stage now-adays, although it is one of those last century triumphs That our grandames and grandsires enjoyed immensely. It is good of its kind, but not the best. When it is revived once in three or four years, it is played often enough.

The meeting held at St. Paul's Church, in Fourth-avenue, last evening, had a peculiar interest for Methodists. All the Bishops of the Church were present, and several of them delivered addresses. Clergymen from distant parts of the country were there, too, in great numbers, and some of them spoke to the people.

FLOUR dull and 25e. lower. WHEAT very dull and lower; sales 3,300 bushels No. 1 Milwaukee Club at $1; and 1,200 bushels No. 2 Chicago Spring at 97c. Other grains quiet. CANAL FREIGHTS declining, forwarders this morning were asking 16c.

The Mormon element of the Utah population, as a general thing, seem to hold themselves as much aloof from the various political creeds and parties as they do from the various religious sects and parties.
The official returns of the election in Pennsylvania are now complete, with the exception of the small County of Forest, which gave CURTIN a majority of sixty.

Since the day when the cry ran through the French camp before Moscow that the Kremlin was on fire, no such fright has been experienced as that which seized on the good people of Paris the other night when they were told that the Credit Mobilier was on fire.

A great Republican jubilee was held yesterday at Springfield, Ill., the home of Mr. LINCOLN. It was intended primarily as a congratulatory county meeting, but it unexpectedly assumed vast proportions, and was attended with demonstrations of the greatest significance. The town of Springfield was illuminated last night in the most brilliant manner, and the most intense enthusiasm was displayed.

The steamship Nova Scotian, from Quebec, arrived to-day. About 15,000 Neapolitan troops, 4,000 horses, and 32 guns, being pursued by the Sardinians, took refuge in the Papal States at Terracino. At Casterna their progress was arrested by the Papal and French authorities, and they will be at once disarmed.

Ira B. Davis et al. vs. Five Hundred and Seventy-four Bags of Coffee.-The libelants were the owners of tho schooner G. H. Townsend. In June, 1859, the master of the vessel chartered her to Christian Thomsen, for a voyage from this port to Rio Janeiro and back. The charter party contained the usual clause binding the vessel and the cargo to be laden on board for the faithful performance of the agreement.

The U. S. steamers Sumpter and Mystic and sloop-ofwar Vincennes were off the coast, cruising; all well.

The accounts that reach us from Syria represent, that the Christians of that country are still in the most deplorable state of suffering and destitution. Thanks to the efficiency of French intervention, they are no longer in dread of perishing by the sword, but the no less, alarming fate of perishing by famine appears now to be staring many of them in the face.
The Aldermen's Committee on the City Deposits met again at 3 P.M. yesterday, Alderman BRADY presiding. The Chairman inquired whether Mr. PLATT, the City Chamberlain, was present.

Just about an hour after I had given you, in my last, a very good reason why the Uncle Sam should be delayed a day or two at the Isthmus, up she came, all well and hearty. She left again on Thursday morning at 11 o'clock with 160 passengers and $1,188,071 of treasure, of which $1,082,071 goes to your City.

REPUBLICAN PRIMARY ELECTIONS.-The election, by the Republican Party, of delegates to the various nominating Conventions for the coming Charter election, took place last evening. The polls were held at the head-quarters of the Republican Associations of each Ward, and were kept open from 7 to 9 P.M. Considerable interest was manifested in this election, and a large vote was polled, although there was no exciting contest between rival delegates in any of the Wards.

The Times, in its Clty Article, dated the evening of the 7th inst., says: "The English funds have been without the least movement to-day, but the tone of the market is rather firm. No gold was taken from the Bank. The principal fluctuations in the Railway market, to-day, hare been in Canada, which have been pressed for sale, the market being over supplied, hare experienced a further decline."

Missouri's loyalty to the Union remains unimpaired and unimpeached. As she is one of the largest Slave States of the Confederacy, her voice declaring the Constitutional election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency no just or tenable reason for dissolution or secession, is entitled to great weight with her Southern sisters.

The meeting of congratulation, which was, at first, intended for a county jubilee, has, unexpectedly, assumed gigantic proportions. An immense and excited crowd is in attendance, and the illumination is nearly universal and brilliant beyond anything ever seen in the West. All the public buildings and a vast number of stores and dwellings are ablaze with fantastic devices. In the dome of the State-House four locomotive head lights are blazing, clearly visible for many miles.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 23.-The boiler of Chemical Works exploded, demolishing a portion of the wall, and seriously injuring two persons.

The only movement of consequence in the Burch divorce case to-day was the filing of a number of depositions on behalf of Mrs. BURCH. One of the most interesting is that of Rev. Mr. PATTERSON, relative to certain correspondence between himself and Mrs. BURCH.

Brown vs. Dawson.-Yesterday this case was resumed. Its character is well known, because of the publicity which has been given to the details on which the suit is based.

The screw steamship Glasgow, from Liverpool at noon of the 7th inst., and Queenstown on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. The Glasgow, brings Queenstown papers of the 8th inst., which contain a few items of fresh European intelligence. The general news has been anticipated by the arrival of the Vanderbilt.
The Court came into session at 9 o'clock. After calling the Jury the case was opened for the complainant by Mr. MILLER, and for the defence by Mr. BECKWITH. The speeches occupied the morning session.

It seems to be generally understood that President BUCHANAN does not assent to the theory of peaceful secession. He holds with every man of national reputation, who has ever expressed his opinion upon the subject, that the Constitution is binding upon the several States, and that no one State has a right to abolish it.

The Board of Education, last evening, received a communication from several Fourth Ward school teachers, setting forth that they had renderd two months' service under contract, and asking the Board to provide for their compensation. These teachers are said to have been illegally appinted. They claim that though their contracts may be null, they are entitled in equity to their salaries. It was referred to the Committee on Teachers' Salaries.

The steamship Palestine from Liverpool on the 8th via Londonderry on the 9th inst. arrived at this port at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The Palestine's dates are one day later than those already received.

THE OFFICIAL CANVASS. The official vote of Kings County shows that 36,456 votes were cast. The Fusion ticket received 20,583, and the Repub lican ticket 15,883. Fusion majority 4,700 OBELL's (Fusion) majority for Congress, in the Second District, is 2,452.

The revolution in Sonora progresses slowly, but with great destruction to life and property. About ten days since 200 Yaguies were killed by the Pesquiera troops under CACHORA. It appears that the party known as the Ganiora party, after they entered the State, received large additions to their force, until they numbered over two thousand men.

AN INHUMAN ACT. In the early part of Tuesday evening a little girl found a female infant about two months old in a vacant lot near the rolling-mill in the Fourth Ward, Jersey City. The child was taken care of for the night by one of the neighbors, and yesterday was sent to the Almshouse.

The Brokers' Circular reports the sales in the Liverpool COTTON market for the week at 95,000 bales, of which 41,000 bales were on speculation and 8,000 bales to exporters.

The first business before Judge GOULD, yesterday, was the disposal of the case of John F. Williams, indicted for the murder of his wife. He had previously pleaded not guilty, but now withdrew his plea and changed it to guilty of manslaughter in the first degree. Counsel asked that the Court would deal leniently with the prisoner, as his intellect had been impaired by the previous habits of his life.

Boston has its panic! Not a regular New-York flare-up in Stock-markets, and a general smash-up of heavy men and their light attendants, but a deliberate, well-considered, and carefully-arranged financial crisis. We do not do things here as you do in Gotham; the old Money-Bags of State-street are not the speculative, risky operators of Wall-street; our most stupid "Bulls" seldom make a "bad" financial bull, and the "Bears" are seldom bitten.

This movement is generally commended in the localities immediately interested, and has had the effect to give more confidence in business circles. The

THE GREAT ROWING MATCH. The great rowing match with shell-boats, between Wm. H. DECKER and ANDREW FAY, took place yesterday afternoon, from the Jersey City Yacht Club House, foot of Van Vorststreet, in which Fay came out victorious. Between two and three thousand persons a large proportion of them from New-York and Brooklyn were present. It was a match for $250 a side.

The public will do well to resume a habit much practiced three or four years ago, of discounting some sixty per cent. of rumors coming from Kansas. That we are on the eve of a repetition of the drama which at that time so agitated the country there is reason to apprehend. The opening scenes have much the same character.

The adjournment of the Burch trial from Saturday until to-day, at 2 P.M., left your correspondent to a Sunday seclusion in this quiet city. I say city, because, although in one of my letters it was labeled and libeled as a village, it is, nevertheless, dignified with the metropolitan title.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the Winter of 1856 I was in Kansas, and there had opportunity to learn the dissatisfaction then felt by the people with their "Territorial Kansas Committee," touching the distribution of relief raised East and sent into the Territory.

The Committee appointed by the state Senate, during its last session, to examine and report in relation to Central Park management, met at the Astor House yesterday morning, Senator JOHN McLEOD MURPHY in the the Chair. Mr. JULIUS KELLERSBERGER testified that he was a civil engineer, of twenty-four years' experience, and a citizen of the United States. He was requested to embody his knowledge of Central Park affairs in a communication to the Committee.

The New Mexican Mail arrived this evening, a day behind time, having been detained by heavy snow storms from Santa F w the crossing of the Arkansas river, and from there the roads are in very bad condition.
The Republican Conventions in the four Councilmanic Districts met last evening.

The first business in this Court yesterday was the case of Franz Hoffman, indicted for murder. The jury had been impanneled on Wednesday, but the District-Attorney now consented to the withdrawal of a juror, and the case went off. The reasons for this course were given by Mr. Brady, who had been assigned as the prisoner's counsel. Until recently he had not had an opportunity to advise with his client, who does not speak English.

We have received a great many communications denouncing the Herald for its systematic endeavors to aggravate the existing sectional and financial excitements of the country. We must decline to publish them. It is quite as much as we can do to manage our own journal, without undertaking, in addition, the management of our neighbor's.

The United States steamship Bienville, J.D. BULLOOK, Commander, from New-Orleans on the 15th and Havana on the afternoon of the 18th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. The Bienville had a strong northerly gale from Hatteras up, and passed an unusually large number of vessels bound to the northward, but none within signal distance.

A caucus meeting was held at the capitol this afternoon for the purpose of appointing delegates for the city and county of Montgomery, to the Conven- tion to be held in January. As the choice of these delegates is probably equivalent to their election, and as this meeting will illustrate the feeling of the vicinity, it may not be without interest to give it a more than passing notice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having seen a number of statements in regard to Kansas suffering. I am constrained, by a sense of duty, to offer my testimony for the cause of humanity. On Friday night, Nov. 9, the new Lord Mayor of London, (Right Hon. W. CUBITT, M.P.,) entertained, according to custom, Her Majesty's Ministers, the Foreign Ambassadors, (of which only the Representatives of France and Sardinia were present,) the Judges of the land, the Ex-Ministers, the Corporation, and a distinguished company, at the Guildhall, which was magnificently decorated for the occasion.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge RUSSELL, Ex-Alderman Wilson was brought forward for sentence, upon a conviction of having assaulted Alderman Russell. The Court remarked that but for the intercession of the complaining witness, and for the heavy damages ($5,000) which had been obtained in a civil suit, the sentence would have been severe. It would now be merely nominal a fine of six cents.

The old-establshed private banking house of HARRIS SONS suspended to-day, in consequence of depreciated stocks. This house has withstood the financial pressures of many years, and has always been regarded with the fullest confidence at home and abroad. The extent of their liabilities is unknown. There is some hope that an extension will be granted, as the proprietors are highly honorable men.

Among the passengers by the steamer Alabama from Savannah was Mr. JAMES SINCLAIR, a native and lifetime resident of this City. The account which he gives of his reception and treatment by the hospitable citizens of Savannah is interesting, as showing the fraternal feeling evinced by them towards all people who have the misfortune of hailing from NewYork.

Two men named POPE and FUNK, employes of Mr. DAVISON, about 17 miles above here on the Platte, came in to-day, and reported that a party of fifteen Indians, supposed Cheyennes, had run them from Elm Creek yesterday. When near the road one Indian rode up to the ox team POPE was driving, and snapped his gun at him, then drew his lance.

The United States corvette Cumberland, which arrived at this port a few days since to receive her armament, left the Battery yesterday, and will sail today to join the Home Squadron. On her arrival at the head-quarters of the fleet, Flag-Officer RANDOLPH, now of the Pawnee, will transfer his wide flag, and the character of the flag ship.

Commodore VANDERBILT has been routed from the Battery. Judge HOGEBOOM, of the Superior Court, has made the recent injunction perpetual, thus leaving the Commodore the pressing necessity of removing his incipient pier at the earliest moment.

A meeting of the Directors of the several banks of this city was held this morning. The subject of suspension was agitated. Finally the Bank of the State, the Bank of South Carolina, Southwestern Railroad Bank, and the State Bank, resolved to suspend and accordingly suspended.
There can be no difference of opinion on the great importance of establishing direct trade between Charleston and Liverpool, or any other country with which we can exchange commodities.

GOWDEY was elected Chairman, and ABRAM TALLMAN, Secretary FREDERICK A. TUCKER, Alderman BRADY, AUGUSTUS F. Dow. Councilman LENT and others made addresses. Resolutions indorsing the nomination were unanimously adopted, and the meeting adjourned with enthusiastic cheers for the Alderman.

The fact that BEECHER lives in Brooklyn is pretty well known. That BEECHER preaches in Brooklyn is also pretty generally understood. But that BEECHER actually constitutes Brooklyn is a truth at which few people have arrived. It is a truth, nevertheless. He is a necessity to Brooklyn, not a luxury. Brooklyn without BEECHER would be like one of the ferry-boats without an engine like our City Hall without its cupola.

The members of St. Andrews Society, who have put bread into the mouths of many Scotch widows and orphans, celebrated the 104th Anniversary of the Association, last evening, by dining together at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

Interesting intelligence has been received at the Indian Office, from New-Mexico. The volunteers have been quite successful in the Navajo Campaign, killing many Indians and taking a large amount of stock and some prisoners. The Peublo Indians, who went out with the volunteers, had returned, bringing a number of horses, sheep and prisoners. They also killed some Navajoes.

Coroner HORTON impanneled a jury of twele men yesterday to hold an inquest on the body of PATRICK KELLY, who was murdered at No. 215 Frontstreet, Thursday night, by Charles McCAULEY. The Jury, after viewing the body of deceased, adjourned until two o'clock to-day, without hearing any testimony.

The Legislature met at 7 o'clock last night There being a full attendance of members, both Houses at once proceeded to business. In the Senate, Mr. ALSTON, from the Military Committee, submitted a report and bill, which were read and made the order of the day for to-day.

The support so long furnished the Clerical Party in Mexico by the British Government is producing its natural fruits. The intrigues of Mr. OTWAY, the English resident, for more than eighteen months sustained the factions of ZULOAGA and MIRAMON at the capital against the most strenuous attacks of the Liberals; while the refusal of the Legation at all times to recognize the Juarez Government has given great additional moral power to the reactionary party.

The present Fugitive Slave Law is a detestable one. Its vindictive feature were designed to insuit and degrade us. But a proper and efficient Fugitive Slave Law is a requirement of the Constitution; and we are as much bound to observe and obey such a law, as South Carolina is to observe and obey any other provision of the Constitution.

CITY MORTALITY. The report of the City Inspector for the week ending Saturday last, gives 409 as the number of deaths during that time, of which 103 were men; 92 women; 102 boys; and 112 girls; being an increase of 40 over the mortality of the preceding week, and 28 over that of the corresponding week in 1859. Of the number 193 were under 5 years of age.

WALLACK'S THEATRE The genius of MOLIERE gave a hypocrite to the world, and named him Tartuffe. In France he is the representative hypocrite, while on the English stage, Charles Surface is but a meagre member of the family. In short Tartuffe is the hypocrite, par excellence, on the stage, and off it.

At the suggestion of many leading clergymen of different denominations in this City and Brooklyn, a prayer-meeting was held at noon yesterday (the hour for the assembling of Congress) at Rev. Dr. ADAES' Church, in Madison-square, to supplicate the Divine blessing upon our National Councils, and to ask for the Devine interposition in the present distracted state of the country.

Secretary TOUCEY says that the Board of Officcers appointed under an act of last session to examine the sailing vessels of the Navy, to determine the expediency of converting them into efficient war steamers, examined all the brigs, sloops, frigates and shipsof-the-line at the Navy-Yards from Kittery, Maine, to Gosport, Va. The character of those at sea being well known, from the records of the Department, they were included in the opinion of the Board.

The United States vs. Rudolph Bloomenberg. The defendant in this cause was put on trial charged with perjury in having sworn as a surety on the bonding of the bark Orion, which was seized as a slaver some time since.

Every Isthmian Steamer brings almost the same story from New-Granada. Month after month the same scenes are enacted and reenacted there. Now the Government party have gained an advantage which is announced from official quarters, as a crowning victory; now their opponents are conquerors, and we are assured that the flight of President OSPINA from the Federal capital may be expected within a week. Just at present our NewGranadian advices come to us filtered through.

The question of disunion was still further debated in the Senate yesterday. After some unimportant preliminary business, Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, introduced a resolution instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the propriety of establishing an armed police in border States, to maintain the general peace and to execute more effectually the Fugitive Slave law. On motion of Mr. CAMERON, of Pennsylvania, it was made the special order for Monday next.

The long-anticipated and much talked-of fight between JOHN WOODS, of Boston, and GEO. KING, from this City, came off early yesterday morning at Bull's Ferry, N.J., (the same ground that CLARKE and HORRIGAN fought on.) for a purse of $300, and after fiftyfive rounds were fought, WOODS was declared the victor, KING having "dropped" foul to avoid a blow.

The Electors assembled in the Capitol to-day at 10 o'clock. The Breckinridge Electors, believing that BELL had carried Virginia, magnanimously resigned, whereupon the vote of the State was cast for BELL and EVERETT. A grand dinner will be given to the Electors to-night at the Exchange Hotel.

The United States vs. Ten Cases, marked J.H.S., containing Petticoating.--This action was brought to forfeit the goods for undervaluation. It was brought to trial in February, 1858, before Judge Hall, who was holding the Court at that term, and a Jury. There was no evidence of a fraudulent undervaluation on the part of the importers, except the evidence of the Custom-house appraisers that the goods were worth more than was stated in the invoice.

The Committee on the Judiciary had under consideration to-day the case of Judge WATROUS, of Texas. Much testimony has been adduced, tending so strongly against him that it is understood they will report soon in favor of his impeachment. Gov. HOUSTON is understood to have done much to bring about this result. I am told by a gentleman from Texas that WATROUS is understood to sympathize with the secession movement in Texas.

Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, (Rep.,) from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a bill making appropriation for the payment of the invalid and other pension; also, a bill for the surport of the West Point Military Academy. Referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union.

The Georgia Senate has rejected the bill calling a Convention of Southern States. This is received as an indication of the intention of Georgia to secade separately.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The Artists' combination, inaugurated at a critical period, for the purpose of sustaining Italian opera when even its friends appear to be desorting it, will give their first performance tonight. The opera selected for the occasion is AURER'S "Masaniello," in which the principal characters will be adequately sustained, we may reiy upon it, by Mme. FABBRI, Mons. STIGELLI and Herr FORKES.

Our reports from Washington this morning are interesting. During the adjourment of Congress speculation turns upon the House Special Committee on the Condition of the Union, and the probable course which will be pursued by it. It seems to be generally understood that the members of the Committee will act simply as spokesman for their respective delegations, and under their advice.

Austin Shuman vs. Michael McKeon. This is an appeal to the General Term of this Court, from a judgement in ejectment. The action was originally tried before Judge Pierrepont, under whose direction the jury found a verdict for the defendant. The original action was to eject the defendant, as lessee of George Harrison, from certain premises on the southeast corner of Bleeoker and Grove streets, in this City.

The Legislature did but little business yesterday, the largest portion of the day having been devoted to the College Commencement. In the Senate, a revolution was agreed to that when the body adjourn at 12 noon on the 13th December, it take a recess until the second Monday in January. It will be sent to the House to-day, buy it is generally supposed it will not be concurred in.

The New-Mexican mail, with dates to the 19th qlt., arrived to-day in time to connect with the mail going East this morning. The mail was detained by very deep snow and excessively cold weather. The Kiowa Indians stopped the mail at McKnees' Creek, and kept them half a day. Their object, they said was to make peace; and they could wipe out the party, but did not feel so disposed.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, which sailed from Liverpool at 8 A.M. on the 24th, and from Queenstown on the 25th ult., arrival at this port last evening.

By dint of unceasing and persevering labor continued day and night, the mass of earth and rock over the broken pipes was cleared away at an early hour yesterday morning, and the extent of the damage as certained. Two lengths of pipe were broken short off, the deplacement of which it is expected will be completed during to-day, and a full supply of water furnished before night.

HIGHLY COMPLIMENTARY. We learn that the Mexican papers, several numbers of which have been issued as a serial by Mr. EDWARD E. DUNBAR, of this City, and formerly the Mexican correspondent of the TIMES, are attracting much attention in Mexico. We see it stated that the Constitutional Government is having the publication translated into Spanish, and taking measures to give it a wide circulation throughout the Mexican Republic.

At a meeting of the Century Club of this City, last week, LANO exhibited and oil-study of his forthcoming picture of MARY, Queen of Scots, heretofore spoken of in the TIMES. The subject is one which has not hitherto been treated by any artist of ability, and all who have been privileged to view the study congratulate Mr. LANG on the selection and treatment of a subject at once original, striking and interesting.

Messrs. D. BELL, Son Co., state that the market for American Securities, during the past week, has shown much animation, and some large transactions have taken place in the various Federal and State Stocks. There have also been some large purchases of Pennsylvania Central, Michigan Central and NewYork and Erie Railroad Bonds, and the market closed with firmness.
The Canal is practically closed. A few boats are being still pressed toward their destination; out no new clearances will be issued, and no additional tolls received.

Rev. J.C. FLETCHER ON SWITZERLAND Another of those entertaining lectures of Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, was delivered last evening, at Cooper Institute, before another large and interested audience. His theme was Switzerland, and he considered it with the same clearness of conception, elegance of diction and purity of pronunciation which have characterized all his recent public efforts.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Of this country, as of the other Central American States, we have knwon comparatively little, save as they have been agitated by internal revolution, or been the scene of of foolish or fillibustering expeditions. Honduras, however, has been free from many of the evils which have afflicted her sister Republies. She has been more secluded, less aspiring, while she has been blessed with a more stable government.

In April, 1859, the Legislature of the State authorised the addition to the Central Park, as then laid out, of the ground lying between. One Hundred and sixth and One Hundred and Ninth streets, and the Fifth and Eight avenues, and during the Summer of that year Commissioners were appointed by the Superme Court to award damages and lay assessments for the property taken for the Park, as well as that benefited by it.

Charles Geiser vs. Henry Bretter. This was an action against the defendant, a constable, to recover damages for an alleged neglect to foreclose a chattel mortgage, placed in his hands for that purpose in April of 1858.

By the explosion on board the Spanish frigate Berenguela, in the Dry Dock at the Navy-yard, Thursday night, three men only were seriously injured. There was no powder on board, as has been stated, except two charges which had just been drawn by a soldier named RAMON. These charges RAMON bad in a "passing box" and was conveying it to the magazine.

Business of all kinds, except the retail trade, continues not only dull, but there is absolutely little or nothing doing. All our staples are declining rapidly under the influence of the deranged money market, and he is a wise man indeed who can tell when the bottom will be reached. Everybody seems determined to wait and see.

Mr. BUCHANAN'S Message does not suit South Carolina; "on the contrary, quite the reverse." The declared intention of the President to enforce the revenue laws she regards as certain evidence of a hostile purpose, which, carried into effect, she will consider an act of war.

A mass meeting to consider the issues of the day, way held at Vicksburg, Miss., on the afternoon and evening of the 29th ult. The Whig says: "It was a magnificent and triumphant success. Notwithstanding the slanders which had been circulated about it that it was a 'submission,' a 'Union-at-any-price' gathering, c., the people came to it, and it was the largest demonstration known in the State since the memorable canvass of "51."

It must be confessed that the aspect of public affairs at Washington is particularly gloomy. The Southern caucus held on Saturday evening is said to have shown that the Representatives of the Cotton States are unanimous in the opinion that secession is inevitable. Mr. COBB will probably withdraw .
Yesterday the Electoral College of this State convened at the Capitol, and organized for the transaction of business. Of the fifteen Electors, six Breckin-...
SIR: I have had the honor to receive your note of the 17th, and I now reply to the grave questions therein propounded as fully as the time allowed me will permit.

FIFTEENTH DAY MORNING SESSION. Mr. Miller proceeded with his summing up for the complainant. He called attention to the time when Mr. Bunch, Mrs. Thomas Burch and Miss Fannie Burch were at Burlington, and the evidence as to Stuart's visits to Mrs. Burch at that time. Stuart stayed an hour and a half alone with Mrs. Burch on that occasion.

In compliance with orders from the Navy Department, a survey was yesterday held on the U.S. sloopof-war Savannah, by naval officers, and a statement of her exact condition will be forwarded to Washington without delay.

Capt. HALL, the Commander of the Arctic Expedition which bears his name, has written the following letter to HENRY GRINNELL, Esq. It is without date, but the circumstance which it narrates will indicate the time at which it was written with sufficient certainty:
From this Report we find that 190 Army invalids have been added to the Pension rolls during the past year, and that 62 hove had their pensions increased.

The idea of a general Southern Convention appears so far quite unacceptable to some of our Union organs and leaders. Mr. PRENTICE and his associates denounce the notion of submitting a Southern ultimatum to the North by the united South in Convention.
The question is made in our commercial circles, how shall a South Carolina ship carry on commerce with foreign nations, after the State has seceded from the Union.

The Boston Courier has an able editorial condemning the spirit, in which Senators HALE, of New-Hampshire, and IVERSON, of Georgia, opened a discussion of the subject of secession last week. In the course of that article the Courier says:
Hon. J.A. Godfrey, C.P. Walcott, of Ohio; G. W. Claftin, of Boston, and W. Cameron, of Liverpool, England, are stopping at the Fifth avenue Hotel.

The artists' combination at the Academy will give their second performance to-night, and will try once more to keep alive the failing fires on the altar of Music. FLOTOW'S charming and seldom performed opera of "Stradella" will be given with FORMES in a part originally written for him, and STIGELLI and Mme. INEZ FABBRI in roles admirably adapted to their talents.

While the most conservative Congressmen freely express the belief that there is no prospect whatever of preventing other States iron following the secession example of South Carolina, others are hopeful that something may yet be done in the way of compromise, and which may at least preserve the Border Slavehotding States in the Union with the non-Slaveholding States.

A German baker, named AUGUSTUS STURMAN, doing business at No. 285 South Third-street, Jersey City, was run over by the-6 o'clock Central Railroad train from New-York, Saturday morning, and sustained serious injuries. Mr. STURMAN was crossing from Henderson-street over the railroad track, and after passing Mr. HOPE'S store, he recollected nothing further. He became conscious some two hours after.

By the mail that came in last evening, we are in reception of a file of your semi-weeklies, giving the first account that has reached us of the arrival of the Japanese Embassy in the Atlantic States. No one can possibly be more interested than ourselves in the good results to both countries that has been hoped would follow the late interchange of messages of peace and good will between them.

It is a curious thing that two of the principal representatives of the "British" drama, or melodrama, in London at this moment, should be a French actor and actress one at the Lyceum and the other at the Princess Madame CELESTE and M. FECHTER.

By the bark La Plata, Capt. CROWELL, arrived yesterday, we have dates to Oct. 24. The La Plata brings home as passengers Commander Thomas I. Page, U.S.N.; Lieut. R.R. Carter, U.S.N.: Lieut. O.F. Johnson, U.S.N.; Jacob Dungan, Passed Assistant Surgeon; John W. Tynan, Third Assistant Engineer, and four men belonging to the La Plata Expedition.
Lieut.-Col. Hardee, of the U.S. Army; G.P. Moores and lady, of Baltimore; Col. Crocker, of Milwaukeel C.H. Rundell, and Paul J. Semmes, of the U.S. Army, are at athe Fifth-avenue Hotal.

The session of Congress, yesterday, was attended with far less excitement than we were led to anticipate, from the tenor of our dispatches of Sunday night. The discussions upon all topics connected with the subject of secession were conducted with calmness, and altogether a decidedly better feeling was exhibited on every side.
Nathan Smith VS. Haskett S. Smith at al. This action is brought to recover a balance due formerchandise sold by the plaintiff.

On Saturday night about 8 o'clock, Officer O'CONNELL, of the First Ward, found a German sailor named HENRY BENATUS lying upon the sidewalk in Albany-street. Believing him to be drunk, the Policeman conveyed the man to the Police Station, ...
The steamship Bienville brings Havana advices of the 7th inst.

The Washington Constitution has made the astounding discovery that, in all their suggestions for conciliation and compromise, the Republicans manifest a "dogged determination to keep the North in possession of the ground it has gained by the election of LINCOLN." That innocent, high-toned advocate of harmony evidently thinks it very unreasonable on the part of the Republicans, that they do not forthwith force Mr. LINCOLN to resign...
The will of Jane Augusta Blankman, alias Fanny White, was now offered for probate, and is contested by two sisters, and the children of a deceased sister.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived from Vera Cruz, 7th inst. The advices from the Capitol are to fire 28th ult. The Liberals were completely investing the City of Mexico. Distress from scarcity of food and water was very great. The main army had not come up.

We have shown the commercial relations existing between the North and South to be necessary sequences of laws or conditions, entirely independent of political relations or boundaries. The South can never be a maritime people; and not for the present generation, a manufacturing one.

The annual election of the Representatives of the New-York Fire Department, was held last evening at Fireman's Ball. Full delegations were, in attendance from all the Companies in the City. Wx. A. WOODHULL, the President, occupied the chair. The Wade tables Committee reported that the expense of the cenotaph was $885.72, which amount had been fully subscribed and paid. The report was accepted, and a vote of thanks tendered to the Committee.

A telegraphic dispatch was forwarded about 12 o'clock on Sunday night to Police Superintendent KENNEDY, from Susquehannah Station on the Erie Railroad, giving information of the arrest at that place on Sunday forenoon, of a young man supposed to be the murderer of Mrs, SUSAN SHANCKS, at No. 22 East Twelfth-street, on Friday morning last.

GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Friday, Nov. 16, 1860. On Sunday the Pony arrived from From Fort Kearney in four days, three hours and fifty minutes. He would probably reach Carson in three more days. The news brought was that LINCOLN'S election was safe.

FIFTEENTH DAY AFTERNOON SESSION. The general anxiety to hear Mr. Beckwith's summing up for the defence, caused the Court-room to be crowded this afternoon, an unusually large number of ladies being among the audience apparently an indication of public sympathy with Mrs. Burch. After the buzz of conversation had subsided, a tardy juror arrived, and comparative quiet been restored, the argument began.

-Late advices from the Rio de la Plata inform us that the National Convention of the Argentine States has completed its labors, and that Buenos Ayres has been readmitted to the Confederation. The final act of union was consummated on the 21st of October last, when the Governor of the ex-rebellious province took an oath to support the Government of the reunited Confederacy.

CITY MORTALITY. The City Inspector reports that the number of deaths in the City during the week ending on Saturday last, was 338, viz; Men, 81; women, 81; boys, 82, and girls, 94 being a decrease of 71 on the week previous, and less 73 than during the corresponding week of 1859, of whom 141 were under 5 years of age.
There was a full attendance of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, the President in the Chair.

The Albany Allas and Argus pronounces the letter we published a few days since from a lady in South Carolina, describing the apprehensions felt there in regard to a slave insurrection, to be a fabrication. The only warrant for such a belief seems to have been the necessity of making a point against the Republicans. The imputation is as false as it is impertinent.
The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company VS. James W. White. This is an action on prommisory notes of the defendant, who is a justice of the Superior Court.
The California Pony express passed here at 5 o'clock this morning, and left the following to be telegraphed to the Associated Press:

The Belmont Branch of the State Bank of Ohio at Bridgeport VS. William Hoge and Thomas Hoge. This action was originally tried before Justice BOSWORTH, the Chief-Justice of this Court, and a Jury, on the 18th day of June, 1860, upon the facts found, and, upon the charge of the learned Judge, the Jury found a verdict for the defendants.

Mrs. Polk, the widow of the Ex-President, has Presented to Mr. A. Nelson, City Revenue Collector in Nashville, Tenn., a cane which was given her husband by some of his friends during his term of office. The gift is understood to be simply a testimonial of Mr. Nelson's official fidelity.

Yesterday, Capt. George F. Lemon, who recently commanded a steamboat plying between this City and Long Branch, was arrested upon an affidavit made by Mrs. Ophelia Taylor, widow of the late Joseph S. Taylor, formerly Street Commissioner of this City, charging him with having ruined her, under the declaration that he was a single man, and a promise of marriage. Since the accomplishment of his purpose.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. If there were any consistency in an operatic public, it would seize with avidity the opportunity to hear a gay and lively opera like "Stradella," on a wet and dreary night like that which awaited its production yesterday evening.
After prayer, the journal was read. On motion of Mr. BIGLER. of Pennsylvania, (Dem.,) the Standing Committees oflast session were ordered to be continued.
The motion to excuse Mr. HAWKINS, of Florida, (Dem.,) from service on the Select Committee of Thirty-three, to take into consideration the perilous condition of the country coming up

Petition of Allan Hays to Vacate the Assessment for Regulating and Paving Second-avenue. This is as application to the Court by the petitioner, who is a property owner upon Second-avenue, to have the assessment for regulating and paving the same set aside or vacated upon the ground of a "legal irregularity," and for an alleged fraud.

The West Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church (Rev. FREDERICK G. CLARK, Pastor) was found to be on fire at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening last. The organ was entirely destroyed, and considerable damage done to adjacent parts of the church. The property was insured for upwards of $20,000. The damage, therefore, is amply covered, the chief misfortune being, that the congregation will be deprived of their place of worship for a few months.

Some of the City papers have commented on the fact that the slaver Cora was once owned by E.D. MORGAN Co., in a way to cost upon that firm some degree of responsibility for her recent employment. This fact renders proper the publication of the following letter which was sent by them to the United States District Attorney in May last:

Mr DEAR SIR: I have been endeavoring to make an opportunity for some days past, to answer your very friendly and seductive letter, but my whole time, day and night, has been so constantly occupied with matter that could not be postponed, that until the present, I have been compelled to defer it and even now I must be brief.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Dec. 10, 1860 6 P.M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of pro duce, since our last, have been: 11 bbls. Ashes, 24,078 bbls. Flour, 24,001 bushels Wheat, 40,212 bushels Corn, 7,720 bushels Barley. 3,611 bushels Oats 4,410 bushels Malt, 659 pkgs. Provisions, and 268 bbls. Whisky.

The deep interest in Mr. BECKWITH'S summing up for the defence, and the general commendation of the opening of his speech, yesterday, caused the Court-room to be again crowed this morning the number of ladies being about the same as yesterday.

JOHN WILSON, second mate, and HANS OLSEN, third mate, of the bark Cora, were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner MORELL for examiniation upon the charge of voluntarily serving on board of a slaver. The first mate, MORGAN FREDERICKS, escaped from custody on Sunday night, while the vessel was lying at anchor at the Navy-yard.

At noon yesterday, Capt. CAFFREY, of the Fif teenth Ward, arrived in this City, having in custody ARTHUR BUCHANAN, the young carpenter against whom strong suspicions are entertained of being the murderer of Mrs. SHANCKS. BUCHANAN, it will be remembered, was apprehended in the town of Susquehanna, Penn., on Saturday night last, on account of his suspicious actions, and word was immediately sent to Superintendent KENNEDY, who forthwith directed.

John A. Harbeck et al. vs. Jacob H. Vanderbilt et al. It appears from the papers in this case that on the 13th of October, 1854, the defendants Decker and Brown, recovered a judgement, on a joint contract against these plaintiffs, the defendent Vanderbilt and others, for the sum of $2,328,15.

The New-Jersey State Convention of "all national men in favor of Constitutional Union measures," called "to consider the condition of national affairs, and concert such measures as may be deemed advisable," in the present crisis, brought together a large assemblage in the Assembly Chamber of the State House at this place to-day. At noon,

Our Washington dispatches announce that Hon. JAMES B. GUTHRIE of Kentucky, has been tendered, and has accepted, the post of Secretary of the Treasury in place of Mr. COBB. It is understood that the place was first offered to Hon. L. 0'B. BRANCH, of North Carolina, but that he declined it.
James H. Hervy et al. vs. John Kerr. This was an appeal from a judgment rendered at Trial Term of the Court, before Justice HOFFMAN.

In this Court, yesterday, before Judge BALCOLM, the only business transacted was the trial of Daniel Finley for the murder of his wife, on the 7th of October last. The Jury were impanneled with no difficulty, and the trial proceeded, the defence being, conducted by James T. Brady, Esq.

The political feeling is becoming more settled. The first flush of the South Carolina movement threatened for a time to carry us off our feet, and whirl us into Dissolution. But the sober second thought has us in its keeping now, and you may depend upon it, whatever other States may do, we shall not rush wildly from our sphere in the galaxy of States.
The Breckinridge men condemn Mr. BOTTS severely for too much conservatism.
Four hundred men are said to be engaged in strengthening the fortifications at Fort Sumpter. The heavy guns are being rapidly placed in position. Castle Pinckney is being put in order.

You have had so much in the way of panic-dispatches, blood and thunder manifestoes, and alarums of all sorts, that it is due to justice that your readers should have a candid statement of the true condition of affairs as they appear to the writer from a standpoint where he has had opportunities for observation shared by very few.

SIXTEENTH DAY AFTERNOON SESSION. Mr. Hoyne proceeded with his argument. He proceeded to consider the case as if Stuart's evidence was not in it, for the purpose of showing that all the separate acts of intimacy proved were sufficient to present a cage where the jury were bound to infer that acts of criminality had occurred. The position and rank of Mrs. Burch was such as not to make her so subject to fall.
I have recently traveled through all the principal cities of Georgia, and find the disunion feeling everywhere overwhelmingly in the ascendant.
Mr. GUTHRIE has been tendered, and has accepted, the Treasury Department. It was tendered to Mr. BRANCH, of North Carolina, but was declined by him.

Jokn Wilmot et al. vs. Thos. Richardson et al. This cause was tried before the late Chief Justice OAKLRY, in 1855, and a verdict was then found for the plaintiffs. The General Term, however, set aside the verdict, and it next came before Chief Justice WOODRUFF, who granted a motion of non-suit against the plaintiffs. A motion for new trial now comes before this Court.

In our issue of last Monday we called attention to the fact, that all the incidents attending the butchery of Mrs. SHANCKS, in Twelfth-street, pointed clearly to an insane man as the only possible perpetrator of such a crime.
DEAR MR. TIMES: I am a woman, and therefore ignorant, but I should like to be enlightened.

The bill providing for the election of delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Baton Rouge on the 23d of January, has passed both Houses. In the House a strong effort was made to put the question, Convention, or no Convention?" before the people.

In this Court yesterday, before Recorder BARN ARD, the first case called was that of Jane Hitzibot, a French woman, indicted for larceny, in stealing $50 worth of laces and other goods from her employer, she pleaded guilty to petty larceny, and was sent to the Penitentiary for five months.
Mr. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, (Dem.,) offered an amendment to Mr. MORRILL'S tariff bill, which was referred to the Committee on Finance, with the bill.
The Cunard screw-steamship Kedar, Capt. LITTLE, from Liverpool, on the 27th ult., at 9 A.M., arrived at this port yesterday.

At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, on Thursday, the Comptroller sent in the financial budget for 1861, which was referred to the appropriate Committee, and directed to be printed under the direction of the Comptroller.
In this Court yesterday, before Judge BALCOM, the first business was the continuation of the trial of Daniel Finley, commenced on the previous day, for the murder of his wife.

THE HEENEY ESTATE AGAIN The Heeney estate valued at $1,000,000, more or less, and located in the Sixth Ward was before the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday. The property is in the possession of the Brooklyn Benevolent Society, who claim to hold it under a codicil to will, made in 1844.

Pursuant to a call, signed by many prominent citizens, a public meeting was held at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to adopt measures for the relief of the starving people of Kansas. About 500 ladies and gentlemen were in attendance. W.C. BRYANT was appointed Chairman, and the meeting was formally opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. GILLETTE. The Chairman briefly stated the objects of the meeting, and alluded to the prompt and liberal...

Southern economists seem to labor under the belief that a miraculous virtue belongs to the foreign trade of a nation, the possession of which will infallibly insure commercial prosperity, and that the stagnation and insignificance which are characteristic of most Southern seaport towns are solely attributable to the fact, that the Northern cities have monopolized the whole commerce of the nation with Europe and other countries.

George Herkimer et al. vs. Seymour Tracy et al. This action is brought by the plaintiff, as administrator of John Rice, who died at Brooklyn in September, 1856, for the purpose of recovering the sum of $7,000, paid by certain insurance Companies upon property of the deceased, situated in Yates County.

The Daily News (City Article) says the funds opened this morning at Saturday's prices, but fell in the afternoon upon the news of the NewYork exchange having fallen to 106 , and ceased at a reduction of 1/8@ , notwithstanding intelligence of a fresh rise at Paris. The other markets were steady in the morning, and flat in the afternoon. The principal exception was in Midland Railway stock, which shows a fresh rise.

The President having settled the question in his Message that the Federal Government has no power to Prevent the secession of a State, one great obstacle to the acquisition of the Island of Cuba seems to be removed; and it would not be surprising if Spain should at once conclude a treaty ceding that fine colony to the United States for the moderate sum of two or three hundred millions of dollars.

It is reported currently that TRESCOTT, the Assistant Secretary of State, has resigned, but it is not authenticated. If so, great trouble will arise, as Secretary CASS knows very little or nothing of the details of the office.
The mails from China reached Marseilles on the 25th ultimo, and were due in England on the morning of the Kedar's departure. The following telegrams are published:

There was an animated contest in the Legislature for an election of Governor to-day. The following is the second ballot: Necessary to a choice, 82; Pickens, 53; Johnson, 50; Rhett, 28; Jamieson, 27; Townsend, Barnwell and Chesnut one each; blank, 1. On the first ballot PICKENS and JOHNSON tied. The election was postponed until Wednesday.

Hon. W. L. YANCEY--Dear Sir: You will see from my last letter that I have no faith in the validity or sincerity of the reasons assigned for a secession of the Southern States. The motive for that movement is neither the failure of the North to surrender fugitive slaves, nor the enactment of Personal Liberty bills, nor the practical inability of Southern slaveholders to take their slaves into the Territories of the United States.

In general, our mercantile affairs, we are happy to say, have experienced to material influence from the... news recently received, as is clearly shown by the prices of he principal articles of trade and the statements published by our banks.
The U.S. Mail steamer Philadelphia, Capt. BROWN, from New-Orleans and Havana, arrived yesterday morning at an early hour.
The Speaker, pursuant to an order of yesterday, called the various States for propositions relating to the present condition of the country.

The annual election for Directors of the NewYork Central Railroad was held to-day. HENRY H. MARTIN, of Albany; RICHARD M. BLATCHFORD, of New York; and HAMILTON WHITE, of Syracuse, were elected in place of JOHN L. SOHOOLORAFT, ISAAC TOWNSEND and HORACH WHITE all deceased.

The Pony Express from San Francis County, 1st inst., passed here at 1 o'clock this morning, being ahead of time on the new schedule of reduced speed. By this arrival we have the following news, to the afternoon of Dec. 1.

A movement is on foot, under the auspices of Mayor WOOD, to call a Union meeting for the purpose of staying, if possible, the disunion movement of some of the Southern States. Quite a number of our prominent citizens are engaged in it, and the cooperation of the Common Council has been proposed. The debate on the subject last night was neither very dignified nor judicious.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. DONIZETTI'S lively opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment," was played here on Wednesday night, and attracted a good house the best so far of the season, and a forerunner, we trust, of future success. The performance was, on the whole, a good one, and the applause sufficiently warm and frequent to justify the management in announcing the work for the Matinee an Saturday.

The Coroner's investigation in the case of Mrs. Sarah Shancks, who was murdered on Friday morning last at No. 22 East Twelfth-street, was concluded yesterday--resulting in a verdict against Alfred Buchanan, the young carpenter, who was arrested on suspicion of having committed the crime. The proceedings were conducted at the Fifteenth Ward Station-house, and the large number of persons in attendance attested the great interest which is felt in the case.

McSpedon and Baker vs. Robert T. Haws, Comptroller. This is an application for a writ of mandamus, to compel the Comptroller to draw his warrant upon the Treasury for the sum of $80,000, which sum the relators allege to be due to them under their contract with the Commissioner of Records.

This action is brought for a limited divorce from bed and board. The parties are highly connected in the City, and possessed of some means. They were married in March, 1857, but have not realized that amount of happiness that may reasonably be expected by those of agreeable dispositions when thus united.
In this Court, on Thursday night, the Jury in the case of Finley, after having been out over thirty hours, returned a verdict of murder in the second degree.

A meeting of the stockholders in the Academy of Music was held, last evening, in the Polytechnic Institute, Livingston-street. An organization was effected by electing Mr. PETER C. The China dispatches from Lord ELGIN, the British Ambassador, and Sir HOPE GRANT, the Commanderin-Chief, with their inclosures, fill several pages of the London Gazette. We briefly condense them.

If the situation in which the Papacy finds itself to-day were utterly without precedent in history, as the uproarious episcopal advocates of the Papal throne would have the world believe, it might be more difficult than it now happily is, to discern a way of escape for united Italy from the dilemma to which PIUS IX. and his few European friends are endeavoring to condemn her.
The South American and New-Granadian mails from the interior not being due till to-morrow, I have but little to write to-day.

The Panama Railroad Company's mail steamship Guatemala, from Central American ports, arrived here this morning. She brings dates from Guatemala to Nov. 24, from Salvador to the 26th, Nicaragua to the 30th, and from Costa Rica to the 2d December. The news is unimportant. The Guatemala brings 1,464 ceroons indigo, 3,500 hides, $41,000 in specie, and 24 passengers.

Perhaps the best idea of the comparative magnitude or value of the productions of Northern and Southern States is to be obtained by considering the relative degree of education, industry and training which prevails, and the amount of capital invested in the different branches of industry. Hardly any census will give the total value of articles produced. Such as enter into commerce from different communities are in every unequal...

Democratic institutions are now on their trial in America. It Would be a strange coincidence if the same year should witness the accomplishment of Italian unity under a constitutional monarchy and the disruption of a far mightier Union under the dislocating agency of Federal Republicanism. The audience which attended Rev. J.C. FLETCHER's last lecture the cap-sheaf of the Course, at Cooper Institute, last evening, was as large as those which the announcements of his previous public discourses have invariably called together the exceedingly cold weather to the contrary notwithstanding. Those who gave ear to the caution whispered by the icy Winter's wind, and stayed at home to keep them warm, reckoned without their host.
There can be no doubt that the President has accomplished the object he had in view, in proposing the extraordinary terms of compromise which are contained in his annual message.

The Mayors of New-Orleans and Mobile have found it necessary to vindicate their positions, by issuing proclamations against Vigilance Committees, and other volunteers, who were disposed to assume the administration of the laws. Allerton, c. vs. Delevan, City Inspector, et al. --This case was now argued, counsel contending in support of the motion, that previous to 1849 butchers licenses were issued by the Mayor to those butchers recommended by the Common Council. That consequently when a butcher purchased a stall it was necessary for him to apply to the Common Council for such recommendation.

Schmersahl vs. Mendleson.--The plaintiff brought this action to recover a balance of account alleged to be due on a quantity of flour claimed to have been sold to the defendant. The sum in suit was $221.42.

After a month's parturition the long-looked for and long promised change in the organic law of the Empire has been realized. The "crowning of the edifice," that vague maximum of political perfection so often promised by the Emperor in his moments of magnanimity, has arrived at "the commencement of the end." From the condition of the one-man power we have suddenly passed into, that of the semi-parliamentary.

A private meeting was held on Saturday, at the office of RICHARD LATHERS, Esq., No. 33 Pine-street, to adopt measures for the postponement of Southern action on the subject of Disunion. No persons were admitted except those to whom written invitations had been sent, reporters even from the Press being excluded. The following list of persons invited has been published with the official report of the proceedings:

On Saturday night a deliberate attempt was made to murder John Hughes, a laboring man, living at a tenement house in East Thirty-eighth-street, by one of his neighbors, a German, named John Ruyter. It appeared from what transpired yesterday betore Judge QUACKENBUSH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, that some time since, Ruyter, who is a carpenter, was engaged by Hughes to do some repairing at his house.

The Trustees of Plymouth Church in Brooklyn, received notice from certain quarters that a mob of roughs from this City intended to interrupt the Sabbath evening service, and possibly demolish the building. The same reports has been industriously circulated throughout the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, and great excitement was caused thereby.

Finance are greatly depressed. KIRKLAND, CHASE Co., the largest shipping-house in Baltimore, suspended payment to-day, caused by the decline in coffee, sugar and molasses, an immense amount of which they held. Their liabilities are supposed to be nearly a million of dollars, and the assets nearly equal. It is hoped they may be able to resume.

SUTHERLAND, J. Theodore H. Vetterline vs. Henry Rodwald, Motion granted. The plaintiff to pay into Court the amount admitted by their bill of laterpleader to be in their hands.

DEC. 6. The sales of COTTON in this market for the three days ending yesterday (Wednesday) foot up 19,000 bales, of which 2,500 were taken by speculators and exporters. The market is generally unchanged, and closed dull.

THE $800 ROBBERY. ALEXANDER SCHULTZ, the young man arrested last week on suspicion of having robbed an emigrant named JOHN GEISLER of $800, on the New-York and Erie ferry-boat, was discharged yesterday morning, upon giving bonds in $800 for his appearance at the January term of Court.

The South Carolina State Convention, called to consider the question of seceding from the Federal Union, assembled at Columbia yesterday. Four ballots were had for a permanent President, which resulted in the choice of Gen. D.F. JAMISON, who made a brief address on taking the chair. A resolution was then immediately offered, that when the Convention adjourned it should be to meet in Charleston this afternoon.

We have some further revelations this morning of the character and objects of the meeting held at Mr. LATHERS' office on Saturday last. In another column will be found a very frank avowal of its designs, contained in a letter intended to be private and confidential, addressed by Mr. LATHERS to sundry gentlemen in South Carolina, and asking them to cooperate in its purposes.

ANNIVERSARY OF MISSIONARY AND TRACT SOCIETIES. At the thirty-fourth anniversary of the NewYork City Tract Society, held at Rev. Dr. MACAULEY'S Church, on Sunday evening, it was stated that the receipts of the Society during the year had been $16,205.75, and its expenses $17,109.96, leaving the Society in debt $904.21.

EXOMO SENE.: I have the honor of inclosing to Your Excellency, for the corresponding ends, copies of the Decree of Convocation issued under this date for the election of Representatives and of President of the Republic.

The South Carolina Sovereign Convention assem bled at the Baptish Church at 12 o'clock at noon. After a prayer, Gen. D.F. JAMISON, on motion of Ex-Gov. J.H. ADAMS, was called to the chair. T.Z. SIMONS was appointed temporary Secretary.
The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool on Thursday, Dec. 6, via Londonderry 7th, passed Cape Race at 4 P.M. to-day, (Sunday,) and was boarded by the Press yacht.

Since the triumph obtained by the Liberal army at Guadalajara, operations have been in a measure suspended on the Liberal side for the want of resources, the obstacle that has always embarassed their movements. The campaign against Guadalajara was made and brought to its successful conclusion by the aid of the $800,000 seized by Gen. DEGOLLADO from the conducta, which was proceeding to this place; but

All other questions connected with secession become unimportant, in view of the position of Fort Moultrie, at Charleston. Sixtyfive men, under a gallant and loyal officer, constitute its only garrison, and are instructed to hold it against assault.
The steamer Arizona has arrived here, with Brazos dates of the 13th inst. Business was active.

A heavy and almost obscuring fog hangs like a pall over Columbia, creating a general gloom. The small-pox panic is intense among citizens and strangers. Many members of the Legislature have gone home.

The Supervisors Committee of Inquiry in relation to the county deposits, held another meeting yesterday afternoon, when it was expected the Mayor would be present. After the Committee had been in session some time, Mr. J.B. AULD, the Mayor's Chief Clerk, appeared and stated that the Mayor was engaged presiding at meeting of the Commissioners of Health.

With two or three exceptions, the suggestions of the Evening Journal, having an adjustment of the controversy which threatens to divide the Union, for their object, have elicited from the Republican Press, in this and other States, responses in the spirit of these head lines. That our views encounter the "vigorous resistance" of our political friends, causes less of surprise than of regret.

DEAR SIRS: The grave aspect of the secession movement in your State alarms a large class of your friends in this State, and induces the fear that the usual influence of conservative men, like yourselves, has not been exercised to check undue excitement and to engraft on laudable Southern resistance, more deliberate and timely measures to enforce redress of Southern wrongs.

JOHN WILSON and HANS OLSEN, who stand charged with voluntarily serving on board of the slave bark Cora, underwent a further examination yesterday before United States Commissioner MORRELL. The "Spanish" Captain of the Cora, who is believed to be JOHN LATHAM, to whom the vessel was sold, and who cleared her from the Custom-house, was also present.
Hon. Chauncey Vibbard, of Albany; Dr. T.D. Warren, of N.C., and P.G. Washington, of Washington, D.C.; are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

Since Capt. GIBSON'S return to this city from the States, he has addressed the Tabernacle congregation several times. He seems to have considerable faith in Mormonism, for the present week sees him starting on a mission to the Orient.

MY DEAR SIR: I thank you for your letter of the 8th. We have fallen, indeed, upon evil times. It is too late to look to South Carolina to pause. Indeed I should much doubt the policy of her doing so.

A SPECIAL SESSIONS' CASE IN A HIESES COURT. In this Court, yesterday, the parties were ready for trial in no cases that were called. The only business transacted was in the case of James Drake, indicted for simple assault and battery. The prisoner pleaded guilty, and was sent to the Penitentiary for thirty days. The Court then adjourned to this morning, at 10 o'clock, when the following cases will be taken up:

United States vs. Isaac V. Fowler. This proceeding, which was to restrain the Government from action against Mr. Fowler's surety, on account of the informality of the bond, was postponed until Thursday.

We have been severely censured by Southern journals and their Northern echoes and allies, for assenting to the truth of that part of Mr. BUCHANAN'S Message which ascribes the present excitement in the South to fears of insurrection. The President asserted the fact, and proceeded to ascribe all these outbreaks which menace the peace and security of the South to the machinations of Abolition emissaries from the Northern States.

Mr. Secretary THOMPSON, of the Department of the Interior, has left Washington for Raleigh. He goes as Commissioner from the State of Mississippi to the State of North Carolina, to consult with the authorities of that State in regard to Southern cooperation in the event of secession. He still holds his office under the Federal Government, and is expected to return within a few days.

The United States mail steamship Atlantic, ALFRED S. GRAY, Commander, from Havre and Southampton on the evening of the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. She experienced strong westerly gales, with heavy sea during nearly the whole voyage.

In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, William B. Lilley, indicted for forgery, in passing an altered $1 note, was first tried. The jury, after a long absence, returned and stated that they were unable to agree. They were thereupon discharged, and the prisoner then pleading guilty to forgery in the fourth degree, was discharged under suspended sentence.

The fact that Illinois and her noble sister States of the West have opened their granaries in a flooding stream for the starving thousands of Kansas is widely known. But it is not so generally known, that for several weeks past some thirty thousand bushels of this generously contributed grain have been lying in the hands of Committees and at depots of railroads through the West, for want of sacks in which to transport it.

The Goodyear Elastic Fabrics Company vs. John A. Fischer Aschenberg. A motion for injunction was made in this case to restrain the defendants from infringing the Goodyear Patent by the sale of vulcanized India-rubber elastic goods, manufactured in Europe and imported into the United States by the defendants.

As the Cotton States are placing great dependence upon England as their future customer for their "Great Staple," it may be well for them to read the third annual report of the "British Cotton-Supply Association," from which some extraordinary facts may be learned, showing the great energy and research of that Association, acting under the determination to obtain a full supply of cotton in the future, without dependence upon the product of slave labor.

Margaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief, This was an action for divorce a mensa et thoro, and was stated in the TIMES of the 15th inst. The cause was now summed up and submitted, counsel for the plaintiff contending that a plain case for a limited divorce had been made out.

Senator JOHNSON'S speech to-day was a strong vindication of the supremacy of the Constitution, and a refutation of the asserted right of any State to secede. It was able and impressive, and was listened to with interest. Naturally enough the ultra Southern Senators are dissatisfied with it, as it was severe in its denunciation of Southern ultraism, and left little hope that Tennessee would yield to it. Gen. LANE made a brief reply.

A detachment of U.S. marines arrived in this City yesterday from Washington, and will be transferred to the Brooklyn barracks. They are destined for the guard of the U.S. corvette St. Marys, of the Pacific squadron and will leave with the crew for that vessel in the California steamer on Friday.
British Columbia dates to the 19th ult., per steamer Labouchere, arrived at Victoria, on the 16th, from the Northwest Coast. She brought a large number of furs.
The last regular meeting of the present Board of Education was held last evening, the President, Mr. CURTISS, presiding.

COTTON The Broker's Circular says: "The advices received on Monday, of the heavy money pressure in the United States, caused great dullness here and the demand, for several days, was very limited. Although there was some little revival of inquiry, yesterday, the market was so freely supplied that a decline in nearly all classes of American, of 1/8d, lb., was submitted to." Other descriptions of Cotton are dull, and generally rather easier.

At a meeting of this General Committee, held at Tammany Hail, Monday evening, Dec. 17, 1860, Judge BRENNAN, from the Committee appointed at a former meeting, consiting of Mathew T. Brennan, J. In this Court yesterday, before Judge BALCOM, counsel for James Massy, indicted for felonious assault on a Police Officer, stated that his client had not left the country permanently, but had only gone to New-Jersey to attend a prize fight. He did not intend to shrink from a trial, and would be ready on Monday, for which day the case was therefore set down.

The report of the Secretary of the Interior was received and laid on the table. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, (Dem.,) moved that the President have power to fill the vacancy on the Special Committee occasioned by Mr. DAVIS' resignation. Agreed to.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 21. The TIMES dispatch stating that if the Forts at Charleston should be attacked, they would be surrendered under the orders of the Government, created a good deal of interest here. That such orders have been issued cannot, of course, be positively known,-- but I have a good grounds for believing that they have, and I am quite willing to rely upon the event to bear me out.

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Dec. 21. Great excitement has existed here all day in certain circles, because it was announced that Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER would speak before the sons of New-England this evening. For nearly four months, tragedy, which it was supposed had no more interest for the New-York public, has reigned triumphant in the New-York theatres. The opera, the pet amusement of the Metropolis, hides its diminished head, and the town goes to Niblo's and the Winter Garden.

FORT SCOTT, Tuesday, Dec. 4, 1860. The saying is an old one, that man is the crea ture of circumstances. Never was that fact made more clear and emphatic, than it now is, by changing my position from Linn County to Fort Scott. I here inhale a different atmosphere, and find the public sentiment in a great degree changed.

A few years ago the only mode of getting the produce of the Western States to market was to float it by its own gravity down the Mississippi. To give us the free use of this river and its outlet, and to avoid a constant source of bickering and quarrel with a foreign Power, the territory of Louisiana was purchased. But this did not accomplish all that was needed.

The opening services at the Tabernacle on Sunday evening, had reference to the advent of our Saviour. The house was well filled. The Christmas anthem, "Behold, I bring you glad tidings," was rendered by Mrs. ELLIOT with great effect, and sustained in the chorus by the choir.

Now, if ever, is the time for youthful lovers and elderly admirers to go to housekeeping. If we may judge from the advertisements that crowd our columns, everything is cheap all things are being sacrificed. Holders of desirable personal property seem determined and "contarmed" to almost give it away, and we are really encouraged to believe that the millenial days are approaching, when generosity and unselfishness shall reign in the hearts of all men.

Hon. W.L. YANCEY Sir: In my last letter I gave you my reasons for regarding Secession as simply Revolution, and for believing that it canneither be peaceful nor successful. I propose now to state my understanding of the nature of the contest, and my reasons for hoping that it will not be compromised nor postponed, but finally settled, by whatever process and through whatever tribulations may be necessary.
