John King et al vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. This was an appeal from a judgment of non-suit. On the trial of the cause it appeared that plaintiffs were livery-stable keepers, and on the 20th February, 1860, one of their carriages was standing in Grand-street, near Elizabeth, waiting for fares. It stood there from 2 to 5 o'clock in the morning.

His Majesty's Netherlands steamer Croningen, with the Dutch Ambassador on board, on his way to Siam, arrived on the 25th ten days from Japan. He received a salute of seventeen guns from the Niagara, which was returned with a like number. We encamped here on the 6th. On the same evening the Emperor's Summer palace, Yuen-min-Yuen, was taken possession of, and yesterday Messrs. H.S. PARKES and HENEY LOOH were liberated and returned to the Embassy.

Steamship City of Manchester, (Br.,) Halescaw, Liverpool Dec. 12, and Queenstown 13th, with mdse, and 134 passengers to John G. Dale, arrived off the Battery at 5:40 A.M. Dec. 26, lat. 42 30, lon. 70 40, saw steamship United Kingdom, hence for Glasgow.

THE MAYOR RETURNED. The Mayor, who had been suddenly invoked home by numerous telegraphic dispatches, announcing the action of his locum tenens, and the Board of Aldermen, returned yesterday, and at 2 P.M. was at his desk administering the oaths of office to the newly-elected City officers. It is presumed that he was not specially pleased at the removal of Mr. PLATT, with whom he had a prolonged interview.
A number of petitions were presented. Mr. RICZ, of Minnesota, (Dem.,) presented a resolution, and asked for its reference to the Select Committee of Thirteen. It was so referred, without reading.

An iminense meeting was held to-day, in the street, opposite the Court House, relative to the removal of ordnance South. Gen. Wa. ROBINSON presided. Several speeches were delivered; among others Gen. J.K. MOREHEAD, member of Congress from this District.

Mr. STEVENS, of Washington Territory, (Dem.,) rising to a personal explanation in relation to a special dispatch in a Boston paper, said that the dispatch states that: "It appears upon investigation that the Indian Trust Bonds were stolen for the use of the Central Breckinridge Committee during the late Presidential Election, etc."

Charles McKenna, a young Irishman, engaged in the negro minstrel business at No. 444 Broadway, was apprehended on Wednesday evening by Officers King said Simms, of the Ninth Ward, charged with being a fugitive from justice. It is alleged that on the 20th of October last, the prisoner nearly killed a man named Patric Dononue, whom be encountered in a porter-house corner of Hudson and Thirteenth streets, by stabbing him with a butcher's knife.
The mails by the Canada, whose arrival at Boston has been announced, reached this City yesterday morning.

The telegraphic dispatches announcing that Fort Moultrie had been evacuated and dismantled by Maj. ANDERSON, was bulletined yesterday about noon, and produced considerable sensation. Crowds gathered about the newspaper establishment, impatiently waiting the appearance of the evening papers; and the various bulletins, where the dispatches were posted, were thronged by an excited multitude eager to catch a glance of the particulars. The news from Charleston yesterday created a decided sensation. It was announced that Major ANDERSON had evacuated Fort Moultrie in the night, spiking the guns and taking the garrison to Fort Sumter. Everybody saw at once that this was a military precaution of the greatest importance, and that it secured the continued command of the port of Charleston by the Federal authorities, in spite of any movement on the part of the Disunionists.

WILLIAM COLLISS, HENRY MAY, WILLIAM PRICE, LAMBERT GITTINGS, HENRY WARFIELD, and others, spoke. The meeting was composed of all parties, and there was intense enthusiasm.

It has been the object of strong censure and complaint from some persons writing for the Press. It has just been promulgated.

There seems to be a considerable difference of opinion among the members of the Convention of South Carolina as to the reasons and motives of secession. The Southern secession movement has already had good effects. It has given us a new view of Southern character, while the recent overt act is enabling us to measure more accurately the means and plans of the Secessionists, the magnitude of the difficulties involved, and the manner in which they are to be encountered.

DEAR BEETHREN The President of the United States having designated Friday, the 4th day of January next, to be observed throughout the country as a day of humiliation, fasting and prayer, on account of the calamtities that threaten us, I hereby express my approval of the appointment, and recommend to the Church in this diocess to observe the said day with the usual solemnities of public worship.

The Panola Star, of Mississippi, has the following paragraph: "We wish to suggest the propriety of all slave owners taking some pains to correct a very false impression now prevailing among the negroes about the election of LINCOLN. On Wednesday next the Senate is expected to take up for final action, the bill from the House of Representatives, for the construction of a Pacific Railroad, the measure having been made a special order for that day. The pending bill extends the aid of the Government to the construction of two roads--one by the central and the other by the Texas route.

MY DEAR SIR: South Carolina, after twentyseven years, Mr. RUETT says thirty years, of constant and increasing efforts by her leaders to induce her to secede, has declared herself out of the Union; and this, too, without the slightest wrong or injustice done her people on the part of the Government of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 31. The scene in the Senate to-day was the most intensely exciting that was ever witnessed in that chamber. Senator BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, who, it had been reported, would make a conciliatory speech, gave out that he would make a parting secession speech,--an announcement which drew an immense audience. Every corner was crowded.

New-Year's Calling, according to old-time fashion in New-Amsterdam, is fast becoming a custom more honored in the breach than in the observance. Alexander McKenzie vs. Jane McKenzie.--This case has been frequently stated in the TIMES. It will be remembered that the original suit was brought to recover back a valuable real estate on Broadway, which the plaintiff claimed to have conveyed to his wife, the defendant, while in a state of delirium occasioned by excessive use of spirituous liquors.

The scene in the Senate to-day was the most intensely exciting that was ever witnessed in that chamber. Senator BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, who, it had been reported, would make a conciliatory speech, gave out that he would make a parting secession speech,--an announcement which drew an immense audience. Every corner was crowded.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, S.P. GRIFFIN, Commander, left New-Orleans, Dec. 23, and Havana Dec. 26, and arrived at this port yesterday. The Star of the West has experienced strong head winds from Havana to the Cape.

GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Friday, Dec. 7, 1860. If any people, living in the same latitude, have been favored with a finer spell of weather than we have been enjoying lately at Salt Lake, they certainly have cause to rejoice. Previous to yesterday the time was, perhaps, the finest and mildest, for the season, known in this region since white men first molded Salt Lake prairie clay into adobes.

On Monday the Cabinet assembled at 12 M., to consider the reply to the South Carolina Commissioners, already prepared by the President. Secretary BLACK, Secretary TOUCZY, Attorney-General STANTON and Postmaster-General HOLT sustained the President's views.

Now that rumor is so busy with the alleged movements southward of United States troops and naval vessels, it may not be out of place to give a statement of the forces likely to be ordered for hostile service in South Carolina, should unfortunate circumstances render extreme measures necessary. The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Columbus, Capt. RATHRUN, arrived at Panama on the 21st inst., from Central American parts. The Columbus brought 1,264 ceroons indigo for Europe and the United States, hides, skins, coffee, vinegar, balsem, etc. The news is unimportant.

The judgment pronounced on the receipt of the telegram about the disgraceful affair at Toluca needs strengthening. We have now voluminous details of the entire business, tending to convict the officers in command of the Liberal advanee-guard of the most shameful corruption; and to implicate our old friend DKGOLLADO, who uniformly turns up when any fact of treason or peculation is a-foot.

In this Court, on Saturday, Justice QUACKENBUSH, OSBORN and BERNNAN, disposed of the Calendar as follows: None of the cases having any interest except to the parties concerned. Of thirty one persons charged with assault and battery, fourteen were discharged on account of non-appearance of witnesses, one was allowed postponement, four were remanded, three were fined, seven imprisoned, and two acquitted. Of twenty-one charged with larceny, seven remanded, twelve were imprisoned, and two acquitted.

BEEVES The receipts heavy and the quality exceedingly poor. But little doing, except in lots of a car-load each, and at retail. Prices have declined c. since last week. The top bunches will not bring over 5c., except a few pairs and single bullocks, which brought 5 1/8c.

The Legislature met at Springfield, to-day. The House adjourned without effecting an organization. Gov. WOOD'S Message will probably be delivered tomorrow. In it he recommends a complete reconstruction of the present military plan, by dividing the State into three divisions of batallion, regimental and brigade formation; that the most liberal legislative encoragement be given to the formation of volunteer companies throughout the State.
On Monday the Territorial Legislature assembled for its annual session, in the Social Hall, in this City, and adjourned to meet next day at the County Court House.

TAMMANY SOCIETY. The regular monthly meeting of the Tammany Society was held at Tammany Hall last evening. In the absence of the Grand sachem Wm. D. KENNEDY presided. Beyond completing the preliminary arrangements for the grand dinner and festival of the Society, to be enjoyed tonight, at Tammany Hall, in commemoration of the forty-sixth anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans, nothing of intereat was transacted.

To any dyspeptic sufferer, who requires a good laugh to put his blood into more active circulation, we recommend the moderate perusal of Mayor WOOD'S Message to the Common Council. It will be found a somewhat violent remedy, but if no more than three paragraphs be taken at one sitting, there can be no danger of bursting a blood vessel.

In this court the calendar was yesterday called through for the purpose of setting down causes for convenient days.

The arrival of the U.S. ship Dacotah, is the principal item of news in this, our unusually dull city. Your gun-boat, though reputed fast, had a long passage from Rio Janeiro. This is attributed to her little coal capacity. Indeed, the Dacotah is a failure so far as her man-of-war qualities are concerned. She rolls incessantly, rendering her battery totally useless, and making it next to impossible to lower her fighting bulwarks.

We understand that an adjustment of the long-standing controversy between the City and the State authorities, concerning the ownership of the West Washington Market property, has been partially made, in conformity with the provisions of the law of last Winter.

Gov. LETCHER'S message, alluding to the condition of the country, says all see, know and feel that danger is imminent, and all true patriots are exerting themselves to save us from impending perils. He renews his proposition in his last message for a Convention of all the States, and says: "It is monstrous to see a Government like ours destroyed merely because men cannot agree about a domestic institution.

The telegraph announces that Ex-Governor JOHN B. FLOYD, the absconding Secretary of War, has for the present taken up his residence in Richmond, Va., where, doubtless, he can place himself in closer correspondence than heretofore with the seceders and traitors, who already owe so much to his official connivance with their plans.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found the correspondence between Mr. BUCHANAN and the South Carolina Commissioners. We must say that it is not particularly creditable on the whole to either party. But it sets forth, in a very strong and striking light, the magnitude of the perils from which the prompt activity of Major ANDERSON has saved the country.
Issued this morning, contains, in addtion to its Summaries of Foreign and Domestic News of general interest, the continuation of DICKENS' CAPITAL CHRISTMAS STORY.

The Senate was full to-day. Mr. TOOMBS made a very noisy and ranting secession speech, and at the close was greeted with a storm of hisses and applause, which was continued some time. His language towards the Republicans and Northern men was most insolent, and towards the Federal Government defiant.

The Legislature met at Columbus to-day. Gov. DENNISON'S Message is a long document, and is occupied mainly with State affairs. He recommends a more effective organization of the militia, the present organized militia numbering only about 1,200 men, while the unorganized force is estimated at 285,000 men. No special prominence is given to this subject.

Application of Commissioners of Central Park Extension to confirm report of Valuation of Property, This is an application to confirm the report of the Commissioners of the Central Park Extension, awarding the amount due to parties for land taken for the extension on One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Tenth streets, and between the Fifth and the Eighth avenues.

A large meeting was held here on Saturday night. Strong speeches were made urging the citizens to arm themselves and place tremselves in a state of defence for any emergency, which were loudly cheered.

The Select Committee appointed for investigating the recent abstraction of Indian Bonds from the Treasury, arrived in this City yesterday morning and took up their quarters at the St. Nicholas Hotel. They immediately communicated with the United States District-Attorney, Ex-Judge ROOSEVELT, who was unable to attend their first meeting, at noon, in room No. 236 of that Hotel.

The Eighth of January stands as one of the monumental columns in American history, and already its hero looms up in the legends of the Republic. The day and its man figure together in the public mind as the types of American independence and democracy, and their memory is one of the strong links that unite the South, the West and the North in the bonds of fraternal suffering and triumph.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last, have been: 37 bbls. Ashes, 7,250 bbls. Flour, 200 bushels Wheat, 346 bushels Corn, 1,100 bushels Rye, 400 bushels Barley, 1,200 bushels oats, 4,062 bushels Malt, 1,1559 pkgs. Provisions, and 505 bbls. Whisky.
The following is an extract from a letter from Maj. ANDERSON to a gentleman in this City, dated Fort Moultrie, Dec. 21, 1860, five days before he transferred his command to Fort Sumter:

That intelligent and instructive body who, for the past five days have been holding secret meetings at the Capitol, this afternoon came forth and stated that we were no longer members of the great Confederacy of America, but a distinct and independent Sovereignty; that Alabama, the rich and river-traced, now belongs, and is accountable only to herself.

The Military Convention met at 10 o'clock. Gen. BURNSIDE offered complimentary resolutions to Gen. WOOL. The following officers were elected: President, Col. G.W. Pratt; Vice-Presidents, Col. Alfred M. Wood, Col. Joseph C. Pinckney, Maj. James L. Gilbert, Gen. W.S. Fullerton; Treasurer, Col. H.S. Fairchild; Recording Secretary, Col. Geo. W. Morrill; Corresponding Secretary, Capt. Hiram Roose; Chaplain, Rev. Chas. E. Hewes.

It would, undoubtedly, be a "twice told tale" if I should give you all the particulars concerning our late ineffectual cruise from Norfolk to Charleston, and the object thereof. To do this I shall not attempt yet.

The sales of COTTON for the three days were 23,000 bales, including 1,600 to speculators, and 1,600 to exporters. The market closed dull, owing to the advance in bank rates, and all quotations have receded 1-16d.@1/3d. Bills for the removal of insane convicts from Auburn to Utica; to encourage rural improvements; to make the salary of the Deputy Clerk of New-York $2,500; and making an appropriation for the debt and maintenance of the canals for next year, were reported favorably.
In this Court, yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, the trial of Jose Varona, indicted for forgery, was proceeded with. This was the third day of the trial.
The Government paper, called the Voz de Sonora, has published the decree of Gov. PESQUEIRA, opening a transit for American and foreign goods through the port of Guaymas to this Territory.
The Times' City Article of Thursday evening, says the English funds opened steadily this morning at the slight improvement of yesterday, and subsequently experienced a further recovery.
The screw-steamship Edinburgh, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at 11 A.M. on the 2d, and from Queenstown on the 3d inst., arrived at this port last night.
The following communication from Gen. S.C. POMEROY, at Atchison, addressed to Mr. BRYANT, Chairman of the New-York Committee, will be read with interest:

FLOUR dull at $4.50 for superfine. WHISKY in geod demand at 13 c. HOGS firm and in good demand; sales 3,000 at $6.15@$6.40. Receipts today, 5,000. Mess Perk in good demand at $16.50, but holders ask $16.75; the market closed buoyant. Bulk Meats in good demand, with large sales for future delivery sales for next month at 6c@8c., on the spot. LARD in good demand; ...

The resolutions of the Joint Committee of Twenty-six, adopted here yesterday by the Bell and Douglas Mass Conventions, were to-night ratified with acclamation by several thousand citizens of Louisville. The principal speaker was Hon. JOSHUA F. BELL. That patriot and orator reiterated the sentiments of his speech before the Conventions, and was loudly cheered throughout.
Honorables R.E. Fenton of Washington, O.B. Matteson of Utica, and G.G. Fogg of Concord, N.H., Jude Gilpin of Rhode Island, Lieut. G. Bacon and Dr. Page of the U.S. Navy, are at the Astor House.

The Legislature of this State is in session now in this city of the woods. It commenced its session the first Wednesday of this month, but has not accomplished, as yet, very much. By our law the outgoing Governor has to send in a meaage, and the incoming Governor an inangural.
The Pony Express passed here at 1 P.M. on the 16th, but, in consequence of a heavy snowstorm, which prostrated the telegraph lines, we have not been able to transmit the news till now.

Ex-Gov. Fairbanks, of Vermont; W.B. Couts, of California; H.R. Stevens, of Newburgh; Dr. D.S. Brock and lady, of Liverpool; A. Paul, of NewHampshire, and J.E. Whipple, of Lansingburgh, are at the Astor House.

The demand has been restricted, as somewhat higher prices have been claimed for good and prime qualities, of which the available supply is not heavy. Coarse and inferior meats are plenty, and in very limited request.

Col. HAYNE is surprised to find by the Herald that his communication was sent to the President yesterday, since it was his intention to withhold it until Monday. He still doubts the correctness of the report.

On the evening of Jan. 15, a large audience assembled in St. Lawrence Hall, Toronto, C.W., to hear an address by Hon. GERRITT SMITH, on the case of ANDERSON, the fugitive slave, whose surrender has been demanded by the United States Government.

The steamer Marion, Capt. ADKINS, vice Capt. SAM. WEITING, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Charleston, S.C., with some 350 tierces of Rice and a quantity of Cotton. The Marion came out of Charleston Harbor through Maffit's or Sullivan's Island Channel, the approach to the main ship channel having been obstructed by the sinking of three or four vessels on the bar, to prevent the entrance of vessels.

WEDNESDAY EVENING. It was announced today, by electric telegraph, that the Bank of France, overcoming their long hesitation in face of the strong action taken by the Bank of England, have raised their rate of discount from 4 to 5 per cent. This measure may, perhaps, trouble French trade, but it is the only one possible under the circumstances.

The secession leaders have discovered that breaking up the Union and destroying the Government are not synonymous terms. It is not the former of the consummations that they designed but the latter; and notwithstanding their persistent declarations that the Union is dissolved, they all confess that the Government still stands.

The "Allocution of Pope PIUS IX.," delivered recently to a conclave of his Cardinals, is a very curious and instructive document. Poor old Pope, he sees the world all tumbling into chaos about his head! "Cruel events" fill the heart of him, and of his "venerable brothers," with anguish.
By Mr. FIERO To provide arms and equipments for the militia of the State. By Mr. SPINOLA Submitting certain propositions for amending the Constitution of the United States to the people.

The Persse Brooks Paper Works vs. James C. Willett. The plaintiffs in this case are a Connecticut corporation, and they sue the defendant for wrongfully taking about $12,000 worth of paper belonging to them upon several executions issued against the property of Persse Brooks.
The inquest on the body of Mr. JOHN TUTTLE who died on Friday week, as was supposed from poison, or, malpractice, was resumed, yesterday afternoon, before Justice SPEER at Greenville.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last, have been: 37 bbls. Ashes, 2,669 bbls. Flour, 8,594 bushels Wheat, 1,995 bushels Oats, 998 bushels Malt, 1,802 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,136 bbls. Whisky.
TRIAL OF XAVIER HOCHREITTER FOR THE MURDER OF LEONARD GONDER TESTIMONY NOT YET CONCLUDED.

As we are now called on to face the alternative of secession, it becomes important to inquire as to the dangers to which it may expose the trade of the Gulf of Mexico. The preconcerted movement of the States border... will never expose itself to a lawless mob or to the danger of being seized by a needy State.

Elizabetha Dietz vs. Frederick Dietz. This action was brought to obtain a divorce a mensa et thorn on the ground of alleged inhuman treatment. The parties were married at Hoboken on the 12th of July, 1860. The defendant is a lithographer and at the time specified in the pleadings was in the employ of Conrad Fatzer, of this City.
LIFE OF ANDREW JACKSON, in Three Vols. By JAMES PARTON. MASON BROTHERS, NewYork.

The Coroner's inquest in the case of John Sexton, who was murdered under mysterious circumstances on Sunday evening last his dead body having been found on the sidewalk oppoeite No. 227 Bowery was resumed yesterday at the Seventeenth Ward Station-house.
The long-anticipated report of the Assembly Committee on Federal Relations came in this morning. I send you a copy for publication.

Only the House was in session, and the attendance there so sparse that they might as well have adjourned yesterday and gone home to gather healthy public opinion, and enjoy the luxury of a pure atmosphere.

Sarah M. Sanford vs. The Mayor, The plaintiff is the owner of certain lots in Seventyseventh-street in this City, upon which, in 1858, she was assessed for regulating that street, in the sum of $2,641,52, with some interest. She handed the matter over to her husband, as her agent, who, supposing the assessment could be collected, paid it, taking a receipt therefor on behalf of his wife, the owner. ...

This 4th day of January, 1861, is a day of no ordina- ry interest to mankind. In this country it will pass like other days, but on the other side of the Atlantic the Americans are observing it as a day of humiliation and prayer in the extreme peril of the State. In the Emperor's speech to the diplomatic corps on New-Year's Day, he used the word encore in connection with his hopes that peace would still be maintained in Europe. The word was caught up at once, and made to mean that, for the present, he had hopes of peace, but that he was not sure but that to-morrow there would be no longer grounds for such hopes. WENDELL PHILLIPS is announced to speak here to-morrow evening. The Anti-Slavery Society asked the protection of Mayor WIGHTMAN, who refused to protect PHILLIPS, but assured the Society that the peace of the city should be maintained.

The Senate is not in session. In the Assembly Mr. COZANS presented a communication from workingmen on national affairs, and called for its reading. The communication assailed the doctrine of the Republican Party. Mr. FISH moved to suspend the further reading. Carried, 43 to 25.
Hon. W. H. Letcher and family of Missouri; C. G. Myers, Attorney-General, N. Y.; E. E. Upham of Portland; Mrs. H. A. Risly of Albany and B. N. Stone of Salem, are at the Astor House.

A correspondent furnishes the following extract of a letter from Paris, dated the 31st of December, which purports to describe the views of the French Government as to the results to be obtained from the clause of the treaty with China legalizing the exportation of labor. It is not known if the writer speaks from authority, and if his extremely sanguine anticipations and inferences are shared in official quarters:

Right Rev. W. R. WHITTINGHAM, Bishop of the Diocese of Maryland, has written Gov. HICKS a letter pledging him that his "humble efforts shall not be wanting to back Gov. HICKS' noble persistency in keeping Maryland in her only true, right, safe attitude of dignified and quiet expectation of legitimate redress of past wrongs, and provision against contingent dangers, in the regular working of the constitutional Government of the United States."

There is no danger of an attack upon fort Monroe. I learn that it is fully garrisoned with from five to six hundred men. Being where Gen. SCOTT can easily issue orders to them, there is no necessity for apprehension as regards that fortification, as has been suggested in many of the papers.
The Army bill was passed. The bill providing for the payment of the California war debt, amounting to $500,000, for suppressing Indian hostilities, was passed.

Mr. JOHNSON, of Arkansas (Dem.,) urged immediate action on the Red River Raft bill. He said heavy duties were imposed on all articles which passed over the thirty mile raft.
The State Convention adopted the secession ordinance at 2 o'clock this afternoon, by Yeas, 208; Nays, 89. It is as follows:

The weather is mild and it is snowing fast. The Western stage with passengers and the mail, and HINCKLEY Co.'s messenger, with $6,000, passed at 10 o'clock last night. Denver City dates are to the 14th instant.

Lieut. TALBOT arrived here last night with gloomy tidings. The Governor and the members of his Cabinet were in consultation the greater part of last night on the intelligence communicated by Lieut. TALBOT.
The Pony Express passed here at 5 o'clock this morning, nearly two days late, owing to much snow on nearly the whole route.

COTTON The Brokers' Circular says, "The raising of the Bank rate suddenly on Monday has tended to check speculations, and as the Trade had previously been large operators the market has since been quiet, irrespective of its holiday character. ...

The House passed to-day a bill to provide against the invasion of the State by sea. It makes pilots liable to fine and imprisonment who bring foreign vessels into the harbor of Mobile, and authorizes the commander of Fort Morgan to destroy the beacon and landmarks at his discretion.

The United States marines who arrived here from the Pacific fleet a few days since, left the Brooklyn barracks on Saturday for Washington, in compliance with official instructions. It is understood that these are to be retained in service for the present.

We find the following letter in the columns of the National Intelligencer, to which it was sent by a gentleman in Utica, as having been "addressed to a distinguished gentleman in "Washington." It was written, as will be observed, over a year ago. Its publication now effectually disposes of the pretext that Mr. WEED's conciliatory language towards the South dates only from the election of a Republican President:

The English funds on the 4th opened buoyantly at an eighth improvement, but in the afternoon a sudden relapse took place, owing to a report that an Indian Government loan of 3,000,000 sterling would probably be announced in a few days. ...

The annual report of the City Inspector for 1860, prepared for the Common Council, is a very lengthy document, and contains much that is of importance to the public. The returns show that during the year there were 4,241 marriages, 12,454 births, and 22,710 deaths. With the exception of an epidemic which prevailed during the Summer months, in the form of scarlet fever, the City has been unusually healthy.

In this Court, on Saturday, before Judge LEONARD, the trial of Hochreitter proceeded. A delay of half an hour occurred on account of the tardy arrival of a juror. He excused himself to the Court, and the trial went on.

The second concert of the fourth season of this popular and most successful society was given on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The building was literally jammed, not a seat being left without an occupant. Bizarre in its extreme illustrations, the disposition to submit the old verdicts passed on characters and lives to reconsideration under the light of a new dispensation, nevertheless justifies itself as a very genuine and generous prompting. In the Senate the consideration of the report on Federal relations, contemplating a National Convention, was resumed.

Maj. CHASE has telegraphed the Mayor of NewOrleans for two thousand men to take Fort Pickens, at Pensacola. The Mayor responded that the men could be raised in two days if Florida would equip them. The Governor telegraphed for them to come to-night, when the Military Board will make provisions for raising and arming the men. Meetings will be called to-morrow.
The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, from Liverpool at 12.30 P.M. on the 5th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 6th inst., arrived at this port on Saturday morning.

It is stated that the English Government has sent a strong note to the Emperor of France, protesting against the extension of the occupation of Syria by the French forces. No reply had yet been received.

On Saturday last orders were issued to the members of a number of military companies in this City and in Brooklyn, to hold themselves in readiness to repair to their several armories, prepared for service, on hearing the alarm signal from the City Hall bells. The orders state that no immediate call for active service is anticipated, and that it is to be understood as merely precautionary. It is believed that the orders were

A special dispatch from Springfield, Ill., to the Republican says that Congressman KELLOGG arrived there on Saturday night, and is in conference with Mr. LINCOLN. His object is supposed to be in reference to a compromise of the national difficulties. It is believed that the Republicans, with Mr. LINCOLN'S sanction, will propose holding a National Convention, and the restoration of the old Missouri line to California.
THE SOUTH CAROLINA COMMISSIONER. There is no truth whatever in the published statements relative to Col. HAYNE'S having sent a communication to the President.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MRRCADANTE's celebrated opera of " Il Giuramento," was produced here last night, and, being accepted with great favor, inaugurated brilliantly the new season undertaken by the associated Italian artists, And to this season we would direct particular attention. It has been commenced under circumstances generally regarded as unfavorable to its commercial prosperity.

When Russia came out of the Crimean war, it was, according to the views of the Western World, in a very mangled, tattered, shabby condition; very much out of pocket, very much in debt. She had been thrown, a la Falstaff, among all the dirty linen, into the horse-pond of disgrace.

For some time past an old gentleman, known as Mr. James Whiting, has been stopping at one of the firstclass hotels at Philadelphia, where, by his engaging manners and plausible conversation, he made many influential acquaintances, and invested himself with all the importance of unlimited wealth. Among those who gave him their confidence was Mr. A.H. Little, an extensive dealer in silk goods, at No. 325 Marketstreet.
The attendance was light. The bill to make an appropriation to redeem the State stock issued to the Auburn and Rochester Railroad was reported favorably.

In the case of Capt. Latham and others, the master and mates of the bark Cora, indicted for being engaged in the Slave-trade, a motion was made some days since to quash the indictment on two grounds, first, that an examination into the offence was pending before a United States Commissioner when the indictment was found, and second, that separate indictments should have been found.

"Devil with devil damned, firm concord holds!" " For ourselves," says the Charleston Mercury of Thursday last, " we look to the Abolitionists for the deliverance of the South." When the Mercury reads the speech of WENDELL PHILLIPS, which we publish this morning, it will see that it has substantial ground for its reliance.

Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, (Dem.,) from Committee on Finance reported the Indian Appropriation bill, and asked to be excused from further service on the Finance Committee. He said it was evident that the party in the majority in the Senate would soon be changed, and he thought justice to himself and the Senate required him to be excused. [Mr. HUNTER has been Chairman of the Committee of Finance fifteen years.] He was excused.

The North American Review for the current quarter begins with an article headed as above. The history and statistics of this important staple are given in a brief but clear account, derived mainly from ELLISON's Handbook, the latest authority on the subject. It is, indeed, a wonderful history.

Hon. L.B. Marsh, from Boston; J.H. Lucking of England; Major Spigg, of the United States Army J. Arnot and family, of Elmira; Dr. J.B. Herbert and lady, of Arkansas, and G. Sanderson, of Pennsylvania, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
Andrew Stevens vs. The New-York Consolidated Stage Company.--This is an appeal from a judgment rendered at a trial term of this Court against the defendants.

Mobile is a city sui generis. With a population less than 30,000, it ranks third in the amount of its exports among the ports of the United States. Surrounded by a sterile country, its business is almost exclusively with agricultural products. With extensive pine forests all around it, producing the most valuable lumber, and large quantities of turpentine, its exports of lumber are constantly diminishing, and those of naval stores are insignificant.

Information that an attack was anticipated reached the police authorities in this City about 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Superintendent KENNEDY was out of town, and the duty of disposing the police in the emergency developed upon Commissioner BOWEN and Inspector CARPENTER. A plan of operation was promptly decided upon, and through the instrumentality of the telegraph it was almost immediately in process of execution.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 69 bbls. Ashes, 11,076 bbls. Flour, 1,875 bbls. Corn Meal, 720 bush. Wheat, 28,000 bush. Corn, 650 bush. Oats, 1,798 bush. Malt. 973 pkgs. Provisions, and 355 bbls. Whisky.

The Tribune, a day or two since, suggested a compromise of the Slavery controversy quite unique in its character, to say the least. It had the merit of being quite certain to exasperate the South, and to encounter the stern hostility of the North,--and thus was in perfect harmony with the Tribune's position, that no compromise on this subject can ever be made.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, the trial of Xavier Hochreitter was proceeded with. The testimony for the People had been closed on Saturday, and now Mr. Rankin, counsel for defence, opened briefly to the jury, saying that the testimony to be introduced he hoped would dispel any doubts which they might entertain concerning the prisoner. He should therefore ask for an acquittal at their hands.
Mr. T.R. WILTBEEGER writes a letter dated Charleston, Jan. 15, which the Philadelphia Pennsylvanian publishes. He says:
We copy from the Boston Atlas and Bee the following report of an address by WENDELL PHILLIPS, at Music Hall, in Boston, on Sunday morning, on the Political Lessons of the Hour:

In our hasty review, published yesterday, of Mr. JOHN B. FLOYD's great confessional speech, delivered at the secession shrine of a Richmond dinner, we find that nothing like justice has been done to the severe spirit of pious invocation which marked almost every sentence of the unbosoming harangue.

The Brooklyn Navy-yard was last evening the scene of unusual excitement, on account of an order issued by Commander FOOTE to have the entire force put under arms and held in readiness to act immediately. The one hundred marines remaining there were accordingly mustered, under command of Captains REED and DOUGHTY and with loaded muskets occupied the guard-house at the gate.
Gentlemen of the Senate and House of Delegates: I have received a communication from His Excellency, EDWIN D. MORGAN, Governor of New-York, inclosing a preamble and resolutions adopted by that State.

The Legislature being out of session, on a recess of a few weeks, the political storm, of which I have already given you full accounts, has subsided; but I am afraid the lull is only a silent preparation for fresh disagreements between the Executive and the two Chambers, whenever members again assemble to proceed to business.

All Brooklyn was thrown into a feverish state of excitement last evening, by a current rumor that the Navy-yard and appurtenances were to be seized by the sympathizers in this vicinity with the Secessionists. Last night, according to Madam Rumor, was the time at which the descent was to have been made.

A private dispatch says that the steamer Wm. Jenkins, of the Baltimore and Boston line, sister ship to the Joseph Whitney, which was chartered by the Government, has been burnt at Savannah. Particulars are not received, but it is understood that the burning was accidental. The Wm. Jenkins went to Savannah from this port.
In this Court yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, after the arraignment of several persons, the trial of Xavier Hochreitter, for murder, was proceeded with.
The Union Petition in Boston has received nearly 14,000 signatures. A special Committee will leave to-morrow with the document for Washington.
In the Senate a Joint Special Committee has been appinted, to consider the expediency of amending the City Charter, that the police may be appointed by the State authorities.
The New-Mexican mail, with dates to the 31st of December, arrived this evening, bringing all the back mails.
The Cunard screw-steamship Marathon from Liverpool at 2 P.M. on the 8th List, arrived at this port yesterday morning.
Hon. L.B. Marsh, of Boston, S.C. Ives, of Hartford, and J.W. Edwards, of Boston, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

As Florida has just seceded and assumed the dignity of an independent nation, it may be interesting to refer to two or three points in her history, first as a Territory, then as a State, from which a good idea may be gained of her probable future glorious career.

Steemships Jamestown, Skigner, Norfolk, Ludlam Hemeken; Monticello, Gager, Savannah, H.B. Cromwell Co. Steamship Marathon, (Br.,) McArthur, Liverpool Jan. 8, with mdse. to E. Cunard, Jan. 20, 1st. 40.41, lon. 68.11, passed steamships Glasgow, hence for Liverpool, and Bremen, hence for Bremen. The steamship Kedar, hence, arr. at Liverpool 6th.

Governor's Island has been again reinforced by recruits. On Friday night a detachment, consisting of drafts from Buffalo and Rochester, arrived in town, but owing to the stringent rules in force at the barge office, were obliged to lodge in the City till Saturday morning, when they reported themselves to Major HOLMES. There are now 730 men, all told, on the Island, and if many more arrive a considerable number of hands must be detached.

Frances Norsworthy et al. vs. Robert Irwin This action is brought by the plaintiffs to recover the sum of $237, alleged to be due to them from the defendant, for rent of premises No. l56 Chatham-street.

The Court opened promptly at the hour appointed. After reading the journal, Mr. O'Gorman for the acoused, renewed his request that the Judge Advocate should state what specific act or omission of the defendant was to be proven in support of the charge.
The following vessels arrived here yesterday from Charleston, having been prevented from going into Charleston harbor, by the sinking of three vessels in the ship channel, by the authorities:

COTTON The market yesterday (Monday) opened with a brisk inquiry, but it was checked by the further advance in the Bank discount. The sales of the day were about 10,000 bales, including 1,500 on speculation and for export at last Friday's rates. This morning the market has been very quiet, and it is computed that the sales will not exceed 3,000 or 4,000 bales.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA COMMISSIONER. Col. HAYNE is still on his oars. He dines to-day with Mr. SLIDELL, who gives a large dinner party to seceding and other Senators. He received a telegram from Gov. PICKENS, to day, saying that the most amicable relations were existing with Major ANDERSON, who obtains fresh supplies daily from Charleston market.
In this Court the Jury, on Monday evening, brought in a verdict of acquittal in the case of Jose Varona, charged with forgery; and the prisoner was discharged.
The United States steamship Bienville, J.D. BULLGCH, commander, from New-Orleans the 15th and Havana the 18th, arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning.

The Bank of England this morning, shortly after the commencement of business, advanced their rate of discount from 6 per cent., at which it was fixed on the 31st ult., to 7 per cent. This is higher than any point attained since the panic of 1857.

Perceiving by a recently-received impression of the TIMES which you kindly sent me that a treaty had been, or was about to be, (1 do not exactly remember which,) negotiated between the United States and the Republic of Venezuela, I have collected a few statistics of revenue of that country, or rather of its chief ports, which I trust will not be deemed altogether uninteresting.

John Lund vs. the Seaman's Bank for Savings. In this case motion was made on the part of the defendants for the substitution, in their place, of Peter Erik Larsson and others, a business firm in Sweden, on the ground that these foreign parties were the parties in interest.

We have more than once alluded to the certainty of an "irrepressible conflict" between different sections and rival interests of the Southern States, as soon as they attempt to organize a Confederacy of their own. We mentioned a day or two since Western Virginia and Northern Alabama as not at all likely to submit to the attempted coercion of the Slavetrade interest which is at the bottom of the Disunion movement.

Mr. SEWARD, of New-York, (Rep.,) presented the petition of E.C. DELAVAN, of Albany, suggesting the appointment of officers in ports of entry to prevent the importation of deleterious liquors; also, a memorial of 746 citizens of New-York of the state of the country; also another memorial signed by 18,000 citizens of New-York. Laid on the table.

The Cleveland Herald publishes a letter written by Rev. ANTHONY BEWLEY, the Methodist clergyman, who was murdered by a Pro-Slavery Vigilance Committee in Arkansas, some weeks since. It is dated Fayetteville, (Ark.,) Sept. 6, and is addressed to his wife and children. Much of it is advice to his wife regarding the disposition which she must make of her scanty means in view of his probable decease. Among other things, Mr. BEWLEY writes:

The Republicans of the House fovorable to the repeal of the obnoxious provisions in the penal code relative to the rendicion of fugitive slaves, held a caucus to-day. Twenty-four were present. It is reported than their vote, combined with that of the Democratic members, will carry the repeal through the House.

The call for a Convention is more doubtful on account of disagreement as to time. One party is for hasty, and the other for deliberate action. The Senate agrees on the 21st of February to elect delegates, which date will likely kill it in the third reading. It was debated in the House-to-day, but no action was taken.

A proclamation of King WILLIAM I., dated Berlin, Jan. 1, has been published. It is headed, "To my People." The proclamation commences by recalling the severe sufferings of the late King, and the profound grief at his death, and how, with free and royal munificence, he granted institutions the development of which was to realize the hopes of the country. THE NEW FEATHERING PADDLE-WHEEL. DENSMORE's improved feathering paddle-wheel was practically tested yesterday in the presence of a large number of steamboat Captains, Engineers and other persons interested in steam navigation. The Anna, a first-class tow-boat, to which the wheel has been attached, made a trial trip some fifteen miles up the East River, during which the party inspected its working with much interest.

AN IMPERIAL INCOGNITO, One evening, just before New Year's day, which was extremely wet, the Emperor and Empress went cut incognito to see the stalls along the Bouleyards. Protected by a large umbrella, their Majesties passed along the southern side from the Rue de Paix to the Rue Montmarte, and returned along the opposite one as far as the Rue Neuve des Capucines.

The regular meeting of the Board of Charities and Corrections was held yesterday, the President, SIMEON DRAPER, in the Chair.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Jacob Miller, convicted on the previous day of arson in the second degree, was sentenced to Sing Sing for twelve years and three months. The prisoner complained that his counsel had forced him to an immature trial, and he asked for a new one, on the ground that he could prove, upon the testimony of fifteen respectable citizens, that he was elsewhere on the night of the fire.

Preparations for a hostile contingency are actively progressing. The fort at Mobile Point is now garrisoned by a force of between 400 and 500 men consisting principally of companies from the interior. The city companies still continue to perform tours of duty, but not so incessantly as before.
The outsiders monopolize the attention here today Tweddle Hall and the Democratic Convention making a very strong diversion from the Capital and the Legislature.

The Committee of Conference of the South Caroilna Legislature, to which was referred the matter of dredging Maffit's Channel, has finally agreed to appropriate $30,000 for this purpose, provided the work shall not be resumed until Fort Sumter shall passinto the possession of the authorities of the State, and all, the troops of the United States shall be removed from the harbor of Charleston.

The President elect starts to-day for the National Capital. He enters upon one of the most momentous and difficult duties ever devolved upon any man, in this country or any other. No one of his predecessors was ever called upon to confront dangers half as great, or to render a public service half as difficult, as those which will challenge his attention at the very outset of his Administration.

Mr. LINCOLN, the President elect, left Springfield, en route for Washington, yesterday morning. He was accompanied to the depot by a large concourse of his fellow-townsmen, to whom he made a brief parting address, expressing his regrets at leaving them, alluding to the difficult and responsible duties upon which he was about to enter, and declaring his reliance upon Divine Providence for aid and assistance.

After a wonderfully fair and pleasant passage, under steam, against a gentle monsoon, from Hong Kong, around the southern coast of Formosa, whose grand and towering sky line of mountain stood up in striking contrast to the green and fertile shores at the base, on the evening of the 8th, we came in sight of Niphon, and for the first time saw the magnificent snow-crowned cone of Fousi-Yamma, rearing its frosted head to the clouds.

Recruiting for the army, not withstanding the large number out of employment, has almost come to a stand-still in this City. Patrick Hennessey vs. The People, This is an appeal from a judgment of conviction for the crime of arson in the third degree, of the Oyer and Terminer, at which Court the plaintiff in error was tried on the 24th of October, 1860, convicted, and sentenced to ten years hard labor at Sing Sing Prison.
A new piece, in five acts, called "Central Park, or the House with two Doors," was produced here last evening, with very marked success.

The Paterson-Bonaparte cause was postponed till the 1st of February for the reply and the speech of the Public Minister. The arguments were expected to be brought to a close on that day, and the judgment would probably be given a day or two thereafter.

The reports from the Bight of Benin confirm the atrocities carried on by the King of Dahomey. Slaves are sold at Whydah in quantities, and American vessels find a good market.

Daily News City Article, (Wednesday Evening.) The funds closed about 1/8@ cent lower, and British Railway Stocks decidedly higher than yesterday. In disconnt market the rate for good bills was 6 to 7 @ cent, lower.
According to the report of the City Inspector, the mortality of this City in 1860 was 22,710, an increase over the preceding year of 1,065.

Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, of New-York, (Dem.,) presented a memorial from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, protesting against the passage of the Morrell tariff bill, and specifying its objectionable features to be the repeal of the Warehousing system, the specific and double or compound duties, and the effect it would have to lessen the revenue by diminishing the exports. Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

A dispatch from official quarters states that SCHIAVORI, one of the chiefs of the reactionary bands in the Abruzzi, has surrendered. Fighting continues to take place on both sides; villages are set on fire, and Sardinian officers have been cut to pieces. Sardinia has claimed the restoration of the soldiers who were made prisoners by the Papal Zouaves, and has arrested the Bishop of Sabine as a hostage.

A large majority of the Trust Fund consists of the bonds of the Northern States, yet the thieves strictly confined their depredations to the stocks of Missouri, Virginia, Tennessee and North Carolina.

A terrible tragedy occurred in this city last night. A party of five Overland Mail and Little Rock coach-drivers entered the grocery of a German named HAGGE, and commenced quarreling. Pistols were drawn on both sides. The bar-keeper, named BUTCHER, was shot through the heart, and died instantly; HAGGE received a shot in the forehead, and died at 8 o'clock this morning.

FREE ACADEMY JUNIOR EXHIBITION. The Junior Class of the Free Academy gave their annual exhibition on Saturday evening at Irving Hall, corner of Fifteenth-street and Irving-place. Dr. WEBSTER, the venerable President of the Institution, occupied the chair; the platform was filled with members of the Faculty an prominent citizens connected with educational movements, while the audience, as usual, comprised a goodly representation of the talent, wealth, solidity and female beauty of the Metropolis.
Vice-President HAMLIN and lady left here this morning on route for Washington. He will arrive at Boston this evening, and leave for the West to-morrow morning.

The celebration of WASHINGTON'S Birthday in this City yesterday was characterized by a popular participation rarely witnessed. The First Division paraded in unusual strength; the line of march teemed with spectators in holiday attire, and the City assumed an appearance worthy of a gala day. The troops were reviewed by Gov. MORGAN, and the Police arrangements reflected the usual credit upon the Superintendent.

There was a general display of flags upon all the shipping, both along the East and North Rivers, which, in the stiff Northwester that prevailed, was exhibited to the best possible advantage, and gave a most animating appearance to the harbor. All the ships of the different Liverpool, London and Havre lines, and the vessels, large and small, composing the various Southern lines, were dressed out in the gayest holiday attire.

Mr. LINCOLN'S presence in Washington is having a decidedly good effect upon all parties there. The Mayor, c., vs. Whitson.-The defendant in this action was an unlicensed carman, who aid business by employing licensed carmen to do jobs contracted for by him. Yesterday the steam gunboat Pawnce was to have gone from Philadelphia, on her third trip. She and the Pensacola are the only newly built steamers that have never done any duty. The Pawnee has broken down twice; and constructors call her a failure. She is over 1,200 tons burthen; and carries over a hundred men. The Department anxiously awaits the report of her next trial.

A lad, eleven years of age, named Edward Brown, whose parents reside near the corner of Twenty-sixth-street and First-avenue, was drowned on Sunday evening, while flying a kite on the pier at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street. The lad while watching his kite, walked into a hole in the pier, and falling into the dock, was drowned. His body was not recovered.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, was yesterday inaugurated as the Sixteenth President of the United States, and the occasion, we are happy to state although the City of Washington was crowded to an unwonted extent, and although apprehensions of scenes of violence were entertained by many was not marred by a single untoward event.

On Tuesday night last, a man named JOHN McCAULEY was attacked, as alleged, by a party of five persons on Columbia, near Atlantic-street, and so severely beaten by them that he died of the injuries on the following day in the Long Island College Hospital. Four of the five parties accused are now under arrest. Their names are THOMAS COSTELLO, JOHN COWAN, JAMES RILEY and JAMES HANLEY.

The tone adopted by the Albany Atlas and Argus towards the Inaugural of the President, is strangely at variance with its past professions of regard for the maintenance of the Federal authority. In speaking of that document it says:
We presume nobody is astonished to hear that the Secessionists regard the Inaugural as a "declaration of war." It would have been very strange, indeed, if they had not done so.

In the present issue will be found highly interesting dispatches from Mexico. The Constitutional Government is pursuing the work of reform with energy, determination, and, to all appearance, discretion, according to the programme laid down in what may be termed the Inaugural Message of the Liberal Government. This able State paper is well worth perusal, and we recommend it particularly to the attention of our legislators and Executive in Washington.

Since my last, of the 4th inst., the Government has followed with great determination the work of reform announced in the official programme, issued by Mr. ZARCO, the chief of the Cabinet, to which I then referred, and a careful translation of which I now inclose.
The Convention to-day debated the resolutions of instruction to the Committee on Federal Relations offered yesterday, and adjourned, on motion of Mr. CARLISLE, who desires to speak to-morrow.
The new Commander of the steam gunboat Mokawk, vice MAFFIT, reported for duty on Tuesday.

The Government official paper of this Island, of the 17th inst., again publishes the "royal order" of the 7th July last, which contains the regulations under which Chinese are to be introduced into this Island, and the provisions for their management, after they shall be located upon the estates of their masters. The document is altogether too lengthy for me to attempt a translation of it.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The gentle zephyrs of Spring, when sandwiched between hyperborean blasts of wind and dust as they have been during the last few days do not regulate the vocal organs with that nicety which singers admire and cultivate. To this circumstance we owe the fact that there was no performance at the Academy last evening.
The Pony Express passed here at 3 o'clock this Morning.

There remained unsold at the commencement of the week at the Twenty-fourth-street stables, 435 horses. No sales of first-class coach teams have been reported; two pair of second-class sold at $500@ $650 28 pair. A few good single horses changed hands at $350@$400 each, for first-class, and $250@$300 for second class.

A motion, in the British House of Commons on the 19th for more equality in assessing and levying the income tax, was carried against the Government, the vote standing 131 to 127. The question was of secondary importance, and involved no necessity of a resignation of Ministers.

In the House of Commons, on the 18th ult., Mr. HORSFALL asked the Secretary of Sate for Foreign Affairs whether any steps had been taken by Her Majesty's Government, with the view of carrying out the recommendations of the Shipping Committee of last year on the subject of belligerent rights at sea.
The following letter from Judge ROBERT LYON, of Abbeville Court-house, South Carolina, speaks for self :

In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Edward Reddy and Thomas Downing, indicted for forgery, in passing counterfeit money, pleaded guilty in the fourth degree, and were remanded for sentence.

FORD, accompanied by Commissioner NICHOLS, found at Brazos twenty soldiers under Lieut. THOMPSON, about twenty heavy guns and plenty of artillery, stores, ammunition, etc. Capt. HILL had previously withdrawn his light battery, and with his party was en route to Brazos to dostroy the gun-carriages and immovables there.

Letters from Paris mention that the French Government are understood to have borrowed 1,000,000 from the Bank of France.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, Alderman FREAR offered a series of resolutions providing for the appointment of a commission of five gentlemen to present to the Legislature the humble petition of the Corporation of the City, that the recommendation of the late Peace Congress be submitted to the people of the State to be voted upon.

Mr. CLAYTON reported a bill providing, in the event of a conflict or the refusal of the United States to recognize the independence of the Confede racy, that no Court of the Confederate States shall have cognizance of civil cases of citizens of the United States, and all pending cases to be dismissed.

Matter of the Habeas Corpus of Thomas MCEvey. This was the return to a writ of habeas corpus issued at the petition of Thomas McEvey, to bring before the Court the child of the petitioner, aged 13 years, and now detained from the custody or control of his father, in the Bloomingdale Orphan Asylum.

The second disastrous fire for this Winter occurred in this place last night, over fifty buildings being destroyed and only one stone left in the town. Among the stores destroyed were those of MALTBY McLEAN, groceries, dry goods, loss $25,000 to $40,000 insured. HAMLIN MARTIN, dry goods, groceries, general produce, c., loss $15,000 to $20,000 insured. HARPENDING'S tavern; loss, $10,000. ELIIS'S new tavern; loss, $10,000 insured $5,000.

The Moniteur publishes the following: "A private dispatch has announced the arrival at Rome, on the 14th inst., of the King and Queen of Naples. They were accompanied by the King's brothers, and by Gen. Bosco, who has been appointed Gentleman of the Chamber. M. CASELLA has remained at Gaeta to settle all matter concerning the surrender of the fortress.
King VICTOR EMANUEL had received, at Milan, Gen. BONIN, the Envoy Extraordinary from the King of Prussia.
The Liverpool Cotton market opens to-day with rather more doing. Sales about 6,000 bales.

The number of troops made prisoners at Gaeta was 11,000. The Sardinians found between 700 and 800 cannons and 60,000 muskets.

The New-Brunswick, Milburn and Orange Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading in the House. The joint meeting is now in session. R.M. SMITH has been nominated for State Treasurer. Three ballots have been taken without an election.

Alexander McKenzie vs. Jane McKenzie. This case, so many times reported in this paper, was again before the Court on a motion of defendant's counsel for an order directing the Receiver to account for moneys collected from the estate in controversy.

The Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning. A number of resolutions of similar import to those already reported and referred to the Committee on Federal Relations were offered. A resolution declaring that Mr. LINCOLN'S Inaugural was a declaration of peace, was tabled, it being considered inexpedient to forestall the action of the Committee on Federal Relations.

The debate in the Senate to-day, between Messrs. DOUGLAS and WIGFALL, was spicy and interesting, and when Mr. W. demanded of the Illinois Senator what he would advise the Administration to do as regards the collection of the revenue in the seceding States, the latter very pertinently reminded his impertinent interrogator that it was bad policy

We see it stated that CARL SCRURZ is to be sent to represent the United States at the Court of Sardinia. We trust this is not so, not from any personal objection to Mr. S., for whose abilities and political services we have the highest esteem, but because of the principle which his appointment would involve.

There is a great deal of speculation as to the intentions of the Administration in regard to reinforcing Fort Sumter. It is assumed by some that the President must of necessity send at once reinforcements to that fortress, and force an entrance inta the harbor regardless of consequences. And the general expectation that this will be done, has created a very general apprehension of immediate hostilities.
Mr. DIXON'S resolution that the usual number of the President's Inaugural Address be printed, was adopted.

The bill to amend the act to facilitate the construction of the Lake Ontario and Hudson River Railroad was reported complete, and, on motion of Mr. SORNOLA, made a special order in Committee of the Whole on Tuesday.
Mr. CLAYTON introduced a bill to establish an Admiralty Court at Key West.

FIRE ON RANDALL'S ISLAND. At about 1 o' clock on Friday morning, a fire was discovered in the three story brick shoe factory on Randall's Island, which, despite of all efforts to extinguish it, entirely destroyed the building and contents. The fire was plainly visible from the upper part of the City, and several fire companies endeavored to cross over, but were uuable to do so on account of its being low tide.

Mr. SEWARD is reported to have advised some Republicans who called upon him lately to sale the Union, and to remember that without the Union there would be no hope of Freedom, no chance of reaping the fruits of the glorious victory recently won by the Republican Party.

The violent gale which swept over the country on Wednesday continued till Thursday. The Crystal Palace was seriously damaged. Part of the north wing is in ruins. Several vessels went ashore, including the American bark Hiawatha.

BREADSTUFFS. RICHARDSON, SPENCE Co. report Flour very dull, and offered at a decline of 6d. without sales. Whear dull, all qualities considerably declined and prices irregular. Red Chicago, 11s. 1d.@11s. 3d.; Red Southern, 12s. 6d.@13s.; White do., 13s.@15s. Corn quiet, and declined 6d; Mixed, 66s. 9d. WAHRFIELD, NASH Co. say Whear declined 1d.@2d.

Thomas Reilly vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company.?This was an action for damages. The plaintiff is the owner of a horse and cart, which were damaged, and the driver killed, by collision with the defendants' cars at Fifty-seventh-street in October last.
Theodore T. Edgerton vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. Action to recover $20,000 damages for injuries alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff through negligence of defendant.

The intelligence brought by the Bremen that the Bonaparte-Patterson case has been decided, in the Tribunal of First Instance, adversely to the claim of the American family, will elicit much regretful sympathy in this country.

On the same night a frame stable in Ainslie-street was destroyed by fire, together with a horse kept there belonging to Mr. MYERS. The building was owned by ALEXANDER H. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday on the body of an unknown man who was crushed to death at Pier No. 5, East River, on Friday evening. It appears that as the steamboat Rescue was coming up to the pier on that evening this man was seen to fall from the pier into the river.

Our Washington dispatches this morning are highly important, and indicate that the question of reinforcing Forts Sumpter and Pickens will soon be decided. Indeed, so far as Fort sumpter is concerned, it may have been decided already.
At an early hour on Saturday morning it was discovered that a diabolical attempt had been made to set fire to the five-story tenement house No. 274 East Houston-street.

The open opposition to the observance of the Sabbath as a day of worship in this City, has heretofore come mainly from our German population, and many have been led to suppose, in consequence, that infidelity was the prevailing sentiment among this class of our population.
Newspaper packages by the North Briton, which having left Liverpool Feb. 21, arrived at Portland on Saturday, reached this City yesterday morning.

Coroner SCHIAMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of Caroline King a married woman, 21 years of age, residing at No. 21 Forsyth street, who took corresive sublimate on Friday last, with the object of suicide.

A permanent Constitution has been adopted. It has been kept secret, but a member of the Congress states that among its provisions the President is to serve six years; the Executive appointments under the grade of Cabinet officers are to hold office during good behavior, and removed for causes assigned in writing; the Slave-trade is prohibited. A clause was adopted that Cabinet officers are not prohibited from holding seats in Congress.

PRIZE-FIGHTS On Sunday afternoon a party of runners, said to belong to Engine Companies Nos. 3 and 4, of Jersey City, repaired to the Cedars, in Bergen, for the purpose of enjoying a prize-fight. Before the performance closed four fights occurred.

The House was compelled to adjourn on Saturday evening for want of a quorum, leaving three items in the Supply bill not passed upon. On meeting this morning, it found itself in the same condition. A call of the House was resorted to, but the morning trains bringing a few members, and our double friend from Erie having succeeded in getting himself both up the Capitol Hill, a quorum was obtained and the call suspended.

The Congress of the "Confederated States" is proposing to effect a loan of $15,000,000, on a pledge of an export duty of one-eighth of a cent on a pound of cotton, redeemable, we believe, in ten years. Supposing these States to export, say 1,600,000,000 pounds of cotton, an eighth of a cent per pound, if collected, would produce $2,000,000 yearly; and in ten years an aggregate of $20,000,OO0.

The Army Register for 1861 bas been issued. It gives the total enlisted men of the army at 17,005; agrregate, 18,122. There are 198 companies in the different regiments. If all these were serving on distant stations, the total enlisted would be 17,549; and the aggregate, 18,666.

THE STREET-CLEANING CONTRACT STRIKE OF THE CARTMEN Yesterday morning the cartmen employed by Mr. HACKLEY, contractor for cleaning streets, struck in a body, demanding twenty shillings per day, instead of eighteen, which they have been receiving. COLLISION ON THE NORTH RIVER Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, as the ferry-boat Chancellor Livingston was crossing from Barclay-street to Hoboken, she was run into by a small propeller, which carried away some twelve feet of the guard and a portion of the rail. The propeller also sustained damage, but to what extent was not ascertained, as she at once proceeded to a dock on the New-York side.

Coroner O'Keefe held an inquest yesterday at No. 226 Sullivan street, upon the remains of Michael Whalen, a native of Ireland, 29 years of age, lately employed as porter at the Hone a House, Broadway. It appeared from the testimony that deceased, on going home last Monday night, accidentally stumbled while descending the stairs, and, falling headforemost to the bottom, fractured his skull. He died yesterday morning.

ROPEWALK DESTROYED BY FIRE A small ropewalk, on Meeker, near Bushwick-avenue, owned by PETER COOPER, and occupied by CHRISTOPHER McWay, was destroyed by fire on Monday night. The fire is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary. The loss is estimated at loss than $1,000, and here was no insurance upon the premises. The stock was mostly saved.

The fifth article of the Constitution of the United States prescribes two modes in which amendments may be made to it. The first and simplest of these declares that, whenever two-thirds of both Houses of Congress shall deem it necessary, amendments may be submitted to the action of the States, and if the Legislatures or Conventions of three-fourths of the States approve the proposed amendments, they become parts of the Constitution.

FIRE IN UNION-SQUARE LODGE ROOMS BURNED OUT. Shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out on the second floor of the brick building No. 8 Union-square, known as Thorp's Hotel. During the first nine weeks of the present year ending on the 4th inst., the City Inspector has reported 3,554 deaths in the City. The average for the first five weeks, (January,) was 397 each week; for the last four weeks, (February,) 392 each week. The returns show a decrease of 856, or 19 per cent. as compared with the same period in 1860.

The reported determination of the President to evacuate Forts Sumpter and Pickens, affords us hope that the pacific promises of the new regime are to be followed by action in the right direction. I propose to inquire into the probable consequences of be bold and unexpected a step.

THE QUESTION OF FORT SUMPTER. A report was received here, to-day, that the vessel sent to Charleston was not sent to bring away the troops from Fort Sumpter, but contained supplies and reinforcements for Major ANDERSON. The news created quite an excitement, but soon subsided when the report was contradicted.
The month of December has been an active one in social and political circles, but not very active in the direction of business. It opened with a mania for lumber.

It seems to have escaped public attention that, in addition to our domestic troubles, we have a foreign quarrel on hand. We have withdrawn our Minister from Peru, and have taken the preliminary steps towards enforcing our demands on that country by war. The French Minister has offered the mediation of his Government, but no steps have yet bees taken, so far as we are aware, to avail ourselves of this proffer.

The concert and dramatic saloon, known as Canterbury Hall, was burned down yesterday morning shortly after 5 o'clock, and by the falling of the walls the contiguous buildings were slightly damaged,involving a loss in the aggregate of probably $17,000. RELIGIOUS FESTIVALS. The Jewish Passover, a festival commemorative of the deliverance of the children of Israel from Egyptian bondage, commenced last evening, and will continue for eight days. The origin of the festival is given in the 12th Chapter of Exodus, and the Bible prediction that it should be forever observed by the Israelites throughout the world, has this far been strikingly fulfilled.

Maj. YELVERTON looks every inch a roue, neither ugly or handsome, but with a face, the aspect of which is, simply unpleasant, dubious, disagreeable. His head is bald on the back of the crown alone. He wears a moustache and flowing whiskers of reddish fair hue.

The appointment Of BENJ. F. ISHERWOOD to be Engineer-in-Chief of the Navy gives very marked satisfaction to those in the service. He is a native of this City, and was educated for the profession of civil engineer, which he practiced before entering the Engineer corps of the Navy-having been employed as an assistant upon the Croton water-works, the Erie, and the Albany and Schenectady Railroads.

The Washington correspondent of the Journal of Commerce says: "The Seward policy may prevail, and that is, for the call of a National Convention as soon as practicable, and submitting to it the expediency of a provision for the peaceful dissolution of the Union, by such boundary lines as may be determined upon, or for reconstructing the same. Meanwhile, Mr. SEWARD proposes that the Federal Government shall avoid even the appearance of a coercive policy."

THE BURGLARY AT THE NEW-YORK EXCHANGE BANK. The remarkable burglary at the New-York Exchange Bank, particulars of which were published in yesterday's TIMES, was the theme of general remark during the entire day. The peculiar features of the matter served to attract a throng about the premises, who gazed at the Bank and peered into the basement which the robbers had occupied in hopes of catching a glimpse of the mouth of the subterranean passage.

It is absolutely necessary that the English Government should speedily decide on the policy it intends to follow with reference to the Southern Confederation of American States. Owing to the contradictory legislation which the two parts of the dissevered Union have adopted on the subject of import duties, the English exporter finds himself in the greatest perplexity, and the Government is exclusively able to remove his difficulty.

Quite a scene transpired at the President's house yesterday. On Friday Senator BAKER, of Oregon, presented to the President ten or eleven men as representative Californians, who, after he retired, recommended Senator BAKER to the Executive as a proper arbiter of the California appointments. The President then invited "all" Californians to call on him yesterday morning.

A Roman Emperor inaugurated his reign by declaring that he was determined to be hated. A similar ambition may he said to possess the statesmen of Southern America, whose constant effort, it seems, is to cut themselves off from all human sympathy, to be abhorred, and to concentrate upon their faction the obloquy of the world. There is something preternaturally repulsive in the slang, the swagger, and the ruffianism of these cowbide desperadoes.

The services at Trinity Church, yesterday, were of a very elaborate and imposing character, and drew together a much larger audience than could be accommodated with sitting or even standing room within its walls. The chancel was tastefully decorated with bouquets of flowers, the chief of which, a colossal pyramid of lilies and roses towering from the baptis- mal font, attracted particular attention.

Mr. MEAGHER'S LECTURE ON McMANUS. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER speaks to-night at Irving Hall, on the life, character and fortunes of TERENCE BELLEW McMANUS, who died but a few months ago in California, McMANUS, it may be remembered, was one of the State Prisoners of '48 in Ireland, and was tried and sentenced by the same Court which condemned MEAGHER, SMITH O'BRIEN and O'DONOHUE to exile in Australia.

CHARTER ELECTION. The Charter Election in this city passed off very quietly yesterday. Nearly 28,000 votes were east for Mayor, of which MARTIN KALUFLESCH, Democrat, received a majority over his Republican opponent, FREDERICK SCHOLES, of about 5,000. The Ward officers elected, so far as known, are as follows:

We have gained another glorious victory. We have elected the entire Republican State ticket, by a much larger majority than that of last year. Our returns, so far as received, indicate a majority of at least 1,600 for WILLIAM A. BUCKINGHAM, a gain of over one thousand since last Spring. We have also elected a majority of the members of both branches of the Legislature.

IMPORTANT MILITARY AND NAVAL NEWS. It impossible to conceive, without witnessing it, the extraordinary change which twelve hours can make in the aspect of military and naval affairs at the New-York station. On Monday last, everything was dull and uninteresting on Governor's Island, at Fort Hamilton, on Bedloe's Island, and at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Yesterday there was intense excitement apparent in all these places.
The telegraph tells us that President LINCOLN is sick. We do not doubt it. He has cause to be sick. It will be a miracle if, in six months, he is not either dead or dazed.
The general average charges in case of ship Aurora, at San Francisco, amount to $1,463.
An opportunity offers once more to let you know how things look downs this way during these troublesome times.

Ib., chiefly on the middling and lower qualities. On Monday and Tuesday the usual elections for Wardens and Vestrymen to serve during the current year were held in the Episcopal Parishes of our City. In some of the Churches there was a generous rivalry between the partisans of the different tickets. We give below lists of successful candidates in a number of the leading Parishes.

They were made public by order of Gen. FRANCE. In the first letter, dated Quito, Dec. 7, there is the following passage:

The brig Samuel French, PARRITT, from Turks Island, with salt, bound to Eastport, Me., has put in here on account of head winds. Capt. P. reports that he has on board Capt. WM. WHITE and two seamen of the British brig Newman, wrecked on Molasses Reef, T.I., about the 20th of March. The Newman was a total loss.
The Paris papers of to-day publish a telegram dated 20th inst., stating that the Ports has consented to the prolongation of the occupation of Syria.

MATINEE Mr. GUSTAV SATTER, the eminent pianist, will give a grand matinee today, at Dodworth's Saloon, in aid of the proposed German Hospital. The programme contains some of the finest morceaux of the classic and modern repertoires, and will be interpreted by Mr. GUSTAV SATTER, Mr. APPY, (violin,) and Miss EMMA ROWOROFT, (soprano.)

ASPINWALL Arr., March 19, Am. brig Chesapeake, Evarts, Boston: 20th Am. brig Costa Rica, Peal, NewYork; Eng. steamer Conway Heenan, Greytown; 21st, Am brig Romance. Duncan, Baltimore; 22nd, Eng. stmr, Soleut.Leeds. St. Thomas.
Remove from the system offending agents, which, if permitted to remain at this season of the year, are fraught with great danger to life itself.
