In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Henry C. Wilson, indicted for forgery, pleaded guilty in the fourth degree, and was remanded for sentence.
The screw-steamer Kangaroo, Capt. MIREMOUSE, from Liverpool on the 20th, at 1 P.M., and from Queenstown on the 21st of March, arrived here late last night.

William Whitney et al., respondent vs. William G. Thomas, appellant. In this case, land of the plaintiff, situated in the Eleventh Ward of the City of Buffalo, was sold for non-payment of taxes in 1853 the plaintiff, at the time, residing in this City.

Col. Bigelow Lawrence, lady and servant; Consul-Gen. W. Florence, Col. C.F. Smith, of the U.S. Army; Lieut. Hugh R. Stewart of the Royal Navy; D.F. Albertson and lady, of New-York; Mrs. and Miss Crowinshield, of Boston; J. Patten and lady, of Philadelphia, and S.E. Peabody, of Boston, are at the Brevoort House.

This periodical vendue, now in course at the spacious rooms of Messrs. GEO. A. LEAVITT Co., Rue de Mercer, still progresses to the eminent satisfaction of all concerned, both buyers and sellers the latter especially.
Still another dispatch has reached here from Charleston, which reports that JEFF. DAVIS has directed Gen. BEAUREGUARD to cut of Major ANDERSON'S supplies of food and mails.
On assembling this morning, sixty-nine members answered to their names, after which the Hall was ordered cleared of all except members within the bar.

Messrs. Stanton Co., brokers, at No. 83 Canalstreet, yesterday caused the arrest of a young foreigner of very distingu appearance, styling himself Baron de Vielinghoff, on a charge of forgery. The prisoner, it is alleged, came to this City last December, and pretending to be a Prussian nobleman, induced the complainants to advance him $1,250 upon certain drafts of the house of Hanbro Son, London, made payable at the Bank of Berlin, Prussia.

The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, PELETIAH PERIT, Esq., the President, in the Chair. Four persons were admitted as members. The President stated that the proposition to confer judicial power on the Chamber had passed one branch only of the Legislature.
George Pollen et al. vs. Thomas Otis Le Roy et al. This action was stated in the TIMES of Tuesday.

The United States Circuit Court met to-day, Judges DICKERSON and GRIER presiding. A.Q KEASEY, the newly-appointed United States Attorney for the District of New-Jersey, appeared and took charge of the Jackalow case. He evinced a familiarity with the points which was hardly expected from the short time it has been in his hands.

The Evening Post makes a faint and feeble endeavor to rebuke the TIMES for complaining of the course of public affairs at Washington. The pith of its retort is contained in the following paragraph, which concludesits article:

Mr. TOWNSEND introduced a resolution requiring the sergeant-at Arms to report what means have been taken! by him to secure the attendance of JOHN M. NELSON, Assistant District-Attorney for Albany County, at the bar of the House to answer certain charges Adopted.

"Mr. Speaker, I ask unanimous consent to offer the following resolution." A page hurries up to the Speaker's desk, bearing the important document. The Speaker saps, "The gentleman from asks unanimous consent to offer the following resolution. It will be read for information." The Clerk reads. The Speaker proceeds "This resolution requires unanimous consent are there any objections?"

At 12 o'clock the debate was terminated in the Convention, and after an ineffectual effort by Mr. WISE to extend the time for explaining the amendment, the Committee of the Whole proceeded to vote on the third resolution, which opposes the formation of geographical or sectional parties in respect to Federal politics, and it was adopted. The fourth resolution was next taken up.

Prompted by the evil examples set them at headquarters, the subordinates of the Government at the Brooklyn Navy-yard on last Wednesday afternoon made an attempt to appropriate to private use a large quantity of the Government property in the shape of copper bolts, amounting in value altogether to some six thousand dollars.

The signs of the times indicate "that the Government has decided to enter upon a vigorous and decided policy, in vindication of its authority and in protection of its interest. Our advices from Washington render it probable, to say the least, that the Revenue laws are to be enforced in Southern ports, as well as Northern, and that vessels will not be permitted to enter ports where duties upon their cargoes will not be paid.

A dispatch just received here states that the mortar batteries on Morris Island, last evening, fired into an unknown schooner which attempted to enter the harbor without displaying her colors. Three shots were fired.
Another dispatch from Charleston has been received, which states that two officers had landed from Fort Sumpter with a white flag, and had gone to head-quarters with Col. HATCH.
The Senate was occupied the whole day in the consideration of the Annual Appropriation bill.

In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, James T. West, indicted for grand larceny of property belonging to a fellow-servant in the Astor House, pleaded guilty of an attempt, and was sent to the Penitentiary for one year.
At a regular meeting of this Board, held last evening, Councilman LENT offered the following resolutions:

The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening at the rooms, Clinton Hall. There was, as usual, a large attendance. The presiding officer was ARCHIBALD RUSSELL, Esq. On the motion of Mr. DISTURNELL, the Governor of Colorado, Mr. WM. GILPIN, was elected a member of the Society. The Librarian announced the receipt of 84 bound volumes and 220 pamphlets, presented to the Society since its last meeting.

"It's all very fine, yet know," trying to write a letter for the TIMES, steamer day, and to have the precocious young gents who do up the collecting, to drop down upon you with that "little bill" which is never little, but quite the reverse. These young hopefuls are selected generally for their qualities of assurance, and impudence, nimbleneas of foot, and universal skepticism on the subject of Mr. Brown's being out.

A special dispatch from Washington to the Delta, reporting a suspected attempt to reinforce Fort Sumpter, and that-the frigate Minnesota, with other ships-of-war, had been ordered to the mouth of the Mississippi to collect the revenue, has created the highest excitement to-day on the streets. There is nothing to confirm the report, which is discredited by men of better judgment.

The Secessionists in, the Richmond Convention are making desperate efforts to create the impression that their cause is gaining strength among the people; but all accounts from the interior, except their own, concur in stating that the pestilent fever is abating, and that the public mind is becoming calm and indifferent to their appeals. Secession hac, from the beginning, been an affair of the politicians, and has never had any hold upon the popular heart.

Mr. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, who has been appointed United States District-Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, was yesterday notified of his appointment, and requested to take immediate possession of the office. He has the appoinitnent of two Assistants, three Clerks and a Messenger.

The State Assembly has expelled one of its members for having entertained a proposition to receive a bribe for his vote. The case as against him was very clearly made out. Indeed, he scarcely denied the fact, and the main effort of his counsel was to show that those who offered the bribe were still more culpable than he.

The movement to bring all business transactions to a par basis is much strengthened to-day, in consequence of the unpleasant rumors respecting the standing of many Illinois and Wisconsin Banks. Missouri and Virginia notes are still received, but are almost universally four per cent, discount.
In view of the possibility that the Schleswig-Holstein question may result in a war, it may not be uninteresting to look at the general features of the case.

There is not the slightest doubt that, to-morrow or Sunday, a large force of army soldiers will leave for some unknown destination. The garrison of Fort Hamilton was paid off yesterday, the last move preparatory to marching. Officers were arriving from Washington, individually, all day yesterday, and, carpet-bags in hand, reporting themselves for duty. The village of Fort Hamilton was like a stormed citadel.

We have taken pains to ascertain whether there is any truth in the report, that Gen. AMPUDIA, at the head of three thousand Mexicans, has invaded, or is about to invade Texas, in the neighborhood of Brownsville. From all that can be ascertaind, we are satisfied it is utterly without foundation.

The sick man is at last terribly sick. There are invalids in the European family. German States suffering from depletion French provinces weakened by a rush of capital to the Parisian head there is Italy in a convulsive fever, and Denmark subject to fits but none of them are positively unable to get along, and the worst are hopefully convalescent. Only Turkey seems to appeal, as though in articulo mortis, to the sympathies of humanity.

The Secretary of the Navy, assisted by Commodore STRINGHAM, who has had large experience as Commandant of many of our most important Navyyards, is now busily engaged in preparing specifications and estimates of the supplies and materials which will be required by the Navy Department for the fiscal year commencing on the 1st of next July.
LEONARD, J. Eastbrook vs. Eastbrook. Report confirmed and judgement of divorce granted.
Jaeques Schieb vs. Samuel Baldwin. This action is brought to recover the sum of $9,289.44 for diamonds, rubies and opals sold by the plaintiff to the defendant in March, 1859.

The reported sales of the principal kings of Produce, since our last, have been: 11,745 bbls. Flour, 2,419 bushels Wheat, 672 bushels Corn, 3,314 bushels Barley, 1,700 bushels Oats, 600 bushels Malt, 1,529 pkgs. Provisions, and 549 bbls. Whisky.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 19 bbls. Ashea, 11,697 bbls. Flour, 188 bbls. Corn Meal, 7,644 bushels Wheat, 9,357 bushels Corn, 112 bushels Rye, 270 bushels Barley, 3,475 bushels Oats, 726 pkgs. Provisions, and 619 bbls. Whisky.

The Charleston Courier speculates on the prospect of an immediate attack on Fort Sumpter, saying that, inasmuch as reinforcements cannot reach it, its reduction is only a matter of time." It adds:
The bill to make the acts of the Commitee of Arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce binding, was reported favorably.
Merrill vs. Grinnell et al. Motion to dismiss appeal granted unless amended return be filed next term. Mr. Larocque for motion; John C. Strong opposed.

The filibustering spirit that pervaded the Assembly, yesterday, and which has centered all interest in this House, the Senate being seldom visited except by those immediately interested in its proceedings, broke loose again, last evening, in the insane attempts of some twenty or thirty members to obtain unanimous consent. In thin way about an hour additional to the two so passed in the morning session, was used up.

The sensation sheet of Charleston is fearfully excited, this morning, because your correspondent has sent to New-York a full account of the batteries at Morris Island. He pitches into the TIMES as " that virulent Abolition sheet," pitches into " Jasper," and is splenetic generally.

The appointment of a District Judge for North Alabama, is said to have been made at the instance of Alabamians themselves, who don't mean to recognize the Government of JEFF DAVIS. I know not how extensive and out-spoken

Sir: The new American tariff having been passed by Congress, will come into operation on the 1st prox.: and should the Southern secession be fully carried out, there is every probability of its remaining in force for some time to come, as, owing to the retirement from Congress of a large portion of the Southern members, the Northern manufacturing interest is all powerful in both branches of the Legislature.

It is impossible that and right-thinking or light-feeling man should regard with indifference, with resentment, or with mockery, the movement new in progress in seven Southern States, looking to their complete severance from the Federal Union, and the establishment of a separate sovereignty of their own.

COTTON Sales to-day 1,600 bales Middling at l2 c. @13c.: sales of the week, 9,500 bales; receipts of the week, 5,000 bales, against 7,900 in the corresponding period last year. Decreased receipts at this port 241,465 bales; exports of the week, 14,395 bales; stock 48,755 bales. FREIGHT to Liverpool, 3/8d. Sterling Exchange, 7@8 premium. Sight Exchange on NewYork, @ premium.
The Pony Express passed here at 6:30 A.M. SAN FRANCISCO, Saturday, March 23 3:40 P.M. Arrived, 23d, bark Catalina, from Matanzas, bringing $70,000 in Mexican coin.

The Chamber of Deputies, while discussing that paragraph of the Address relating to the budget and the financial and commercial condition of the Empire, paid a passing salute to the American crisis. Several members spoke of the crisis and its probable influence on French affairs, but no opinions of importance were expressed.
The ship Virginia, Dare, previously reported at Bermuda, has reloaded her cargo, and sailed March 18 for Liverpool.

Hons. William Appleton, of Boston; J.S. Pike, of the Tribune, newly-appointed Minister to the Hague; Douglas Irvine, Secretary to the British Legation, from Washington; Prof. Balcom, of Connecticut; W. Amory and N. Hooper, of Boston; T. Bowles, of the Springfield Republican, and H. Wikoff. of Washington, are at the Brevoort house.
A terrible moment is evidently, at hand. The news from Washington and New-York to-night corroborates the general impression that within twenty-four hours war will be upon us.
The bill to incorporate the New-York Loaners' Association was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to incorporate skating parks and sporting grounds.

The mining population of Pino Alto, Arizona, held a meeting on the 4th inst., and elected delegates to the Mesilla Convention. A resolution was passed in which they pledged their lives and fortunes to prevent any official,civil, or military appointed under Lincoln's Administratian from, exercising jurisdiction in that vicinity.

The intelligence from Charleston looks warlike, and indicates that a collision is likely to take place at any moment. The reports which have reached there relative to the movements of the Administration have created much excitement, and the feeling appears to be general that war is inevitable within a short time. Gen. BEAUREGARD, who yesterday morning
Steamship Patapsco, Vale, Portland, with mdse. and passengers to H.B Cromwell Co. Steamer Westchester, Jones, Providence, with mdse. to Issac Odell.
Cleared. Steamships Quaker City, Cooper, Havana, Hargous Co; Atlantic, Gray, Brazos, North Atlantic Steamship Co.

As the legislative hundred days are now rapidly drawing to a close, we beg to ask the conscript fathers of the State, individually and collectively, whether they mean that this City shall be doomed to endure another term of DELAVAN and the cohort of incompetents facetiously known as Board of Health, Health Wardens, Street Inspectors, and what not?
In the Convention to-day the sixth resolution was up in the Committee of the Whole.
A second company of Zouaves, numbering 100 men, left this city this evening to join the battalion of Zouaves before Fort Pickens.
The Albany Evening Journal thus set forth a day or two since, what it believes to be the policy of the Administration in regard to secession:
Mr. MANIERRE favorably reported the bill to authorize the Supervisors of New-York to levy a tax in anticipation of the collection of the taxes for the present year.

The Virginia State Convention reassembled this forenoon. Secession resolutions from the people of Charlotte and Norfolk Counties were presented. MR. HALLADAY said that the signers to the latter constituted a small minority of the people of the county.
Both the Import and Export movements at New-York the past week were quite active, and a fair trade, for the season, is going on among the Foreign Merchandise and Domestic Commission houses.

The people of this city relish the war news exceedingly. They are greatly pleased with the prospect of a "brush," but are afraid that the Lincoln Administration will evade a conflict. The news of the firing into a schooner at Charleston brightens all faces.

The movement of troops in this vicinity excites universal interest, and intensifies the general anxiety to know something of the policy which it indicates. The Government has maintained the most complete secresy in regard to the destination of these troops, and the public is consequently left wholly to conjecture. The general impression, we think, is that they are destined for Texas.

Tha latest reports from Charleston, telegraphed on Saturday, taken in connection with the fact that telegraphic communication with the South has been cut off below Petersburgh, Va, render it extremely probable that actual war has at last been commenced by the Secessionists, and that the bombardment of Fort Sumpter is now proceeding.

The Sunday Courier publishes a startling narrative touching the actual gathering of a fleet of armed vessels off this coast bearing letters of marque from JEFFERSON DAVIS, whose object is to prey upon the commerce of the North, and particularly upon the incoming California steamers and their specie.

To follow up and ascertain the truth or falsity of a current rumor in this City on Friday last, that the troops stationed at Fort Hamilton and Fort Lafayette, were to be moved on Saturday, a reporter was dispatched from this office to that point for observation.

If there is any State that ought to support the policy of the Administration, it is Illinois. Her favorite son is at the head of affairs. She has enjoyed a very generous share of public patronage, and a liberal not to say controlling influence in public legislation since November, 1860. Will she support or submit to the present Tariff?
Reliable information has been received from the North that reinforcements are ordered to Fort Sumpter, and will be accompanied by a squadron under command of Com. STRINGHAM.
Another suspicious vessel was fired into yesterday. We furnish the following statements, from reliable parties, for the information of our readers:

Steamships R.R.Cuyler, Crocker, Savannah, H.B. Cromwell Co.; Yorktown, Parriah, Norfolk , Ludlam Heineken; Hankow, Sands, Hong Kong, master; Alabama, Schenck, Savannah, S. L. Mitchill Son; Parkersburgh, Stannard. Wilmington, N.C., H.B. Cromwell Co.; Monticello, Gager. Alexandria, c., H.B. Cromwell Co.

The patriotic virtues of JOHN B. FLOYD have at length found a worthy eulogist in the person of a traitorous ex-diplomat, who has been handsomely paid by the National Government during the past four years, for his effective efforts to disgrace the American name and character at the Court Of VICTOR EMANUEL.

The Albany Evening Journal says it "has no sympathy and but little patience with those who are daily goading the Administration into a premature expose of its policy." The great body of the American people are profoundly anxious to know what policy their Government proposes to adopt in regard to secession.

Immediately after the reading of the journal, the roll of members was called, under the resolution of Mr. ROBINSON. and each one named a bill, which was either referred to the Committee of the Whole or sent to select Committees, to be reported complete forthwith.

Immediately after the reading of the journal, the roll of members was called, under the resolution of Mr. ROBINSON. and each one named a bill, which was either referred to the Committee of the Whole or sent to select Committees, to be reported complete forthwith.
Steamships Matanzas, Leisgang, Matanzas,Mora Bros., Navarro Co.; Baltic, Ketchum, Indianola, North Atlantic Steamship Co.
The Senate was engaged during the morning session in the consideration of the Supply bill.

The Journal of Commerce claims and endeavors to represent the commercial classes of this City. As a general thing it does so with a good degree of intelligence and success. Whether its course in regard to the revolution that now distracts the country, indicates the sentiment of the mercantile community, is at least open to doubt.

Rumors are rise in the city in regard to the policy of the Administration; and if we are to believe the quid nunes, war is immediately at hand between the North and South. Everyone asks the question, shall we have war? Men of business are peculiarly sensitive on this point, and manifest the utmost solicitude.

The advices of our special correspondent at Charleston indicate the rapid approach of the crisis. Preparations seem to have been made for an immediate attack on Fort Sumpter. All the families had removed from Sullivan's Island; vessels had been directed to keep out of range with the Fort: and the floating battery was to be towed to its station last evening.
To create a Commission to amend the Charter of the City of New-York, and to provide for the submission of the same to the people of the City.

We had two very extraordinary sensations Wednesday evening a firing into a schooner sensation and a Wigfall sensation. It would be difficult to say which bore off the palm. Let me describe both correctly. The city was startled late in the afternoon by firing from Morris Island.
Parliament stood adjourned for the Easter recess till the 8th of April.

Public attention continued to be mainly engrossed, yesterday, with the great activity in the military and naval departments of the Government. Without any positive knowledge of the destination of the ships, speculation ran high as to where they were bound, and, in some cases, bets were freely offered that they were destined for this or that point of the South according to the favorite theory of each person.
An imperial decree convokes a Servian National Congress.

COTTON. The Broker's Circular reports the sales of the week (5 days) at 68,800 bales, including 12,500 to speculators and 18,000 to exporters. The market opened active, and fully 1/8 d. higher on the news from America per Adriatic, but subsequently owing to the disturbed state of the manufacturing districts, closed quiet at barely maintained prices.
The advices from Manchester are favorable. Holders demanded an advance for yarns, which checked business.

Hons. L. Morrill, of Maine; A.H. Cragin, of New-Hampshire; G. Ashman, of Springfield; and W. P. Sebell, of Pennsylvania; Gen. J.H. Butler, of Bangor, Me.; C.G. Myers, Attorney-General for the State of New-York; Col. Isaac V. Baker and J.B. Caroll, of Troy, are at the Astor House.

The steamship Canadian, Capt. GRAHAM, left Liverpool at 11.30 A.M. of the 28th, and Londonderry on the evening of the 26th ult., and arrived at Portland yesterday morning, in eight days and a half from Londonderry.

Our advices from Charleston and Washington are of exceeding importance. Telegraphic communication with the former city having been restored, our special correspondent there telegraphs that the preparations for the expected conflict are entirely completed, and that all vessels in the harbor have received a notification from Gen. BEAUREGARD to keep out of the range of fire between Fort Sumpter and Sullivan's Island, on which Fort Moultrie is situated.
It is stated that the Porte had consented to the prolongation of the occupation of Syria. The International Committee at Beyrout had demanded the prompt execution of the condemned Druses.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 31 bbls. Ashes, 11,683 bbls. Flour, 407 bbls. Corn Meal, 6,680 bushels Wheat, 21,854 bushels Corn, 846 bushels Barley, 3,880 bushels Oats, 400 bushels Malt, 1,940 pkgs, Provisions, and 1,161 bbls, Whisky.
Mr. TOWNSEND endeavored to get in a resolution requiring the Military Committee to report to the House a bill limiting the tenure of office in the militia to seven years.

A mercantile house in this City has received a letter from a valued correspondent at Austin, the capital of Texas, which confirms the rumors that secession has not completed its victory, in that State.
The mail from Calcutta to Canton Feb. 15, and Shanghai Feb. 6, reached Malta on the 22d March. They would reach England on the 28th.
NAPOLEON received the address from the Corps Legislatif on the 23d ult. In returning thanks he said:
The day has been one of exciting rumors, most of which were, upon investigation, found devoid of foundation or sense.

The disunion dervishes of Virginia are taking on truly Oriental frenzies. They whirl around, they howl, contort their faces, tear their hair, attitudinize, hold red-hot things between their teeth, and rend themselves generally; they appeal wildly to Heaven, and then plunge wildly into whisky; now they exhibit themselves in the most shameless moral nudity, and now figure in coarse homespun garments. Such exhibitions were never before known outside of Turkey, and seldom even there.

The alarming progress made by burglars, as shown by the ingenuity and mechanical skill with which their implements are constructed and their burglaries committed, as exhibited by recent deeply laid and successfull schemes, calls upon Bank Officers and Bankers to seek the securities best adapted to protest their valuables.
An apparently half cracked individual, calling himself Capt. WYATT, has been hoaxing the public with an absurd narrative of the organizing of twenty vessels as a privateering fleet on this coast.
The Santa Fe mail, with dates to the 25th of March, arrived here this morning.
The Confederate States of the South are in need of a navy, and strong efforts are apparently being made by their friends in the North to supply the deficit.

On the demand of the National Committee at Warsaw, M. MUHKANOFF was deprived of his functions as Director of the Interior and of Public Worship. He subsequently left Warsaw with great precipitation, but was unable to avoid popular demonstrations at the railway terminus and the other stations along his route.
A resolution was offered in the Convention, today, to suspend the execution of the order for going into Committee of the Whole, for the purpose of completing the unfinished business of Saturday.

The Home Fleet is provisioned at last. I am in a hurry to have this important news conveyed to the hundreds of people who have friends on board the different vessels. The Brooklyn got the necessaries at Key West, where her officers had quite an adventure.

Thomas D. Carman, Executor , vs. Gorwood Plass et al. In this case one of the defendants guaranteed the payment of certain rent when it should fall due, by the other. The guarantee was written on the lease. The plaintiff brought his action against the defendants jointly. The defendants demurred, urging that they could not be properly joined, their contracts being separate.

In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, John Cuff, indicted for grand larceny, was put to the bar for trial. It seems that the prisoner and the complainant, Michael Murray, were fellow-laborers at the Central Park.

Count CAVOUR has announced to the Italian Chamber of Deputies, that the Ministerial, programme remains unchanged. In a speech on the Roman question he claimed that Italy had a right to have Rome for her capital, but that she must go there with the consent of France. He said that the union of the temporal and spiritual power was the source of evil.
Everything is now prepared for action. All vessels have been ordered to keep out of the range of fire between Fort Sumpter and Sullivan's Island.

James Alexander vs. Mary Ann Lundy, Robert L. Lundy, her husband, and Ruthella Lundy. The Lundys and the Alexanders, since their acquaintance with each other, have seldom reciprocated confidence or fellow-feeling. On the 18th of October, 1858, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander, and Mr. and Mrs. Lundy and family occupied a mansion together in the vicinity of Twenty-sixth-street.

As the political horizon in America graually darkens, both sides are engaged in mustering their forces, and estimating the probabilities of a future struggle. The South, having been trusted almost up to the present time with the management of the War Department of the Confederacy, has managed to secure stores and money, for which it has long been.
The hero now at the head of the Cotton States Army and Republic, has, after mature deliberation, selected Pensacola as the first field for the display of his strategical qualities.
The Royal Mail steamship Persia arrived here yesterday morning from Liverpool, via Queenstown, making the shortest passage on record.

Friday, the 29th, was a strict holdiday on 'Change in London. On Thursday, the 28th, the funds were heavy and dull, and censols declined 1/8, closing at 91 5/8@91 for money, and 91 @ 91 7/8 for account.
Dates from British Columbia to the 18th, and Oregon and Washington Territories to the 20th, are received.

Matter of the application of Hiram Miller. This application was for leave to take proofs of certain frauds and irregularities alleged to have been committed in assessments for the improvement of Seventy-ninth-street. The opinion of the Court explains the case:
I have information to-night, entirely satisfying me that the steamer Baltic has gone to Fort Sumpter, where she will land supplies in small boats.
The State authorities last night received official notification that supplies would be furnished to ANDERSON at any hazard peaceably if possible, by force if necessary.

Comparative quiet prevailed, yesterday, in the City respecting military and naval movements, the sailing of the steamers Baltic and Illinois on Monday night having, for the time, left the public to occupy itself with other matters.
The Pony Express with later intelligence for the Associated Press, passed here to-day at 2:30 P.M. SAN FRANCISCO, Friday, March 29 3:40 P.M.
The Democrats have called a Convention to nominate a candidate for Congress on the 14th of May, and the Republicans on the 20th. J.J. STEVENS is the most prominent Democratic candidate.

BURGLARS CAUGHT IN A CLOTHING STORE. About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, Officer MULDOON, of the Sixth Ward, observed two men inside of LEVI'S clothing store, No.114 Bowery, and believing them to be burglars, he obtained assistance for the purpose of arresting them. A search of the premises resulted in showing that an entrance had been effected to the store through the rear window, and the burglars were found in the out-house.
Everything is quiet to-night as regards excitement. People are becoming accustomed so suspense. The floating battery has been to wed into position between Sullivan's Island and Fort Sumpter.

Some of Mr. LINCOLN'S friends having heard that a conspiracy existed to assassinate him on his way to Washington, set on foot an investigation of the matter. The capture of the ship Montauk in the month of December last by a Spanish frigate off the island of Cuba, with 1,140 negroes on board, is still freshly remembered. The slaves were landed in Cuba and were sent into the interior; the vessel was, of course, condemned, and the officers and crew allowed to depart, after a decent show of detention.

RUMORED PLOT TO SEIZE THE CAPITAL. ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. On Friday forenoon a young lady, about 20 years of age, jumped overboard from the boat Phoenix, on the Christopher-street Ferry. Mr. SAMUEL BENSON plunged in and rescued her. She resided in Greenwich-avenue, N.Y., and the only reason she gave for the attempt was that she was "tired of life."

The London Saturday Review seems to be in distress, by reason of the inability of the English language to find words for the proper expression of its spleen towards the United States. One of its latest griefs finds inadequate expression in the following paragraph:

In accordance with the call of the Commander in-Chief of the companies comprising the four Regiments ordered to report for service in this City, they commenced arriving before 9 A.M. this morning, the companies first arriving not having received their orders until last night. Already about 30 companies have arrived, numbering over 1,700 men in uniform, and with these are several hundred who are importunate to be allowed to join the ranks.

Charles Dimon, Receiver, , vs. Lorenzo Delmonico et al. This action is brought against the defendant and his two assignees, for the purpose of setting aside an assignment made by Lorenzo Delmonico, on the ground that it was made to hinder and delay creditors, and to make the assignees personally liable.

The People Ex rel. Wm. B. Belch vs. Charles Bearfield. The plaintiff. in this case, claimed to be the rightful incumbent of the office of bell-ringer for the Sixth District; claiming his right under an appointment by Mayor Westervelt, in 1854; having served as such until Jan. 24, 1860, when he was superseded by the defendant, who was appointed by Mayor Wood.

The people of Hudson County are becoming thoroughly aroused in regard to national difficulties, and they stand united in their determination to support the Federal Government, and in Hudson County alone nearly or quite the quota of men required from the State can be raised.

Now that Fort Pickens is likely to be the scene of some military and naval strategy, it may not be out of place to give a statement of the available force in Florida at the command of the Federal Government, both for land and sea service. In a naval vessel, in war time, a certain portion of the crew are told off for disembarking, should circumstances render that cource necessary.

Now that the Southern Confederacy has named its foreign diplomatic agents, and that one of them, the avant-coureir, Mr. KING, has already arrived, you will naturally be interested in knowing how the recognition question stands here.

All eyes are turned with intense anxiety toward Fort Pickens. There seems little reason to doubt that it was the design of the rebels to attack Sumter and Pickens at the same time. We have no reliable intelligence from the latter place to a later date than the 11th, and as the traitors have complete control of the telegraph, we may very well be kept in ignorance of their movements at that point.
The citizens of Oswego, without distinction of party, assembled in immense numbers at Doolittle Hall last evening, on four hours' notice. Mayor FITZHUGH presided, assisted by sixteen Vice-Presidents.
Nothing of stirring importance has occurred today.

The public mind of old Virginia is to-day boiling like one of the ocean's great whirlpools; or rather, I should say, rushing like the Gulf Stream's torrent; for it has ceased to meet in jarring conflict, resulting in a round of policy without progress, but is dashing onward to action decided, open and irrevocable. What that action is, I need not repeat; I have already signified it clearly enough in the TIMES.
The following is an extract from a private letter received in this City yesterday:
One gentleman of this city has taken $125,000 of the Confederate loan at par, and paid the amount in gold.
The Eastern Arizona Convention met at Messla on the 16th, and was numerously attended.
The Louisville Journal, which has hitherto been a staunch Union paper, thus speaks of the President's Proclamation :
EDMUND C. CARRINGTON, formerly of Virginia was to-day appointed Attorney-General for the District of Columbia.
Mr. LINCOLN'S war proclamation was received with no astonishment. Everybody is highly pleased, and the people are resolved to maintain their position at all costs and all hazards.
Proclamation by the President of the Confederate States of America:
Gov. WASHBURNE has issued a Proclamation convening the Legislature on the 22d inst.
Gov. YATES, of Illinois, and Gov. RANDALL, of Wisconsin, to-day issued proclamations calling for the volunteers asked for by the Federal Government.

War business must be done whether it rains or shines. Accordingly Governor's Island, Fort Hamilton, Bedloe's Island and the Navy-yard yesterday reassumed the life-like aspect temporarily put off by bad weather.

An adjourned meeting of merchants, and prominent business men of all classes, was held yesterday noon at the Chamber of Commerce, to consult upon the state of the country, and to make arrangements for a Mass Meeting of the citizens of New-York to sustain the Government in the approaching contest with treason and rebellion. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been : 7,672 bbls. Flour, 1,920 bbls. Corn Meal, 4,138 bushels Wheat, 15,120 bushels Corn, 396 bushels Barley, 2,572 bush. Malt, 145 pkgs. Provisions and 154 bbls. Whisky.
The Governor of New-Hampshire to-day issued the following proclamation to JOB. C. ABBOTT, Adjutant and Inspector-General of the New-Hampshire militia:

CONCERTS. The sound of the drum is not the only music with which the City is rejoiced just now. To-day and tonight we are promised no fewer than four concerts. First in musical importance is the third subscription soirce of the Orion Society at Irving Hall a superb entertainment, with full orchestra, chorus, , and a programme equal to the best that the Philharmonic Society has given us this season. Proclamation by Edwin D. Morgan, Governor of the State of New-York: The President of the United States, by proclamation and through the Secretary of War, by formal requisition, has called upon this State for a quota of seventeen Regiments, of seven hundred and eighty men each, to be immediately detached from the Militia of this State, to serve as Infantry or Riflemen for a period of three months, unless sooner discharged.

Gen. JAMES A. McDOUGALL has been declared United States Senator for California, for the next six years. Do you remember Senator DOUGLAS' prophecy, as he punched the ribs of BURLINGAME just before the last election? "Won't it be a splendid sight, BURLINGAME, to see McDOUGALL returned from California, BAKER from Oregon, and DOUGLAS and Uncle Abe all at Washington on together?" But, don't you, like our folks, "holler before you're out of the woods."

The Naugatuck Transportation Company vs. The Schooner George Gillmer. This was a libel filed by the owners of the steamboat Ansonia to recover about $800, the amount of the damages occasioned to her by a collision with the schooner, which occurred about noon on the 19th of May, 1858. The steamboat

Gov. LETCHER has issued a proclamation, recognizing the Confederate States as independent. He says that the President has no authority to call an extraordinary force to an offensive war against any foreign power, and threaten to use this unusual force to compel obedience to his mandates.

Too much praise cannot be given to the conduct of the Metropolitan Police in the present emergency. In all scenes of excitement they appear as if summoned by magic, not harshly exerting their authority to disperse the crowd, but rather allaying the stormy passions around them by their unvarying good humor, coupled with a clear determination and ability to do their duty.

The steamship Baltic, Capt. FLETCHER, which left Charleston Bar at 8 P.M. on the 8th inst., came up to the City and anchored off the Battery at 1 P. M., to-day. She had flying from her mainmast head the flag which lately waved over Fort Sumter, and at her foremast-head the flag which was hauled down when Fort Moultrie was evacuated.
The National flag has been profusely displayed here to-day on the public buildings, and by the citizens generally.

Gov. LETCHER, of Virginia, yesterday commenced active opposition to the operations of the Government, by obstructing the entrance to Norfolk Harbor, by sinking boats, so that the vessels-of-war now at the Gosport Navy-yard cannot be taken out. The news was brought to Baltimore by the captain of a steamer which arrived from Norfolk yesterday.

A regular meeting of the Board was held last evening, the President in the Chair. The Stars and Stripes were displayed over the Speaker's desk, and miniature frogs were posted on the desks of the members, and from the chandeliers.

[General Orders, No. 20.] The Brigadier General Commanding is happy to congratulate the troops under his command, on the brilliant success which has crowned their gallantry, privations and hardships, by the reduction of the stronghhold in the harbor of Charleston. This feat of arms has been accomplished after a severe cannonading of about thirty-three hours, in which all the troops have indicated, by their daring and bravery, that our cause must and shall triumph.
The city is to-day again excited by news from abroad the reports of war preparations from the North, of secession in Virginia, and movements in North Carolina.

The Constitutionnel's last weekly commercial article from London, an article which exercises a good deal of influence in the commercial world at Paris, speaks as follows of the now engrossing question of cotton:
A meeting of Viginians, Louisianians, Tennesseeans, Kentuckians, and others, will be held at the Exchange Hotel, this evening, to hold a rejoicing over the glorious news from these States.

Morgan L. Curtis vs. Gilbert M. Gillett. This was an action brought to recover damages in a special action, for defamation. The defendant had been a former partner with the plaintiff, who is now doing business at No. 141 Elm-street, as a manufacturer of chandeliers, gas fixtures, The charge of the defendant was that the plaintiff had swindled the defendant at the time he had purchased from the plaintiff an interest in the business.
We are indebted to the officers in command of the forces at Fort Sumter, for what the public have not had hitherto, a detailed account of the defence of the Fort.

SEIZURE OF FEDERAL PROPERTY IN VIRGINIA. Dispatches to the Associated Press, posted on the bulletin-boards at the hotels, announcing the seizure of public property at Norfolk, excite deep interest here. That immediate steps will be taken to recover and hold this property there need be no doubt.

Ellen Miller vs. Peter Puels.--The plaintiff in this case, on the 13th of May, 1859, while on her way to prayer-meeting, about 7 o'clock in the evening, and when opposite the house of the defendant, No. 87 Division-street, fell into a hole used for the purpose of letting down coal in the vault immediately beneath, and severely injured herself.

This gallant officer arrived, with his command in this City yesterday, and was received with a hearty and enthusiastic welcome. Thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens crowded the streets through which he passed, and lingered for hours in the vicinity of his hotel, eager to see him and assure him of the universal applause which greets his gallant and noble defence of the Stars and Strives.
Stemers Josephine, Green, Philadelphia Jersey Blue, Chadsey, Bristol master. Ships Wild Pigeon, Mayhew, Valparaiso, Fabri Channcy; London, Huribut, London, Grinnell, Minturn Co.

The largest and most enthusiastic meeting ever held in this City was held here this evening. It was called to sustain the Government. With the exception of a few leading Democrats, the mass of the people are true to the Stars and Stripes.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 21 bbls. Ashes, 4,646 bbls. Flour, 11,146 bushels Wheat, 34,849 bushels Corn, 858 bushels Oats, 804 bushels Malt, 528 pkgs. Provisions and 641 bbls. Whisky.
New-Orleans is jubilant at the news of the secession of Virginia. One hundred guns were fired, amid the wildest rejoicings.

Men never realize the rapidity with which a revolution moves. Three months ago a person would have been regarded as a madman who had predicted the present state of affairs, which are but the logical and inevitable sequences of premises as pronounced as are the events now before us.

A call is now out, and largely signed by men of standing, for a Uuion meeting, to consider the best course to pursue. The Governor has net yet indicated the action he will take upon the Presidents call for troops. There are no secession sentiments here whatever.
The Legislature has passed the bill authorizing the raising of a regiment. It is understood that $500,000 will be appropriated.
The Pony Express, with San Francisco dates to the 6th inst., passed here, at 3:30 P.M., with the following intelligence for the Associated Press:

Capt. PEARSON, of a Norfolk steamer, arrived in this city this morning.. He reports that the main entrance to the harbor of Norfolk has been obstructed by the sinking of small boats by order of Gov. LETCHER. Capt. PEARSON says that he was compelled to go over the flats, and states that the object is to prevent the Government vessels leaving as ordered.
The Union men of the convention were in caucus last night, the purpose being to consult up- the mode of secession. The majority undoubt-...

The patriotism of the loyal States is at last aroused, our people gradually realizing that an attack on the National Government is no longer confined to the bombast of Southern speeches, but has become an active and embodied principle, dominant in seven of the extreme Southern States, and struggling for impious ascendency in all.
The United States Mail steamship Quaker City, WILLIAM D. COOPER, Esq., Commander, left Havana on the 15th inst., and arrived here yesterday afternoon.

In this Court yesterday, Joseph C. Heenan, indicted for burglary, was next tried, Mr. Kochanewiski testified that he lived, and had a tobacco store in Pearlstreet. The place was entered by a rear window in the night time, and about $20 worth of tobacco stolen therefrom.

The City Councils this morning, at a special meeting, appropriated $1,000,000 to equip the volunteers and support their families during their absence from their homes. The merchants are holding a meeting for the same purpose.
The United States corvette Cumberland is at Hampton Roads, and not inside Norfolk harbor. She is caulked anew. It is said she got up anchor last night.

Stephen A. Dillaye vs. Emanuel B. Hart. This action is brought to recover damages for an assault made by the defendant upon the plaintiff, by striking him on the head with a cane at the corner of Pine and Nassau streets, on the 28th of July, 1858.
The President's proclamation will be issued tomorrow, announcicg the blockade of the Southern ports.

The gratifying news reaches us from Washington that the President has issued a Proclamation announcing a blockade of the Southern ports. This important movement effectually disposes of JEFF. DAVIS' letters of marque and reprisal.

Gov. MORGAN has been repeatedly telegraphed to-day by citizens of New-York, to send forward large numbers of troops, but the authorities at Washington have requested him to wait for further directions.

Yesterday was a sad, and yet triumphant day for New-York. It was sad that a thousand of our noblest citizens should be so suddenly called away from their homes perhaps to death to defend the Constitution and the laws. It was a triumphant vindication of the loyalty of our citizens' thus promptly volunteering to the hardships of a soldier's life. Never before were the people roused to such a pitch of patriotic enthusiasm.
There was an immense Union meeting here last night. Speeches were made by Messrs. GUTHRIE, NICHOLAS, BULLOCK and BROWN.

The news from the South is of the most warlike character. Every effort at preparation is being made for the anticipated conflict; and private dispatches, from unprejudiced sources, represent the feeling of resistance as unanimously extreme.
The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, from Queenstown 7th inst., arrived at this port at 7 o'clock this morning. She has 48 passengers for Boston and 36,000 in specie.

During a sojourn of several months in the Gulf States, and more particularly in the very hot-bed of secessionism, South Carolina, and at its very fountain head, Charleston, I obtained possession of several very important facts, which it is absolutely necessary the North should know at this particular time.
Harper's Ferry was burnt last night, and abandoned by the United States troops.

There was a horrible scene on Pratt-street, today. The railroad track was taken up, and the troops attempted to march through. They were attacked by a mob with bricks and stones, and were fired upon. The fire was returned. Two of the Seventh Regiment of Pennsylvania were killed and several wounded.

Yesterday was an important day in the history of the impending conflict. The Massachusetts and Pennsylvania troops, on their way to defend the capital of the Republic against the threatened attack of traitors, were assailed by a mob in Baltimore and were compelled to fight their way through that city. They did it gallantly, however, and are now at the capital.

The Granite Hall Hotel, in the old Washington block, was burnt yesterday, resulting in a loss of about $30,000, which, however, is covered by insurance. The goods in the stores below were mostly saved.

On the 14th of November last, Mr. A.H. STEPHENS, Vice-President, and now a leading spirit genius of the Southern Confederacy, delivered a speech in the Hall of Representatives, at the seat of Government in Georgia, in favor of the maintenance of the Union. This speech, so truthful and appropriate, and delivered in a spirit so earnest and sincere, elicited universal admiration, and was published by us in full.

Lieut. JONES is now at the Carlisle Barracks. He states that hearing yesterday that 600 Virginians were approaching by the Winchester road to seize the arsenal, they put piles of powder in straw in all the buildings, and waited quietly the approach of the picket guard, who gave the alarm, when the garrison set on fire the out-houses, carpenter shop, and powder fuses, and then began to retreat.

The Empire City never before saw such an immense consourse of people as gathered yesterday at Union-square, to respond to the call for a Union meeting. Our most experienced reporters have never had occasion to estimate the numbers of so large an assemblage, and the lightning calculator could hardly do justice to the subject.
The steamship Columbia, with Liverpool dates of the 9th inst., arrived here yesterday, but the wires not being in working order, we were unable to transmit her news until this evening.
Colonel ELLSWORTH, at half-past ten o'clock last (Saturday) evening, received the following dispatch:

Business has been partially suspended to-day. At 2 o'clock P.M. merchants were generally closing their stores, with a view to a full attendance of the commercial classes at the great Union meeting. At the Corn Exchange, as at the Merchants' Exchange, and elsewhere, this meeting was the chief topic. Even the news from the South was apparently of secondary interest.

The impenetrable veil of secrecy continued this morning to shroud the action of the two Conventions in session at Richmond the regular State Convention and the irregular Secession Convention. Nevertheless the very atmosphere was laden with secession, and no one failed to feel the influence.

I sailed in the good ship Mary Whitridge, W.A. CRUSY, Commander, from Hong-Kong on the 18th of January, and arrived here yesterday, after an unprecedented passage of 33 days. We bring but two days' later dates than those transmitted by the English Overland mail which left on the 15th, and which I forward, though the papers contain no additional news of importance.

We give elsewhere copious extracts from the speech of Hon. A.H. STEPHENS, VicePresident of the Confederated States, in the Hall of the House of Representatives of Georgia, on the 14th of November last, and after the result of the Presidential election was fully known.

The pirates directed by JEFFERSON DAVIS at Northern commerce will naturally pounce on the richest prize within their reach; and that unquestionably is the treasure which thrice-monthly passes from San Francisco to New-York. The Companies to whom this wealth is intrusted have no intention of letting the golden fleece fall into piratical hands without a struggle.
The bridges on the Northern Central, and on the Philadelphia roads are gone. The bridge between Woodbury and Mount Washington has been destroyed.
To ELLIOTT F. SHEPARD: You and other friends in New-York, telegraph me, requesting more troops sent from New-York, but the authorities at Washington ask me to wait for further directions.

The news that war has already begun creates an excitement beggaring anything ever before known amongst us; while the circumstances under which the terrible game opens unite all classes of men in the determination to sustain the Government. For the occasion, party is dropped and a zeal to stand for order and the honor of the country is the absorbing sentiment.

The great campaign is fairly opened; and everything now depends on the vigor and energy with which we strike the first blows. The next sixty days should break the backbone of Secession by crushing it in Virginia. We have fortunately secured Fort Monroe beyond the possibility of capture. It is an admirable point as a base of operations, and a large force should be concentrated within it.

A passenger, who left Washington yesterday, reports all quiet, but it was rumored that the President was about to call for additional troops from the faithful States, to make up the deficiency caused by States refusing to furnish their quota.

Mr. LINCOLN was elected as partisan. On taking office the country was divided into two great political factions. He commenced his official duties by following the precedent of rewarding his friends and punishing his foes.

A gentleman who left Washington at half past four o'clock on Saturday morning, informs us that the general belief in that city in the best informed circles, was that JEFFERSON DAVIS was on his way North--at the head of a considerable force, which he was augmenting on the way.

It is almost impossible to get reliable information from any point below Philadelphia. All telegraphic and railroad communication with Baltimore has been cut off, and what intelligence does reach us comes by roundabout channels and through suspicious authorities.

During the first quarter of the year 1861, ending on the 1st inst., the City Inspector has reported 5,167 deaths in New-York. The weekly average has been, in January, 397; in February, 392; in March, 403. For the whole 13 weeks, there has been an average of 567 deaths each day. The mortality for the quarter shows a decrease of 1,038, or 16.7 per cent as compared with the first quarter of the year 1860.

Our whole community are aroused. The ladies are making clothes for the Union Guards, who are ready to march. The surrounding towns are in a blaze of excitement, our citizens contributing money, . and the young men are rallying for the Union. The students in the College have formed themselves in a Company, and are daily drilling in the armory. They are ready to march at a moments notice.

Gen.KEIM and Staff have been ordered here from Washington, to take charge of the troops here. He left Washington this morning, and arrived to-night, traveling eighteen miles from Baltimore in a carriage; Judge WILMOT accompanying him. He found five bridges destroyed on the Northern Central Road, ten miles from Baltimore. Intense excitement prevails in that city. SHERMAN'S battery, also the battery of the Reading Artillery, (four pieces,) reached here at midnight.

The tone of the English and French journals, brought by yesterday's steamer, furnishes a curious reflex of the aspect of American affairs a month ago. FIVE THOUSAND MEN MORE THAN REQUIRED. Col. CORCORAN received orders yesterday to em bark his regiment, the Sixty-ninth, on board the James Adger at 11 A. M. to-day. The order also indicated that the regiment should not number more than 1,000 men.

In the State Assembly on the 16th, when the vote was taken on the bill providing military aid to the Government at Washington, Mr. KERNAN, of Oneida County, declared his purpose to vote for it, though he proceeded to apologise far his vote and to protest against the troops of this State being used to coerce the South.

To-day New-York City, besides being the headquarters of the regular Army of the United States, will be also the head-quarters of the Department of the East. Major General JOHN E. WOOL, of the staff, the next in rank to General SCOTT himself, arrived here yesterday, will remove his quarters to this City from Troy.

FELLOW-CITIZENS: The iron hail at Fort Sumter rattles on every Northern breast. It has shot away the last vestige of national and personal forbearance. A loaf of bread on its way to a starving man was split in two by a shot from his brother. You might saturate the Cotton States with all the turpentine of North Carolina; you might throw upon them the vast pine forests of Georgia, then bury the Gulf storms' sharp.

New-York, Monday, April 22, 1861 6 P.M. The new Produce Exchange was formally opened to-day. Large numbers of buyers and sellers of Produce were present, and a very good commencement, in the way of business operations, was made. The attendance at the Corn Exchange under the circumstances, was also fair.

The British Press has swung round again. At the outset of the secession movement, its sympathies, (if such cold-blooded speculations deserve the name,) were with the American Government. It saw no good reason for destroying a Union which had made the American people so prosperous, and purchased so largely of British goods.

HARRISBURGH. Penn., Wednesday, April 24, 1861. The Pawnee, with the Commedore's flag at her peak, and about six hundred trusty men aboard, cast off from the dock of Fort Monroe, about 7 o'clock on Saturday evening. The crowded parapets of the Fort sent a loud and hearty cheer to the departing ship, which was answered with an exulting huzza from her populous deck.

Over a dozen American flags were raised in Baltimore en Friday. The Chief of Police has ordered all flags to be taken down during the session of the General Assembly here. Great floods have taken place in this island, causing calamities only interior to those in Holland. Hundreds have lost their lives, and many thousands have been ruined. The Government has sent 800,000 florins for the relief of the sufferers. The commercial community of Batavia has already subscribed 150,000 florins.

A SOLDIER SHOT. HUGH MCNICHOL, a member of the Second Regiment of Jersey City, on the way to Washington, was accidentally shot at Bordentown on Friday evening. Two of the soldiers were sky-larking, one having a bowie-knife and the other a revolver, when the revolver was accidentally discharged, shooting MCNICHOL, who was standing near, in the bowels. It is thought the wound will prove fatal.

I regret exceedingly to announce that a very serious accident has befallen Mr. SIMONTON, special correspondent of the TIMES. He was driving this afternoon, in company with Mrs. SIMONTON, in the neighborhood of Blighwood, and on turning the corner of Seventh-street suddenly passed a picket-guard of militia, whose Captain accidentally discharged his musket, which was leveled full at SIMONTON'S back.

The Trustees of the New-York Produce Exchange Co., elected on Monday the 6th inst., met on Thursday afternoon, the 9th inst., to choose executive officers for the ensuing year. The result of the election was as follows:
To-day the English and French Ministers go back,bag and baggage, to Jeddo.

At the present momentous period is American affairs, it is perhaps idle to expect, with a foreign date, to attract the eyes of many readers. Domestic politics must of necessity absorb all interest, and the ups and downs of foreign countries be content for the time to pass by unheeded.

Col. ANDERSON and Mrs. LINCOLN and suite arrived here last night. The former is to be officially received in Independence Hall this afternoon. He will be escorted there by three regiments and two companies of cavalry.

The sales of COTTON for three days, including Wednesday, were 30,000 bales, including 11,000 to speculators and exporters. Messrs. JAMES HEWITT Co. report an advance 0f 1/8d, 1b, since Friday's market, the market closing quiet but steady, at 7 d, for Middling Orleans, and 7 d, for Middling Mobile.
The railroad battery has arrived from Philadelphia, and will be sent to Bush River tomorrow perhaps further.

Information reached here this morning that Harper's Ferry had been fortified on all sides commanding the approaches to that place. Batteries had been erected, and the place surrounded with troops and scouts.

Messrs. SIMSON DRAPER and CHARLES H. MARSHALL, returned from Washington via Annapolis yesterday, and report the condition of troops at the Capital and en route, perfectly satisfactory. They have visited nearly all the New-York regiments, and found them contented, healthy and well provided for, and loyal to the cause.
The Minnesotians are priding themselves on the fact that the first offer of troops to the Government came from their State.
A gentleman just arrived in St. Louis from Houston, Texas, makes some interesting statements.
The following communication was read before the Baltimore City Council, on May 7:

Important events occur with such startling rapidity, that merely to chronicle them requires an active pen. I saw, last evening, Capt. SCHUYLER HAMILTON, Aid-de-Camp of Gen. BUTLER, fresh from the Relay House via Washington.

The agent in charge of the Winans' steam gun testifies, on examination, that he was on his way to Harper's Ferry, and not going out to practice at long range as stated by a Baltimore paper. The gun now guards the viaduct at the Relay House.
The Legislature will adjourn on Monday, to meet here again on the 4th of June.

Secession in Mary and is not only sick, it is dead. The Up as tree, however, cannot at once, in all its roots, be so entirely eradicated, that it may not, under circumstances auspicious to its growth, here and there, occasionally, sprout up again. But, for the present, it has disappeared; and its wildes advocates admit, that any attempt at its resuscitation would, under the present condition of affairs, be not only vain, but mad.

With the exception of the Winter Garden, where Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JEFFERSON keep large audiences in a constant state of jubilation, the theatres have not been especially cheerful during the past week.

The Louisville Journal, of May 7, has but little doubt that an attack on Cairo is meditated by the rebel forces, It says:

The advices which we publish this morning from the seat of Army operations seem to indicate that we are just at that point when almost the turning of a hair might cause a collision of the opposing forces, and we shall not be surprised to hear at any moment that the conflict has commenced.

The twenty day's limit for the dispersion of rebels now in arms against the United States has expired. Whether the struggle for vindication of the imperiled Union shall be brief, or protracted, the result is certain.
The Santa Fe correspondent of the Missouri Republican writes on April 22:

I have no confidence in any pacific movements that may be made here. The secession leaders are subtle and polite men. Everything will be kept quiet until they are ready for some overwhelming and irresistible movement, when another 19th of April scene will be enacted.

The officers commanding the forces on Staten Island, report that the troops are making excellent progress in drilling, and the two regiments are in good spirits, and only impatient to be called into service as early as possible.

The departure of the Great Eastern from Mil- ford Haven, for New-York, was fixed for the 1st inst. The announcement produced no excitement. The least powerful of steamers arriving from America was more of a topic.
At a large public meeting, held recently in Rochester, Hon. Mr. ELY, Member of Congress from that District, made the following remarks:

"The Legislature adjourned at 10 o'clock, yesterday, after having fully completed the work for which it was called together. The total amount of appropriations for war purposes is $3,500,000. Of this sum $1,000,000 is to organize and equip the ten Regiments called out by the State ; $500,000 was appropriated to purchase arms for the State and build a powder magazine, and $2,000,000 for general purposes of State defence and National aid.

Indignation at the attack on Fort Sumter seems to be the prevailing feeling throughout the Northern States. Mankind will always be more moved by the sound of actual warfare than by the violation of rights or the abandonment of compacts.

The Washington Republican states that the withdrawal of the secession forces from Alexandria was in consequence of an error in a telegram which read so as to order the withdrawal of a battalion when only a battery was needed.
The steamship Great Eastern, Capt. THOMSON, from Milford Haven of the evening of the 1st inst., arrived off Sandy Hook yesterday morning, and anchored near the light-ship.
Delegates continue to arrive at head-quarters, the McClure House. About 300 delegates are expected.
Among our intelligence by the Great Eastern, we give an article from the London Times upon the affairs of this country.

Congress met to-day, at noon, and was opened by prayer. The journals of yesterday were read and confirmed. No business being offered, Congress went into secret session.

There has recently been a change of officers in the Bank of Albany, and some difficulties discovered in the accounts, in consequence of which the Bank suspended business to-day, for the purpose of instituting a thorough investigation into its affairs.
By an arrival from Old Point we learn that that post is now fully prepared to resist any attack.

We learn from the New-Orleans True Delta that the Governor of Louisiana has authorized the organization of a regiment of free negroes in that State, for active service against the "mean, false, dastardly black Republicans of the North;" and that FELIX LABATUT, Esq., of New Orleans, an "old, esteemed and wealthy citizen," will probably be appointed Colonel of the African contingent.

Gen. FROST'S brigade of Missouri militia, encamped at Camp Jackson, on the western outskirts on the city, surrendered unconditionally, this afternoon on demand of Capt. LYON, commander of the United States forces of this city. Capt. LYON marched on Camp Jackson with some 6,000 volunteers, surrounded it, and planted eight field places on the adjoining eminences. An attempt has been made to cut off the Cochituate water from the city by breaking open the main conduit, near Newton Lower Falls. The attempt was unsuccessful, the mason work being too strong for the implements used.

The funeral of Major CLARKE, United States Army, was a very imposing affair. The regular troops turned out in large bodies.

The United States transports Huntsville and Keystone State left the Brooklyn Navy-yard on Saturday. The destination of the latter is said to be Boston, as she has on board a marine guard for the United States steam frigate Mississippi, ordered to the blockade fleet. The Huntsville is to act as a gun-boat, and has naval sailors and an armament on on board.
Gen. BUTLER, with fifty men and two pieces of Capt. VARIAN'S battery, left this afternoon on the propeller J.S. Shriver for important and secret service in the direction of Baltimore.

Ten o'clock P.M., and I have just come from the military levce at the White House. The rooms were filled, but not uncomfortbly crowded, and the scene was quite brilliant. At eight o'clock the carriages began to arrive at the President's mansion, and continued to roll up the graveled path leading to the main entrance until half past nine.

Gov. CURTIN has addressed a message to the Legislature of Pennsylvania, telling them in general terms how the money appropriated by the act of April 12 has been expended. He concludes his message with an appeal to the Legislature to act in harmony, that the rebellion may be put down.

The spirit Of REVERDY JOHNSON, of Maryand, and of ANDREW JOHNSON, of East Tennessee, is possessing and arousing some of the noblest sons of old Kentucky. Some of our most prominent men along the frontier and throughout the interior are beginning to speak out pointedly, boldly and decidedly for the Union, the Constitution and the Government.

During the past ten days very little has occurred worthy of note. There have been no arrivals from South or Central America, and our news from the interior of the Republic, although important, if true, is too meagre and indefinite to be much relied on. The U.S. Mail steamer Conway, from Carthagena, is due here to-morrow, just twenty-four hours too late to forward her news.

Delegates to the Convention are arriving by every train, and nearly all the hotels are fully occupied. The call embraces the counties west of the Alleghany Mountains and north of the Kamawha River. All are overwhelmingly for the Union, and thirty-three are expected to be represented.

Several homicides and fatal accidents have occurred among the troops in this military division, all tending to prove the importance of rigid discipline. Such occurrences are rare among regulars, and might be guarded against to a considerable extent among new levies, if the officers had the morel courage to enforce thearmy regulations.

The recent document of the Sabbath Committee was entitied "The Civil Sabbath Restored." The unanimity and strength of public sentiment evinced in popular demonstrations of different nationalities, by the Press, by Legislative votes, by the decisions of Courts and Juries, and by the action of Police authorities, and the consequent suppression of the most offensive forms of Sabbath desecration, seemed to justify the claim that this great bulwark of morals and self-government had been reestablished.

The city was the scene of another terrible tragedy last night. About 6 o'clock a large body of the Home Guards entered the city, through Fifth- street, from the Arsenal, where they had been enlisted during the day, and furnished with arms. On reaching Walnut-street, the troops turned westward, a large crowd lining the pavement to witness their progress.

No one was hurt at this point. The second firing occurred from the rear of the column guarding the prisoners.

Robert M. De Witt vs. James Brooks et al. This was an action for an alleged infringement of copyright. The plaintiff claimed to be assignee of the copyright of the confession of the murderer and pirate Hicks, which the defendants had published in the New-York Express, of which they were the owners and publishers.

There are, doubtless, loyal men all over the South, even in South Carolina, who would gladly see their several States return to their allegiance; men who would fight for the Union if there was hope for anything short of their own destruction.

In the House of Lords, on the 29th ultimo, Earl of Malmesbury, adverting to the state of affairs in America, said: I beg leave to put to my noble friend, the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, a question of which I have given him private notice, in reference to a subject which deeply interests this country, and, I may say, the whole of Europe.

John Fagan vs. John L. Stoltz. In December, 1859, the plaintiff went to defendant's place of business in Kent-avenue, where, upon going down cellar, he was set upon by a large dog and badly bitten. He now sues for damages.

The Convention of representatives from the Northwestern Counties of Virginia effected an organization at Wheeling yesterday, most of the Counties to which invitations were addressed, having delegates in attendance, and participating sympathetically in the proceedings.

Two recent appointments to office in this City have given much gratification to the public. I allude to that of Mr. J.J. COOMBS, as one of the Board of Supervisors in the Patent Office, and to that of Mr. CLEPHANE, as Postmaster.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 68 bbls. Ashes, 28,065 bbls. Flour, 115,606 bushels Wheat, 49,401 bushels Corn, 2,717 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,406 bbls. Whisky.

At a meeting of this Board, last evening, a com munication was received from the City Inspector, in answer to a resolution of inquiry as to the manner in which Mr. Hackley had performed his contract for cleaning the streets.
In this Court, yesterday, before Justice McCUNN, Mr. Garvin prosecuting for the people, David Sterling and Charles Tucker, indicted for felonious assault, were brought to the bar for trial.

The Governor is still receiving offers from all parts of the State from Companies anxious to volun teer for three years. Four Companies (the first on the list for the service) are now here quartered at the Arsenal. It is expected that two Regiments for three years' service will be called for from this State, and they are ready at a moment's notice.

E.D. MORGAN, Jr., son of Gov. MORGAN, has resigned his office on the Staff as Aid-de-Camp, and Capt. EDMUND SCHEIVER, late Captain of Second Artillery and Assistant Adjutant-General in the United States Army, is appointed in his place, with the rank of Colonel.

The delegates to the Convention of Western and North-Western Virginia, called to deliberate upon the best means of opposing the policy of Secession adopted by the late Convention at Richmond, assembled yesterday at Wheeling, and proceeded to business.

A person employed in the special service visited Harper's Ferry, last week, and reached Chambersburgh to-day. He reports that the troops concentrated at that post number 6,000 altogether, about three-fourths of them armed. Most of these are well armed, but the balance are not armed at all. Only two hundred Kentuckians are there now, and one Company of South Carolinians.

In our issue of Sunday morning, we presented a brief summary of the latest news brought by the Great Eastern, with an account of the voyage by our own correspondent, and some extracts from London journals indicative of British opinion of our national crisis.
Congress met to-day at noon, and was opened with prayer. The journals of the preceding day were read and confirmed.

THE NEWSBOYS' CONCERT. The Newsboys' Lodging house, being in want of funds, and we would remind our readers that this is really one of the most benevolent institutions of the City, a concert by the boys themselves was given last night, at the Central Presbyterian Church, corner of Elm and Broome streets. The pulpit was draped with the American flag.
Our Spanish brethren are repaying the kindness shown in repairing the Berenguela at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, by dispatching her this day to carry the correspondence to New-York.

The Convention met at 11 o'clock. WM. B. SINN, of Preston Co., was appointed temporary Chairman. A motion was made by Gen. JACKSON, of Wood County, to admit all gentlemen present from Northwestern Virginia to seats on the floor of the Convention.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of Saturday last, you again urge the propriety of striking from the Stock List of the Board of Brokers the securities of seceding and seceded States, and go even so far as to call on the District Attorney to interfere, inasmuch as, according to your intimation, the cupidity of the members of that body overrules their patriotism.

No demonstration has yet been made on the part of the Government, indicative of the course which it intends to pursue. It is still engaged in strengthening its hands for the contest, and it is thought in some quarters that it will continue to do so, until the certainty of success cannot be questioned. It is believed that delay will be advantageous to the Government, while it will prove the contrary to its enemies.

About 8 o'clock this evening a large train filled with troops arrived at the outer depot, from the Relay House, containing one thousand troops, from each of the regiments stationed at the Relay House.
The Royal Mail steamship Europa, from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 4th, via Queenstown on the evening of the 5th inst., arrived at Halifax at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

PRISONERS PUNISHED--OFFICERS CENSURED. In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Mr. Garvin, prosecuting for the people, David Sterling and Charles Tucker were placed at the bar. They had been convicted the day before, Sterling of a felonious assault, and Tucker of a simple assault. The former was sent to State Prison for two years, and the latter to the City Prison for thirty days.

When the train containing many members of the Legislature from Frederick reached the Relay House this evening, Ross WINANS was arrested by Federal officers, and retained. The train came on without him.

It is understood in high circles here that Govs. CURTIS and DENNISON have pledged the Union men of Western Virginia the entire support of all the forces of Pennsylvania and Ohio, to protect them against the home Secessionists and Eastern Virginia. Indiana and Illinois have pledged the Union men of Kentucky and Missouri the same way.
Congress met to day at noon, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. HEARD. The public proceedings of the previous day were read and confirmed.

We must have an army to defend the country and uphold the Union in its integrity, and it must be fed and clothed. Soldiers can no more fight without eating than they can live without air.

After a perilous journey of eight days from Richmond, I have arrived in this City, having left behind me everything except the clothing I happened to have upon my person at the time of my escape. My arrest had been ordered by the Mayor, and the officers were in hot pursuit and determined to arrest me, as I had been quite too free in denouncing Secessionism.

The Appropriation bill for three millions of dollars for State expenses for the war, as well as the Seven Million Loan bill by the General Government, passed both branches of the Legislature today unanimously. The bill for the organization of a Home Guard, also was passed.

The Second Regiment of Volunteer Maine Militia was expected to arrive in the City yesterday morning vid Fall River, but owing to some unforeseen delay did not arrive until 3 P.M., to the great disappointment of thousands who had waited in the streets, with a view of participating in the welcome.

Powell Lopell and Ellis Elling were put on trial, charged with passing counterfeit coin. The evidence showed that Elting, on the 6th of March, passed a quarter of a dollar for three cents' worth of chocolate, and got the change, and that the quarter proved bad; and that he afterwards handed one to another party for a paper of tobacco, which was refused.

Kingston, Jamaica, papers of April 30 are received per steamship Cleator, which arrived at this port yesterday. There is no news of any interest to be found in them, their columns being principally devoted to chronicling the recent events transpiring in the United States.
