The blockade begins to pinch. The Charleston papers are greatly disgusted at the performances of the Niagara, in stopping vessels that are about to leave that port. The South Carolinian is of opinion that when she attempts to stop a British vessel that is daily expected, "John Bull will have something to say." We fear it will be nothing which Charleston will be very glad to hear.

It is ascertained beyond cavil that the report of the desecration of the Tomb of WASHINGTON, and the removal of the remains, is wholly untrue. The Government has this from a reliable messenger, who visited Mount Vernon and returned to-day. He found everything unmolested, and Mount Vernon in its usual quiet condition.

The United States brig. Bainbridge is now under sailing orders, and was hauled into the stream to-day. Repairs on the steam frigate Mississippi are completed, and she is expected to sail Tuesday, Commodore MERVINE, Flag-Officer of the Gulf Squadron, will sail in her.

The British and North American Royal Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. LE MESSUREIER, arrived at her wharf last evening at 6 P.M., from Havana May 11, and Nassau, N.P., 13th inst., with a large freight of segars, , and 128 passengers from the above ports.

Col. ASBOTH has just returned from Washington, having gone there for the purpose of offering to the Federal Government a Brigade, comprising infantry, cavalry, artillery, pioneers and pontoniers, in the most feasible proportions.

Express companies and transportation lines complain of the system pursued by Mr. Superintendent KENNEDY in reference to the forwarding of arms to distant cities. There is no discrimination used by Police Officers stationed on the wharfs. Government arms are detained, although properly marked and authenticated as for Government use and for loyal States.

The official statement, furnished by the Superintendent of the Census, of the number of men between the ages of 18 and 45, in the several States and in the sections, shows the ultimate result of the pending contest.

Nearly all the members of the Legistatare have gene home. Few are still lingering to get companies accepted. The Governor is overwhelmed with applications to receive companies, but will positively receive no more until the General Government issues another requisition. Great indignation is felt among the military that fourteen additional regiments are to be taken from New-York.

A Naval Medical Board, consisting Of Surgeons BARRINGTON, LOCKWOOD and WHEELWRIGHT, has been ordered to convene at the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, to examine candidates for admission into the medical corps of the navy, on the first of June.

The deplorable state of things in the United States has very much affected trade in this island. All parties look with the greatest anxiety for the result which the struggle must have upon the question of Slavery a question in which this colony is deeply interested.

MY DEAR : I have promised myself for some time that I would write you fully. I always endeavor never to break a promise, and had I not also promised you I think I should have broken the promise to myself.

The Secretary of War has to-day accepted the First Brigade of Chicago, three thousand strong. They go in for the war. Col. MILLIGAN leaves here for Illinois to-morrow morning, to bring them on. They have orders for marching in this direction as soon as he arrives.

One hundred men, Capt. THOMAS' company, (Thirteenth New York Regiment,) with two pieces of artillery and three days rations, went down the Bay yesterday on the propeller Wm. Woodward, to retake the Smith Point light-ship, towed a few miles up the Great Wycomico. The Secessionists have two more in their possession.

A National Hymn seems almost as indispensable an appanage of nationality, as a national flag. Patriotic feeling, excited by any unusual incident, always seeks expression in verse and music those universal mediums of emotion.

Gov. MAGOFFIN, of Kentucky, has sent a messenger to Gen. PRENTISS, commanding the United States forces here, demanding an explanation of the arrest of a traitor and spy, a resident of Columbus, Ky. Gen. PRENTISS declined making a written communication in reply, and said that he denied the right of Gov. MAGOFFIN or any other man, excepting the proper United States authorities, to interrogate him.

The Synod resumed its session yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. After some time passed in devotional exercises, reports from the various Committees were taken up and considered. The first report was on the subject of the Sabbath, means for its better ob servance being therein suggested.
Congress met to-day at noon, and after prayer by Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY, the Secretary read the journals of the previous day, which were approved.

Florida, "the smallest toad in the puddle" of secession, has spread upon the record of the C.S.A. Congress her protest against certain portions of the Constitution of that august Confederation. She protests against any scrutiny into the qualifications of her voters for President and members of Congress.

The news from the Federal Capital this morning is not of special importance, excepting as indicating the continued vigor with which the Administration is preparing everything for the great struggle which is now impending.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Union cause, since the riot here of the 19th ultimo, is gradually regaining ground in many parts of Maryland, "taking and repossessing" political strongholds, it is also true that there exists much of that raw material for secession industry, which, skillfully wrought upon, would render her liable to the fate that has befallen other of the Border States.
We published yesterday a letter addressed by Judge CAMPBELL, lately of the United States Supreme Court, to Hon. W.H. SEWARD, with sundry accompanying documents.

Mr. OCHILTREE, of Texas, offered in the Montgomery Congress, the other day, a resolution in relation to the protection of the Indian tribes scattered over the territories, in which he speaks flippantly of the "late United States."

Samuel Collins, Lewis Featherstone, John Dunlevy and John Kelly, were put on trial charged with murdering Geo. W. Pike, the Captain of the ship Gen. Parkhill. Before commencing the trial, Mr. Smith, the District Attorney entered a nolle prosequi against Kelly, proposing to use him as a witness.

Several Union men having been driven from Potosi, on the Iron Mountain Railroad, a detachment of volunteers, under command of Capt. COLE, was sent on Tuesday night to protect the loyal citizens in that section.

The official world of Spain seems to be enjoying at this moment a profound tranquillity. Queen ISABELLA is at Aranjuez, a magnificient royal residence, passing the first fine days of Spring, and getting ready to give birth to a fourth prince or princess. The head of the Government, O'DON- ELL, Marshal Duke of Tetuan, has just got happily through a rather severe tempest in the Cortes.

Kinney, appellant, vs. Francis Delluc, respondent.--This case comes to the Supreme Court on appeal from a decree of the Surrogate, made on the 7th day of October, 1859, and entered and filed 27th of October, 1859. Of all the many maps of the "seat of war," decidedly the best is that published by A. RUMPF, No. 175 Broadway. It gives a panoramic view of the country, and enables the observer to obtain a much better idea of the situation and location of the points where the common interest now centers, than he could derive from the old-fashioned straight lines and blue and yellow dots and patches.

The Toronto Leader publishes the appended correspondence on a subject which has not yet lost all its interest:

WYANDOTTE, Kansas, Saturday, May 11, 1861. This has been a glorious day for Wyandotte. Three weeks ago to-day, just two miles below us and in plain sight of us, the Secessionists raised the black piratical flag of the Southern Confederacy. To-day, in full view of that flag, we have hoisted, one hundred and thirty feet high, the old flag of the Union. Although it was rainy and muddy, everybody seemed ...

The latest news from Montgomery tells us that the Confederate Congress has authorized a new loan of $50,000,000, and probably before the first one of $15,000,000 has been taken. This immense sum indicates the pressing necessities of the rebels, and the manner in which the call for more money will be met, will do more than anything else to give a finishing blow to their already sinking cause.

"A paragraph is going the rounds of the press that our fellow-townsman, W.W. CORCORAN, had offered the Treasurer of the United States a large amount of gold in exchange for Treasury drafts on New York, and had been rudely refused, and told that he must fight for and defend his own gold.

Senator BAYARD publishes a lengthy address to the people of Delaware, vindicating himself from false charges against him. He declares that his visit to New-Orleans was solely on social and business purposes, which was contemplated more than a year ago, without any anticipation of the exciting events which were occuring during his visit. He made no political arrangements at Montgomery, and returned ...
The General Assembly, to-day, adopted a resolution urging the ministers and churches to a faithful effort against the temptations to intemperance which beset young men in camp life.

Congress passed a number of bills to-day, organizing a Patent Office, regulating Telegraph, lines, authorizing the issue of $50,000,000 in bonds, payable in twenty years, at an interest not exceeding 8 per centum, and in lien of bonds, to issue $20,000,000 in Treasury notes, in small sums, without interest.

Harpers' Monthly is before the public with its customary promptitude. The number for June may be characterized as unusually good, and even above the happy average which this periodical has secured for itself. "What is Best"--a keen and biting paper from the pen of CHARLES NORDHOFF, Esq., is searching as a nor'wester, and equally health-giving.

Two pieces of cannon, several hundred muskets and rifles, and a number of pistols and ammunition, were taken from the custody of the Police Commissioners to day, by order of the United States anthorities. Sixty Colt's navy revolvers were also seized, while in the hands of the American Express Company. All these arms have been sent to the arsenal.

Mr. FAULKNER has just emancipated his favorite slave DAVE, an intelligent and amiable mulatto, whom all persons will recollect who ever visited the Minister's house at Paris. DAVE, it appears, is the last slave of the PIPER family, the most noted and valuable family of slaves in the Harper's Ferry region, and all of whom have been owned and emanicipated by Mr. FAULKNER.

No army movement of special interest has occurred at Washington within the last twenty-four hours, if we except the arrival there of the New- York Eighth Regiment, which left the Relay House, yesterday morning.

Hon. THOMAS CORWIN, U.S. Minister to Mexico, and suite; Sir CHARLES WYKE, Minister from England, and Mr. VON KINT, Ckarge des Affairs from Belgium, arrived at Vera Cruz by the English steamer Solent, from Havana, on the 30th ult. The three Legations are to proceed at once to the city of Mexico.

We take it for granted that reason will one day return to the Southern mind, and the truths of history be comprehended by the Southern people. When that time shall come, they will hold a stern reckoning with the demagogues who have deluded and the leaders who have betrayed them.

An auction sale of the flour stands on the business floor of the new Produce Exchange was commenced yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, and closed at 2 o'clock. Mr. THOS R. MINTURN, of the firm of MINTURN PATRIDGE, was the auctioneer.

The Federal Government has proclaimed a blockade of the Southern ports, but until they can cover 2,000 miles of seaboard with their cruisers, the blockade will not be what is called "effective," and the British Admiral on the station will protect British vessels in entering and leaving ports not effectively closed by a considerable naval force.

There were thousands of visitors at the Pennsylvania camp to-day, observing the movements of the National Guards. The camp is in excellent condition, though in a bad location, but fortunately there is no very heavy rain, or fear of a submergement in the low ground on which the tents are pitched. Religious exercises were held this afternoon.

The steam gun-boat Pembroke, Capt. COFFIN, from Fortress Monroe, 16th inst, arrived at this port this morning. She brings several passengers, including Capt. CHARLES GALE, of the bark D.C. Pierce, of Cleveland, Ohio, and Capt. JOHNSON, of bark Ida, of Boston.

I telegraphed you yesterday that our excellent and obliging Governor had met the wishes of the Mobile Committee to the fullest extent in his power, and placed at the disposition of the city two rifled cannon, one howitzer, three hundred muskets, and as much cannon powder and as many percussion caps as may be required, Capt. BARNARD, of Gen. SMITH'S Fire Brigade will have these arms in charge and convey them to Mobile.

A suit recently pending before the Superior Court at Bridgeport, Conn., to recover damages for the bursting of a steam-boiler, has resulted in a verdict against the maker thereof, and, as a matter of warning and precedent, against the makers of bad boilers in general.

The Union men of Washington County having been threatened with extermination, and some of them having been driven from Potosi, the County- seat, complaint was made to Gen. LYON, of the St. Louis Arrenal, and that brave and gallant officer determined to give the Union men in that section of the country protection.

The active and well-directed efforts of our patriotic women in the loyal States, to supply this necessary protection from sun-stroke, to our troops in the approaching campaign, are already yielding very satisfactory results.

We learn from the Kingston Daily News of Thursday morning, that the steamer Comet collided with the schooner Exchange, on Tuesday night, and sunk in eighty feet of water. The Comet was on her passage from Kingston to Toronto and Hamilton.

During the sessions of the Circuit Court of the Eighth Judicial Circuit of Alabama, Judge SHORTER held the plea of "Alien Enemy" was sufficient to sustain a motion for dismissal of all civil actions brought in the names of citizens of non-seceded States. In consequence a great many cases brought by plaintiffs residing in these States, were summarily disposed of.

LAUNCH OF THE YACHT HRNRIETTA. The launch of this fine yacht, which was to have taken place on Saturday, at 4 o'clock, from the shipyard of Mr. HENRY STEERS, at Greenpoint, was unexpectedly retarded by the chains which held the poppets of the launching-ways, under the quarter, getting jammed fast in the ground, for want of sufficient space being excavated to clear her great depth of keel.

Immense bodies of troops are to be transported to Fortress Monroe with the least possible delay, including the entire quota from Massachusetts, and a number of regiments from New-York. The Massachusetts Fifth have already received their orders, and will go by way of Annapolis.

Judge MASON, arrested yesterday, was released to day and sent over the Maryland line. He was known to entertain secession sympathies, but his character was too high to believe he would condescend to play the spy. There was no anthority from the Secretary of War to retain him. His discharge meets with approval amongst the most judicious residents.

SEWER ACCIDENT. Two men were instantly killed, on Saturday evening, by the caving in of a sewer bank, where they were, on Jay, near Yorkstreet. There were several other men who narrowly escaped losing their lives. The names of those killed were Owen BRACKEN and MICHAEL CLARK. Coroner HORTON held an inquest, and the Jury rendered a verdict that their death was the result of accidental causes.

The propeller Wm. Woodward returned yesterday, having in tow the South Point Lightship, found up Mill Creek, a branch of the Great Wycomico. They were fired into, and some fifty musket shots exchanged. The two pieces of artillery could not be brought to bear on the enemy, who were concealed in the bushes.

Six hundred troops from Georgia and Alabama arrived to day. They are the advanced guard of two thousand recently ordered to this point. They will increase Gen. BRAGGS' command to about ten thousand every one of them men. The new levies are all well uniformed among them the "Warrior Guards," of Tuscaloosa.

A letter to the American, from Williamsport, says that about 1,000 Virginia and South Carolina troops, from Harper's Ferry, took a position on Sunday, on the Virginia side of the Potomac, opposite to that from, and commanding, the ferry, and they expected to be joined by another thousand to day, with field pieces. Williamsport is but 7 miles from Hagerstown, Md.
There are few military movements to-day. The sudden death of Col. VOSBURGH has cast a gloom over the encampments of his fellow soldiers.

I have just returned from Harper's Ferry. Two thousand Mississippians arrived there to-day. They are a hard-looking set, poorly clad and dirty. Two Regiments arrived from Alabama yesterday. They are of the same stamp.

Col. VOSBURGH, Commandant of the Seventyfirst Regiment, New-York, died at the Navy-yard about half past eight o'clock this morning. He was attacked with bleeding from the lungs only last Friday. His remains will be taken to New-York under escort of a detachment from his late command.

In his recent admirable speech, on the presentation of a national flag by the ladies of Frederick to the Home Guard, Mr. REVERDY JOHNSON precisely defined the true character of the revolutionary control of the Confederate States when he styled it "the usurped Government at Montgomery." An usurpation is an unjust or illegal seizure and occupation of public power and property.

Charles W. Frederickson and Joseph A. Weeden vs. Henry O. Brewer and Samuel B. Caldwell. The plaintiffs in this action are Cotton brokers, and the defendants commission dealers and receivers of cotton.

The Chamber of Commerce have called the attention of the French Government to the necessity of taking measures for the protection of French vessels in American waters. The Minister of Commerce, in concert with the Minister of Marine, promised to have a conference with the Emperor on the subject.

The failure of the Bank of the Capital, on Saturday, which had a savings department, as was expected, produced yesterday some excitement among the depositors of the Savings Banks of the city. These deposits, mostly in small sums, are from a class of people easily alarmed, and to whom, indeed, their small deposits are quite as important as much larger ones of persons of more means.

A gentleman who arrived From Washington this evening, says that the secession flag which has insulted the eyes of the President for some time past, floating prominently over Alexandria, was not to be seen this morning. It was reported that a couple of Col. ELLSWORTH'S Zouaves had crossed over during the night, escaped the vigilance of the sentinels, cut it down and returned safely.

The Government is absolutely adverse to accepting any more men at present from New-York. She has already surpassed any other State in proportion to her population. Col. DE FOREST'S Regiment, offered for the war, will not therefore be accepted now.

The state of affairs in the United States has compelled Ministers to strengthen the squadron under the command of Sir ALEXANDER MILNS; and on Friday the Challenger, a powerful screw corvette, mounting 22 guns; the Rinaldo, a screw aloop, mounting 17 guns; and the Driver, a paddle-wheel steam sloop, mounting six guns, were commissioned, and in all probability will be dispatched as soon as ready to the North America and West India station.

The event of to-day in Washington was the funeral of Col. VOSBURGH. At an early hour, it was determined to forward his remains by the 2 o'clock train. By the following document it will be seen that Mr. FRANK E. HOWE of New-York, has tendered the State authorities the use of his spacious room in NewYork as head-quarters for Massachusetts troops in New-York, and they have designated him to look after our men there. His thorough business habits and extensive experience will well fit him for the trust confided to him.

The ship Gen. Parkhill, of Liverpool for Charleston, has arrived in charge of a prize crew of the Niagara. She was spoken off Cape Romain the 12th, and ordered off. The next day she was captured in attempting to run the blockade. She was towed up to the Navy-yard.

DODWORTH'S SALOON.--In the present paucity of amusements and, we may add, disinclination for them, a first rate concert is as unexpected as it is agreeable. The drum for the moment supplies all our musical need, and managers who hate its imperative roll generally avoid a direct competition with it.

The District-Attorney of Maryland was here today, consulting with the President concerning the Merriman habeas corpus. It is understood that the writ will be suspended, and possibly the functions of His Honor Judge TANEY.

The case of America has again been considered in the House of Lords, and with pretty much the same degree of intelligence as characterized previous discussions of the same problem. The subject is clearly beyond the reach of their Lordships. The disposition of all the debaters, is evidently to so interpret the neutrality of England, as to make it most efficacious in aid of the Confederate rebels;

DEDICATION OF A MONUMENT BY THE SONS OF TEMPERANCE The Sons of Temperance, on Wednesday, the 29th inst., dedicated a large and very handsome monument, which has been recently erected at Cypress Hills Cemetery, to the memory of DANIEL H. SANDS, one of the founders of the Order. This monument enterprise has been the subject of active effort in the Order for the past two years, and has now reached a very successful consummation.

Fortune has smiled upon Col. DURYEA'S Advance Guard thus far. Under sunny skies and over a smooth sea, the vessel that carries the Regiment and its fortunes has proceeded, until we are within an hours' sail of Fortress Monroe. If our Virginia experiences are as pleasant as those of our Alabama trip, we shall have nothing to complain of.

Gen. SCOTT is not prone to precipitate great battles. He is a commander of excessive caution, avoiding general engagements to the utmost extent of his power, and seeking by slow and sure approaches to so emmesh his enemy in gradually contracting web as to leave no loophole of escape but quick retreat; when, being master of the situation, he is able, in a few brilliant moves, to force inevitable check.

As an exposition of its life, the literature of the South is a study. For even in our Slave States the thoughts of scholarly men, who have the leisure and inclination for reflection, are, in due process of time, translated into the prose of every-day conduct. An elaborate article on the "Causes of the American Civil War" appears in the London Times of the 23d and 24th ultimo. It is signed J.L.M. (MOTLEY, the historian,) and it agrues that the whole responsibility of the war, and the deepest political guilt, attaches to the South.

The engagement at Philippi took place at 5 o'clock on Monday morning. The plan was well laid for the surprise, but the impetuosity of a few troops gave the rebels evening. They fled in haste, leaving their baggage, forty horses, four wagons loaded with provisions, and five hundred maskets.

Treasurer DORSHEIMER, Comptroller DENNISON, and Attorney-General MYERS went down to NewYork last night, to make an investigation into matters pertaining to the contract for the clothing of the volunteers, about which so much complaint has been made.

It will be seen from our dispatches that a movement of the Federal troops was made yesterday in the direction of Manassas Gap. The exact nature of this movemnet, however, does not appear, though there is no doubt, now that the Government has concluded to strikes a blow, that it will be an irresistible one.

The meat markets have all been fully supplied with live animals during the past week. Beeves are largely in excess of last week's supply, the total footings amounting to 4,659, or 1,100 more than on the previous market. Notwithstanding this large supply, trade was quite lively, though prices declined c.@ c. since our last report.

In regard to the American war, he took occasion to say: "It was a matter in which they in England, and espeially shipowners, were deeply interested.

In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Mr. Anthon prosecuting for the people, Daniel Bruce, indicted for felonious assault with a knife, pleaded guilty and was sent to Sing Sing for three years and ten months.

The solider Col. ROBERT ANDERSON is at his head quarters the better. The loyal men of Louisville need and want him. They rejoice that he is to command the Department of Kentucky, and that he is to be stationed at this important point. He may have his hands full for a time, and is doubtless making due preparations to meet every possible contingency.

We believe that Canada, equally with England, will stand neutral in the quarrel, and that the provinces of British America will be enabled to maintain their own without fear of aggression on the part of any assailant. But to be forearmed is true and sound policy.

At noon to-day the Pawnee and Thomas Freeborn stood in towards the steamboat landing at Aquia Creek. When about two miles off, a battery opened upon the Pawnee with two rifled caution and a heavy gun, suppose to be a 68 pounder. The twosteamers stood as near as the sheal water would permit and opened upon the battery. The Pawnee with her Dahlgren guns, and the Freeborn with two heavy 32 pounders.

The approval by President LINCOLN of Gen. BUTLER'S course in declaring slaves contraband of war causes much rejoicing here. In consequence of this decision we shall secure a large amount of muchneeded labor at the Fortress and the neighboring encampments, and get at a variety of valuable information with regard to the movements of the Secessionists.

One hundred and eighty of the men constituting a portion of Lieut. BARTLETT's Brigade, returned from Fortress Monroe yesterday by the steamer, Coutza coalcos. On which they embarked from States Island about ten days ago. After landing, the men formed and visited several of the newspaper establishments to announce their arrival. Their appearance was calculated to excite commiseration.

Dr. WM. J. WALKER, of Boston, who is one of the most opulent surgeons in the country, has given property estimated to be worth $90,000, to establish Professorships of Mathematics in three of the colleges of Massachusetts. These institutions are Williams, Amherst and Tuffs Colleges, each of which will receive $30,000 for the purpose above named. Dr. WALKER is a graduate of Harvard College, and a Unitarian.
The Royal mail steamship Australasian, Capt. HOONLEY, which sailed from Liverpool at 10 A.M., on the 25th, and from Queenstown on the evening of the 26th ult., arrived here last evening.

The Maine Third Regiment will reach Boston about 4 P.M. The city provides a collation for them on the Common. The Regiment leaves for NewYork to-night.

The valuable aid afforded by this Society of experienced medical men and their willing assistants is daily realized by our troops. Their plans are so admirably adjusted that at a moment's notice a Committee of instruction will be sent with models and patterns to aid the efforts of cooperative societies. Articles which have been found to be most useful and of the proper material are constantly on exhibition and open to inspection.

In consequence of the heavy Northeast storm which prevailed yesterday, no further demonstrations in the direction of the Manasses Gap Junction were made by the Federal troops. They were held in readiness, however, to move at a moment's warning, or to repel an attack had one been attempted. The rebels still threaten to move on Alexandria, but they probably have as much as they can attend to in other directions.

A forward movement towards Harper's Ferry by the Pennsylvania troops was made from Chambersburgh yesterday, a strong ad vance having probably reached Hagerstown, six miles beyond the Maryland line, last night. From Hagerstown the troops are to follow the direct road a distance of about twenty miles, to near the Maryland Heights, opposite Harper's Ferry, when the movements of the rebels will determine the course to be pursued by our men.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Wednesday, June 5, 1861. It is by no means surprising that Ex-Gov. WISE should have expressed himself in very strong terms as to the importance to the State of Virginia of attacking Fortress Monroe. The work is truly one of immense strength. It would be impossible for 50,000 Secessionists to take it from Gen. BUTLER. As long as ships can bring him men, provisions, and munitions of war, he will be impregnable.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN AND COUNCILMEN THE MODE OF PUBLISHING ITS PROCEEDINGS TO BE INVESTIGATED. At a meeting of the Board, last evening, a resolution to appoint a special Committee of Three, who should be empowered to send for persons and papers, for the purpose of investigating the present mode of publishing the proceedings of the Board, was adopted over the Mayor's veto.

The passage of the Maid of the Mist through the Rapids of Niagara, continues to cause considerable talk, and now that the feat has been accomplished, the wonder that it was undertaken does not cease. We hear some further particulars about the matter, which are interesting.

A horrible tragedy, resulting in the death of an old man named JOHN STEVENSON, at the hands of his son JOSEPH took place, on Sunday night, at No. 30 Newark-street, Hoboken. The affair, as related by the family, is as follows: They allege, that on Sunday evening Mr. STEVENSON came home, very much under the influence of liquor, and commenced beating his wife in most brutal and cruel manner.
The Steamship Fulton, from Southampton on the 29th May, arrived here yesterday morning.

Friends of Gov. HICKS, Senator GOLDSBOROUGH and the Secretary of State of Maryland, arrived this morning from Frederick, and have visited Gen. THOMAS' Brigade, and asked troops for Frederick. Gen. PATTERSON will immediately advance a Brigade to that point, and it will march to-day.

Before Justices Clerke, Satherland and Leonard. John R. Sears vs. Joseph Conover. This case has been twice before reported in the TIMES. The action was brought to recover for the alleged breach of a contract in the sale of potatoes.

The most extraordinary item of intelligence which reaches us by the last mail, is the announcement that the Federal Government has notified to foreign Powers, that it will cease to hold intercourse with any foreign Power which recognizes any Commissioners from the rebel States.
Yesterday, the weekly report of Army recruiting was made, as usual. At this station, twenty-eight men were received since Saturday last, which shows an improvement in the number of enlistments.

"A banner with a strange device" was seen boating in our harbor yesterday. Some thought it was a revival of the Lone Star of Texas; others, that with its beautiful combination of red, white and blue secession had attempted to do away with the "bars." But the flag we refer to is by far the prettiest belonging to South America.

Sunday is a peculiar day in this city. Going to church a half a day is rather a necessity, as there does not seem to be any other place to go. Among a small number of really devout people, who would go to church come what will, there is quite a throng who go to worship to please a lady friend, and quite a company who drift round.

The rebels crossed at Mercerville, on Saturday night, and attempted to seize canal boats and 800 bbls. Flour, but failed in consequence of the Shrpsburgh Home Guards being stationed there. This has been an exciting and sorrowful day at Old Point Comfort. Gen. BUTLER having learned that the rebels were forming an intrenched camp with strong batteries at Great Bethel, nine miles from Hampton, on the Yorktown Road, he deemed it necessary to dislodge them; accordingly movements were made last night from Fortress Monroe and Newport News.

Senator ANDREW JOHNSON arrived here yesterday, en route to Washington. He made a three hours' speech last night to a very large audience, and declared in favor of a positive and unconditional Union and the maintenance of the General Government. East Tennessee, he said, would never leave the Union, if armed to prevent subjugation. His remarks were well received and warmly applauded.

Our Washington correspondence a day or two since gave late and important intelligence from Mexico. It appears that our Minister, Mr. CORWIN, presented his credentials, and was duly received by the Mexican Government on the 21st ult. From all we can learn, it does not appear that Mr. CORWIN has any immediate prospect of success in the negotiation of a treaty.

On the 15th day of March, 1859, the defendant Gordon, residing in the City of Brooklyn, assigned his store of goods there to the defendant, McCrosson, in trust for the payment of his debts. The Second New-Hampshire Regiment, Col. MARSTON, numbering 1,000 men, and fully armed and equipped, arrived in this City yesterday morning, and were appropriately welcomed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 15th, you inform the public that there is a petition in private circulation, among officers of the Army, "praying that the practice of exalting uneducated military men above old officers be discontinued."
